content: ABM Industries Inc.'s ABM, +0.75% fiscal second-quarter earnings rose 65% as the facility-services contractor benefited from recent acquisitions and organic growth in certain divisions. Shares were up 4.7% at $25.75 after hours as core per-share earnings topped analysts' expectations and the company lifted its fiscal year earnings projection by five cents. ABM now expects full-year adjusted earnings from continuing operations of $1.40 to $1.50 a share. ABM, which provides janitorial, parking, engineering and security services for commercial, institutional and retail facilities, in recent quarters reported a mixed bottom line amid sluggish economic conditions and lower government spending. However, the company in the latest period reported organic growth in its janitorial, facility services and security segments. In the latest period, ABM entered into a joint venture with Building Energy, an Italian-based independent power producer, to expand its solar and distributed energy capabilities in large-scale commercial and utility-scale solar power markets. Last year, the company agreed to buy Air Serv Corp. for about $158 million in cash. President and Chief Executive Henrik Slipsager said ABM expects to begin reorganizing its Northeast and Midwest markets in the third quarter and remain on track to reduce expenses by $3.5 million to $4 million in fiscal 2013. For the quarter ended April 30, ABM reported a profit of $19.3 million, or 35 cents a share, up from $11.7 million, or 21 cents a share, a year earlier. Excluding special items, earnings from continuing operations improved to 36 cents from 30 cents. Revenue was 11% higher at $1.17 billion, due to $97.7 million in contributions from recent acquisitions and $28.8 million in organic growth from the company's janitorial, facility services and security units. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters had estimated earnings of 33 cents a share and revenue of $1.18 billion. The company's provision for income taxes more than doubled. Revenue in the janitorial segment, its largest revenue source, rose 2.7%, while revenue from the facility-solutions segment increased 8.4% and security revenue climbed 3%. The building and energy solutions division saw revenue improve 8.4% due to acquisitions. The stock is up 28% over the past six months. title: ABM profit up 65% on acqusitions, growth

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) — General Motors Co. rallied in after-hours activity late Monday on its expected re-inclusion into the S&P 500, while shares of G-III Apparel Group jumped after the apparel licenser raised its outlook for the year. General Motors GM, +2.45%  shares rose 3.6% to $35.65 in heavy volume after Standard & Poor’s said it was re-including the automaker in the S&P 500 SPX, +1.38% after a four-year absence. GM was removed from the S&P 500 in June 2009 after the automaker filed for bankruptcy protection. G-III Apparel Group Ltd. GIII, +3.01%  shares rose 7.6% to $46.00 after the company reported earnings of 5 cents a share on revenue of $272.6 million. Analysts expected a loss of 5 cents a share on revenue of $267.4 million. The Next 24: Calvin Klein Parent Company Reports, and More G-III, licensee for brands including Calvin Klein and Tommy Hilfiger, also raised it full-year outlook to a range of $3.20 and $3.30 a share from a previous $3.10 and $3.20 range. Analysts expect $3.20 a share. SAIC Inc. US:SAI   fell 2.2% to $14.52 a share in light volume after the government-services contractor posted earnings of 23 cents a share on revenue of $2.71 billion. The company was expected to post first-quarter earnings of 25 cents on revenue of $2.58 billion, according to analysts surveyed by FactSet. SAIC also forecast annual earnings of $1.16 to $1.33 a share on revenue of $10 billion to $10.7 billion. Analysts see $1.16 a share on revenue of $10.28 billion. Verint Systems Inc. VRNT, +13.90%  shares slipped 3.8% to $32.71 on light volume after the company reported adjusted quarterly earnings of 44 cents a share on revenue of $205.4 million, while analysts expected 52 cents a share on revenue of $203.4 million. The data analysis firm forecast annual earnings of $2.70 to $2.80 a share. Analysts expected $2.76 a share. ABM, +0.75%  rose 4.1% to $25.60 after the facilities services provider reported quarterly earnings of 35 cents a share on revenue of $1.17 billion. Analysts expected 33 cents a share on revenue of $1.18 billion. ABM also raised its annual adjusted earnings forecast to a range of $1.40 to $1.50 a share. Analysts expect $1.40 a share. FedEx Corp. FDX, +2.26%  shares dropped 0.9% to $96.81 in light volume after the shipper announced a dividend hike and plans to speed up the retirement of some aircraft. Zynga Inc. ZNGA, -0.54%  shares wobbled back and forth after hours. Shares were up 0.6% to $3.01 on heavy volume at last check. During the session, they dropped 12% after the social-media games maker said it would cut nearly a fifth of its work force. Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. BMY, +1.09%  and Merck & Co. MRK, -1.13%  shares continued gaining in moderate volume after the closing bell. General Motors 2013 Cadillac made by General Motors. Shares of Bristol-Myers advanced 0.6% to $47.85 in moderate volume. Shares gained 3.4% to close at $47.59 during the session. Merck shares rose 0.3% to $48.61 in after-hours activity, after gaining 3.8% during the session. Shares of both firms were on a roll following presentations made over the weekend at the American Society of Clinical Oncology. content: Among the companies with shares actively expected to actively trade in Thursday's session are OCZ Technology Group Inc. OCZ VeriFone Systems Inc. PAY, -0.52% and AAR Corp. AIR, +1.36% OCZ Technology's fiscal second-quarter revenue is expected to fall short of its previous guidance, as the data-storage company said it has been affected by supply constraints. Shares tumbled 21% to $4.23 after hours. VeriFone's fiscal third-quarter income rose 43% as the electronic-payments company's revenue strengthened, led by its services business. Still, shares dropped 11% after hours to $31.48 as the company predicted weak fourth-quarter revenue. AAR reported preliminary fiscal first-quarter results above analyst expectations, pointing to stronger commercial sales. The aircraft leasing and maintenance company's shares jumped 9.6% to $15.99 after hours. AeroVironment Inc. AVAV, +1.04% swung to a worse-than-expected fiscal first-quarter loss as sales of its unmanned aircrafts slipped. Shares were off 2.4% to $23.63 after hours. BreitBurn Energy Partners L.P. BBEP is offering 10 million common units representing limited-partner interests in the energy company. Units fell 4.3% to $18.45 in after-hours trading. Enbridge Energy Partners L.P. EEP, +2.99% has commenced an offering of around 14 million Class A units representing limited-partner interests. The oil and gas transporter's shares slid 4.6% to $28.35 after hours. FuelCell Energy Inc.'s FCEL, +0.58% fiscal third-quarter loss widened as the power-equipment maker's product sales weakened and expenses increased. Shares sank 10% to 90 cents after hours Wednesday as results missed analyst expectations. Harry Winston Diamond Corp.'s (HWD, HW.T) fiscal second-quarter earnings fell 52% as the jewelry retailer reported weaker sales in both its mining and luxury brand segments. Shares slipped 2.4% to $11.95 after hours as per-share earnings missed analyst expectations. Men's Wearhouse Inc.'s MW fiscal second-quarter earnings rose 4.1% as same-store sales grew for its namesake and Moore's brands and as margins strengthened. Shares jumped 7.1% to $34.11 after hours as per-share profits beat the apparel retailer's expectations and as the company lifted its full-year view. Mitcham Industries Inc.'s MIND, +0.93% fiscal second-quarter profit surged as the seismic equipment supplier recorded a favorable tax impact, masking a decline in equipment leasing revenue. Shares jumped 6.1% to $16.55 in after-hours trading as adjusted earnings beat analyst expectations. SeaChange International Inc. SEAC, +0.37% swung to a fiscal second-quarter loss as the video-gear maker's sales fell and its profit margin narrowed. Shares fell 8.1% in after-hours trading, to $7.90. Pharmaceutical company Warner Chilcott PLC WCRX said funds affiliated with Bain Capital Partners, J.P. Morgan Partners, Thomas H. Lee Partners, L.P., and members of its senior management are offering an undisclosed number of shares. Shares slipped 8.4% to $13 after hours. Zillow Inc. Z, +0.62% said it will offer 3.18 million Class A shares as the real-estate information provider raises funds for general purposes. Shares were down 3.7% to $40.85 after hours. Watchlist: ABM Industries Inc.'s ABM, +0.75% fiscal third-quarter profit fell 55% as the company said lower government spending sapped revenue, while expenses rose. Enbridge Inc. (ENB, ENB.T) said President Al Monaco will take on the additional title of chief executive, effective Oct. 1, succeeding Patrick D. Daniel, who will retire at that time. Encana Corp. (ECA, ECA.T) said Wednesday an internal investigation concluded that the natural-gas producer didn't engage in collusion with competitor Chesapeake Energy Corp. CHK, +1.00% regarding Michigan land leasing in 2010. Korn/Ferry International's KFY, +0.47% fiscal first-quarter earnings fell 32% as the company reported lower fee revenue at its executive-search business and as currency fluctuations hurt its overall revenue. M/I Homes Inc. MHO, +1.92% said its offering of 2.2 million common shares priced at $17.63, matching Wednesday's closing price. Nordion Inc. (NDZ, NDN.T) swung to a fiscal third-quarter profit as the medical-technology company logged fewer one-time expenses, and sales grew modestly. Sigma Designs Inc.'s SIGM, +0.40% fiscal second-quarter loss narrowed as the company's revenue climbed with help from a recent acquisition. Snyder's-Lance Inc. LNCE has agreed to acquire Snack Factory LLC and certain affiliates for $340 million in cash, adding the fast-growing Pretzel Crisps brand to the snack company's portfolio. content: WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) — Among the stocks that could see active trade in Wednesday’s session are FedEx Corp., Verso Paper Corp. and Guidewire Software Inc. Companies queued up to report quarterly financial results on Wednesday include Dollar General Corp. DG, +0.66% Conn’s Inc. CONN, +5.10%  , Men’s Wearhouse Inc. MW  , Harry Winston Diamond Corp. HWD  , H&R Block Inc. HRB, +1.03%  , SeaChange International Inc. SEAC, +0.37%  , VeriFone Holdings Inc. PAY, -0.52%  , AeroVironment Inc. AVAV, +1.04%  , Nordion Inc. NDZ  , Stewart Enterprises Inc. STEI  , Pike Electric Corp. PIKE  , Mitcham Industries Inc. MIND, +0.93%  , ABM Industries Inc. ABM, +0.75%  and Matrix Service Co. MTRX, +3.40%  , among others. Late Tuesday, FedEx FDX, +2.26%  said profit for the first quarter ended Aug. 29 will come up short of management’s prior projection of $1.45 to $1.60 a share. The package-delivery company cited “weakness in the global economy [that] constrained revenue growth at FedEx Express more than expected.” FedEx now sees the quarter’s earnings in a range of $1.37 to $1.43 a share. Additional information will be made available when FedEx formally releases quarterly earnings on Sept. 18. Another Memphis-based company, Verso Paper Corp. VRS, +1.32%  said it’s ceased discussions with NewPage Corp. or its creditors about a potential business combination. Verso’s discussions, including certain holders of NewPage’s 11.375% first-lien senior secured notes, came to light two months ago. NewPage, which entered Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings last year, filed a reorganization plan in mid- August. “After careful analysis, we believe it is in the best interests of our company and its stakeholders to focus on the many other opportunities for Verso, including internal growth projects and other potential strategic alternatives,” said President and Chief Executive David Paterson in a statement. TimeFrancesca's Holdings Corp.May 17Jul 17Sep 17Nov 17Jan 18Mar 18 US:FRAN $5.0 $7.5 $10.0 $12.5 $15.0 Along with reporting results for the second quarter ended July 28, Francesca’s Holdings Corp. FRAN, -4.57%  announced changes in senior management to take effect at year’s end. Neill Davis, currently the Houston-based company’s president, has been promoted to CEO as of Jan. 1, replacing John De Meritt. In addition, Chief Operating Officer Theresa Backes has been promoted to the president’s post. De Meritt has decided to retire “to pursue personal endeavors,” Francesca’s Holdings said. The company said second-quarter results exceeded management’s expectations, and for the third quarter ending Oct. 27, Francesca’s Holdings is aiming for a profit of 21 cents to 22 cents a share on an adjusted basis, on projected sales of between $70.5 million and $71.5 million. And for the full fiscal year, adjusted earnings are forecast at 96 cents to 98 cents a share on sales of $290 million to $292 million. TimeKirby Corp.May 17Jul 17Sep 17Nov 17Jan 18Mar 18 US:KEX $60 $65 $70 $75 Kirby Corp. KEX, +3.57%  announced a deal to buy the assets of Allied Transportation Co. and two affiliated companies at a cash price of $116 million. The transaction’s expected to contribute 6 cents to 8 cents a share to Houston-based Kirby’s bottom line in 2013, according to Chairman and CEO Joe Pyne. Allied operates offshore barges and tugboats used for transporting petrochemicals and dry sugar products in U.S. waters. The acquisition, expected to occur late in the third quarter or early in the fourth quarter, “provides Kirby with a strong footprint from which to grow the petrochemical segment of our offshore business,” Pyne said in a statement. Transaction-related expenses will offset any earnings contribution in 2012, as Kirby affirmed a profit target range of $3.50 to $3.70 a share TimeCapital One Financial Corp.May 17Jul 17Sep 17Nov 17Jan 18Mar 18 US:COF $80 $90 $100 Capital One Financial Corp. COF, +1.64%  said ING Bank NV, as selling stockholder, plans a public offering to dispose of all of the 54 million or so shares of McLean, Va.-based Capital One it owns. Underwriters will propose to offer the shares at prevailing market prices or otherwise and from time to time. ING ING, +0.06%  came into possession of the shares along with cash as a result of selling ING Direct to Capital One, a deal valued at $9.2 billion that closed last February. Capital One said it won’t receive any proceeds as a result of ING’s move. Sarepta Therapeutics Inc. SRPT, +3.29%  said it’s entered into an at-the-market sales agreement for company equity. Terms call for Sarepta to, from time to time, offer and sell up to $40 million in common shares via investment dealer Citadel Securities LLC. Net proceeds will be used for general corporate purposes including the development of product candidates, Cambridge, Mass.-based Sarepta said. The board of PartnerRe Ltd. PRE, -1.92%  authorized the repurchase of up to 6 million common shares, the Bermuda-based company said. The new authorization supercedes a previous one under which PartnerRe bought back about 4.3 million common shares in the year to date through August. Repurchases will be made from time to time, depending on market conditions, in the open market or via privately negotiated or structured transactions, the reinsurer said. The board of DeVry Inc. DV, +2.94%  approved a stock-buyback plan covering up to $100 million in common shares, the higher-education company said. The authorization, to run through the end of 2014, will take effect once Downers Grove, Ill.-based DeVry’s current repurchase program, also authorized at $100 million, expires. Tuesday earnings recap Guidewire Software GWRE, +2.05%  said both earnings and revenue in the fourth quarter ended July 31 exceeded management’s expectations for the Foster City, Calif.-based company serving the insurance industry. Read more on Guidwire. Pep Boys — Manny, Moe & Jack PBY, -2.02%  reported a profit of profit of $33 million, or 61 cents a share, for the second quarter ended July 28, up from $14 million, or 26 cents, earned in the year-earlier period. Quarterly sales edged up less than 1% to $526 million, as the Philadelphia-based automotive aftermarket retailer’s comparable-store sales came in flat. Profit for the latest quarter got a boost from a $43 million merger-cancellation fee paid by Gores Group as plans to take Pep Boys private fell apart late last May. Also Tuesday, Pep Boys announced plans to cut its debt by $100 million via a refinancing. title: Stocks to watch Wednesday: FedEx, Verso, Guidewire

content: WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) — Among the stocks that could see active trade in Wednesday’s session are Iron Mountain Inc., MasterCard Inc. and Coinstar Inc. A broad cross section of companies — including Oil-Dri Corp. of America ODC, +2.03% Greif Inc. GEF, +2.96% Pall Corp. PLL, -6.21% ABM Industries Inc. ABM, +0.75% Brown-Forman Corp. BF.B, +2.99% BF.A, +3.59% Stewart Enterprises Inc. STEI Vail Resorts Inc. MTN, -0.91% Harry Winston Diamond Corp. HWD Men’s Wearhouse Inc. MW Annie’s Inc. BNNY, +0.00% Hovnanian Enterprises Inc. HOV, +0.55% SeaChange International Inc. SEAC, +0.37% Cyberonics Inc. CYBX Verint Systems Inc. VRNT, +13.90%  and Analogic Corp. ALOG, +1.75%  — is due to report quarterly financial results on Wednesday. TimeIron Mountain Inc.May 17Jul 17Sep 17Nov 17Jan 18Mar 18 US:IRM $32.5 $35.0 $37.5 $40.0 The board of Iron Mountain IRM, +0.46%  gave its approval to a plan to pursue converting the company to the status of a real estate investment trust. Doing so would “maximize value as we advance our operating strategy,” said Richard Reese, chairman and chief executive of Boston-based Iron Mountain, in a statement. A REIT structure would set the stage for “higher returns and new value-creating opportunities,” including through dividends from savings on federal taxes, the company said. Iron Mountain noted that renting out storage space in buildings around the world constitutes the biggest proportion of the company’s income. REIT status would come no sooner than the company’s taxable year beginning Jan. 1, 2014, with one-time conversion costs projected to range from about $325 million to $425 million, Iron Mountain said. The company will consider the issuance of debt, equity or some combination to satisfy conversion-related cash requirements. Plans call for Iron Mountain to distribute some $1 billion to $1.5 billion in accumulated earnings and profits, in line with tax rules applicable to REIT conversions, starting in the fourth quarter of 2012. Iron Mountain’s board also declared a quarterly cash dividend of 27 cents a share, an increase of 8%. It’s payable July 13 to stockholders of record as of June 22, as the company accelerates distributions to stockholders. Total cash dividends over the next six quarters are expected to total $280 million. Also late Tuesday, the board of MasterCard MA, +2.82%  approved the authorization of up to $1.5 billion in buybacks under a new share-repurchase program covering Class A common stock, the company said. This program will take effect once MasterCard’s current $2 billion buyback authorization has been exhausted; it had about $270 million remaining as of the end of May. Separately, the Purchase, N.Y.-based company’s directors declared a regular quarterly dividend of 30 cents a share, payable Aug. 9 to stockholders of record as of July 9. TimeCapStar Financial Holdings Inc.May 17Jul 17Sep 17Nov 17Jan 18Mar 18 US:CSTR $16 $18 $20 $22 Coming soon to a store near some of you: Coinstar Inc. CSTR, +0.00%  announced plans to begin rolling out coffee-dispensing kiosks featuring Seattle’s Best, a Starbucks Corp. SBUX, -0.02%  brand. Dubbed Rubi, the coffee kiosks will first appear this summer in groceries, drugstores and mass merchants in the Northeast and the West Coast. The kiosks will grind and brew fresh whole beans in a single-cup process and will offer specialty drinks including mochas and vanilla lattes as well as coffee, with prices starting at $1. About 500 of the kiosks serving Seattle’s Best are expected to be up and running by the end of the year, expanding to “thousands” in the next several years, the companies said. It’s Bellevue, Wash.-based Coinstar’s third automated retail business, following on its coin-counting machines and the Redbox machines for movie rentals. Soon-to-be-public Hillshire Brands Co. will deliver annual revenue growth of 4% to 5%, generate an operating margin of 10% percent by fiscal 2015 and have a near-term dividend payout ratio of 30% to 35%, parent Sara Lee Corp. SLE, +0.51%  said. Earlier Tuesday, the Downers Grove, Ill.-based company designated its North American foods business as Hillshire Brands, effective upon the June 28 spin-off to stockholders of Sara Lee’s international coffee and tea business. Hillshire Brands will trade on the New York Stock Exchange under the ticker HSH, while the coffee and tea arm will be known as D.E Master Blenders 1753 NV. In connection with separating its businesses, Sara Lee last week announced plans for a $3-a-share special dividend as well as a 1-for-5 reverse stock split. Dollar General Corp. DG, +0.66%  said that the size of its follow-on public offering of common stock has been increased, rising to 30 million shares from the 25 million contemplated earlier this week, and that the shares priced at $46.75 each. All of the net proceeds from the stock being sold will go to certain company stockholders, who also increased the size of the greenshoe granted to underwriters to 4.5 million additional shares. The offering is expected to close June 11, the Goodlettsville, Tenn.-based deep discounter said. title: Stocks to watch: Iron Mountain, MasterCard

content: WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) — Among the stocks that could see active trade in Monday’s session are American International Group Inc., Advanced Micro Devices Inc. and BP PLC. On the earnings front, VeriFone Systems Inc. PAY, -0.52% Nutrisystem Inc. NTRI, -0.92% Steinway Musical Instruments Inc. LVB Black Diamond Inc. BDE, +0.00% Asset Acceptance Capital Corp. AACC Air Transport Services Group Inc. ATSG, +2.91% Ducommun Inc. DCO, +1.37% ABM Industries Inc. ABM, +0.75% Cross Country Healthcare Inc. CCRN, +1.83% Santarus Inc. SNTS  and First Majestic Silver Corp. AG, +1.50%  are the notable companies scheduled to report results. TimeAmerican International Group Inc.May 17Jul 17Sep 17Nov 17Jan 18Mar 18 US:AIG $55 $60 $65 AIG AIG, -0.18%  , the New York-based insurance and financial-services giant bailed out by the federal government in 2008, is taking a further step toward paying down its U.S. ownership stake. The company said it’s commenced a sale of ordinary shares of Hong Kong-oisted AIA Group Ltd. AAGIY, +2.43%  via a placement with institutional investors. It’s expected to be priced no later than Tuesday, and media reports place the size of the offering at about $6 billion. Net proceeds will go toward reducing the balance due the Treasury Department, according to AIG, which holds about a 33% stake in AIA Group. Shares of AIA Group were placed on a trading suspension Monday in Hong Kong, at the company’s request. The Asian life-insurance arm of AIG raised some $17.9 billion via a 2010 initial public offering. Read more. TimeAdvanced Micro Devices Inc.May 17Jul 17Sep 17Nov 17Jan 18Mar 18 US:AMD $10 $12 $14 Also Sunday, Sunnyvale, Calif.-based AMD AMD, +2.45%  said it would take a $703 million charge against first-quarter financial results, reflecting in part a payment that the company will make to transfer its remaining ownership interest in GlobalFoundries to the other owners of the joint venture. The amount of the cash payment is $425 million, to be paid in four installments through the first quarter of 2013. GlobalFoundries, formed as a result of AMD spinning off its manufacturing operations, has experienced chip production problems. In addition, AMD and GlobalFoundries amended their wafer supply agreement, entering into a negotiated price mechanism for 2012 and setting forth a framework for 2013. The balance of the one-time charge will be non-cash in nature, AMD said. TimeBP PLC ADRJul 16Oct 16Jan 17Apr 17Jul 17Oct 17Jan 18 US:BP $30 $35 $40 BP BP, +2.37%  announced a $7.8 billion settlement struck with a “substantial majority” of the thousands of plaintiffs who sued the oil major in the wake of the 2010 Deepwater Horizon disaster in the Gulf of Mexico.The settlement, which will be paid from a $20 billion trust fund set up after the largest-ever U.S. maritime oil spill, came just ahead of a Monday civil trial that had been scheduled to convene in federal court in New Orleans. “The proposed settlement represents significant progress toward resolving issues from the Deepwater Horizon accident,” said Bob Dudley, BP’s chief executive, in a statement. Read more on BP. Fifth Third Bancorp FITB, +0.60%  priced at a slight discount to par $500 million in 10-year senior notes to be sold in a public offering expected to close Wednesday. The notes will bear interest at 3.5%, the Cincinnati-based company said. Fifth Third intends to use net proceeds for general corporate purposes. Hornbeck Offshore Services Inc. HOS, +2.11%  said it agreed to sell a further $25 million in 5.875% senior notes due 2020, bringing the total size of the company’s offering to $375 million. Net proceeds will be used in part by Covington, La.-based Hornbeck Offshore to buy any and all of its 6.125% senior notes due 2014 via a cash tender offer. Closing is expected March 16, the company said. Underwriters have fully exercised their option to buy more stock in connection with a secondary equity offering by NorthStar Realty Finance Corp. NRF the New York-based company said. As a result, the the company sold nearly 17.3 million common shares in the offering. Last month, NorthStar Realty Finance sold 15 million of the shares at a price of $5.55 each. title: Stocks to watch Monday: AIG, AMD, BP

content: WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) — Among the stocks that could see active trade in Wednesday’s session are Marriott International Inc., Avon Products Inc. and Warnaco Group Inc. Companies on Wednesday’s earnings calendar include VeriFone Systems Inc. PAY, -0.52%  and Joy Global Inc. JOY, +0.64%  as well as Nordson Corp. NDSN, +1.75% National Technical Systems Inc. NTSC Apogee Enterprises Inc. APOG, +0.74% MedCath Corp. MDTH  and Synovis Life Technologies Inc. SYNO shares of which rallied Tuesday on a buyout agreement announced with Baxter International BAX, +1.86% J.W. Marriott Jr. will step down from the post of the chief executive of Marriott International MAR, +1.55% next March, according to a Washington Post report. Marriott, son of the founder of the global hotel chain, will be replaced by Arne Sorenson as CEO but will stay on as executive chairman. Sorenson, a company veteran who currently serves as president and chief operating officer, thus will become the first person outside the Marriott family to run the Bethesda, Md.-based company, the Post reported. Also on the executive front, Avon Products AVP, -1.05%  said it will separate the roles of chairman and CEO starting in 2012. Andrea Jung, who currently holds both posts, will be named executive chairman as the distributor of beauty products conducts an external search for a new CEO. Jung has served as New York-based Avon’s CEO since 1999. “Separating the chairman and CEO roles as well as strengthening overall management capabilities are important steps to help the company capture its future opportunities,” said Fred Hassan, managing director and partner of Warburg Pincus LLC and Avon’s lead independent director, in a statement. And Warnaco Group WRC, -7.60%  set in motion its succession plan, saying the company’s board elected Helen McCluskey to serve as president and CEO effective Feb. 1. COO McCluskey, who joined the maker of sportswear and intimate apparel in 2004, will succeed Joe Gromek in the posts. Gromek said he will retire from the New York-based company and give up his seat on the board, which will be filled by McCluskey. Also late Tuesday, American Woodmark Corp. AMWD, +3.04%  said it would reduce production capacity in the face of a continuing slump in the housing industry. The Winchester, Va.-based company will close a component facility in West Virginia as well as a lumber dimension business in Kentucky and will put its Tahlequah, Okla., assembly plant, idled more than two years ago, up for sale. The number of employees affected by these moves wasn’t specified by the manufacturer of kitchen cabinets and vanities. The company pegged total pre-tax costs associated with these actions at about $18 million to $20 million, with most of the charges to be taken against results for the third quarter ending Jan. 31, and said it expects to realize ongoing annual cost savings of about $16.5 million to $18.5 million. American Woodmark’s actions “will reduce the company’s breakeven point and enhance our ability to generate favorable results,” said Chairman and CEO Kent Guichard in a statement. The board of Amerco UHAL, +0.68%  declared a special cash dividend of $1 per common share, payable Jan. 3 to stockholders of record as of Dec. 23. The company had nearly 19.5 million weighted average common shares outstanding as of Sept. 30, according to financial results for the second quarter of fiscal 2012. Reno-based Amerco is the parent of U-Haul International Inc. and has interests in insurance and real estate. Along with reporting results for the fourth quarter ended Oct. 31 and issuing a profit forecast for fiscal 2012, ABM Industries Inc. ABM, +0.75%  said its board declared a quarterly cash dividend of 14.5 cents a share on common stock. This works out to a 4% increase, the New York-based provider of facility services said. The dividend’s payable Feb. 6 to shareholders of record as of Jan. 5. Duluth, Ga.-based Primerica Inc. PRI, -0.31%  said a public offering of nearly 8.1 million common shares has been priced at $22.29 each. The shares are held by a subsidiary of Citigroup Inc. C, -1.11% which will receive all net proceeds. The offering reflects the sale of all of the remaining Primerica common stock owned by Citigroup. MarkWest Energy Partners LP MWE, -3.45%  priced a public offering of 10 million common units at $54.25 each. The size of the offering was increased from 8 million common units. Underwriters have a 30-day option to buy up to 1.5 million additional common units if investor demand warrants. Denver-based MarkWest will use net proceeds to finance the proposed acquisition of all of the interests in MarkWest Liberty Midstream & Resources LLC held by an affiliate of Energy & Minerals Group, a private-equity firm. Read more on MarkWest’s business plans in the Utica shale region. Also on the energy front, Union Drilling Inc. UDRL, +0.00%  said it expects to realize net proceeds of $10 million from an auction of 31 unused rigs and related equipment, with funds to be used to pay down borrowings under the Ft. Worth-based company’s credit facility. Management also anticipates a gain of about $3 million from the assets sold at auction, which will be reported in fourth-quarter results. More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? title: Stocks to watch Wednesday: Marriott, Avon, Warnaco

content: WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) — Among the stocks that could see active trade in Tuesday’s session are Urban Outfitters Inc., Medtronic Inc. and Best Buy Co. Best Buy BBY, +2.09%  heads up the roster of companies scheduled to report financial results. Others on deck include the Pantry Inc. PTRY Learning Tree International Inc. LTRE, -3.51% ABM Industries Inc. ABM, +0.75% Nordion Inc. NDZ  and FactSet Research Systems Inc. FDS, +0.49% among others. Late Monday, Urban Outfitters URBN, +1.59%   issued an upbeat sales update, saying in a regulatory filing of its third-quarter results that in the fourth quarter, comparable retail segment net sales have been running “mid-single-digit positive.” Fridley, Minn.-based Medtronic MDT, +2.24%  said it agreed to pay $23.5 million to settle a Justice Department investigation of four post-market studies. The federal agency had alleged that the company violated the False Claim Act by using payments related to the post-market studies and device registries as kickbacks to induce physicians to implant its pacemakers and defibrillators. Medtronic, which established a reserve for the full anticipated payment in the fourth quarter, said it “makes no admission that any studies were improper or unlawful.” Forest Oil Corp. FST, +0.28%  said it’s budgeted $550 million to $600 million for capital projects next year, including $480 million to $520 million for exploration and development, primarily in the Texas Panhandle as well as in the eastern part of the state and northern Louisiana. The company also projected annual organic growth of 5% to 6% for net sales volumes next year as well as a 10% increase in net liquids sales volumes from estimated 2011 levels. content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of the following companies made noteworthy moves in the U.S. stock market on Thursday: Advancers Allegheny Technologies Inc. ATI, +3.91% shares climbed 5.6% after the metals processor raised its fourth-quarter forecast. Read more about the improved view. Facet Biotech Corp. 590024, -2.09% shares gained 4.4% after the company's shareholders rejected a $93 million takeover offer by Biogen Idec Inc. BIIB, +0.74% See more about terminated offer. Pier 1 Imports Inc. PIR, +2.88% shares gained 9.4% after the home-décor retailer reported a profitable third quarter, topping analysts' expectations. Pier 1 shares buck sector's early trend. Rite Aid Corp. RAD, +0.60% gained nearly 13% after the drugstore chain reported results that beat analysts' forecasts. Read details about losses at nation's third-biggest drugstore operator. MARKETS | • The Tell: Market news and analysis • | Canada section • Columns: Stocks | Oil | Gold | Bonds | Dollar  TOOLS AND DATA | • My Portfolio: Know where your funds are? • Real-time currency exchange rates • After-hours stock screener Decliners ABM Industries Inc. ARNA, -0.28% shares dropped 5.5% after a Jefferies & Co. analyst initiated coverage on the drug developer with a cautious take on its obesity drug candidate. Bon-Ton Stores Inc. BONT shares declined 5.8% after Moody's Investors Service hiked some of its ratings for the retailer's corporate family. Citigroup Inc. C, -1.11% shares fell 6.7% one day after the bank's stock offering drew a less-than-anticipated price. See details on government backing off plan to sell Citigroup shares. title: Thursday's biggest gaining and declining stocks

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Shares of the following companies made notable moves in the stock market on Thursday: Gainers Ciena Corp. CIEN, +2.29% shares rose 6% as the company reported a third-quarter loss of $26.5 million, or 29 cents a share, a reversal from its year-earlier profit of $11.7 million, or 12 cents a share. On an adjusted basis, the communications networking equipment supplier lost 5 cents a share in the fiscal 2009 quarter. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had, on average, expected a loss of 14 cents a share. Revenue for the quarter ended July 31 fell 35% to $164.8 million. See full story on Ciena. Costco Wholesale Corp. COST, +2.63% shares gained 8.6%. The warehouse retailer reported August comparable-store sales fell 2% as total sales were level with monthly sales of $5.4 billion a year ago. See full story on retail stocks. Del Monte Foods Co. DLM shares added 7.5% after the company said it swung to a fiscal first-quarter profit and pushed its full year outlook past Wall Street expectations on Thursday. Del Monte earned $58.6 million, or 29 cents a share compared to a loss of $10.1 million, or 5 cents a share, in the same quarter a year ago. On a continuing-operations basis, it would have earned 30 cents a share. Sales rose 11% to $813.7 million. See full story on Del Monte. Pilgrim's Pride Corp. PGPDQ shares gained 5.2%. JBS SA JBSA of Brazil said it plans to acquire the bankrupt chicken producer for more than $2 billion, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing sources familiar with the matter. Read more on Pilgrim's Pride. Layne Christensen Co. LAYN, +3.54% shares rose 11%. The drilling-services company swung to a second-quarter loss from a year-earlier profit as revenue fell 19% to $217.2 million. The loss for the three months ended July 31 was 45 cents a share compared with 78 cents in the year-earlier second quarter. Adjusted earnings for the latest quarter were 23 cents, "reflecting continued weakness in mineral exploration and certain water markets," Layne Christensen said in a statement late Wednesday. Quanex Building Products Corp. NX, +0.00% shares added 5.6%. The materials provider for U.S. residential window and door markets reported Wednesday that second-quarter net income fell 7.7% on 32% lower sales. For the quarter ended July 31, net income was $8.1 million, or 22 cents a share. Zumiez Inc. ZUMZ, +0.00% shares gained 18%. August sales at stores open at least one year sank 12.1%. Analysts, on average, had expected same-store sales to fall 18.9%, according to Thomson Reuters. Total sales for the four weeks ended Aug. 30 also fell, down 2.9% to $51.7 million. Read more on Retail Stocks. Decliners ABM Industries Inc. ABM, +0.75% shares fell 4.6% after the company reported late Wednesday that its third-quarter profit dropped 25% to $12.3 million, or 24 cents a share, because of an after-tax insurance-expense. Children's Place Inc. PLCE, +1.20% shares slipped 5% after the children's clothing retailer said its net sales for the four-week period ended August 29 fell 4% to $138.7 million compared to the same period a year ago. Read more on Retail Stocks. Jackson Hewitt Tax Services Inc. JTX shares dropped 8.5% as the company reported Thursday a fiscal first-quarter loss of $21.8 million, or 76 cents a share, compared with a year-earlier loss of $20.5 million, or 72 cents a share. On an adjusted basis, the company posted a loss of 67 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters predicted a loss of 71 cent a share. Hovnanian Enterprises Inc. HOV, +0.55% shares fell 13%. The home builder said Thursday its third-quarter loss narrowed to $168.9 million, or $2.16 a share, from $202.5 million, or $2.67 a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue fell to $387.1 million from $716.5 million. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had forecast a quarterly loss of $1.56 a share on revenue of $378.2 million. title: Thursday's biggest gaining and declining stocks

content: Among the companies whose shares are expected to actively trade in Thursday's session are Oxford Industries Inc. OXM, -1.25% Hovnanian Enterprises Inc. HOV, +0.55% and Vical Inc. (VICL) Oxford Industries' fiscal second-quarter profit dropped 64% on charges while sales and margins also fell. But shares jumped 13% to $15.90 in premarket trading as the apparel maker's earnings excluding charges smashed Wall Street's expectations. Hovnanian's fiscal third-quarter loss narrowed as the home builder reported fewer write-downs and a $37 million gain. The company also said its contract cancellation rate improved. Still, shares fell 9.5% to $4.21 in premarket action as revenue missed analysts' expectations. Vical said it received a U.S. patent for influenza vaccines, including for H1N1 it has been developing and is waiting to test on humans. Shares jumped 15% premarket to $5.01. Curis Inc. CRIS, -2.96% said the current edition of the New England Journal of Medicine contains two articles on the cancer treatment it is developing with a Roche Holding AG's RHHBY, -0.61% subsidiary Genentech. The experimental drug designed yielded encouraging results against two rare tumors, researchers said, potentially opening up a new front in the battle against the disease. Shares of Curis leapt 20% to $2.52 premarket. Hot Topic Inc. HOTT and Zumiez Inc. ZUMZ, +0.00% reported lower same-store sales in August as the teen retailers kick off what is expected to be another poor month of sales. Abercrombie & Fitch Co. (ANF), led the way down, posting a bigger-than-projected 29% same-store-sales slump for August. Shares of Zumiez, which recorded its smallest percentage drop this year, rose 16% to $14.15 premarket while Hot Topic's were inactive. Abercrombie dropped 3.7% to $30.89 premarket. Movado Group Inc.'s MOV, +15.66% unexpectedly stayed in the black in its fiscal second-quarter, though profit fell 94%, as the high-end watch maker slashed its perating expenses. Shares rose 5.9% to $12.15 premarket. Layne Christensen Co. LAYN, +3.54% swung to a fiscal second-quarter loss as the drilling-services company took a $13 million write-down in its small energy business and continued to suffer from a steep demand drop at its mining business. But core results beat expectations and Chief Executive Andrew B. Schmitt said all businesses saw stronger results from the prior quarter. Shares rose 6.3% to $26.99 premarket. SAIC Inc.'s SAI, +11.11% fiscal second-quarter profit grew 13% as the defense contractor benefited from increased government spending. Shares rose 2.1% to $18.45 in premarket trading as SAIC's results topped Wall Street's expectations. Methode Electronics Inc. MEI, +0.90% reported a fiscal first-quarter loss of $19,000, compared with a prior-year profit of $6.8 million, or 16 cents a share. The results included restructuring charges of 10 cents and 9 cents, respectively. The maker of electromechanical devices also said bankrupt auto-parts supplier Delphi Corp. (DPHIQ) has told the company it will terminate its supply deal with Methode in one week. Methode shares rose 8.3% to $9 premarket. UTi Worldwide Inc.'s UTIW, +0.74% fiscal second-quarter earnings slumped 65% as revenue for the supply-chain services company sales fell by a third and results missed expectations. Share fell 5.4% to $12 premarket. Collective Brands Inc.'s PSS fiscal second-quarter profit more than doubled because of prior-year litigation costs, as the retailer said sales continued to fall. Shares dropped 1.6% to $15.52 in after-hours trading, as the results missed Wall Street's expectations. Martek Biosciences Corp.'s MATK fiscal third-quarter profit fell 4% as the infant-formula company's efforts to clear out inventories led to a double-digit decline in revenue. The maker of nutritional products used in infant formula and other products also trimmed expectations for the year, though its fourth-quarter outlook is roughly in line with Wall Street expectations. Shares fell 2.9% to $23.30 in premarket trading. Endo Pharmaceuticals Holdings Inc. ENDP, +1.71% said the Food and Drug Administration extended its review period until early December on the company's injectable testosterone therapy. Shares slipped 1.9%, then rose 2.3% to $22.31 in late trading. Casella Waste Systems Inc. CWST, -0.04% swung to a fiscal first-quarter loss on a double-digit revenue decline driven by weak demand from construction customers. But the waste-management company said higher commodity prices helped its recycling operations. Shares jumped 9.9% to $2.78 after hours. Watch List: Abbott Laboratories ABT, +1.16% said it agreed to pay $400 million for Visiogen Inc., a privately held maker of cataract-correction technology, as the drug maker continues its push into the eye-care business. ABM Industries Inc.'s ABM, +0.75% fiscal third-quarter profit dropped 25% on an insurance charge, but the facility-services contractor's earnings topped analysts' estimate. American Software Inc.'s AMSWA, +4.00% fiscal first-quarter profit jumped 94% on increased margins and interest income. The provider of e-business solutions and supply-chain management products has reported lower revenue in the past several quarters amid a double-digit drop in services revenue. Greif Inc.'s GEF, +2.96% fiscal third-quarter earnings dropped 39% as the packaging company posted higher restructuring charges and sales well below analysts' estimates. But margins improved on lower costs. Jackson Hewitt Tax Service Inc.'s JTX fiscal first-quarter loss widened slightly, though its results excluding items narrowed from a year ago and beat analysts expectations. Quanex Building Products Corp.'s NX, +0.00% fiscal third-quarter profit fell 7.7% as higher margins nearly offset slumping revenue for the building-products maker. Results far surpassed analysts' expectations. Regency Energy Partners LP RGNC sold $80 million of convertible preferred units to investors led by MTP Energy Management and private-equity firm Harvest Partners LLC. The natural-gas producer and distributor plans to use the proceeds to strengthen its position in the Haynesville shale area. Regency announced a joint venture in March to more than double its pipeline system in northern Louisiana's Haynesville shale by the end of the year. content: (Includes corrected item on VeriFone.) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Among the stocks expected to see active trading Wednesday are those of Collective Brands Inc., Zale Corp., Joy Global Inc. and SAIC Inc. ABM Industries ABM, +0.75% is forecast to post fiscal-third quarter earnings of 35 cents a share, according to analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters. Bio-Reference Laboratories BRLI is projected to post fiscal third-quarter earnings of 38 cents a share. Collective Brands Inc. PSS is expected to post second-quarter earnings of 33 cents a share. DHT Maritime Inc. DHT, -0.58% is forecast to post second-quarter earnings of 16 cents a share. Hovnanian Enterprises Inc. HOV, +0.55% is projected to post a fiscal third-quarter loss of $1.52 a share. Joy Global Inc. JOYG is forecast to post fiscal third-quarter earnings of 95 cents a share. SAIC Inc. SAI, +11.11% is expected to post second-quarter earnings of 30 cents a share. Synovis Life technologies Inc. SYNO is forecast to post fiscal third-quarter earnings of 17 cents a share. Zale Corp. ZLC, +0.65% is projected to post a fiscal fourth-quarter loss of 72 cents a share. After Tuesday's bell, VeriFone Holdings Inc. PAY, -0.52% said it swung to a fiscal third-quarter profit of $21.9 million, or 26 cents a share, from a loss of $7.2 million, or 9 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue for the quarter fell to $211.2 million from $258.7 million. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research estimated a profit of 18 cents a share on revenue of $205.9 million. Watch List ADC Telecommunications Inc. ADCT said late Tuesday that its fiscal third-quarter net income fell to $5.6 million, or 6 cents a share, from $13.4 million, or 11 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Excluding one-time items, the company would have reported earnings of 17 cents a share for the latest quarter. Revenue fell to $283.4 million from $381.8 million last year. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research estimated third-quarter earnings of 10 cents a share on revenue of $281.7 million. EMC Corp. EMC, +9.92% said late Tuesday that it will acquire privately held Kazeon Systems Inc., a developer of identification and classification software. Kazeon specializes in software used by corporations to determine the merits of legal cases and possible legal strategies to be taken in the event of litigation. Financial terms weren't disclosed. EMC expects the deal to close in third quarter of this year. Take-Two Interactive Software Inc. TTWO, +0.33% said Tuesday afternoon that it swung to a loss for its third fiscal quarter as video game sales fell sharply from the same period last year. For the period ended July 31, Take-Two reported a net loss of $55.5 million, or 72 cents a share, compared to earnings of $51.8 million, or 67 cents a share, for the same period last year. Wells Fargo & Co. WFC, +1.81% said Tuesday it plans to repay government support soon without diluting existing shareholders. In October, the government invested more than $100 billion in the nation's nine largest banks through the Troubled Asset Relief Program, with Wells Fargo getting $25 billion. While several of those banks repaid TARP this year, Wells Fargo hasn't yet. See full story on Wells Fargo.
