title: Stocks in focus for Wednesday

content: Xilinx cuts third-quarter view on weaker-than-expected sales (5:11 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Xilinx Inc. XLNX, +1.25% late Tuesday cut its third-quarter sales outlook to reflect sluggish business. The company now expects quarterly sales to decline 6% to 10% from the previous period, compared with its previous forecast of up 2% to down 2%. But it projected sales from the wireless communications and defense end markets to increase quarter-on-quarter while gross margin is expected to be unchanged at 63% to 64%. Operating expenses are estimated to be about $175 million to $177 million, below the original forecast of about $180 million. Xilinx will release its third-quarter results on Jan. 14. Hovnanian quarterly loss narrows to $5.79 a share (4:57 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Hovnanian Enterprises HOV, +0.55% reported late Tuesday its after-tax loss available to common stockholders in the fourth quarter was $450.5 million, or $5.79 a share, compared with a net loss of $469.3 million, or $7.42 a share, in the same quarter last year. Revenue fell to $721.4 million from $1.39 billion a year earlier. "The housing industry typically leads the U.S. economy into and out of recessions. It is important that a housing stimulus package is passed in order for a turnaround to occur in housing and the U.S. economy overall," President and Chief Executive Ara Hovnanian said in a statement. Adobe posts quarterly results at high end of projections (4:13 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - Adobe Systems Inc. said Tuesday its fiscal fourth-quarter net income rose to $245.9 million, or 46 cents a share, from $222.2 million, or 38 cents a share in the same period a year earlier. San Jose-based Internet and design software maker Adobe said revenue for the period ended in November rose to $915.3 million from $911.2 million. Excluding special items, Adobe said earnings for the period were 60 cents a share. Analysts on average estimated Adobe ADBE, +1.67% would post earnings excluding special items of 57 cents a share, on $917.7 million in revenue, according to FactSet Research. Adobe earlier this month issued disappointing early projections for its fourth-quarter results, which included earnings excluding special items between 59 and 60 cents a share, and revenue between $912 million and $915 million. Energy stocks mixed after Fed rate cut (2:32 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of petroleum and natural gas producers rose after the Federal Reserve cut the funds interest rate to a record low of 0.25%, but oil drillers remained in the red. The Amex Oil Index XOI, +2.04% rose 2.8% to 970. The Amex Natural Gas Index XNG, +2.25% rose 1.9% to 378. The Philadelphia Oil Service Index OSX, +2.53% fell 1.6% to 122. Exxon Mobil commmits $1 billion for clean diesel boost (10:12 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- ExxonMobil XOM, +2.47% said Tuesday it will invest more than $1 billion in three refineries to increase its supply of cleaner burning diesel by about six million gallons per day. The company will construct new units and modify existing facilities at its Baton Rouge, Louisiana; Baytown, Texas; and Antwerp, Belgium, refineries. Exterran Holdings up on share buyback boost (10:09 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Oil service firm Exterran Holdings Inc. EXH rose 5.5% to $20.94 after it set plans to increase its share purchase program to $300 million to $200 million. It also extended its buyback timeline to December, 2010 from August, 2009. Analysts at Pritchard Capital said the move marks an "encouraging sign of optimism." Goldman shifts fiscal year-end to December (9:12 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Goldman Sachs Group Inc. GS, +1.00% on Tuesday said its board has approved a change that shifts the company's fiscal year-end to the last Friday of December. Previously, the firm's fiscal year had ended in November. Goldman, which has converted to a bank-holding company, said the change is effective for its 2009 fiscal year. Goldman reports loss in trading and principal investments (8:46 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Goldman Sachs Group Inc. GS, +1.00% before Tuesday's opening bell said its trading and principal investments business saw negative net revenue of $4.36 billion in the fourth quarter, compared with net revenue of $6.93 billion in the year-ago quarter. The company also swung to negative net revenue of $3.4 billion in the fixed-income, currencies and commodities business. The results were hurt by "unprecedented weakness across the broader credit markets, reflecting broad-based declines in asset values [and] substantially reduced levels of liquidity," Goldman said. The principal investments business booked a net loss of $3.6 billion in the fourth quarter. Goldman Sachs shares were up about 3% in premarket trading. Vishay says revenue to fall short of forecast (8:39 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Vishay Intertechnology Inc. VSH, +2.20% said Tuesday that fourth-quarter revenue will be below the company's previous outlook. Vishay now expects fourth-quarter revenue to be in the range of $560 million to $590 million, down from a range of $640 million to $670 million. In response to market conditions, the company expects restructuring and severance charges of approximately $15 million to $30 million in the fourth quarter of 2008. Eaton cuts fourth quarter outlook (8:29 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Eaton Corp. ETN, +1.09% revised its fourth quarter earnings guidance on Tuesday, saying it now expects profits per share to be between 90 cents and $1. According to FactSet Research, the previous earning guidance expected between $1.70 and $1.80 a share. Analysts polled by FactSet are expecting earnings of $1.69 a share. Eaton had previously expected the fourth quarter to be flat with the year-ago period. It said on Tuesday it now expects a decline of between 3% and 4%. "We have experienced recent, dramatic deceleration in global demand in our automotive, truck and hydraulics segments," said Alexander Cutler, chairman and chief executive officer. "We have also begun to see weakness in certain markets within our electrical and aerospace businesses." Cutler added that Eaton has cut 3,400 staff this year. "We continue to evaluate a range of additional actions to further align our cost structure to the lower markets," he said. "Our current expectation is that these additional actions will be taken very early in 2009." Goldman's investment-banking revenue falls 48% (8:28 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Goldman Sachs Group Inc. GS, +1.00% on Tuesday said fourth-quarter net revenue in investment banking fell 48% from the year-earlier period to $1.03 billion. The company blamed a sharp slowdown in mergers and acquisitions for the 54% decline in net revenue from its financial-advisory business, which came in at $547 million. The credit crunch also took a toll on the firm's underwriting business, and net revenue there dropped 37% to $460 million, said Goldman, which has converted to a bank-holding company and participated in the government's financial rescue. GE Energy wins $3 billion turbine contract with Iraq (8:27 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- General Electric GE, -1.46% said Tuesday it inked a $3 billion contract with the government of Iraq for power generation equipment. The Fairfield, Conn. conglomerate's GE Energy unit will provide heavy-duty frame 9E multi-fuel gas turbines capable of supplying 7,000 megawatts of electricity. Iraq plans to install the units at key sites around the country to provide support for the electricity grid. Goldman Sachs posts $2.12 billion loss in fourth quarter (8:26 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Goldman Sachs GS, +1.00% on Tuesday reported its first ever loss as a public company in the fourth quarter, posting a deficit of $2.12 billion, or $4.97 a share, compared to a profit of $3.22 billion, or $7.01 a share in the year ago period. The firm's net revenue fell to negative $1.58 billion from $10.74 billion a year ago. "Our results for the fourth quarter reflect extraordinarily difficult operating conditions, including a sharp decline in values across virtually every asset class," Lloyd Blankfein, Goldman's chief executive, said in a press release. Johnson Controls withdraws 2009 forecast (8:24 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Johnson Controls Inc. JCI, +2.77% on Tuesday said it's withdrawing its 2009 targets as its eyes a first-quarter loss tied to deteriorating automobile production. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research forecast earnings of 20 cents a share for the coming quarter and earnings of $1.83 a share for 2009. The Milwaukee industrial firm also cut its 2009 capital spending forecast by about $350 million to $625 million. The company did not specify the size of its loss in the first quarter, traditionally the weakest period of the year. Johnson Control said it does expect to post a profit in 2009. "We are optimistic about the new U.S. Administration's infrastructure investment plans which target energy efficiency improvements in federal buildings and schools, two of our building efficiency businesses' largest markets," the company said. "This could substantially strengthen the growth opportunities for our company." Best Buy earnings drop to 13 cents a share from 53 cents (8:17 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Best Buy Co. BBY, +2.09% said Tuesday that it earned $52 million, or 13 cents a share in the third quarter, compared to $228 million, or 53 cents, in the same period a year ago. Revenue was $11.5 billion, compared to $9.9. billion last year in the quarter. Analysts polled by FactSet Research estimated, on average, earnings per share of 28 cents and sales of $11.1 billion. Same-store sales fell by 5.3% in the period. On an adjusted basis, Best Buy earned 35 cents in the quarter. The retailer says nearly all employees are eligible for voluntary separation packages, but involuntary job cuts may be required. Capital spending will be cut by approximately 50% next year, including a substantial reduction in new store openings in the United States, Canada and China, in preparation for a difficult business environment. Ener1's $30 million credit to fund operations through 2009 (7:17 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Ener1 HEV said Tuesday it secured $30 million in credit to allow it to continue operations until 2010 as the lithium-ion battery maker gears up for a contract to supply systems to Think electric vehicles in Oslo, Norway. "The environment for automotive suppliers and manufacturers has reached a nadir," the New York company said. "However, demand to supply advanced battery systems for the dozens of hybrid and electric vehicle programs already committed to by the world's automakers will remain healthy and robust." FactSet Research net climbs 21%, surpassing estimate (7:12 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- FactSet Research Systems Inc. FDS, +0.49% said Tuesday first-quarter net income for the three months ended Nov. 30 increased 21% to $35.6 million, or 73 cents a share, from $29.4 million, or 58 cents a share in the year-ago period. The Norwalk, Conn. data and analysis provider said revenue increased 16% to $155.6 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters forecast earnings of 63 cents a share, on average. The company expects second-quarter revenue of $156 million to $159 million, with operating margins of 31.5% to 33%, including FactSet Fundamentals. GE analysts unsure if firm will continue forecasts: Journal (7:02 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- General Electric Co. GE, -1.46% analysts wonder whether the Fairfield, Conn., industrial and financial-services giant might stop forecasting quarterly earnings, The Wall Street Journal reported. Chairman and Chief Executive Jeffrey Immelt is set to offer his annual review of operations on Tuesday. GE missed its forecasts in the first and third quarters, which contributed to a 54% stock drop this year, the Journal reported. Also in focus: the prospect of a cut in the 31-cent quarterly dividend, which currently provides a 7% yield but costs the company $12 billion a year, the Journal reported. ABM 4th-period net off 23% on 31% higher revenue (3:07 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- ABM Industries Inc., ABM, +0.75% the New York provider of janitorial, parking, security and engineering services, reported late on Monday that fiscal fourth-quarter earnings fell 23% on 31% higher revenue. For the quarter ended Oct. 31, earnings fell to $11.6 million, or 22 cents a share, from $15 million, or 30 cents, in the year-earlier period. Earnings from continuing operations were flat at 29 cents a share; on an adjusted basis, profit from continuing operations rose 28%. Revenue rose to $905.8 million from $691.4 million. The revenue growth reflects the acquisition of OneSource Services in November 2007. For the first half of 2009, ABM expects to earn 42 cents to 50 cents a share from operations, or an adjusted 46 cents to 54 cents. Beckman Coulter affirms 2008 outlook, outlines 2009 goals (2:39 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Beckman Coulter Inc., BEC, -2.19% the Orange County, Calif., provider of products to simplify and automate biomedical testing, late on Monday affirmed its 2008 earnings outlook. In 2008, the company expects to earn $3.55 to $3.65 a share as revenue rises 12%. A survey of analysts by FactSet Research produced a consensus estimate of $3.58 for the year. For 2009, Beckman Coulter targets 10% earnings growth as sales grow 5% on a constant-currency basis. FactSet's survey is looking for $3.93 in 2009. Drax sees fuel prices holding steady in 2009 (2:25 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Power station operator Drax Group(UK:DRX)said Tuesday that trading since its last update in late October has continued in line with expectations, though commodity prices have been volatile. The group said it expects fuel costs for 2009, excluding the cost of purchasing emissions allowances, to be similar to those in 2008. The group said it expects to close 2008 with between 125 million pounds ($191 million) and 130 million pounds in cash and expects to distribute all excess cash to shareholders. More from MarketWatch How to Get a Job: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- ABM Industries Inc., ABM, +0.75% the New York provider of janitorial, parking, security and engineering services, reported late on Monday that fiscal fourth-quarter earnings fell 23% on 31% higher revenue. For the quarter ended Oct. 31, earnings fell to $11.6 million, or 22 cents a share, from $15 million, or 30 cents, in the year-earlier period. Earnings from continuing operations were flat at 29 cents a share; on an adjusted basis, profit from continuing operations rose 28%. Revenue rose to $905.8 million from $691.4 million. The revenue growth reflects the acquisition of OneSource Services in November 2007. For the first half of 2009, ABM expects to earn 42 cents to 50 cents a share from operations, or an adjusted 46 cents to 54 cents.
title: ABM 4th-period net off 23% on 31% higher revenue

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Shares of the following companies were among those making notable moves in the U.S. stock market Tuesday. Advancers Shares of ABM Industries Inc., ABM, +0.75% the New York facilities-services provider, gained 6.8%. It reported fiscal first-quarter net income fell 27%, boosted its full-year earnings outlook, and lifted its quarterly dividend 4.2%. Barr Pharmaceuticals Inc. BRL, -30.00% shares jumped 7.7%. It said late Monday a federal court ruled in favor of its Barr Laboratories unit, invalidating a patent protecting Bayer AG's BAYRY, +1.24% Yasmin birth-control pill. Barr filed with the Food and Drug Administration to make a generic version of Yasmin in 2005 and Bayer sued. CBRL Group Inc. CBRL, +1.03% shares were slightly higher. Same-restaurant sales rose 0.9% in February, while same-store retail sales increased 1.2% for the four-week period ended March 2. The Lebanon, Tenn.-based operator of Cracker Barrel Old Country Store restaurants and gift shops also said its average check rose about 3.1% in February, citing an average menu price increase of about 3.2%. Ceradyne Inc. CRDN shares rose. It plans to buy back as much as $100 million of common stock. Shares of Elbit Systems Ltd., ESLT, +1.72% the Haifa, Israel, defense contractor, gained. It said on Tuesday that its Cyclone Aviation Products Ltd. subsidiary received a $160 million contract from Spirit AeroSystems, the Wichita, Kan., aviation manufacturer, to supply doors for commercial aircraft. Deliveries are scheduled from 2009 through 2016, Elbit said. Microsoft MSFT, +2.10% shares were higher. Chief Financial Officer Chris Liddell said Yahoo Inc. YHOO could play an important role in the tech superpower's embrace of the growing trend of selling software as a Web-based service. Liddell cited Yahoo's potential role in response to a question on how the major shift in the way software is sold could affect the tech company's business model -- even as he maintained that Microsoft is still weighing its options after the board of Yahoo rejected its acquisition offer. See full story Shares of Simcere Pharmaceutical Group, SCR, +3.57% the Nanjing, China, generic-drug maker, advanced 6.3%. It reported fourth-quarter net rose 44% as revenue rose 56%. Profit reached 78.7 million renminbi ($10.7 million), or 1.21 renminbi (US$0.17) a share, from 54.1 million renminbi, or 0.54, in the year-earlier period. Revenue reached 398.6 million renminbi from 255 million. The company expects to earn 390 million to 400 million renminbi in 2008 on revenue of 2 billion to 2.1 billion renminbi. Tech Data Corp.'s TECD, +2.14% shares rose. Fiscal fourth-quarter net income rose 39% to $50.2 million, or 92 cents a share, from $36.1 million, or 66 cents, a year earlier. On a non-GAAP basis, income rose to 96 cents a share from 67 cents a share in the year-ago period. Sales for the quarter ended Jan. 31 rose 5.9%, to $6.48 billion from $6.12 billion. Trina Solar Ltd.'s TSL, +2.00% shares jumped 10%. Fourth-quarter net income tripled to $15.7 million, or 62 cents a share, from $4.59 million, or 28 cents, a year ago, due in part to the company tripling its in-house cell production. The Chinese maker of solar photovoltaic products said revenue more than doubled to $101.4 million from $38.8 million the previous year. Trina Solar expects first-quarter revenue of $112 million to $120 million and full-year revenue of $770 million to $808 million. See full story. Walgreens Co.'s WAG shares gained. February same-store sales, or sales at stores open a year, rose 8.3%. The Deerfield, Ill., drugstore chain said sales rose 14.5% to $4.93 billion from $4.3 billion a year earlier. The company said February sales benefited from one extra day because of the leap year. Decliners Shares of Ambac Inc., ABK, +0.00% the New York bond insurer, fell 6%. It won't split its business in two as it recapitalizes, the Financial Times reported insiders as saying. Ambac was mulling the idea of separating its municipal-bond-insurance business and its structured-finance division. A capital infusion into Ambac from Citigroup, C, -1.11% UBS UBS, +0.40% and other banks and investors may be announced as early as Wednesday, people involved in the talks told the FT. Under the plan, Ambac would remain unified and retain its AAA credit rating, the FT reported. Anadarko Petroleum APC, +2.56% shares moved lower. StatoilHydro is paying $1.8 billion, plus up to $300 milliom more before tax depending on oil prices, to Anadarko for 50% in the Brazilian Peregrino project. In addition, StatoilHydro STO, +1.63% is acquiring Anadarko's 25% interest in the Kaskida discovery in deepwater U.S. Gulf of Mexico. American International Group Inc. AIG, -0.18% shares fell. Moody's Investors Service affirmed the insurer's Aa2 senior unsecured debt rating despite its fourth-quarter loss. Moody's maintained its negative outlook on the company. Moody's said the rating reflects AIG's leading positions in many insurance markets. Shares of Auto Makers: Ford Motor Co. F, +2.03% General Motors Corp. GM, +2.45% and Toyota Motor Corp. TM, +0.77% fell. All three car makers reported declines in February U.S. sales, reflecting the tough climate for consumers during the persistent housing slump and credit crunch. See full story Barnes & Noble Inc. BKS, +1.02% shares tumbled 9.1%. It raised its fiscal fourth-quarter per-share earnings forecast as the company reported sales of $1.85 billion for the period. The bookstore giant's store sales were $1.51 billion, a 2.8% increase over the year-ago period excluding the impact of the extra week in the 2006 retail calendar. Comparable-store sales fell 0.5%. The company said it expects fourth-quarter earnings of $1.76 to $1.82 a share, boosted by 10 cents a share in non-operating benefits received in January. Best Buy BBY, +2.09% shares were lower. It was downgraded to neutral from buy at Banc of America Securities, with the broker saying it's a great company but many factors that drove its 2007 performance will reverse. In particular, TV margins were a big positive, but there may be lackluster demand as slowing big ticket purchases will be exacerbated by an overly optimistic production schedule from the manufacturers. Diebold Inc. DBD, +7.32% shares fell. It said it will be unable to file its 2007 annual report by the SEC's deadline. The company plans to file the annual report and quarterly reports for the periods ended June 30 and Sept. 30 as soon as possible after completion of the previously disclosed review of accounting items by the company and its audit committee. The ATM maker expects the review to be completed by the end of the second quarter. Finisar Corp. FNSR, +4.84% shares lost. It reported a fiscal third-quarter net loss of $10.6 million, or 3 cents a share, compared with profit of $396 million, or break even, a year earlier. Pro forma earnings were 2 cents a share compared with 4 cents a share. The data communications equipment company said revenue rose to $112.7 million from $107.5 million. Genesco Inc. GCO, +2.01% shares were lower. It confirmed Tuesday that it definitively agreed to terminate an accord under which it was to be acquired by Finish Line. FINL, -2.52% The move also settles all related litigation between the companies and including UBS, UBS, +0.40% which was involved in financing the deal. Under the terms, UBS and Finish Line will pay Genesco $175 million of cash and Finish Line will issue 12% of its stock to Genesco. General Electric Co. GE, -1.46% shares fell. The chairman and chief executive officer of the Fairfield, Conn., industrial and financial-services giant received 9.1% more cash compensation in 2007 than he did in 2006. In GE's proxy statement, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday, the company said that Jeffrey R. Immelt, 52, who was named to the top two posts in 2001, received $9.1 million in 2007 versus $8.3 million a year earlier. Shares of H.J. Heinz Co., HNZ the Pittsburgh foods giant, were slightly lower. It recalled 40,000 cases of Boston Market lasagna with meat sauce because the product contained meat that was recalled by Hallmark/Westland Meat Packing Co., The Wall Street Journal reported on Tuesday. Intel Corp. INTC, +5.00% shares fell. It lowered its first-quarter gross margin forecast to between 53% and 55% from a previous view of 56%, "plus or minus a couple of points," citing lower than expected NAND flash memory chip prices. The company affirmed all other first-quarter guidance. See full story. Jackson Hewitt Tax Service Inc.'s JTX shares plunged 27%. Fiscal third-quarter earnings fell 34% to $18.2 million, or 61 cents a share, from $27.5 million, or 83 cents a share, a year earlier. The Parsippany, N.J., tax preparation services company said the slow start for the tax season industry resulted in customer traffic shifting from the third to the fourth fiscal quarter due to later filings. Joy Global Inc. JOYG shares lost. Chief Financial Officer James Woodward resigned. The surface mining equipment provider said it expects to name director Jim Tate, chairman of the audit committee, interim CFO. KLA-Tencor Corp. KLAC, +2.29% shares fell. It said Chief Financial Officer Jeffrey Hall will resign on March 31 to become CFO at Express Scripts ESRX, -0.93% President and Chief Operating Officer John Kispert adds the post of interim CFO. Men's Wearhouse Inc. MW shares moved lower. It will close its Golden Brand manufacturing facility in Montreal by July, as the Canadian dollar strengthened and competition sharpened. The menswear retailer said none of the company's 116 Moores stores in Canada will be affected by the closure. Citigroup C, -1.11% shares lost 4.1%. Merrill Lynch analyst Guy Moszkowski took a knife to the banking giant's earnings estimates, forecasting it will earn 24 cents for the year and post a loss of $1.66 a share for the first quarter. His previous forecast was $2.74 a share in annual earnings and 55 cents a share in first-quarter earnings. Citigroup may report a $15 billion hit on its subprime/CDO exposure and another $3 billion hit from commercial real estate, leverage lending and consumer lending provisions. See full story. Shares of MGIC Investment Corp., MTG, +1.01% the Milwaukee mortgage insurer, fell 5.3%. It registered an offering of common stock with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company also said it might sell securities other than common stock. In a statement late on Monday, the company said it hadn't decided how much stock to issue. The registration as filed covers only a negligible amount of shares, and MGIC said it would amend the filing with a firm number when it decides how much to issue. NCI Building Systems Inc. NCS, +1.72% shares tumbled 10%. It reported its fiscal first-quarter net income fell to $7.5 million, or 39 cents a share, from $10.5 million, or 49 cents a share, a year earlier. Adjusted earnings were 45 cents a share, down from 52 cents. Revenue totaled $361.5 million, up from $359.3 million. The metal products maker also lowered its outlook for 2008 and now expects to report earnings of $3.09 to $3.44 a share. Shares of Pfizer Inc., PFE, +0.54% the New York drugmaker, moved lower. It was set back when a tie vote at the U.S. Supreme Court enabled a product-liability lawsuit over its diabetes drug Rezulin to go forward, The Wall Street Journal reported. The court, voting 4 to 4 with Chief Justice John Roberts Jr. recusing himself, appeared split on the question of whether its own precedent restricts lawsuits claiming injury from prescription drugs unless a drugmaker committed fraud to gain Food and Drug Administration clearance, the paper reported. Shares of Retalix Ltd., RTLX the Ra'anana, Israel, producer of management systems for supermarkets and distributors, were slightly lower. It said that Barry Shaked would step down as chairman and remain chief executive. The move is in line with a plan, announced in December, to separate the posts. The company said in a statement on Tuesday that it reached an accord with FIMI, an Israeli fund that holds 11.6% of Retalix. Shares of Staples Inc. SPLS the largest U.S. office-supplies chain, fell. It said on Tuesday that quarterly profit dropped 1%, hurt by a decline in North American retail sales and increased expenses. See full story. UAL Corp. UAL, +2.30% shares lost 5%. It said February traffic for United Airlines fell 0.5% to 8.15 billion revenue passenger miles from 8.19 billion a year earlier. Load factor, or the percentage of available seats filled with passengers, fell to 74.4% in February from 77.5%. UDR Inc. UDR, +0.06% shares moved lower. It said it completed the sale of 25,684 apartment homes for $1.7 billion and expects 2008 funds from operations of $1.50 to $1.60 a share. UDR expects to reinvest $500 million to $800 million of the funds from the sale into its remaining apartment home portfolio, primarily in the West Coast and D.C. corridor markets, the company said. U.S. Concrete Inc.'s RMIX shares fell. Fourth-quarter net loss widened to $80.2 million, or $2.09 a share, from $23.8 million, or 63 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue was flat at $198.7 million as higher ready-mixed concrete prices were offset by lower volumes. The loss included a $1.99-a-share non-cash charge to reduce the carrying value of its goodwill. Adjusted profit from continuing operations was 2 cents a share for the quarter, in line with the company's estimate. Weyerhaeuser Co. WY, -0.06% shares fell. It permanently closed its iLevel Veneer Technologies facility in Junction City, Ore. The forest products company attributed the closure to a decline in demand for engineered wood products from the slowdown in the housing market More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Tuesday's biggest gaining and declining stocks

content: Fremont General says it got default notices (9:39 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Fremont General FMT, -0.93% said on Tuesday that it got default notices from two affiliated entities that purchased a total of $3.15 billion of residential subprime mortgage loans from the company in March 2007. As part of the deals, Fremont promised that its tangile net worth wouldn't drop below $250 million. If that happened, Fremont agreed to make up the difference, either in cash or a letter of credit. Fremont said it probably won't be able to comply with that obligation. If the purchasers file a lawsuit against the company and it can't successfully defend that litigation, "its ability to continue to conduct business as a going concern would be called into question," Fremont said. Fremont shares fell rouhly 10% in early trading on Tuesday. Porsche first-half pretax profit rises 24% (9:07 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Porsche(DE:693773)reported a 24% rise in profit before tax in the six months to Jan. 31 to 1.66 billion euros ($2.5 billion), helped by its stake in Volkswagen and by revenue rising 14% to 3.49 billion euros. The sports car maker sold 17% more vehicles than a year ago to 46,736 units. Conseco reschedules earnings release (8:31 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Conseco Inc. CNO, -0.87% said Tuesday that it has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to formally extend the due date of its annual report to March 17 because it hasn't yet finalized its Dec. 31 financial statements. The Carmel, Ind.-based insurance company said it expects its quarterly net income to be about breakeven. It has also been consulting with the SEC staff about its accounting policy for long-term care premium rate increases. Conseco plans to report fourth-quarter results on March 17. Shares of Conseco closed Monday at $11.64. Xinyuan Real Estate profit up 81% excluding one-time charge (7:07 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Chinese Residential real estate developer Xinyuan Real Estate Co. XIN, +0.19% said Tuesday that its fourth-quarter net income rose 81% to $6.6 million as revenue more than doubled to $91.4 million from $42.7 million. Earnings attributable to shareholders, however, fell to a loss of $1.53 a share, or $3.06 per American depository share, due to a $182 million one-time charge as a result of a waiver of the conversion option in certain convertible shares. Simcere Pharma 4th-quarter net up 44%, revenue up 56% (6:49 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Simcere Pharmaceutical Group, SCR, +3.57% the Nanjing, China, generic-drug maker, reported fourth-quarter net rose 44% as revenue rose 56%. Profit reached 78.7 million renminbi ($10.7 million), or 1.21 renminbi (US$0.17) a share, from 54.1 million renminbi, or 0.54, in the year-earlier period. Revenue reached 398.6 million renminbi from 255 million. The company expects to earn 390 million to 400 million renminbi in 2008 on revenue of 2 billion to 2.1 billion renminbi. U.S. Concrete loss widens after goodwill charge (6:17 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.S. Concrete Inc. RMIX said Tuesday that its fourth-quarter net loss widened to $80.2 million, or $2.09 a share, from $23.8 million, or 63 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the quarter held roughly flat at $198.7 million as higher ready-mixed concrete prices were offset by lower volumes. The company said its loss included a $1.99-a-share non-cash charge to reduce the carrying value of its goodwill. Adjusted income from continuing operations was 2 cents a share for the quarter, in line with the company's guidance. U.S. Concrete says it expects to report a loss from continuing operations of 13 cents to 19 cents a share in the first quarter of 2008. ABM Industries 1st-period net off; outlook is lifted (4:28 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- ABM Industries Inc., the New York facilities-services provider, reported fiscal first-quarter net income fell 27%, boosted its full-year earnings outlook, and lifted its quarterly dividend 4.2%. For the quarter ended Jan. 31, earnings fell to $6.4 million, or 13 cents a share, from $8.7 million, or 18 cents, in the year-earlier period. Adjusted earnings nearly doubled to $18 million from $9.3 million. Revenue reached $922.6 million from $703.5 million. For fiscal 2008, the company now expects to earn $1 to $1.15 a share, or an adjusted $1.20 to $1.35. ABM raised its quarterly payout to 12.5 cents a share from 12 cents, payable May 5 to holders of record April 10. ProSiebenSat.1 net drops 63% on cartel fine, interest costs (2:43 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- ProSiebenSat.1 Group(DE:777117), Germany's largest television company, said its annual profit slumped 63% to 89.4 million euros ($136 million), hurt by a 120 million euro fine by Germany's Federal Cartel Office, higher operating costs and higher interest exepnses from financing the SBS acquisition. On an adjusted basis, its earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization would have climbed 36% to 661.9 million euros, as revenue rose 29% to 2.7 billion euros on the SBS deal as well as strong international growth and organic growth in the German-speaking region. The company said it's going to focus on its competitive position in free television by focusing on content and launching new channels, and it expects growth revenue and profits this year. Premier Foods swings to loss, cuts dividend (2:42 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Premier Foods(UK:PFD)said Tuesday that it swung to a loss of 63.3 million pounds in 2007 from a profit of 47.1 million pounds a year earlier due to rising ingredient costs and the impact of integrating recent acquisitions. The group said revenue jumped to 2.25 billion pounds from 840.7 million pounds due to the acquisition of RHM and the U.K. and Ireland operations of Campbell Soup. Among the hardest hit operations was the company's bread business, which saw its trading profit roughly halved. Given the high costs in 2007 and the potential for further inflationary pressure in 2008, Premier Foods said it would cut its dividend by 46% to 6.5 pence a share. NXP Semiconductors operating profit up 13.5% (2:33 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- NXP Semiconductors, the Eindhoven, Netherlands chipmaker held by KKR Private Equity KPEGF Philips Electronics PHG, +0.79% and other investors, said fourth-quarter adjusted operating profit rose 13.5% to 243 million euros, with sales up 9.3% on a comparable basis to 1.16 billion euros. Its book-to-bill ratio was 0.89. The chipmaker said it grew in line with the market, and reiterated that it expects to play an "active role in industry consolidation." On a comparable basis, sales in the first quarter should fall 9% to 13% from the fourth quarter, or a low single-digit rise when compared to the year-ago quarter. The fourth quarter marks the last in which it will report results in euros, as it will change to dollars to increase comparability with peers. Cable & Wireless sets five-year growth targets (2:29 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K.-listed telecom group Cable & Wireless(UK:CW)said Tuesday that it's set a new five-year growth plan for its Europe, Asia and U.S. business. The plan targets annual revenue growth of between 5% and 8% a year and growth in earnings before interest, taxes, amortization and depreciation of between 20% and 25% a year. The group said future revenue growth for Europe, Asia and the U.S. will be driven by customers' adoption of new applications, including digital marketing and video-conferencing. More from MarketWatch Uber for Bikes Could Save Your Commute More Coverage Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- ABM Industries Inc., the New York facilities-services provider, reported fiscal first-quarter net income fell 27%, boosted its full-year earnings outlook, and lifted its quarterly dividend 4.2%. For the quarter ended Jan. 31, earnings fell to $6.4 million, or 13 cents a share, from $8.7 million, or 18 cents, in the year-earlier period. Adjusted earnings nearly doubled to $18 million from $9.3 million. Revenue reached $922.6 million from $703.5 million. For fiscal 2008, the company now expects to earn $1 to $1.15 a share, or an adjusted $1.20 to $1.35. ABM raised its quarterly payout to 12.5 cents a share from 12 cents, payable May 5 to holders of record April 10.
title: ABM Industries 1st-period net off; outlook is lifted

content: EnCana rallies as it doubles dividend, ups capital spending (10:09 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of EnCana ECA, +4.56% jumped 4% to $67.77 after the Canadian natural gas and oil sands company said it would double its annual dividend and boost capital spending by 13% to $6.9 billion. EnCana will pay an annual dividend of $1.60, up from $0.80, upon approval from the board beginning in 2008. Energy stocks rally along with overall market (9:45 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Energy stocks rose along with the overall market Wednesday ahead of key weekly inventory data, and after an oil spill in Norway and ice storms in the Midwest. A move by the U.S. Federal Reserve to inject more cash into the international banking system through an auction of short-term funds and other moves prompted a big rally in the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +1.07% Exxon Mobil XOM, +2.47% the lone energy giant in the Dow, rallied 2.7% $92.75. The Amex Oil Index XOI, +2.04% rallied 2.5% to 1,490. The Amex Natural Gas Index XNG, +2.25% rose 2.2% to 570. Crude prices jumped $1.01 to $91.03 as traders bid prices up on expectations of economic growth. StatoilHydro STO, +1.63% rose nearly 4% to $30.42 after the Norwegian authorities estimated an oil spill in the Norwegian North Sea of 21,750 barrels, or 3,840 cubic meters. The leak took place from a loading buoy operated by StatoilHydro. Lukoil net income edges up despite higher oil costs (9:04 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Lukoil LUKOY, +2.25% said Wednesday net income for the three months ended Sept. 30 rose to $2.48 billion, or $3 a share, from $2.43 billion, or $2.90 a share in the year-ago period. Revenue at the Russia-based oil giant rose to $21.4 billion from $18.4 billion. Operating expenses rose to $1.6 billion from $1.1 billion. Cost of purchased crude oil, gas and other products increased to $7.4 billion from $5.7 billion. Crude oil production for the quarter declined 1.1% compared to the same period last year. PNC sees fourth-quarter profit below consensus (9:00 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- PNC Financial Services Group Inc. PNC, +1.20% in a regulatory filing Wednesday said it expects to report fourth-quarter earnings in the range of 60 cents to 75 cents a share, and adjusted earnings between $1 and $1.15 a share. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial are looking for profit of $1.39 a share, on average. "This revised expectation is primarily due to lower noninterest income attributable to valuation adjustments on $1.5 billion of commercial mortgage loans held for sale and lower than historically reported trading results due to unprecedented market price volatility, an additional anticipated increase to the provision for credit losses primarily related to residential real estate development, and an increase in the corporation's BlackRock/LTIP shares obligation due to a significant increase in the price of BlackRock's BLK, +2.59% common shares," PNC said in the filing. The company said its adjusted provision for credit losses is expected to be about $45 million higher in the fourth quarter compared with the third quarter. "Despite the anticipated increase in provision for credit losses, current asset quality remains relatively strong given the existing credit environment," PNC said. The stock lost more than 4% in premarket trading. Progressive November net income falls 29% (8:54 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- The Progressive Corp. PGR, +0.81% on Wednesday said November profit fell 29% to $93 million from $132 million. The Mayfield Village, Ohio auto insurer said earnings per share fell to 14 cents from 17 cents. Net premiums written fell 5% to $913 million. Wachovia raises loan loss provision estimate (8:41 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Wachovia Corp. WB, +3.87% in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing Wednesday said it now estimates that its loan loss provision for the fourth quarter will be approximately $1 billion in excess of charge-offs. Its previous forecast was between $500 million and $600 million due to slowing loan growth and ongoing credit deterioration in its loan portfolio. Wachovia shares were down more than 1% in premarket trading. International Speedway sees 2008 EPS at $3.05-$3.15 (7:36 AM ET) International Speedway Corp. ISCA, +1.26% said Wednesday it estimates 2008 earnings between $3.05 and $3.15 per share for the year ending Nov. 30, 2008. The promoter of motorsports activities expects revenue of $805 million to $825 million. The company said it expects to post increases in all its major revenue categories in fiscal 2008. The growth is expected to drive higher free cash flows to support capital allocation strategy, including a more aggressive share repurchase program, the company said. Magellan announces fiscal 2008 guidance (6:50 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Health care management company Magellan Health Services Inc. MGLN, +0.09% on Wednesday released financial guidance for fiscal 2008, saying it expects earnings for the year in the range of $1.88 to $2.34 a share and revenue of $2.53 billion to $2.66 billion. Magellan said contracts it won in 2007 have established "a foundation for strong topline growth in 2008." Wright Medical gets U.S. subpoena; affirms outlook (2:55 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Wright Medical Group Inc., the Arlington, Tenn., producer of reconstructive joints, said the Justice Department subpoenaed documents from January 1998 through the present "related to any consulting and professional-service agreements with orthopedic surgeons in connection with hip or knee-joint replacement procedures or products." The company said it would fully comply with the request. Wright said it can't yet say how the inquiry might affect its results, if at all. In a separate statement on Tuesday, Wright affirmed its outlook for fourth-quarter sales and earnings. It sees adjusted earnings of 23 cents to 25 cents a share on sales of $98 million to $101 million. For 2007, it expects to earn an adjusted 75 cents to 77 cents on sales of $382 million to $385 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson Financial produced consensus estimates of 16 cents a share of profit on $100 million of revenue for the quarter, and 42 cents on $384 million for the year. Conergy says probably won't get 1 billion euros in revenue (2:53 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Conergy(DE:604002), the German solar systems supplier, said it probably won't get to 1 billion euros ($1.47 billion) in revenue this year, resulting in a loss before interest and tax between 150 million euros and 200 million euros. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had expected revenue of 1.02 billion euros and a 17 million euro profit before interest and tax. It's planning 500 job cuts and the discontinuation of non-core activities in the areas of bioenergy and solar thermics. It will operate with three segments beginning in January: components, sales and systems and projects. HMV swings to profit after selling Japanese division (2:32 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Books and music retailer HMV(UK:HMV)said Wednesday said it swung to a fiscal first-half profit of 25.9 million pounds ($52.8 million) from a loss of 26.1 million pounds. Revenue for the period rose 9.5% to 729 million pounds. The turnaround in profit was largely due to a 49.2 million pound gain on the sale of its Japanese business. The operating loss from continuing operations was 21.5 million pounds compared to 24.8 million pounds a year ago. The group said it's made good progress in its three-year plan to cut costs and expand revenue from high-growth products, such as games consoles and software, which now represent 15% of U.K. sales, up from 9% a year ago. ABM Industries 4th-quarter net fell on year-ago gain (2:12 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWAtch) -- ABM Industries Inc., ABM, +0.75% the San Francisco facility-services contractor, reported fiscal fourth-quarter net income fell 76% -- reflecting in part a year-earlier gain -- on 6.8% lower revenue. For the quarter ended Oct. 31, earnings fell to $15 million, or 30 cents a ashare, from $61.6 million, or $1.24, in the year-earlier period. Shares outstanding rose 2.8% to 50.9 million. The latest figure reflects a cut of 8 cents a share in the benefits from adjustment of self-insurance reserves. The year-ago figure includes a gain of 91 cents a share from a settlement of World Trade Center insurance claims. Revenue fell to $723.9 million from $776.7 million. Excluding the year-ago $80 million from the insurance claim, sales rose 3.9%. ABM estimates fiscal 2008 earnings of 90 cents to $1 a share, or an adjusted $1.15 to $1.25; reported net income for fiscal 2007 was $1.04. The adjusted estimate excludes 25 cents a share of costs related to the acquisition of OneSource as well as other matters. First-quarter earnings should range 8 cents to 12 cents, or an adjusted 14 cents to 18 cents. title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: TEL AVIV (MarketWAtch) -- ABM Industries Inc., ABM, +0.75% the San Francisco facility-services contractor, reported fiscal fourth-quarter net income fell 76% -- reflecting in part a year-earlier gain -- on 6.8% lower revenue. For the quarter ended Oct. 31, earnings fell to $15 million, or 30 cents a ashare, from $61.6 million, or $1.24, in the year-earlier period. Shares outstanding rose 2.8% to 50.9 million. The latest figure reflects a cut of 8 cents a share in the benefits from adjustment of self-insurance reserves. The year-ago figure includes a gain of 91 cents a share from a settlement of World Trade Center insurance claims. Revenue fell to $723.9 million from $776.7 million. Excluding the year-ago $80 million from the insurance claim, sales rose 3.9%. ABM estimates fiscal 2008 earnings of 90 cents to $1 a share, or an adjusted $1.15 to $1.25; reported net income for fiscal 2007 was $1.04. The adjusted estimate excludes 25 cents a share of costs related to the acquisition of OneSource as well as other matters. First-quarter earnings should range 8 cents to 12 cents, or an adjusted 14 cents to 18 cents.
title: ABM Industries 4th-quarter net fell on year-ago gain

content: ABM posts drop in quarterly profit (7:56 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - ABM Industries Inc. ABM, +0.75% late Wednesday reported third-quarter net income of $12 million, or 23 cents a share, down from $17.3 million, or 35 cents a share during the same period a year earlier. The San Francisco-based facility services contractor said revenue for the three months ended July 31 rose to $717.5 million from $689.3 million. ABM cited "self insurance reserve adjustments" as the primary reason for its drop in profit. Fred's same-store sales rise 1.7% in August (4:55 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Fred's Inc. FRED, +4.91% late Wednesday said its August sales at stores open at least one year rose 1.7%. Analysts, on average, had expected the same-store sales to rise 1.8%, according to Thomson Financial. Total sales for the four weeks ended Sept. 1 rose 4% to $129 million from $124.2 million a year ago, the Memphis, Tenn.-based operator of discount general merchandise stores said. Altera maintains sales target, secures credit facility (4:32 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Altera Corp. ALTR, +1.98% in its midquarter update late Wednesday, stuck to its third-quarter revenue target. The chipmaker said revenue will be flat to up 3% from the three months ended June 29. This forecast puts Altera sales in the range of $319.7 million to $329.3 million. Separately, Altera said it secured a five-year $750 million unsecured credit facility. It plans to use $500 million of that credit line to fund repurchases of its common stock. San Jose, Calif.-based Altera designs chips that customers can program for specific purposes. The processors are used in a wide range of products such as Internet routers, mobile-phone base stations, flat-panel televisions and DVD players. CORRECT: Glitnir eyes $40 bln in geothermal financing (2:26 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Iceland and Norway-based Glitnir bank on Wednesday said it's forecasting up to $40 billion in industrywide financing behind geothermal energy projects in North America by 2025. Arni Magnusson, managing director of sustainable energy for Glitnir, said the lender's mission is to be a leading financial player to the global sustainable energy sector, with a "unique" interest in the geothermal space. The bank is readying a formal announcement of a financing deal of more than $10 million behind Iceland America Energy Inc., a geothermal specialist with a deal to provide energy to PG&E PGE, +0.00% in California. Other recent deals include a $19 million financing of Western GeoPower Corp. NGLPF a $23 million financing round for ThermaSource in Santa Rosa, Calif. and a $20 million debt financing round to help Nevada Geothermal Power Inc. conduct drilling operations. (Upated to report $40 billion in industry financing for geothermal, not just from Glitnir.) Starbucks sees dairy drag in 2008 (12:50 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Starbucks Corp. SBUX, -0.02% on Wednesday said it expects dairy prices to be a "negative" in 2008. Speaking at a Goldman Sachs retail conference in New York, Peter Bocian, Starbucks' executive vice president and chief financial officer designate said the company had tried to mitigate the cost of dairy through two price increases over 12 months. He said the company worked to try and balance price points and customer experience with the "reality of rising dairy costs." Bocian said Starbucks hasn't seen a "huge impact" from jitters in the macro economic environment, except for some customers "on the margin." He backed the company's fiscal 2007 profit forecast in the range of 87 cents to 89 cents a share and net revenue growth of about 20%. He said hitting the high end of the range will be "challenging." For fiscal 2008, the company also said it expects revenue growth of about 18%. B/E Aerospace wins pacts worth up to $250 mln; backs outlook (12:22 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- B/E Aerospace Inc. BEAV said Wednesday it has been awarded contracts by four airlines to outfit their new Boeing 787 Dreamliner aircraft with business- and coach-class seats. The firm portion of the awards is initially valued at more than $100 million, and will increase to more than $150 million after expected orders for oxygen systems, passenger service units, and food and beverage products are confirmed, the Wellington, Fla.-based firm said. Including option aircraft, the total value of the programs is about $250 million. B/E Aerospace reaffirmed its 2008 per-share earnings outlook of about $2.25 on revenue that's up 25% to about $2 billion. The company also said it expects continued backlog growth from 2008 to 2011, as it's awarded programs to outfit new wide-body and super wide-body aircraft. Home Depot CEO sees continued macro weakness (9:44 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Home Depot Inc.'s HD, +1.99% Chief Executive Frank Blake said Wednesday he expects weakness in the macro environment through the end of the year and characterized the rest of the year as "tough." Speaking at the Goldman Sachs Retailing Conference in New York, Blake said he expects much of 2008 will "face headwinds." On a regional basis, California and Florida have been "stressed" markets, but the company has seen some strength in Texas, the Midwest and Ohio valley region and the Southeastern U.S. Walgreen August same-store sales rise (8:08 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Walgreens WAG on Wednesday said August same-store sales rose 6.5%. Net sales for the month rose 10.3% to $4.62 billion. August pharmacy sales rose 9.9%, while pharmacy same-store sales increased 6.5%. Pharmacy same-store sales were hurt by 4.2 percentage points due to generic drug introductions in the last 12 months. Total prescriptions filled at comparable stores increased 3.4% and pharmacy sales accounted for 66.4% of total sales for the month. Front-end same-store sales, which include general merchandise such as cosmetics, snacks and stationery, rose 6.6% in the month. Weekly chain-store sales rise 2.3% from year earlier: survey (7:48 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Chain-store sales for the week ended Sept. 1 rose 2.3% compared to the year-ago period, the International Council of Shopping Centers and UBS Securities said in a survey released Wednesday. On a week-over-week basis, sales rose 0.2%. "Sales improved slightly by the end of August, but the year-over-year momentum remained relatively steady and sluggish," said ICSC chief economist Michael Niemira. ICSC still expects sales to increase by about 2% to 2.5% for the month. Chico's FAS August same-store sales fell 9.3% (7:28 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Chico's FAS Inc., CHS, +0.33% the Fort Myers, Fla., women's-apparel retailer, reported that for August, same-store sales fell 9.3% while total sales rose 6.3% to $118.8 million. DSW profit tumbles, hurt by markdowns (7:16 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Shoe retailer DSW Inc. DSW, +0.67% on Wednesday said second-quarter profit tumbled as the company slashed prices to clear seasonal merchandise, which pressured gross margins. Net income fell to $6.5 million, or 15 cents a share, from $14.3 million, or 35 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Net sales rose to $348.7 million from $301.3 million. Same-store sales, or sales at stores open at least one year, rose 5.9%. DSW backed its profit estimate for the year of a range of $1.63 to $1.68 a share, and is maintaining its forecast for same-store sales in the range of flat to 3%. In addition, the Columbus, Ohio-based retailer plans to open at least 35 new DSW stores during the year, up from its original estimate of at least 30 new stores. Analysts, on average, expected DSW to earn 31 cents a share on revenue of $349 million for the second quarter and $1.67 a share for the year, according to Thomson Financial. Delta Fi backs securitization w/ $900 mln in mortgages (7:06 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Delta Financial Corp. DFC, +0.55% said Wednesday it priced a securitization, backed by $900 million of mortgage loans, through its subsidiary, Renaissance Mortgage Acceptance Corp. "Pricing this securitization was paramount for our Company in light of the rapid deterioration in the credit markets," said CEO Hugh Miller. "This securitization removes the majority of the loans from our warehouse lines which greatly reduces our exposure on these facilities." The company will account for the transaction as a sale and not as a financing. Costco same-store sales up 2% in August, 5% in 4th quarter (3:19 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Costco Wholesale Corp., COST, +2.63% the Issaquah, Wash., warehouse retailer, reported that for August, total sales rose 6% from the year-earlier month to $4.84 billion and same-store sales rose 2%. For the month, same-store sales, those from outlets open a least a year, eliminating the effect of acquisitions and divestitures, rose 1% in the U.S. and 8% overseas, Costco said. For the fiscal 2007 fourth quarter ended Sept. 2, Costco's net sales rose 3% to $20.06 billion while same-store sales rose 5%. For the year through Sept. 2, total sales rose 7% to $63.06 billion while same-store sales rose 6%. ABB sets new targets, sees up to 5 point margin boost (2:33 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Swiss-Swedish engineering group ABB ABB, +0.76% (SE:ABB)set new margin targets, saying it's planning to increase its operating margin by as much as five percentage points from 2007 to 2011, compared to 2006. The improvement will be driven by economies of scale, such as strong factory loading, and further operational improvements. As a result, the company forecasts earnings per share to grow by a compound average of 15% to 20% a year over the planning period and its return on capital employed, after tax, to exceed 30% by 2011. ABB expects demand for new and upgraded power infrastructure to continue in all regions, and further industrial investments in improved productivity and energy efficiency. Continental Air load factor widens 2.9 points in August (2:17 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Continental Airlines, CAL, -0.62% Houston, reported that its load factor, the percentage of its seats occupied by paying passengers, in August widened to 85.3% from 82.4% in the year-earlier month. The arrival rate, based on U.S. Department of Transportation standards, was 75.3% in the month, Continental said. Traffic increased 8.1% in the month from a year earlier, to 9.1 billion revenue passenger miles. Capacity rose 4.4%. title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - ABM Industries Inc. ABM, +0.75% late Wednesday reported third-quarter net income of $12 million, or 23 cents a share, down from $17.3 million, or 35 cents a share during the same period a year earlier. The San Francisco-based facility services contractor said revenue for the three months ended July 31 rose to $717.5 million from $689.3 million. ABM cited "self insurance reserve adjustments" as the primary reason for its drop in profit.
title: ABM posts drop in quarterly profit

content: Advancers Guess GES, -0.81% shares climbed 3.7% Wednesday after the company reported first-quarter earnings of $35.5 million, or 38 cents a share, up 72% from the year-ago period. The Los Angeles apparel company's revenue for the three months ended May 5 rose 42% to $377.9 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had forecast profit of 28 cents on revenue of $331 million. Guess expects fiscal second-quarter earnings of 31 cents to 33 cents a share on revenue of $335 million to $345 million. Analysts are looking for a per-share profit of 27 cents on revenue of $306 million. The company also raised its fiscal 2008 earnings outlook. Macrovision Corp. MVSN shares gained 8.4% after the company said it will realign into four business units, cut its worldwide headcount by about 7% and incur a restructuring charge of about $4.5 million in the second quarter. Optical Communications OCPI shares rallied 6% after Oplink Communications Inc. OPLK said it'll pay $1.65 in cash to buy the 41.9% of Optical Communication stock it doesn't already own. Oplink said it has closed its previously announced transaction with Furukawa Electric Co. to acquire Furukawa's 58.1% stake in Optical Communication Products for $1.50 per share, payable in cash and stock of Oplink. Printronix PTNX swung to a fiscal fourth-quarter profit of 2 cents a share from a year-ago net loss of $1.19. The Irvine, Calif., maker of printing products for the supply chain said revenue in the three months ended March 30 fell to $32.6 million from $33.2 million. Russ Berrie & Co. RUS, +1.67% shares added 5.9% after the company received an unsolicited offer of $18 a share but said the proposal undervalues the company. Prior to receiving this unsolicited proposal, the Oakland, N.J., maker of collectible bears and gifts had started to explore the possible sale of its gift division and has received indications of interest from several prospective acquirers. Starent Networks STAR, +0.89% shares surged 17% in the company's initial public offering. TAT Technologies TATTF shares gained 4.9% Wednesday. The company confirmed that its Limco-Piedmont Inc. subsidiary filed an amendment to its registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission, reflecting that LPI expects to offer 3.5 million shares, at a price of $9.50 to $11.50 each, in an initial public offering. TAT plans to sell 500,000 shares of LPI in the IPO. Following the offering, TAT will own about 68% of LPI's outstanding common stock. Shares of TD Ameritrade Holding Corp. AMTD, +3.49% the online financial-services firm, rose 3.8% Wednesday after the company revealed it's being urged by certain investors to merge with a rival. See full story. Decliners ABM Industries Inc. ABM, +0.75% shares fell 8.3% after the company reported second-quarter earnings of 33 cents a share, up from 21 cents in the year-ago period. The San Francisco facility-services contractor's revenue for the three months ended April 30 rose to $697.9 million from $660.1 million. The company also raised its fiscal 2007 outlook. Angeion Corp. ANGN shares lost 15% after the company reported second-quarter net earnings of $453,000, or 11 cents a share, up from $206,000, or 5 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue rose to $9.96 million from $7.21 million. The company said revenue from its largest clinical research customer will continue in fiscal 2007, but at a reduced level, which will affect its overall third and fourth quarter revenue and profitability as compared with the same periods in 2006. Angeion expect to remain profitable in the second half of the year and to report double-digit revenue growth for the year as whole. Bare Escentuals Inc. BARE shares slipped 7.5% after the company said it still expects fiscal 2007 earnings of 89 cents to 94 cents a share. The company also forecast a second-quarter profit of 20 cents to 22 cents on sales growth of 27% to 30%. Borders Group Inc. BG, +1.20% shares fell 4.6% after the company was cut to sell from neutral at Goldman Sachs, which said the Federal Trade Commission's decision to oppose a deal between Whole Foods Market Inc. and Wild Oats Markets Inc. means a merger for Borders is less likely. "Like the organic- food market, the book-superstore business features only two major specialty players," the other being Barnes & Noble, BKS, +1.02% Goldman Sachs said. Matria Healthcare Inc. MATR, -2.33% shares dropped 6%. The company and Wellmark Blue Cross & Blue Shield of Iowa said they have mutually determined to discontinue Matria's provision of services to Wellmark at the end of 2007. Matria began providing the services in February 2007. Shares of Panera Bread Co. PNRA tumbled 14% after the bakery/restaurant chain reported anemic May growth and cost pressures that led it to slice its second quarter profit target. See full story. Plato Learning Inc. TUTR shares dropped 6.3% after the company reported a second-quarter net loss of $5.13 million, or 22 cents a share, vs. $5.9 million, or 25 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue fell to $15.2 million from $20 million. Analysts were expecting a per-share loss of 19 cents on revenue of $16.5 million. Towerstream Corp. TWER, -2.51% shares plunged 33% after the company said it has agreed to sell 10 million shares for $4 each. XTL Biopharmaceuticals Ltd. XTLB, +1.76% (XTL) shares sank 18% after the Rehovot, Israel, drug developer, said it stopped developing XTL-2125, a potential treatment for chronic hepatitis C. More from MarketWatch Uber for Bikes Could Save Your Commute More Coverage Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Wednesday's biggest stock gainers and decliners

content: Copart quarterly profit rises 12% as revenue falls (7:17 PM ET) Updating to correct location of Copart's headquarters SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - Copart Inc. CPRT, +2.21% late Tuesday reported third-quarter net earnings of $38.9 million, or 41 cents a share, up 12% from $34.7 million, or 37 cents a share, during the year-ago period. The Fairfield, Calif.-based provider of vehicle-salvage disposition services said revenue for the three months ended April 30 fell to $145.7 million from $149.5 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had forecast, on average, a per-share profit of 41 cents on revenue of $154 million. ABM Industries quarterly profit surges; boosts outlook (6:33 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - ABM Industries Inc. ABM, +0.75% late Tuesday reported second-quarter net earnings of $16.7 million, or 33 cents a share, up from $10.4 million, or 21 cents a share, during the year-ago period. The San Francisco-based facility services contractor said revenue for the three months ended April 30 rose to $697.9 million from $660.1 million. Additionally, ABM said it expects third-quarter earnings of 25 cents to 29 cents a share. The company also raised its fiscal 2007 outlook, saying it now sees per-share earnings of $1.05 to $1.10. Smith & Wollensky comparable sales rise 0.4% in May (6:03 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWtch) -- Smith & Wollensky Restaurant Group Inc. SWRG late Tuesday said that comparable restaurant sales for May rose 0.4% from the year-ago period to about $8.6 million. Total consolidated restaurant sales were $9.4 million for the month ended May 28, a 3.4% decrease from the $9.8 million last year, the New York-based restaurant operator said. Printronix swings to a fourth-quarter profit (4:42 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Printronix Inc. PTNX said late Tuesday it swung to a fiscal fourth-quarter net profit of $151,000, or 2 cents a share, from a year-ago net loss of $7.43 million, or $1.19 a share. The Irvine, Calif.-based maker of printing products for the supply chain said revenue in the three months ended March 30 fell to $32.6 million from $33.2 million in the comparable period last year. Printronix expects fiscal first-quarter per-share earnings in a range of breakeven to 10 cents a share on revenue of $30.5 million and $32 million. Altera sticks to sales target (4:32 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Altera Corp. ALTR, +1.98% in its midquarter update Tuesday afternoon, reiterated its second-quarter sales target, calling for revenue to grow 1% to 4% from the three months ended March 30. This forecast puts Altera's sales in the range of $308 million to $317 million. San Jose, Calif.-based Altera designs chips used in a wide range of products such as Internet routers, mobile-phone base stations, flat-panel televisions and DVD players. Altera shares closed at $23.17, a gain of almost 2%. The stock is up more than 16% so far this year. Cooper swings to quarterly loss; backs 2007 outlook (4:16 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Cooper Cos. COO, +1.63% late Tuesday reported a second-quarter net loss of $527,000, or a penny a share. During the same period a year ago, the Pleasanton, Calif.-based eye-care company posted net earnings of $14.2 million, or 30 cents a share. Revenue for the three months ended April 30 rose to $225.5 million from $211.4 million. The current results included a write-off of $6.2 million, or 13 cents a share of manufacturing assets associated with Ocular integration activities, the company said. Pro forma earnings were $22.5 million, or 48 cents a share, compared with $29.8 million, or 64 cents a share, last year. Additionally, Cooper said it still expects 2007 per-share earnings of $1.55 to $1.90, or $2.90 to $3.05 on a pro forma basis, on revenue of $927 million to $967 million. CMGI's quarterly profit falls 57% (3:29 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- CMGI Inc. CMGI on Tuesday reported fiscal third-quarter net earnings of $9.42 million, or 2 cents a share, down 57% from $21.7 million, or 4 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Excluding charges related to depreciation, amortization of intangibles, stock-based compensation and restructuring, CMGI reported operating income of $7.5 million versus $7 million last year. The Waltham, Mass.-based provider of supply chain management products and services said revenue in the three months ended April 30 rose 6.5% to $282.1 million from $264.7 million in the comparable period last year. CMGI forecast fiscal 2007 revenue of $1.1 billion to $1.15 billion. Financial Federal shares rally on third-quarter results (11:28 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Financial Federal Corp. FIF, +1.35% shares surged 6.8% to $29.38 in Tuesday morning trade. Late Monday, the New York-based financial services company reported fiscal third-quarter net income rose 14% to $12.7 million, or 48 cents a share, from $11.2 million, or 42 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting, on average, a per-share profit of 46 cents. Brown-Forman net dips; outlook sees 'strong' premium brands (8:50 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Brown-Forman Corp. BF.A, +3.59% BF.B, +2.99% said Tuesday its fiscal fourth-quarter 2007 net income fell to $66.8 million from $78.4 million, including discontinued operations. Earnings from continuing operations fell to $69.3 million, or about 56 cents a share, from $75.7 million, or 61 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Four analysts polled by Thomson Financial forecast earnings, on average, of 50 cents a share. Louisville, Ky.,-based liquor producer said sales in the three months ended April 30 rose 18% to $690.8 million from $585.1 million. Brown-Forman forecast earnings of $3.53 to $3.68 per share for fiscal 2008, saying "global trends for our premium beverage portfolio remain strong." Procter & Gamble backs sales and profit forecast (8:35 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Procter & Gamble Co. PG, +0.56% on Tuesday backed its prior sales and earnings forecast for its fiscal fourth quarter. It said it still expects sales growth for the quarter of 6% to 7%, organic sales growth in line with its previous guidance and earnings per share in a range of 64 cents to 66 cents. Analysts, on average, expect the consumer products company to earn 66 cents a share, according to Thomson Financial. The company plans to release results for its fiscal fourth quarter and fiscal year on Aug. 3. Weekly chain store sales up 2.3% from year ago: survey (7:46 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Chain store sales for the week ended June 2 rose 2.3% from the year-ago period, according to a survey released on Tuesday by the International Council of Shopping Centers and UBS Securities. On a week over week basis, sales slipped 0.5%. "The month as a whole showed some recovery after weakness in April, but the consumer environment continues to be somewhat unsettled," said Michael Niemira, chief economist for the International Council of Shopping Centers. "Thankfully, gasoline prices at the pump have receded a little in the last couple of weeks and the economic picture has brightened a bit, which points to better times ahead." United Airlines May load factor 84.6% (7:34 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - United Airlines UAL, +2.30% on Tuesday said its May passenger load factor was 84.6%, up 0.8 points. Total scheduled revenue passenger miles rose in May by 0.5% on a capacity decrease of 0.5% in scheduled available seat miles compared with the year-ago period. American Woodmark 4th-quarter net and sales drop (6:56 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- American Woodmark Corp., AMWD, +3.04% the Winchester, Va., manufacturer of kitchen cabinets and vanities, reported fiscal fourth-quarter net income fell 54% on 23% lower sales. For the quarter ended April 30, earnings fell to $6.2 million, or 40 cents a share, from $13.5 million, or 83 cents, in the year-earlier period. Sales fell to $166.1 million from $216.4 million. A survey of four analysts by Thomson Financial produced a consensus estimate of 46 cents of profit. In the quarter, the company said, it completed a transition out of certain low-margin products. Sales of core products declined 15% "as remodeling sales were roughly flat and new-construction sales accounted for the decline," American Woodmark said in a statement. Looking ahead, AMWD said both markets should "modestly improve" as fiscal 2008 progresses. Net income for fiscal 2008 should range $1.50 to $1.80 a share compared with $2.04 in fiscal 2007, it said. Total fiscal 2008 sales should fall 7% to 11% with core sales, excluding the low-margin products, down 3% to 7%. Thomson Financial's survey is looking for earnings of $2.24 in fiscal 2008. UPDATE: CDC posts profit on 41% revenue growth (6:47 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- CDC Corp. CHINA, +0.00% said first-quarter adjusted net income was $9.85 million, or 7.5 cents a share, with revenue up 41% to $91.3 million. CDC's net income was $209,000 during the quarter. CDC, a maker of games for Chinese mobile phones, didn't provide a historical comparison pending a restatement. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial expected earnings of 7 cents a share on revenue of $90.67 million. For the year, CDC expects adjusted earnings between $57 million and $62 million on revenue between $415 million and $420 million. Analysts expect annual revenue of $415.7 million. (Updates for annual outlook.) Cache cuts earnings outlook after 2% same-store sales fall (6:22 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Women's apparel retailer Cache Inc. CACH, +200.00% says it's cutting its second-quarter sales and earnings outlook after reporting a "disappointing" May same-store sales fall of 2%. It expects second-quarter same-store sales flat to down slightly, down 2% in the third quarter and flat-to-up-low-single-digits in the fourth quarter. Second-quarter EPS is seen between 6 cents and 8 cents, down from a previous forecast of 20 cents to 24 cents. Sales are seen in the second quarter between $67 million and $69 million, down from $71.7 million in the year-ago quarter. It expects a loss between 6 cents to 8 cents in the third quarter and earnings between 46 cents and 48 cents in the fourth quarter. Russian dairy, juice firm Wimm-Bill-Dann posts 85% net rise (6:10 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Wimm-Bill-Dann WBD said its first-quarter profit climbed 85% to $32.1 million, or 73 cents a share, from $17.4 million, or 39 cents a share, with sales rising 40% to $543 million. The Russian food firm said it benefited from above-market growth rates in dairy, a turnaround of its beverage arm and 37% sales growth of baby foods. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial expected earnings of 67 cents a share on revenue of $507 million. Ryanair '07 profit rose 42% on 32% higher revenue (2:40 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Ryanair, RYAAY, +1.64% (UK:RYA)the Dublin low-cost carrier, reported fiscal 2007 earnings rose a stronger-than-forecast 42% and adjusted earnings rose 33% on 32% higher revenue. Net income reached 435.6 million euros ($586.3 million), or 0.28 euro a share, from 306.7 million, or 0.2, in the year-earlier period. Adjusted profit rose to 401.4 million euros from 301.5 million. Revenue reached 2.24 billion euros from 1.69 billion. Fares rose 7% even as the airline reported 22% more traffic, Ryanair said. Fuel costs rose 50% for the year. For the current year, Ryanair expects fares to fall by up to 5% and unit costs to rise by 6% or 7%. Profit growth should be 5%, it said. (Updates to include current year outlook.) Royal Bank of Scotland sees profit growth ahead of forecasts (2:27 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Royal Bank of Scotland Group(UK:RBS)said Tuesday that it has continued to perform well in 2007 and expects the rate of underlying earnings growth in the first half to be slightly ahead of the rate analysts are expecting for the year as a whole. The bank said its corporate markets unit has continued to perform well across all its activities and the corporate credit environment remains stable. In retail markets, RBS has seen good growth in business banking, mortgages and savings, but has maintained its cautious approach to unsecured lending. Credit quality is improving and it expects a slight reduction in impairment losses. In the U.S., retail deposit and lending volumes remain subdued, though margins have stabilised, the bank said. RBS did not comment on its proposed acquisition of ABN Amro as part of a consortium. Carphone Warehouse adj profit drops less-than-forecast 9.5% (2:22 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Carphone Warehouse(UK:CPW), the European mobile phone retailer and fixed-line telecom, said its annual to March 31 pretax profit dropped 16% to 68.4 million pounds ($136 million), while revenue rose 31% to 3.99 billion pounds. Its profit before reorganization costs, amortization of intangibles and goodwill dropped 9.5% to 123.1 million pounds due to start-up costs for broadband and Virgin Mobile France. A company-compiled analyst forecast was for an adjusted pretax profit of 114.9 million pounds on revenue between 3.9 billion and 4 billion pounds. For the current year, it's targeting 15% growth in subscription connections but said it will need a further year of significant infrastructure investment into TalkTalk and AOL UK. It's hiking its dividend 30% to 3.25 pence a share. C-Cor sees 2nd-quarter net 11c-15c; is selling a business (1:20 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- C-Cor Inc., CCBL the State College, Pa., provider of broadband access equipment, estimated fiscal fourth-quarter earnings at 11 cents to 15 cents a share on sales of $71 million to $74 million. The figures for the quarter ending June 29 reflect special items for amortization, stock-compensation expense, and restructuring netting to a 4-cent charge. A survey of analysts by Thomson Financial produced a consensus estimate for the company of 18 cents of profit on $81 million of revenue. C-Cor also said it definitively agreed to sell its outside plant and installation services business to closely held Source Broadband Services LLC, a Georgia provider of fulfillment and technical services to cable operators, for $7 million. More from MarketWatch What Picking Up an Apple Tells You About the Future of Robotics More Coverage Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Among the companies whose shares are expected to see active trading in Wednesday's session are ADC Telecommunications Inc., Guess Inc., and TD Ameritrade Holding Corp.
