ADC Telecom ADCT is expected to report second-quarter earnings of 24 cents a share, according to a survey of analysts by Thomson Financial. Comtech Telecommunications Corp. CMTL, +2.22% is expected to post earnings of 54 cents a share for the third quarter. DSW Inc. DSW, +0.67% is expected to report first-quarter earnings of 47 cents a share. G-III Apparel Group Ltd. GIII, +3.01% is expected to post a loss of 51 cents a share for the first quarter. Korn Ferry International KFY, +0.47% is expected to report fourth-quarter earnings of 34 cents a share. Martek Biosciences Corp. MATK is expected to post earnings of 15 cents a share for the second quarter. SAIC Inc. SAI, +11.11% is expected to report first-quarter earnings of 20 cents a share. SeaChange International SEAC, +0.37% is expected to post a loss of 10 cents a share for the first quarter. Shuffle Master Inc. SHFL is expected to report second-quarter earnings of 13 cents a share. After Tuesday's closing bell, TD Ameritrade AMTD, +3.49% said in a regulatory filing that hedge funds SAC Capital and Jana Partners have taken an 8.4% stake in the company, an recently told the discount broker to pursue a merger with one of its rivals. See full story. Also, Cooper Cos. COO, +1.63% said it swung to loss in the latest quarter, largely due to costs associated with its acquisition of Ocular Sciences Inc. See full story. Watch list ABM Industries Inc. ABM, +0.75% reported second-quarter net earnings of $16.7 million, or 33 cents a share, up from $10.4 million, or 21 cents a share, during the year-ago period. The San Francisco-based facility services contractor said revenue for the three months ended April 30 rose to $697.9 million from $660.1 million. Additionally, ABM said it expects third-quarter earnings of 25 cents to 29 cents a share. The company also raised its fiscal 2007 outlook, saying it now sees per-share earnings of $1.05 to $1.10. Altera Corp. ALTR, +1.98% in its midquarter update, reiterated its second-quarter sales target, calling for revenue to grow 1% to 4% from the three months ended March 30. This forecast puts Altera's sales in the range of $308 million to $317 million. San Jose, Calif.-based Altera designs chips used in a wide range of products such as Internet routers, mobile-phone base stations, flat-panel televisions and DVD players. Altera shares closed at $23.17, a gain of almost 2%. The stock is up more than 16% so far this year. Basic Energy Services Inc. BAS, +2.34% said it has acquired Wildhorse Services Inc., a Woodward, Okla.-based provider of rental and fishing tool services. Basic Energy, a Midland, Texas-based provider of well site services, also said it has purchased substantially all of the operating assets of Eagle Frac Tank Rentals LP, including 103 frac tanks located in the Permian Basin market of west Texas. The value of the two separate transactions totaled $19 million in cash, excluding working capital acquired, the company said. BCE Inc. BCE, +0.68% (BCE) said another group is entering into discussions to explore the possibility of taking the company private. Montreal-based BCE, which owns Bell Canada, said the consortium includes Teachers' Private Capital, the private investment arm of the Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan and Providence Equity Partners Inc. BCE said in April it was holding talks with a group of large Canadian pension funds and the private-equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts about a potential buyout. Boeing Co. BA, +2.46% said Philippine Airlines agreed to buy two more Boeing 777-300ER twinjets, bringing its total order to six. The Chicago-based aerospace giant said the two airplanes have a list price of about $500 million. Boeing had 2006 revenue of $61.53 billion. Bois d'Arc Energy Inc. BDE, +0.00% retained its financial advisers to help the company explore strategic options, including a possible sale of the company. Separately, the Houston-based exploration company expects its second-quarter results to include an $18 million expense related to three unsuccessful exploratory wells. Bon-Ton Stores Inc. BONT total sales for the four weeks ended Saturday increased 1% to $234.7 million from $232.3 million. The York, Pa, retailer said Bon-Ton and Carson's combined same-store sales for period increased 1.2%. Carson's same-store store sales grew 4.9% and Bon-Ton same-store sales fell 5.3% from the year-earlier period. Year-to-date total sales increased 22.4% to $972.3 million, from $794.1 million. Year-to-date Bon-Ton same-store sales decreased 3.7% and year-to-date Carson's comparable store sales grew 0.5%. Copart Inc. CPRT, +2.21% reported third-quarter net earnings of $38.9 million, or 41 cents a share, up 12% from $34.7 million, or 37 cents a share, during the year-ago period. The Fairfield, Calif.-based provider of vehicle-salvage disposition services said revenue for the three months ended April 30 fell to $145.7 million from $149.5 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had forecast, on average, a per-share profit of 41 cents on revenue of $154 million. CPI Corp.'s CPY, -18.18% first-quarter net income grew 39% to $2.56 million, or 40 cents a share, from $1.84 million, or 29 cents a share, a year earlier, as expenses fell. The St. Louis portrait photography company's revenue fell 3.2% to $57.8 million from $59.7 million. Expenses dropped 5% to $53.7 million from $56.5 million. EBay Inc. EBAY, +0.32% plans to broker the sale of radio advertisements through an online auction site, according to a report Tuesday in The Wall Street Journal. EBay , in partnership with closely-held Bid4Spots Inc., will let more than 2,300 radio stations auction their airtime to advertisers via its Media Marketplace Web site, the report said. EBay plans to receive a portion of fees paid by advertisers, the report said. Guess GES, -0.81% reported first-quarter net earnings of $35.5 million, or 38 cents a share, up 72% from $20.7 million, or 23 cents a share, during the year-ago period. The Los Angeles-based apparel company said revenue for the three months ended May 5 rose 42% to $377.9 million from $265.7 million in the comparable period last year. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had forecast, on average, a per-share profit of 28 cents on revenue of $331 million. Guess expects fiscal second-quarter earnings of 31 cents to 33 cents a share on revenue of $335 million to $345 million. Analysts are looking for a per-share profit of 27 cents on revenue of $306 million. The company also raised its fiscal 2008 earnings outlook to a range of $1.75 to $1.80 a share, and forecast revenue of $1.51 billion to $1.56 billion. Analysts currently expect per-share earnings of $1.71 on revenue of $1.48 billion. Macrovision Corp. MVSN will realign its company into four business units, cut its worldwide headcount by about 7% and incur a restructuring charge of about $4.5 million in the second quarter. The Santa Clara, Calif., company backed its second-quarter revenue guidance of $65 million and $68 million and earnings, excluding items, of 24 cents to 27 cents a share. On average, analysts polled by Thomson Financial expect second-quarter earnings of 27 cents a share on revenue of $67.2 million. The company said 2007 earnings, excluding items, will increase to a range of $1.33 to $1.43 a share, from a previous range of $1.25 and $1.35. Microsoft Corp. MSFT, +2.10% has acquired closely held business software maker Engyro Corp. Financial terms were not disclosed. Cincinnati-based Engyro has previously partnered with Microsoft , and makes products used to connect Microsoft's management software with other applications for event sharing and other tasks. "This alliance will further Microsoft's commitment to its customers' longer term need for interoperable enterprise solutions," Microsoft said in a statement posted online. Navarre Corp. NAVR swung to a fourth-quarter loss of $2.24 million, or 6 cents a share, from a year-ago profit of $1.06 million, or 3 cents a share, as revenue fell 1.9%. The Minneapolis home entertainment and multimedia company's revenue dipped to $168.6 million from $171.9 million. On average, analysts expected revenue of $162.8 million, according to a poll by Thomson Financial. For fiscal 2008, the company expects net income of $9 million to $10 million on revenue of $670 million to $690 million. Navarre's shares closed trading on Tuesday down 5 cents, or 1.3%, to $3.85. Northwest Airlines Corp. NWA said that traffic in May was flat compared with the year-ago period as capacity rose 1.9%. Load factor, or the percentage of the plane filled with passengers, fell 1.6 percentage points to 84.3%, the Eagan, Minn.-based carrier said. Oxford Industries Inc. OXM, -1.25% cut its fiscal fourth-quarter outlook for continuing operations to a range of $1 to $1.05 a share from its previous range of $1.07 to $1.14. The Atlanta private-label apparel company expects fourth-quarter sales in the lower half of its previously issued outlook of $285 million to $295 million. Adjusted earnings from continuing operations are expected at 96 cents to $1.01 a share. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial estimate, on average, fourth-quarter adjusted earnings of $1.03 a share from continuing operations on sales of $296 million. Parker Hannifin Corp. PH, +1.71% reported that total orders for May were unchanged from the year-ago period. The Cleveland-based maker of motion and control technology products and systems also said that the international and aerospace segments gained strength during the period. Printronix Inc. PTNX said it swung to a fiscal fourth-quarter net profit of $151,000, or 2 cents a share, from a year-ago net loss of $7.43 million, or $1.19 a share. The Irvine, Calif.-based maker of printing products for the supply chain said revenue in the three months ended March 30 fell to $32.6 million from $33.2 million in the comparable period last year. Printronix expects fiscal first-quarter per-share earnings in a range of breakeven to 10 cents a share on revenue of $30.5 million and $32 million. Sirius Satellite Radio Inc. SIRI, +1.05% said it has obtained a $250 million senior secured term loan commitment from Morgan Stanley Senior Funding Inc. The proceeds will be used for general corporate purposes, New York-based Sirius said. Smith & Wollensky Restaurant Group Inc. SWRG late Tuesday said that comparable restaurant sales for May rose 0.4% from the year-ago period to about $8.6 million. Total consolidated restaurant sales were $9.4 million for the month ended May 28, a 3.4% decrease from the $9.8 million last year, the New York-based restaurant operator said. TD Ameritrade Holding Corp. AMTD, +3.49% named Fred Tomczyk as its new chief operating officer, succeeding Randy MacDonald, who retired from the brokerage services provider on June 1. Tomczyk previously served as the vice chairman of corporate operations for TD Bank Financial Group and was a member of the TD Ameritrade board. Tomczyk has resigned from the board and will resign from TD Bank Financial Group in July. TD Ameritrade is based in Omaha, Neb. Volterra Semiconductor Corp. VLTR said it now expects second-quarter revenue of $18.5 million to $19.5 million, down from its previous view of $20 million to $21 million, and forecast a loss excluding items of 4 cents to 7 cents a share. The Fremont, Calif.-based company said the expected revenue shortfall is primarily due to a process defect with one of its vendors, which caused Volterra to recall $2 million to $3 million of product and will result in a $3 million to $4 million charge in the second quarter. Volterra said it will replace the recalled products, and revenues associated with the products will be recognized in the quarter in which the replacement products are shipped. More from MarketWatch How to Get a Job: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Stocks in focus for Wednesday

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - ABM Industries Inc. ABM, +0.75% late Tuesday reported second-quarter net earnings of $16.7 million, or 33 cents a share, up from $10.4 million, or 21 cents a share, during the year-ago period. The San Francisco-based facility services contractor said revenue for the three months ended April 30 rose to $697.9 million from $660.1 million. Additionally, ABM said it expects third-quarter earnings of 25 cents to 29 cents a share. The company also raised its fiscal 2007 outlook, saying it now sees per-share earnings of $1.05 to $1.10.
title: ABM Industries quarterly profit surges; boosts outlook

content: Conseco quarterly net slumps on long-term care losses (5:45 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Conseco Inc. CNO, -0.87% reported a large drop in fourth-quarter net income late Tuesday after the insurer was hit with significant losses in its long-term care business. Net income was $5.8 million vs. $77.1 million a year earlier. Conseco reported a net loss applicable to holders of its common stock of $3.7 million, or two cents a share. Operating income, which excludes realized investment gains and losses, came in at $5.7 million, or four cents a share, the company added. Conseco was expected to make 37 cents a share in the quarter, according to the average estimate of six analysts in a Thomson Financial survey. Conseco said it had to bolster claim reserves by $54.1 million in its so-called run-off businesses, which are being slowly closed down. Long-term care insurance reserves were also lifted by $7.1 million, the company added. Conseco said it can't provide an earnings forecast because it will take time to improve the performance of its run-off long-term care business. Copart quarterly profit more than triples (4:58 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Copart Inc. CPRT, +2.21% late Tuesday reported second-quarter net earnings of $30.4 million, or 32 cents a share, up from $7.85 million, or 8 cents a share, during the year-ago period. Last year's results were adversely impacted by about $4.9 million as a result of the Gulf coast hurricanes. The Fairfield, Calif.-based provider of vehicle salvage disposition services posted revenue of $128.9 million vs. $125.1 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had forecast second-quarter earnings of 33 cents a share on revenue of $136 million. Same-store sales, excluding the revenue associated with the public auction business exited in fiscal 2006, rose by 3% during the quarter, Copart said. Maxwell Technologies swings to a profit (4:57 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Maxwell Technologies Inc. MXWL, +1.37% late Tuesday reported fourth-quarter net income of $633,000, or 3 cents a share. In the same period last year, the company posted a net loss of $1.12 million, or 6 cents a share. San Diego-based Maxwell said the 2006 fourth quarter included a non-cash gain of $5 million, or 30 cents a share, for a change in calculated fair value of conversion features of convertible debentures. Revenue at the San Diego-based maker of energy storage and power delivery products rose to $15.1 million from $12.6 million. Maxwell expects first-quarter revenue of to be lower than it was in the fourth quarter. Chico's same-store sales down 4.3% in February (4:36 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Chico's FAS Inc. CHS, +0.33% late Tuesday said its February sales at company-owned stores open at least one year fell 4.3%. Total sales for the four weeks ended March 3 rose 15% to $113.6 million from $98.7 million, the Fort Myers, Fla.-based specialty retailer said. Chico's quarterly profit falls; revenue rises 19% (4:26 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Chico's FAS Inc. CHS, +0.33% late Tuesday reported fourth-quarter net earnings of $18.2 million, or 10 cents a share, down from $44.5 million, or 24 cents a share, during the year-ago period. The latest results include pretax impairment expenses of about $8.6 million, or 3 cents a share, related to the planned closure of the Fitigues brand operations in the first quarter of fiscal 2007. The Fort Myers, Fla.-based retailer posted net revenue of $446.3 million, up 19% from $375.7 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had forecast fourth-quarter earnings of 13 cents a share on revenue of $443 million. Comparable sales for company-owned stores fell 2% during the quarter. Additionally, Chico's said it will no longer provide specific quarterly or annual sales and earnings outlooks. The company said it believes that if it achieves a low-single-digit same-store sales increase for fiscal 2007, the current consensus analyst estimates for the period "appear reasonable." Payless ShoeSource swings to a quarterly profit (4:21 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Payless ShoeSource Inc. PSS late Tuesday reported fourth-quarter net earnings of $24.6 million, or 37 cents a share. In the same quarter last year, the company posted a net loss of $5.6 million, or 8 cents a share. The Topkea, Kan.-based retailer said fourth quarter 2006 earnings benefited by the release of $14.3 million, or 22 cents a share, of income tax reserves related primarily to the closing of income tax audits in various jurisdictions. Revenue rose 13% to $692.7 million from $611 million, while comparable store sales in the quarter rose 6.8%. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting a per-share profit of 7 cents on revenue of $640 million. Payless said it remains committed to its goal of achieving low single-digit same-store sales growth. The company also said its long-term goal is to see earnings per share percentage growth in the mid-teens. Acadia Pharmaceuticals quarterly loss widens (4:11 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Acadia Pharmaceuticals Inc. ACAD, -2.77% late Tuesday reported a fourth-quarter net loss of $12.5 million, or 42 cents a share, compared with a net loss of $10.2 million, or 44 cents a share, during the year-ago period. There were 29.9 million shares outstanding during the quarter vs. 23.4 million a year ago. Collaborative revenue at the San Diego-based biopharmaceutical company fell to $1.77 million from $2.44 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial had forecast a fourth-quarter loss of 44 cents a share. Countrywide CFO sees 'dark time' for other subprime lenders (12:58 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Countrywide Financial CFC, +5.04% CFO Eric P. Sieracki said some subprime lenders will go out of business in the current downdraft in the sector, but said his company will emerge. "If you're a monoline subprime lender, this is a dark time for you," Sieracki said in his presentation at the Raymond James 28th Annual Investors Conference. He said Countrywide's subprime business represents only 9% of loans, but pointed out that 30-day deliquencies for sub-prime have risen to nearly 19% from 12%-14%. He said it's too early to tell if woes in the subprime business will spill over to other products, with fresh data on deliquencies coming after March 31. More than 80% of Countrywide's subprime loans are rated A-minus or better, he said. "This is the pain phase of a healthy cycle," he said. "We're a top conditioned athlete and the future value of this pain is greater...we need to see supply leave the system. We've been through these kinds of cycles before and we've seen another day." Countrywide plans to 'dominate' real estate finance (11:51 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Countrywide Financial CFO Eric P. Sieracki said the company plans to grow by dominating real estate finance, enhancing earnings stability and diversifying its business mix. Speaking at the 28th annual Institutional Investors Conference, Sieracki said the company's origination market share growth has outpaced the industry but said Countrywide "is not a one-trick pony." Only 9% of the company's fundings come from subprime, he said. He said there may be regional opportunities to grow the company, but didn't set plans for any major acquisitions. Fuel Tech shares rally on fourth-quarter results, forecast (11:14 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Fuel Tech Inc. FTEK, -0.83% shares gained 9.1% to $25.68 in Tuesday morning trade after the Batavia, Ill.-based company reported a fourth-quarter net profit of $1.46 million, or 6 cents a share, down from $2.62 million or 11 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue rose 11% to $18.1 million from $16.3 million in the same period last year. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting a per-share profit of 5 cents on revenue of $17.1 million. Fuel Tech forecast 2007 revenue of $90 million to $95 million. Frozen Food Express' profit falls; shares slip (10:48 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Frozen Food Express Industries Inc. FFEX shares fell 6.3% to $7.60 in Tuesday morning trade after the Dallas-based perishable goods carrier reported fourth-quarter net earnings of $4.32 million, or 24 cents a share, down from $6.36 million, or 34 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue fell to $113.5 million from $141.9 million. ABM Industries' quarterly profit jumps; shares rise (10:39 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- ABM Industries Inc. ABM, +0.75% shares rose 9% to $28.25 in Tuesday morning trade after the San Francisco-based facility services contractor reported fiscal first-quarter net earnings of $8.7 million, or 18 cents a share, up from $4 million, or 8 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue rose 5.5% to $703.5 million from $666.6 million. ABM forecast fiscal second-quarter earnings of 28 cents to 32 cents, and raised its fiscal 2007 forecast to a range of $1.04 to $1.08 a share, or $1.12 to $1.16 a share excluding items. IPG Photonics shares fall on fourth-quarter results (10:27 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- IPG Photonics Corp. IPGP, +3.37% shares fell 8% to $21.36 to $21.43 in Tuesday morning trade after the company reported fourth-quarter net earnings of $16.6 million, up from $3.9 million in the year-ago period. Due to a dividend payment related to the company's initial public offering, IPG reported a per-share loss of 11 cents compared with net earnings of 11 cents in the same quarter last year. Excluding certain items, IPG posted fourth-quarter 2006 adjusted earnings of $6.6 million, or 17 cents a share. Revenue at the Oxford, Mass.-based maker of fiber lasers and amplifiers rose 23% to $42.1 million from $34.1 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting a per-share profit of 14 cents on revenue of $39.4 million. InfoSonics shares fall on fourth-quarter results (10:09 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- InfoSonics Corp. IFON, -1.29% shares fell 13% to $3.90 in Tuesday morning trade after the San Diego-based distributor of wireless handsets reported fourth-quarter net earnings of $560,958, or 4 cents a share, down from $811,179, or 6 cents a share, in the same quarter a year ago. Revenue rose 74.1% to $60.9 million from $35 million. Bausch & Lomb's results hurt by lens solution recall (8:26 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Bausch & Lomb BOL, -12.50% on Tuesday released preliminary results for the fourth quarter and year and, citing a recall of its MoistureLoc contact lens solution, said its U.S. operations will be unprofitable. The eye care company said it expects to report consolidated full-year net sales of about $2.29 billion for the year, down 3%, mainly due to lower sales of vision care products. Reported sales in both years were reduced by charges associated with provisions for customer returns and consumer coupon redemptions related to the May 2006 recall of ReNu with MoistureLoc contact lens solution. Because the company has not yet completed its year-end financial closing process, it is unable to estimate net earnings or earnings per share at this time. The company expects to report income before income taxes and minority interest of about $70 million in 2006, compared to $246.4 million in 2005. For the fourth quarter of 2006, the company expects to report income before income taxes and minority interest of about $25 million, compared to $84.3 million a year ago. Iconix buys Rocawear for $204 mln, with Jay-Z remaining (8:19 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Iconix Brand Group Inc. ICON, -0.89% on Tuesday said it would pay $204 million in cash plus contingent payments of an additional $35 million of Iconix stock to buy Rocawear, a fashion brand co-founded by rap star Jay-Z. Iconix expects $43 million in Rocawear royalty revenue in the first year. Jay-Z will be in charge of product development, marketing and licensing for Rocawear. His senior management team in licensing, marketing and product development will also join Iconix. Jay-Z will retain his stake in the operating company that manufactures Rocawear men's apparel. Partners Alex Bize and Norton Cher will continue to run the men's apparel business and enter into a long-term license agreement with Iconix for the core young men's apparel category. Bausch & Lomb sets limited recall of lens solution (8:14 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Bausch & Lomb BOL, -12.50% on Tuesday said it initiated a limited voluntary recall of from distribution centers and retail shelves in the U.S. and specific other countries of 12 lots of ReNu MultiPlus lens care solution made at its plant in Greenville, S.C. because they contain an elevated level of trace iron. This may result in discoloration of the solution in some bottles, and the shelf life of the product may be shortened to less than its two-year expiration date, due to a potential loss of effectiveness over time. The company has received no reports of serious adverse events associated with these lots and believes virtually all of the affected product has already been used by consumers. The Rochester, N.Y.-based company has notified the U.S. Food and Drug Administration of this action. The company initiated a probe after receiving three customer reports of discolored solution. Bausch & Lomb does not expect the costs associated with this recall will have a significant impact on its financial results. The eye care company has struggled recently after it recalled its ReNu with MoistureLoc contact-lens solution due to an outbreak of eye-fungus infection. UnitedHealth Group net for 2006 up 35%, revenue up 54% (8:03 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- UnitedHealth Group Inc., UNH, -2.06% the Minnetonka, Minn., health-care provider, reported that for 2006, it earned $2.97 a share, up 29% from 2005. Net income was $4.2 billion, up 35%. In its Securities and Exchange Commission Form 10-K, the company reported that revenue rose 54% to $71.54 billion from $46.43 billion; excluding acquisitions, revenue rose 21%. Earnings from operations rose 37% to $6.98 billion from $5.08 billion. UnitedHealth 9-month '06 net up 29% as option costs revised (7:44 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- UnitedHealth Group Inc., UNH, -2.06% the Minnetonka, Minn., health-care provider, reported that for the first nine months of 2006, net income rose 29% on 56% higher revenue. In a Securities and Exchange Commission Form 10-Q, UNH reported earnings rose to $2.98 billion, or $2.13 a share, from $2.31 billion, or $1.73, in the year-earlier period. Revenue reached $53.41 billion from $34.14 billion. The year-ago numbers are restated. UNH said that the numbers reflect additional stock-based compensation expense and related tax effects stemming from the company's assessment of its accounting for stock options. United Health 2005 net rose 28% after revised option costs (7:33 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- UnitedHealth Group Inc., UNH, -2.06% the Minnetonka, Minn., health-care provider, reported in its restatements for 2005 and 2004 that earnings rose 28% year on year as revenue rose 21%. Earnings in 2005 reached $3.08 billion, or $2.31 a share, from $2.41 billion, or $1.83, in 2004. Revenue climbed to $46.43 billion from $38.22 billion. In its Securities and Exchange Commission Form 10-K, UNH said that the numbers reflect additional stock-based compensation expense and related tax effects stemming from the company's assessment of its accounting for stock options. United Health files 10-K and quarterly reports (7:10 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- UnitedHealth Group Inc., UNH, -2.06% the Minnetonka, Minn. health-care provider, filed a Securities and Exchange Commission Form 10-K that restates financial results for the years 2004 and 2005 and for the fourth quarter of 2005. The company also filed an amended report for first-quarter 2006 as well as reports for the second and third quarters of 2006. The restatements arose from the company's inquiry into its grants of stock options. UnitedHealth had withdrawn its earlier financial reports because operating costs did not correctly reflect non-cash stock-based compensation expenses related to its grants options. ExlService Holdings' quarterly revenue leaps 97% (7:03 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- ExlService Holdings Inc. EXLS, +0.94% reported fourth-quarter net income of $6 million, or 22 cents a share, up from $3.2 million, or 14 cents, earned in the final three months of 2005. There were nearly 25% more weighted average shares in the latest quarter than a year earlier. The New York-based outsourcing services provider generated quarterly revenue of $39.3 million, up from the prior year's $20 million. For 2007, ExlService pegged its revenue forecast in a range of $160 million to $170 million. Analysts, on average, are looking for revenue of $166 million, according to estimates compiled by Thomson Financial. There were no forecasts for the company's results for the latest quarter. Shares of ExlService added 68 cents, or 3%, to end Monday's trading at $23.56. Barrier Therapeutics, Novartis agree Vusion marketing deal (6:41 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Barrier Therapeutics Inc. BTRX said it has entered an agreement with Novartis AG NVS, -0.49% under which Novartis' consumer health division will promote Barrier Therapeutics' Vusion treatment for diaper dermatitis to pediatricians in the U.S. Under the agreement, which runs through 2008, Barrier will pay Novartis a flat fee for each sales call made to a pediatrician. First Consulting delays 4th-quarter report by a week (6:39 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- First Consulting Group Inc., FCGI the Long Beach, Calif., provider of outsourcing, consulting and systems-implementation and -integration services to health-related industries, delayed releasing its fourth-quarter and full-year financial results by a week, to March 13. In a statement, FCGI said it needed the extra time to complete tax-related analysis regarding how to apply certain net-operating-loss carry-forwards. "The analysis is not expected to impact the company's pre-tax operating results in any period," First Consulting said. SGX Pharmaceuticals' quarterly loss narrows, revenue grows (6:25 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- SGX Pharmaceuticals Inc. SGXP reported a fourth-quarter loss of $4.9 million, or 32 cents a share, narrower than the prior year's loss of $5.9 million, or $7.61 a share. The San Diego-based biotechnology company focusing on cancer therapeutics, which went public during 2006, generated revenue of $8.4 million, up from $6.9 million in the final three months of 2005. Analysts, on average, had been looking for a loss of 21 cents a share on revenue of $7 million, according to estimates compiled by Thomson Financial. SGX Pharma spent $11.4 million on research and development during the latest quarter, higher than $10.3 million in the same period a year earlier. Shares of SGX Pharma added 26 cents, or 5.4%, to end Monday's trading at $5.04. Telekom Austria 4th-quarter net up 64%, revenue up 2.6% (3:35 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Telekom Austria AG, TKA, -0.28% Vienna, reported fourth-quarter net income rose 64% from the year-earlier period on 2.6% higher revenue. Net reached 63.3 million euros ($83.4 million), or 0.14 euro a share, on 1.2 billion euros of revenue. The board will urge holders to approve an increase in the dividend 36% to 0.75 euro a share. Retalix 4th-quarter net fell 38% on 5.7% higher revenue (3:20 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Retalix Ltd., RTLX the Ra'anana, Israel, producer of software and solutions of supermarkets, food-service firms, and goods distributors, reported fourth-quarter net income fell 38% on 5.7% higher revenue. Earnings were $3.4 million, or 17 cents a share, compared with $5.5 million, or 28 cents, in the year-earlier period. Adjusted net for the period was 27 cents a share against 32 cents. Revenue reached $56.8 million from $53.7 million. In 2007, Retalix expects to earn about $9 million to $16 million, or an adjusted $15 million to $22 million. Revenue should range $220 million to $230 million, the company estimated. In 2006, Retalix earned $1.3 million, or 6 cents a share, on revenue of $203.8 million. Redrow profit up 1.6%; higher rates not hitting sales (2:58 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. home builder Redrow Plc(UK:RDW)said its net profit in the six-months to Dec. 31 rose 1.6% to 37.9 million pounds ($74 million) as revenue grew 8.1% to 366.2 million pounds. The firm said interest rate rises have not had a discernible impact on sales, but noted the housing market remains competitive. It added its strategy is to optimise returns from its existing landbank, which is growing in value in the current land market conditions. Redrow added it is on track to deliver its completion target for the year and expects further growth in fiscal 2008. OMV quarterly profit up 25% (2:52 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Oil and gas group OMV OMVKY, +0.25% said Tuesday its fourth-quarter net profit rose 25% to 295 million euros from 237 million euros a year earlier as sales grew 13% to 5.16 billion euros. The company said a decline in production and higher exploration expenses were outweighed by income from investment activities and OMV's stake in Turkish marketing company Petrol Ofisi. France Telecom profit drops 27%; no sales outlook (2:50 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- France Telecom FTE, +0.55% (FR:013330)on Tuesday said its annual profit slumped 27% to 4.14 billion euros ($5.45 billion), while revenue rose 7.5% to 51.7 billion euros. The company said its profit was hurt by intensifying Western European mobile competition, higher network and information technology costs and increased work on local loop unbundling initiatives, while service fees and inter-operator costs remained almost stable on a comparable basis. Its operating profit declined 1.4 percentage points to 35.9%. For 2007, it hopes to keep its organic cash flow at 6.8 billion euros and a near stabilization of its operating margin. It didn't provide sales guidance. It's proposing to pay a 1.20 euros a share dividend and hold its 2007 dividend at the same level. Allied Irish Bank profit rises 63% (2:45 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Allied Irish Bank(UK:ALBK)said Tuesday that its 2006 net profit rose 63% to 2.19 billion euros ($2.88 billion) as total operating income grew 19% to 4.33 billion euros. The bank said its profit included a 365 million euro gain on the sale of property. Operating income rose to 1.91 billion euros from 1.49 billion euros due to a stronger performance across all divisions, with investment banking and asset management fees rising 57%. The net interest margin shrank slightly due to competitive pressure on loans and deposits pricing and lower yields from the reinvestment of deposit and current account funds. The bank said the prospects remain bright for sustaining its growth into 2007. CRH profit before tax climbs 25%, tops forecast (2:38 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- CRH(UK:CRH) CRH, +0.71% the Irish buildiing materials firm, said 2006 profit before tax climbed 25% to 1.6 billion euros ($2.1 billion), with revenue up 30% to 18.74 billion euros. Analysts polled by FactSet JCF expected a profit of 1.5 billion euros on revenue of 18.08 billion euros. It's lifting its dividend 33% to 0.52 euros a share. It grew profit in its materials, products and distribution arms in Europe and the Americas despite higher input costs and declining U.S. residential construction, the company said. International Power profit up 44%, raises dividend (2:35 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- International Power Plc(UK:IPR) IPR, -0.61% said Tuesday that its 2006 net profit rose 44% to 410 million pounds ($800 million) as revenue for the year including its share of joint ventures grew 29% to 3.78 billion pounds. Group revenue was 2.45 billion pounds, with adjusted profit of 21.3 pence a share. Analysts had been expecting earnings of 21.6 pence a share on revenue of 2.39 billion pounds according to a JCF-compiled forecast. Profitability improved due to higher power prices in the U.K. as well as an improved performance from U.S. assets and the contribution from acquisitions. The firm said it will increase its dividend by 75% to 7.9 pence-a-share and is well placed for further growth in 2007. Miner Xstrata more than doubles annual profit (2:32 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Xstrata(UK:XTA), the U.K.-traded nickel and copper miner, said annual adjusted profit more than doubled to a stronger-than-forecast $4.89 billion, with revenue rising 56% to $26.88 billion. The company cited three major acquisitions that closed, including the acquisition of Canada's Falconbridge, and stronger commodity prices for the profit and revenue growth. It's lifting its final dividend 34% to 30 cents a share. Xstrata said that while it is unlikely that average prices for base metals will continue to rise at a similar rate in 2007, the fundamental outlook for the industry remains positive. "This positive outlook often appears to need reiteration in the face of the increased volatility that is now such a feature of the equity and commodity markets," the company said. The rate of cost increases may have slowed somewhat in the second half of the year, although it is too early to see if this will continue in 2007, it added. More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? More Coverage Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’ Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- ABM Industries Inc. ABM, +0.75% shares rose 9% to $28.25 in Tuesday morning trade after the San Francisco-based facility services contractor reported fiscal first-quarter net earnings of $8.7 million, or 18 cents a share, up from $4 million, or 8 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue rose 5.5% to $703.5 million from $666.6 million. ABM forecast fiscal second-quarter earnings of 28 cents to 32 cents, and raised its fiscal 2007 forecast to a range of $1.04 to $1.08 a share, or $1.12 to $1.16 a share excluding items.
title: ABM Industries' quarterly profit jumps; shares rise

content: ABM quarterly income up; board OKs dividend hike, buyback (10:14 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- ABM Industries Inc. ABM, +0.75% Tuesday evening said fourth-quarter net income rose to $61.6 million, or $1.24 a share, from $8.43 million, or 17 cents a share, during the same period in the prior year. Quarterly revenue rose to $776.7 million from $658.7 million in the prior year. For fiscal 2007, the facility services contractor said it sees income from continuing operations of $1 to $1.05 per share, and earnings before items of $1.10 to $1.15 per share. Also, ABM's board raised the quarterly cash dividend 9% to 12 cents per share. The dividend is payable Feb. 5 to shareholders as of Jan. 12. The board has also authorized a buyback for up to two million ABM shares. CHC Helicopter quarterly earnings fall (6:45 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- CHC Helicopter Corp. FLI, +0.73% after Tuesday's closing bell reported second-quarter net earnings of C$8.9 million ($7.2 million), or 20 Canadian cents a share, compared with C$39.2 million, or 85 Canadian cents a share, in the same period last year. This year's results included C$4.9 million in aircraft introduction costs, while last year's results included a C$25 million pretax gain related to the sale of Canadian Helicopters Ltd. and other investments. The Canadian provider of transportation services said revenue rose 8% to C$276.5 million from C$256.5 million. Plato Learning quarterly loss narrows (5:23 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Plato Learning Inc. TUTR after Tuesday's closing bell said its fourth-quarter net loss narrowed to $11.6 million, or 49 cents a share, compared with a net loss of $13.9 million, or 59 cents a share, in the same period last year, as impairment charges and other expenses dropped. Excluding restructuring charges, among other items, the Bloomington, Minn.-based provider of computer-based and online instruction posted a net loss of 7 cents. In the same period last year, the company reported per-share earnings of 9 cents, excluding items. Revenue fell 29% to $23.8 million from $33.7 million. The company expects its 2007 net loss to narrow by 15% to 30% from its net loss in 2006, excluding items, although revenue will fall. Plato expects to become profitable in 2008, when the transition from perpetual to subscription license products is almost completed. Peerless Systems swings to quarterly loss; revenue declines (5:02 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Peerless Systems Corp. PRLS after Tuesday's closing bell said it swung to a third-quarter net loss, as revenue fell, of $18,000, or breakeven on a per-share basis. During the same period in the prior year, net income was $1.05 million, or 6 cents a share. The imaging technologies provider said quarterly revenue fell to $7.98 million from $9.65 million. Peerless backed its prior view for fiscal 2007 revenue of $33 million to $36 million, with net income of $3 million. The company added that declining demand for monochrome technologies, along with later-than-expected realization of licensing revenue for the company's Sierra technologies, will likely lead to a year-over-year revenue decline during the first half of fiscal 2008. CKE Restaurants quarterly income falls on income tax expense (4:38 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- CKE Restaurants Inc. CKR after Tuesday's closing bell said third-quarter net income fell, as income tax expense rose, to $9.46 million, or 13 cents a share, from $15.8 million, or 23 cents a share, during the same period in the prior year. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected per-share income of 16 cents. The operator of Carl's Jr. and Hardee's restaurants said quarterly revenue rose to $364.9 million from $344.1 million in the prior year, while Wall Street had expected $363 million. Cooper quarterly income rises; lowers 2007 outlook (4:30 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Cooper Cos. COO, +1.63% after Tuesday's closing bell said fourth-quarter net income rose, as costs fell for items such as research and development, to $13.6 million from $8.57 million during the same period in the prior year. Income applicable to shareholders rose to $14.1 million, or 30 cents a share, from $9.09 million, or 19 cents a share, in the prior year. The medical supplies company said quarterly revenue fell to $216 million from $220.6 million in the prior year. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected revenue of $234 million. For 2007, Cooper now sees 2007 revenue of $920 million to $960 million, compared with its prior view of $948 million to $1 billion. Cooper now sees annual per-share income, before items, of $2.90 to $3.05, compared with its prior view of $3.35 to $4. With items, the company sees per-share income for 2007 of $1.55 to $1.90. SAIC quarterly income rises; revenue gains (4:17 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- SAIC Inc. SAI, +11.11% after Tuesday's closing bell said third-quarter net income rose, as revenue gained, to $98 million, or 28 cents a share, from $91 million, or 25 cents a share, during the same period in the prior year. The provider of research, engineering, and technology services said quarterly income per share from continuing operations was 26 cents, up from 20 cents in the prior year. Wall Street was looking for a per-share result of 23 cents. SAIC said third-quarter revenue rose to $2.14 billion from $2.02 billion in the prior year. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were looking for revenue of $2.11 billion. For fiscal 2007, the company sees revenue of $8.15 billion to $8.25 billion and per-share income from continuing operations of 96 cents to 98 cents. Analysts are looking for annual revenue of $8.22 billion and per-share income of 97 cents. For fiscal 2008, SAIC sees revenue of $8.7 billion to $9 billion and per-share income of 83 cents to 88 cents. Analysts are looking for fiscal 2008 revenue of $8.7 billion and per-share income of 88 cents. WellPoint sees 1Q 2007 EPS $1.25, rising to $1.49 by 4Q (3:39 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- WellPoint Inc. WLP on Tuesday said it expects to report earnings of $1.25 a share for the first quarter of 2007, rising to $1.49 a share by the fourth quarter. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call are currently looking for a first-quarter per-share profit of $1.28, on average. Indianapolis-based health insurer also said it sees a full-year profit of $5.53, in line with its previous target for a 15% rise over projected 2006 results. GE backs fourth-quarter, 2006 outlook; issues 2007 forecast (3:15 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- General Electric Co. GE, -1.46% on Tuesday reaffirmed its forecast for the fourth quarter and full-year 2006. The Fairfield, Conn.-based company said it expects fourth-quarter per-share earnings growth of 13% to 16%, or 62 cents to 64 cents a share. For 2006, GE said it sees per-share earnings growth of 15% to 16%, or $1.97 to $1.99 a share. The company also forecast 2007 per-share earnings growth of 10% to 13%, or $2.17 to $2.23 a share. Additionally, GE raised its quarterly dividend 12% to 28 cents from 25 cents a share. The dividend is payable on Jan. 25 to shareholders of record as of Dec. 26. The company delivered the projections at its annual outlook meeting. Dana identifies four plants slated for closure; sees charges (1:49 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Dana Corp. DCNAQ on Tuesday identified four of eight facilities it plans to close during the next two years as part of a previously announced plan. They are the traction products facilities in Syracuse, Ind., and Cape Girardeau, Mo., and the structural solutions plants in Guelph and Thorold, Ontario, Canada. The bankrupt Toledo, Ohio-based auto-parts maker said it expects to incur pretax charges of about $26 million during the fourth quarter, and additional pretax charges of about $19 million during 2007 to 2009 in connection with these closures. Dana also said that four additional facility closures are expected to be finalized in 2007. Axcan Pharma outlines fiscal 2007 revenue expectations (11:35 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Axcan Pharma Inc. AXCA (CA:AXP)said Tuesday it expects fiscal 2007 revenue of $300 million to $307 million. The projection assumes unit volume and price increases will contribute approximately 8.5% in increases in total revenue over the previous fiscal year, while certain non-recurring items will negatively affect revenue by about 3.5%, the Canadian pharmaceutical company said. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call are currently forecasting fiscal 2007 revenue of $293 million. Drug shares rise in early trading (9:47 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Drug shares rose on Tuesday, with Merck & Co. MRK, -1.13% seeing morning gains after it said it expects to file file for regulatory approval of three new drugs in 2007. Epix Pharmaceuticals EPIX, +6.10% shares soared 48% after saying it entered into a development pact with GlaxoSmithKline GSK, -0.79% As part of the deal, Epix will receive an upfront payment of $35 million, including $17.5 million from the sale of 3 million shares. Idevus Pharmaceuticals' IDEV, +0.97% shares fell 7.3% after it said it agreed to buy Valera Pharmaceuticals VLRX, -4.93% for about $120 million, plus contingency payments of up to $3.50 a share. Valera shares rose 49%. Hewlett Packard issues 2007-08 forecast; no big deals likely (9:44 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Hewlett-Packard Chief Executive Mark Hurd said Tuesday that he's intent on driving down costs at the technology giant and is unlikely to make any large acquisitions. At the company's annual investors day, HP HPQ, +1.06% also reiterated its 2007 forecast and gave a glimpse into fiscal 2008. For 2007, HP predicted earnings before one-time items of $2.48 to $2.53 a share on revenue of more than $97 billion. In 2008, the company expects to earn $2.78 to $2.98 a share, before one-time items, on revenue ranging from $100.9 billion to $102.8 billion. Those forecasts are generally in line with Wall Street's consensus. While Hurd would not rule out any major acquisitions, he told investors not to expect any. He said HP would continue to make smaller acquisitions to fill in gaps in the company's product portfolio. Hurd also said HP has more room to cut expenses. Yahoo up on new ad platform, e-tailers choppy (9:43 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Shares of large Internet companies were trading with mixed results early Tuesday, with Yahoo Inc. YHOO gaining ground after opening up its new advertising platform to all U.S. businesses, while online sellers Amazon.com Inc. AMZN, +1.11% and eBay Inc. EBAY, +0.32% opened the day choppy following a note from Lazard Capital Markets lauding the ongoing online holiday shopping season. Shares of VeriSign Inc. VRSN, +1.86% were trading higher after Deutsche Bank Securities analyst Todd Raker raised his price target for the stock to $30 from $26. Meanwhile, shares of Napster Inc. NAPS, +0.00% were up 4% after it announced that it'll launch a mobile music download service in Europe starting in about a month. Both the Dow Jones Internet Index DJI_DJINET and the technology-heavy Nasdaq Composite Index $COMPQ began the day fractionally higher. Celestica lowers fourth-quarter view due to reduced demand (9:10 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Celestica Inc. CLS, +0.68% Tuesday said it expects between breakeven results and a profit of 6 cents a share on an adjusted basis for the fourth quarter ending Dec. 31 on revenue of between $2.20 billion and $2.25 billion. This view is below the company's previous forecast for adjusted earnings of 15 to 23 cents a share in the quarter on revenue of $2.25 billion to $2.45 billion. The current average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for a profit of 19 cents a share in the December period on revenue of $2.21 billion. The Toronto-based provider of electronics manufacturing services attributed the lower outlook to demand reductions from several customers. It added that the revised adjusted earnings view for the fourth quarter includes a charge of 8 to 12 cents a share related to an increase in inventory provisions at its Monterrey, Mexico facility. The stock closed Monday at 9.37, down 11 cents. Merck expects to file for 3 drug approvals in 2007 (9:02 AM ET) BOSTON (MarkeWatch) -- In conjunction with its annual update for analysts on the state of its product pipeline, Merck MRK, -1.13% said early Tuesday that it plans to file for regulatory approval of three new drugs in 2007. The drugs include: MK-0518 for HIV; Gaboxadol, a treatment for insomnia; and MK-0524A. Merck also affirmed its previously-issued financial forecast of double-digit compound earnings-per-share growth, excluding extraordinary items, by 2010 from its 2005 base. The drugmaker added that its "strong" cash flow will support its current dividend and allow it the opportunity to repurchase more of its stock. Merck also said that the Food and Drug Admintration plans to hold an advisory panel meeting to discuss approval of its pain releiver Arcoxia, a drug similar to Vioxx, but has not yet set a date. Kellogg names Boromisa Asia Pacific head, Bryant CFO (8:53 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Kellogg Co. K, +1.74% Tuesday named Jeff Boromisa as president of its Asia Pacific division, a new organization comprised of Australia, Asia, and South Africa that was formerly part of the European business. John Bryant, president of Kellogg International, will add the responsibilities of chief financial officer for Kellogg Co. The changes are effective Dec. 31. Separately, the Battle Creek, Mich., food company affirmed its full-year outlook for earnings of $2.48 to $2.50 a share. Chile's LAN Airlines November traffic rises 25% (8:50 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Chile's LAN Airlines S.A. LFL, +16.29% said its passenger traffic in November rose 25% while its capacity increased 20.2%, resulting in a 3-point increase in its load factor, or the percentage of seats filled with paying passengers, to 76.9%. The Santiago-based airline said late Monday that international passenger traffic accounted for 86% of the total number of passengers it carried and that long-haul trip capacity grew because of increased operations to the South Pacific, Europe and the U.S. Midwest Air traffic rises, load factor up to 74% (8:44 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Midwest Air Group Inc. MEH, +0.44% said Tuesday its November traffic rose 13.2% while its seat capacity climbed 6.2%, resulting in a load factor improvement of 4.2 points to 74% compared to the same month last year. The group, which includes Midwest Airlines and Midwest Connect operations, posted an estimated 1% improvement in revenue yield while experiencing a 3.7% rise in November's per-gallon fuel cost, year-over-year. Dollar General swings to loss (8:40 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Dollar General Corp. DG, +0.66% said Tuesday it swung to a third-quarter loss of $5.3 million, or 2 cents a share, from year-ago income of $64.4 million, or 20 cents a share. Planned store closings and the elimination of its packaway inventory model resulted in pretax costs and charges if about $79.2 million. Sales for the three months ended Nov. 3 rose to $2.21 billion from $2.06 billion a year ago. Same-store sales, or sales at stores open at least a year, increased 2%, the Goodlettsville, Tenn., discount retailer said. Analysts, on average, expected Dollar General to post earnings of 15 cents a share on sales of $2.24 billion. Goldman Sachs net income jumps 93% from year ago (8:34 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Goldman Sachs Tuesday said its fourth quarter net income rose 93% to $3.15 billion, or $6.59 a share on $9.4 billion of revenue. Earnings per share and revenue both surpassed analyst estimates as capital market advances, strong advisory fees and big gains on proprietary investments lifted the Wall Street giant's earnings. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had, on average, expected the firm to earn $6.04 cents a share on revenue of $8.96 billion. A year ago, the company earned 1.63 billion, or $3.35 a share. Salesforce.com raised revenue outlook (8:17 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Salesforce.com CRM, +3.03% said it raised its revenue forecast for fiscal 2008 to $710 million to $720 million. The San Francisco business services firm had previously said it expected 2008 revenue of $700 million to $710 million. The stock closed Monday up 2 cents at $38.55. E.W. Scripps' networks ops revenue up 17% in November (8:15 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- E.W. Scripps Co. SSP, -0.99% Tuesday said its Scripps Networks' businesses posted a 17% rise in revenue in November to $96 million. Scripps Networks includes the company's national cable and satellite television networks, such as HGTV, Food Network and Fine Living. Cincinnati-based Scripps said its newspapers business posted revenue of $61.8 million for the month, down from $62.4 million a year ago. The company's television station group had revenue of $39.6 million in November, up 26% from last year, mainly due to strength in political advertising. The stock closed Monday at $50.34, down 16 cents. Best Buy profit rises, but short of analysts' view (8:11 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Best Buy Inc. BBY, +2.09% the nation's largest consumer-electronics retailer, said Tuesday that third-quarter income rose to $150 million, or 31 cents a share, from $138 million, or 28 cents, a year ago. Sales for the three months ended Nov. 25 advanced to $8.47 billion from $7.34 billion last year. Same-store sales, or sales at stores open at least a year, gained 4.8%. Analysts, on average, expected Best Buy to post earnings of 35 cents a share on sales of $8.42 billion. The Minneapolis company said "a very competitive climate" put pressure on its margins, but affirmed its outlook for full-year earnings of $2.65 to $2.80 a share. Analysts' estimate stands at $2.81 a share. Continental sees 6% capacity rise, 1%-3% revenue gain (8:07 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Continental Airlines Inc. CAL, -0.62% said Tuesday it estimates a 6% total rise in capacity, or available seat miles, in the fourth quarter, compared to the same period a year ago. The Houston-based company forecasts a fourth-quarter domestic load factor, or the ratio of seats filled with paying passengers, of 83% to 84%, and an overall load factor of 79% to 80%. In a federal filing, Continental added that its fourth-quarter consolidated cost per available seat mile, an industry measure of operating expenses, would be 11.44 to 11.49 cents; its profit-sharing pool had grown to $106 million; and that its mainline advanced booked seats for the next six weeks would be flat compared to last year. December total revenue is expected to increase 1% to 3%. Imperial Sugar swings to profit, declares $3 special payout (7:58 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) - Imperial Sugar Co., IPSU Sugar Land, Texas, reported that it swung to a fiscal fourth-quarter profit from a year-earlier loss and declared a $3 special dividend. For the quarter ended Sept. 30, Imperial earned $15.7 million, or $1.36 a share, compared with a loss of $20.3 million, or $1.92, in the year-earlier period. Continuing operations produced earnings of $1.34 compared with a loss of 26 cents. Sales reached $240.3 million, up 6.1% from $226.6 million. In a statement, Imperial said gross-profit margin widened to 15.5% from 4.7%, primarily because of higher sales prices, offset by higher energy, freight and raw-sugar costs. The special dividend, which comes in addition to the company's regular dividend, is payable Jan. 5 to holders of record Dec. 26. Looking ahead, Imperial said fiscal 2007 prices and margins probably will lag 2006 levels, offset partly by reduced raw-sugar and energy costs. The combination of factors leads the company to believe it can "maintain a profit outlook that is superior to historical averages," Imperial said. Hexcel sees revenue rising 5% to 10% (7:41 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Hexcel Corp. HXL, +0.67% said it expects the impact of the A380 aircraft delivery delays to continue to hurt it performance during the fourth quarter and through the first-half of 2007. For all of 2007, the Stamford, Conn. structural materials company said it expects revenue to rise 5% to 10% over 2006, with revenue from its commercial aerospace and space & defense divisions growing 10%. The company also said it expects to record consolidation and restructuring costs of $8 million to $9 million, with $6 million to $7 million of the total to be recorded in the fourth quarter. The stock closed Monday down 6 cents at $18.13. Indevus to buy Valera Pharma in $120 million stock deal (7:24 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Indevus Pharmaceuticals Inc. IDEV, +0.97% said Tuesday it will acquire Valera Pharmaceuticals Inc. VLRX, -4.93% in a move to boost its presence in the urology and men's health category and leverage its national sales force. The deal is valued at about $7.75 a share in stock, or about $120 million, plus payments of up to $3.50 a share based on product milestones. Valera shares last traded at $5.41 a share. Upon completion of the deal and subject to the approval of the Indevus board, James Gale, Valera's chairman and chief investment officer of the Corporate Opportunities Funds and Life Sciences Opportunities Fund, affiliates of Sanders Morris Harris, will join the Indevus board. Sanders Morris Harris is currently the largest shareholder of Valera. Separately, Indevus and Valera have entered into a co-promotion agreement under which Indevus' sales force will co-promote Valera's prostate cancer drug Vantas in the U.S. SkyWest Nov. revenue passenger miles up 12% (7:13 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- SkyWest Inc. SKYW, +0.83% said November revenue passenger miles increased by 12.2%. Available seat miles increased 8.3%. The combined airlines generated approximately 1.3 billion revenue passenger miles for the month, while available seat miles increased to approximately 1.7 billion. Load factor was up 2.6% to 76.7%, compared to 74.1% last year. Factory Card & Party seeks in increase shareholder value (6:52 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Factory Card & Party Outlet Corp. FCPO said it was exploring strategic alternatives to increase shareholder value, including the potential sale of the company. The Naperville, Ill. retail party chain also said it lost $17,000, or 1 cent a share in its third quarter, narrower than the $1.2 million, or 39 cents a share, it lost a year earlier. Revenue rose to $57.1 million from last year's $56.2 million, as same-store sales grew 0.1%. The company said Halloween sales were lower than expected. The stock closed Monday up 36 cents at $7.52. Remy Cointreau operating profit up 7% on champagne, cognac (3:15 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Remy Cointreau(FR:013039)said first-half ending Sept. 30 operating profit rose 7% to 58.9 million euros ($77.6 million), while revenue fell to 254 million euros from 353 million euros, or up 1.3% on a comparable basis when excluding its discontinued Polish operations. On a comparable basis, its champagne profit jumped 49% on increased Piper-Heidsieck prices, volumes and improved product/market mix, while its cognac operating profit rose 39% on selling more premium versions of Remy Martin cognac. For the first time it announced the charges for terminating the Maxxium distribution, saying it will have to pay 240 million euros before tax. Remy Cointreau confirmed its target of double-digit organic growth in profit from operations for the 2006/07 financial year. Cadbury sees '06 margins in line; CEO out at Nigeria unit (2:49 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Cadbury Schweppes, the U.K. drinks and candy producer, said it expects 2006 results in line with its estimates. It sees revenue growth in the middle of its target range and underlying profit margins broadly similar to those of the year earlier. The company said these estimates exclude the Nigeria unit, at which a financial review is continuing. Cadbury said in a statement that the review so far shows "a significant and deliberate overstatement" of the Nigeria unit's "financial position over a number of years. The [chief executive] and finance director have been relieved of their positions. A complete review of the business has been initiated by the board of Cadbury Nigeria." The unit expects to report one-time charges for the current and prior years of around 55 million to 60 million British pounds. The Nigeria unit previously said it expected an operating loss of 5 million to 10 million pounds. Club Med profit edges up on first revenue rise in four years (2:49 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Tour operator Club Mediterranee(FR:012156)said fiscal year net profit edged up to 5 million euros from 3 million euros, with the group growing revenue for the first time in four years with 6% growth to 1.68 billion euros. It said by having an "upmarket" strategy it was able to grow revenue despite a disappointing market environment in France and flat demand in Europe. Revenue per available bed rose 9%, driven by a 57% rise in 4-trident villages RevPAB. It said its new business model targeted to the upscale market will be completed by the end of 2008, with plans as well to boost online sales, use management contracts in unstable regions, use condominium-style financing and develop villas. Winter 2007 bookings are up 10.2%, it added. More from MarketWatch What Picking Up an Apple Tells You About the Future of Robotics More Coverage This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition Don’t ever do this with your credit card Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- ABM Industries Inc. ABM, +0.75% Tuesday evening said fourth-quarter net income rose to $61.6 million, or $1.24 a share, from $8.43 million, or 17 cents a share, during the same period in the prior year. Quarterly revenue rose to $776.7 million from $658.7 million in the prior year. For fiscal 2007, the facility services contractor said it sees income from continuing operations of $1 to $1.05 per share, and earnings before items of $1.10 to $1.15 per share. Also, ABM's board raised the quarterly cash dividend 9% to 12 cents per share. The dividend is payable Feb. 5 to shareholders as of Jan. 12. The board has also authorized a buyback for up to two million ABM shares.
title: ABM quarterly income up; board OKs dividend hike, buyback

content: ABM Industries quarterly profit falls; updates outlook (7:09 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- ABM Industries Inc. ABM, +0.75% late Wednesday reported third-quarter net earnings of $17.3 million, or 35 cents a share, compared with $34.8 million, or 69 cents a share, during the year-ago period. Earnings from continuing operations were $17.3 million, or 35 cents a share, vs. $20.6 million, or 41 cents a share, a year ago. The San Francisco-based provider of janitorial, parking, security, engineering and lighting services posted revenue of $689.3 million compared with $650.1 million. ABM Industries said it expects fiscal 2006 earnings from continuing operations of $1.80 to $1.85 a share, which includes about $45 million, or 90 cents a share, for the settlement of the business interruption insurance claim related to the destruction of the World Trade Center complex in New York City. Spartech to restate some results after excluding charge (6:11 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Spartech Corp. SEH, -3.91% late Wednesday said it has restated its financial statements to exclude $8.8 million of the non-cash fixed-asset charge previously recorded during fiscal 2005. The amount was related to equipment that was determined to no longer exist based on the physical counts completed in fiscal 2005. The company said its previously issued 2005 and prior financial statements should no longer be relied upon, pending the restatement. The restatement has no impact on financial results reported for fiscal 2006, Spartech noted. The company expects to file the full restatement as soon as possible in its fourth quarter. Spartech quarterly profit more than doubles; raises outlook (5:51 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Spartech Corp. SEH, -3.91% late Wednesday reported third-quarter net earnings of $10.6 million, or 33 cents a share, compared with $4.42 million, or 14 cents a share, during the year-ago period. Per-share earnings before stock-option expenses and special items were 46 cents vs. 30 cents a year ago. The maker of plastic compounds posted revenue of $377.7 million vs. $348.7 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had forecast third-quarter earnings of 34 cents a share on revenue of $361 million. Spartech said it expects fourth-quarter per-share earnings of 31 cents to 37 cents. For fiscal 2006, the company raised its outlook, saying it now sees earnings of $1.38 to $1.44 a share. Both forecasts include stock-option expenses but are before the impact of special items. Autodesk to buy France's Robobat for $33 million cash (5:14 PM ET) LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) -- Autodesk Inc. ADSK, +0.83% late Wednesday said it agreed to acquire France's Robobat for $33 million in cash. Autodesk said the deal is not expected to impact its expected fiscal 2007 per-share profit, exclusive of one-time items. Based in Grenoble, France, Robobat is a privately held maker of software for structural engineering analysis, design, and steel and concrete detailing. Palm lowers first-quarter revenue outlook (5:01 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Palm Inc. PALM, -2.60% after Wednesday's closing bell said it now expects first-quarter revenue of $354 million to $356 million, down from its previous forecast of revenue between $380 million and $385 million. The Sunnyvale, Calif.-based company said the revenue shortfall was primarily due to lower Treo volumes in carrier retail channels. Palm said it still expects per-share earnings of 13 cents to 14 cents, or 18 cent to 19 cents on a pro forma basis, in line with its previous outlook. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call are currently estimating first-quarter earnings of 19 cents a share on revenue of $383 million. Casella Waste swings to a quarterly loss; expenses rise (4:44 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Casella Waste Systems Inc. CWST, -0.04% after Wednesday's closing bell said it swung to a first-quarter net loss as operating expenses rose. The solid waste management services company said the quarterly net loss applicable to shareholders was $934,000, or 4 cents a share. During the same period in the prior year, net income applicable to shareholders was $2.26 million, or 9 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected a per-share loss of 3 cents. Casella said quarterly revenue rose to $143.5 million from $132 million in the prior year. The company added that it sees fiscal 2007 revenue of $550 million to $570 million. BEA Systems delays filing quarterly results on options probe (4:39 PM ET) LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) -- BEA Systems Inc. BEAS late Wednesday said it would delay filing its quarterly results with regulators due to its previously announced internal probe of its stock-option practices. The San Jose, Calif., corporate software company said it would file its results with regulators on a so-called Form 10-Q "as soon as practicable" after it completes the review. Nevertheless, the company said it doesn't expect to meet a Sept. 11 deadline for filing the results for the period, ended July 31. Martek Biosciences swings to a quarterly gain; revenue rises (4:34 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Martek Biosciences Corp. MATK after Wednesday's closing bell said it swung to third-quarter net income as revenue gained. The company said quarterly net profit was $5.3 million, or 16 cents a share. During the same period in the prior year, the company reported a net loss of $109,000, or breakeven on a per-share basis. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected a per-share result of 15 cents. Martek said quarterly revenue rose to $70.4 million from $39.5 million in the prior year. Analysts had expected a result of $69.6 million. For the fourth quarter, the company sees revenue of $63 million to $66 million, and net income per share of 9 cents to 12 cents. Analysts are looking for revenue of $74.8 million, and a per-share result of 20 cents. Martek sees fiscal 2006 net income per share of 62 cents to 65 cents, with analysts looking for 70 cents. LVMH first-half profit surges 46% (3:41 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton(FR:012101)on Wednesday reported first-half net earnings of 817 million euros ($1.05 billion) up 46% from 559 million euros last year. Operating profit at the Paris-based luxury goods maker surged 35% to 1.26 billion euros. The company reported a 13% increase in profit from recurring operations in its fashion and leather goods business group, and an 11% increase in its wines and spirits group. The company also confirmed that it expects a "very significant increase in results for 2006." In July, LVMH reported a 13% rise in first-half revenue to 6.97 billion euros. Furniture Brands lowers quarterly earnings outlook (1:57 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Furniture Brands International Inc. FBN on Wednesday said it now expects third-quarter earnings of 9 cents to 13 cents a share on revenue that's slightly positive vs. the year-ago period. The earnings outlook includes the effect of 7 cents of previously disclosed restructuring, asset impairment and severance charges, as well as the effect of 3 cents in increased interest expense due to the upfront recognition of the gain on interest rate swaps at the end of the first quarter. The effect of a reversal of $1.8 million in tariffs paid on products from certain offshore vendors wasn't reflected in the forecast, among other items, the company said. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call are currently estimating third-quarter earnings of 29 cents a share on revenue of $566 million. Cherokee quarterly earnings rise 8% (1:32 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Cherokee Inc. CHKE, +1.96% on Wednesday reported second-quarter net earnings of $4.94 million, or 56 cents a share, up 8% from $4.58 million, or 52 cents a share, during the year-ago period. The Van Nuys, Calif.-based company posted royalty revenue of $12.4 million vs. $11.3 million. Two analysts polled by Thomson First Call had forecast second-quarter earnings of 58 cents a share on revenue of $12 million. Cherokee is a marketer, licensor and manager of a variety of brands, including Cherokee, Sideout and Carole Little. Komag shares tumble on lower third-quarter revenue view (12:40 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Komag Inc. KOMG dropped almost 15% to $30.86 on Wednesday after the company lowered its financial outlook for the third quarter, saying demand for the current quarter has been slower than the normal seasonal pattern. The San Jose, Calif., maker of thin-film media for disk drives said it now sees sequential revenue growth of 3% in the third quarter with its net margin within a range of 14% to 16%, including stock compensation expense. The company's previous view was for growth of about 5% with net margins of between 16% and 17% for the period. The news weighed on shares of hard disk drive makers Seagate Technology STX, +2.87% down almost 8% to $20.50, and Western Digital Corp. WDC, +1.62% losing 7.5% to $16.96. Carrier Access lowers quarterly outlook, shares fall (11:19 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Carrier Access Corp. CACS, -0.15% were down more than 29% at $6.40 in late morning trading on Wednesday. On Tuesday, Carrier Access said it now expects a third-quarter per-share net loss of 14 cents to 19 cents, or a loss of 11 cents to 16 cents on a pro forma basis, on revenue of $16 million to $18 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call are currently forecasting third-quarter earnings of a penny a share on revenue of $25 million. The Boulder, Colo.-based broadband-technology provider said it lowered its outlook after order flow and bookings in August were significantly below previous quarters. Bookings and associated shipments during the month were impacted by one customer ordering less than previously anticipated, the company added. Corning narrows third-quarter growth, earnings forecasts (9:21 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Corning Inc. GLW, +1.94% said Wednesday narrowed its third-quarter growth forecast for volume in its liquid crystal display glass unit to 10% to 15%, up from 5% to 15%. LCD volume growth at Samsung Corning Precision Co. was narrowed to 8% to 12% from the previous range of 5% to 15% growth. Corning said third-quarter earnings would be 24 cents to 26 cents a share, up from a previous range of 22 cents to 26 cents a share. Third-quarter sales are now forecast at $1.27 billion to $1.31 billion from the previous $1.26 billion to $1.33 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call forecast earnings, on average, of 25 cents a share in the third quarter and sales of just less than $1.3 billion. Pathmark Stores posts wider loss (7:54 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Supermarket operator Pathmark Stores Inc. PTMK said Wednesday its second-quarter loss widened to $8.8 million, or 17 cents a share, from $5.1 million, or 12 cents, a year ago. Sales for the three months ended July 29 rose fractionally to $1 billion, while same-store sales, or sales from stores open at least a year, gained 0.5%. Three analysts polled by Thomson First Call expected the Carteret, N.J., company, on average, to post a loss of 12 cents a share on sales of $1.01 billion. Pathmark said results were hurt by lower pharmacy profitability because of the new Medicare Part D program, higher costs for utilities, self-insured workers' compensation and general liability claims, and medical and pension costs, among other expenses. Haverty Furniture Aug. same-store sales up 10% (7:38 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Haverty Furniture Company Inc. HVT, +3.33% on Wednesday said August same-store sales rose 10.3%. Total sales for the month rose 13% to $77 million. Clean Energy Fuels files $288 mln IPO (7:31 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Clean Energy Fuels Corp. on Wednesday filed to raise up to $288 million in an initial public offering with underwriters W.R. Hambrecht and Simmons & Company International. The Sea Branch, Calif. builder of natural gas filling stations for automobiles and trucks plans to trade on the Nasdaq under the symbol "CLNE". Billionaire Boone Pickens is listed as one of the founders of the company, which promotes natural gas as a cheaper and cleaner fuel compared to gasoline and diesel. Panera Bread reduces sales growth target (7:22 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Panera Bread Co. PNRA said Wednesday that August same-store sales rose 1.3%. The company cut its third-quarter same-store sales growth target to 2% to 3% from 3% to 4%. Fairchild Semiconductor ups sales outlook (7:08 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Fairchild Semiconductor FCS, +1.96% said it raised its estimate for sequential third-quarter sales to flat to up 2%, as continued healthy order rates has led to lower-than-anticipated cancellation rates. The South Portland, Maine high-performance power products company had previously expected sequential sales to be just flat. Over the previous four years, third-quarter sales had averaged a sequential decline of 2%. The stock closed Tuesday up 17 cents at $18.02. French bank Credit Agricole's profit climb 34% (2:38 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- French bank Credit Agricole(FR:004507)said second-quarter net income rose 34% to 1.28 billion euros ($1.6 billion), after 21% growth in net banking income and after taking its cost-to-income ratio down to a record low of 59.8% from 65.1% last year. By division, a 36% improvement in profit from its asset management, insurance and private banking division and a 48% profit lift from its corporate and investment bank offset a 37% profit fall from its share of French regional bank profits and a 109 million euro loss from its investments. It said its approval of Banca Intesa's merger with SanPaolo IMI is conditional on an agreement which "safeguards and enhances" the bank's strategic interests in Italy. Tullow Oil profit up 51%, on track to meet production target (2:37 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Independent oil and gas producer Tullow Oil Plc(UK:TLW)on Wednesday said first-half net profit rose 51% to 95.4 million pounds as revenue climbed 54% to 311 million pounds.
