The company said it sees year-end production at 75,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day from a current level of about 70,000 boepd. Tullow Oil doubled its interim dividend to 2 pence a share. Carillion profit down 28%, sees 2006 beating expectations (2:36 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. construction group Carillion(UK:CLLN)said Wednesday that its first-half net profit slipped 28% to 10.1 million pounds ($19.3 million), after taking a 13 million pound charge for amortization and goodwill impairment. Pretax profit before one-off items rose 23% to 24.7 million pounds following a 71% rise in revenue to 1.73 billion pounds. Carillion said the revenue figure reflected the acquisition of peer Mowlem as well as organic growth. It added it now sees the company's performance in 2006 slightly exceeding its previous expectations. Carillion also announced it has agreed to sell its stake in eight partnerships between the public and private sectors to two funds for 46 million pounds. The sales should generate a profit of 22 million pounds, the company added. Bouygues raises 06 sales target as it posts 1H profit up 47% (2:30 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- French construction, media and telecoms conglomerate Bouygues(FR:012050)on Wednesday said first-half net profit rose 47% to 565 million euros on a strong perfomance at its construction and infrastructure divisions. Sales climbed 9% to 12.05 billion euros. Sales rose in every division except Bouygues Immobilier, its property development arm, which is expected to recover in the second half. Margins are expected to suffer at the telecoms division in the second half because of "significant commercial investments," the group said. Bouygues raised its sales target for the year to 26 billion euros from an earlier forecast of 25.8 billion euros. Chief Executive Martin Bouygues said he has never before witnessed such a favorable situation concurrently in all the group's businesses in terms of both sales and commercial activity. Accor profit climbs 54%, conducting Red Roof Inn review (2:27 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Hotels owner Accor(FR:012040)said first-half net profit rose a stronger-than-forecast 54% to 241 million euros ($310 million), or 1.06 euros a share with operating profit before tax and non-recurring items up 37%. Accor had previously reported that revenue rose 8% to 3.4 billion euros, or up 6% on a comparable basis. Accor sees 2006 operating profit before tax and non-recurring items between 680 million and 700 million euros for the year, a rise of more than 20% on a proforma basis. It also reported that in July and August, revenue per available room climbed 10.4% in Europe upscale and midscale hotels, 6.3% in Europe economy hotels and 3.6% in U.S. economy hotels. The company said it's planning 500 million euros in investments into its services business by 2010, plans to create a new brand for non-standardized economy hotels in Europe, is having a strategic review of the Red Roof Inn, plans to sell 3.2 billion euros of property by 2008 and will open 200,000 rooms at a cost of 2.5 billion euros by 2010. Swiss Life profit up 14%, tops expectations (2:24 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Pensions and life insurance group Swiss Life(CH:001485278)said Wednesday that its first-half net profit rose 14% to 511 million Swiss francs ($426 million). Analysts had been expecting profit in a range of 411 million francs to 505 million francs, according to an AFX News-compiled poll. The profit growth followed a 9% increase gross written premiums to 12.7 billion francs, with the company also benefiting from 124 million francs of tax provisions being written back into the figures and 50 million francs from disposals. The group said it cut its operating expenses by 4% to 1.47 billion francs, partly due to a reduction in work force. Heineken profit climbs 26%, helped by Premium Light (2:19 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Dutch brewer Heineken N.V.(NL:00916)said first-half profit rose 26% to 433 million euros ($557 million), with revenue up 12% to 5.74 billion euros and beer volume also up 12%. It sold over 300,000 hectoliters (63.4 million pints) of Heineken Premium Light in the U.S. by the end of the year, putting it on track for 2006 sales 50% above its original forecast and giving a boost to sales of Heineken lager. The company's cost-cut program to slash 200 million euros of costs by the end of 2008 is on track, it said. For the year, it stuck to its recently upgraded comparable profit before interest and amortization forecast of "slightly above 10%" following a 13.7% rise by that measure in the first half, though it said it's going up against a more challenging comparison in the second half of the year. It's holding its dividend payment to 0.16 euros a share. More from MarketWatch How to Run a Better Meeting: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- ABM Industries Inc. ABM, +0.75% late Wednesday reported third-quarter net earnings of $17.3 million, or 35 cents a share, compared with $34.8 million, or 69 cents a share, during the year-ago period. Earnings from continuing operations were $17.3 million, or 35 cents a share, vs. $20.6 million, or 41 cents a share, a year ago. The San Francisco-based provider of janitorial, parking, security, engineering and lighting services posted revenue of $689.3 million compared with $650.1 million. ABM Industries said it expects fiscal 2006 earnings from continuing operations of $1.80 to $1.85 a share, which includes about $45 million, or 90 cents a share, for the settlement of the business interruption insurance claim related to the destruction of the World Trade Center complex in New York City.
title: ABM Industries quarterly profit falls; updates outlook

content: Advancers Abercrombie & Fitch ANF, +2.41% shares surged 14% Wednesday after the company late Tuesday reported second-quarter net earnings of $65.7 million, or 72 cents a share, vs. $57.4 million, or a 63 cents a share, in the same period last year. See full story. ABM Industries ABM, +0.75% shares rose 6% after the company said it settled a World Trade Center legal dispute with insurer Zurich Financial Services for $80 million. The payment, due in September, will increase ABM's net income in the quarter ending Oct. 31 by roughly $45 million, or 90 cents a share. Shares of Celadon Group Inc. CLDN, +0.00% rallied 9% after Morgan Keegan upgraded the truckload carrier to outperform from market perform, citing "attractive" valuation, expectations of margin improvement and accelerating growth opportunities. Charming Shoppes Inc. CHRS, -1.34% shares climbed 11% said second-quarter net profit fell 17% to $32.6 million, or 24 cents a share, while net sales rose 10.8% to $763.4 million. Same-store sales for the company's retail brands rose 2% during the quarter. The company said its gross margin for the quarter was hit by higher levels of promotional activity and the inclusion of a full quarter of catalog operations, compared to just two months of operations in the year-ago quarter. The figures also include a $3.6 million, or 3 cents a share, expense related to the opening of new stores. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were expecting earnings of 25 cents a share on sales of $764 million. Leap Wireless International Inc. LEAP shares added 5.4% after the company said that it has entered into forward sale agreements for the sale of 5.6 million shares to affiliates of Goldman, Sachs & Co. and Citigroup Corporate and Investment Banking, who are offering 5.6 million shares in a public offering at $42.00 a share. The underwriters have been granted an option to purchase up to 840,000 shares to cover over-allotments. Leap intends to use the net proceeds, if any, for general corporate purposes and working capital. InnerWorkings INWK, +0.44% surged 16% in its stock market debut. See full story. Parlux Fragrances Inc. PARL shares soared 26% after the company said it has entered has entered into a letter of intent to sell its Perry Ellis fragrance rights to Victory International LLC. The letter of intent is subject to the execution of a definitive agreement, the Fort Lauderdale, Fla.-based company noted. The letter provides for Victory to pay Parlux a total of up to $140 million, $120 million for the fragrance rights and up to $20 million for inventory, the company said. Pep Boys PBY, -2.02% shares climbed 10% after the company reported second-quarter earnings from continuing operations of $1.47 million, or 3 cents a share, compared with $832,000, or a penny a share, during the year-ago period. Revenue at the Philadelphia-based auto parts retailer rose to $578.6 million from $577.4 million a year ago. Shares of SpectraLink Corp. SLNK shot up 8% after Morgan Keegan upgraded the workplace wireless telephony company to outperform from market perform, saying the company's operational outlook makes the current valuation "compelling." Talbots Inc. TLB, -5.71% shares gained 11% after the company said it swung to a second-quarter loss, hurt by acquisition costs and stock option expenses. The Hingham, Mass.-based retailer posted a net loss of $3.86 million, or 7 cents a share. In the year-ago period it earned $18.88 million, or 35 cents a share. Net sales rose to $571.4 million from $449.6 million. Analysts, on average, expected it to post a loss of 8 cents a share on revenue of $576 million, according to Thomson First Call. Total company same-store sales rose 1.3% for the second quarter. Decliners Casella Waste Systems Inc. CWST, -0.04% shares fell 10% Wednesday after it reported preliminary fiscal first-quarter results. The Rutland, Va.-based company said it expects a first-quarter loss of 2 cents to 4 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call are forecasting a per-share profit of 7 cents. Casella said its results were impact by record rainfall in the northeast. The company added that its overall first-quarter revenue is on track, with the exception of its southeastern region. Casella also forecast fiscal 2007 earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization of $113 million to $117 million. Daktronics Inc. DAKT, +0.00% shares tumbled 28% after the company posted net earnings of $5 million, or 12 cents a share, for its fiscal first quarter 2007, compared with earnings of $4.6 million, or 11 cents a share, the year earlier. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were on average expecting earnings of 16 cents. Net sales rose to $92.2 million from $72.3 million the year earlier. The Brookings, S.D.-based company said it expects earnings for its fiscal second-quarter to come in a range of 13 to 18 cents per share. The Thomson First Call forecast is for earnings per share of 18 cents. Shares of Daktronics were recently at $21.86, down $9.02 in pre-market activity. Golfsmith International Holdings Inc. GOLF, +0.09% shares lost 12% reported a second-quarter net loss of $7.94 million, or 73 cents a share. During the same period a year ago, the Austin, Texas-based company posted net earnings of $6 million, or 60 cents a share. Mills Corp. MLS, -1.38% shares lost 20% said in a filing late Tuesday that it has terminated Mark Ettenger as president of the company effective Aug. 11. Mills said Ettenger remains employed at the firm, but did not specify his role in the filing. Additionally, the company said James Napoli, executive vice president of leasing, has delivered notice he will terminate his employment effective on or before Oct. 27. Mills is being investigated by the SEC over accounting problems and has indicated it is exploring strategic options including a potential sale of all or part of the company. Shares of Optical Cable Corp. OCC, +3.10% fell 9.7% after the company rejected an unsolicited proposal from Superior Essex Inc. to acquire the company for $6 a share. The proposal is the same as a private proposal from Superior Essex first received by Optical Cable on Aug. 1, which was considered by the board and rejected as financially inadequate, the company noted. Shanda Interactive Entertainment Ltd. SNDA lost 5.3% after the company reported second-quarter net earnings of 133.6 million yuan ($16.7 million), or 1.86 yuan (24 cents) per American Depositary Share, compared with 223 million yuan, or 3.06 yuan per ADS, during the year-ago period. Tween Brands TWB shares fell 5.3% after the company reported a 49% jump in second-quarter earnings and backed its previous full-year forecast. See full story. More from MarketWatch Uber for Bikes Could Save Your Commute More Coverage My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers S&P 500 logs longest losing streak of the year as trade-war jitters weigh Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Wednesday's biggest stock gainers and decliners

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Among the companies whose shares are expected to see active trade in Wednesday's session are Hewlett-Packard Co., Applied Materials Inc., and Abercrombie & Fitch Co. BEA Systems Inc. BEAS is expected to report second-quarter earnings of 12 cents a share, according to analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Big Lots Inc. BLI is expected to post a per-share net loss of 6 cents in the second-quarter. Daktronics Inc. DAKT, +0.00% is expected to report first-quarter earnings of 16 cents a share. Estee Lauder Companies Inc. EL, +2.53% is expected to post fourth-quarter earnings of 48 cents a share. Gymboree Corp. GYMB is expected to report second-quarter per-share earnings of 3 cents. Hewlett-Packard HPQ, +1.06% is expected to post per-share earnings of 47 cents in the third quarter. Network Appliance Inc. NTAP, +3.73% is expected to report first-quarter earnings of 23 cents a share. Ross Stores Inc. ROST, +2.39% is expected to post second-quarter per-share earnings of 32 cents. Salesforce.com Inc. CRM, +3.03% is expected to report per-share earnings of 4 cents in the second quarter. Synopsys Inc. SNPS, +1.14% is expected to post third-quarter earnings of 19 cents a share. Applied Materials Inc. AMAT, +2.87% said its quarterly net income rose 39% from a year ago as the company sold more machines that make chips used in personal computers and other consumer electronics. The world's largest maker of chip equipment reported fiscal third-quarter net income of $512 million, or 33 cents a share, up from $369.6 million, or 23 cents a share, in last year's same period. Watch List Abercrombie & Fitch ANF, +2.41% reported second-quarter net earnings of $65.7 million, or 72 cents a share, vs. $57.4 million, or a 63 cents a share, in the same period last year. ABM Industries ABM, +0.75% said that it settled a World Trade Center legal dispute with insurer Zurich Financial Services for $80 million. The payment, due in September, will increase ABM's net income in the quarter ending Oct. 31 by roughly $45 million, or 90 cents a share. American Power Conversion Corp. APCC said Rodger Dowdell, Jr. is retiring as president and chief executive, effective immediately. The West Kingston, R.I.-based power solutions provider named Rob Johnson as interim president and CEO. Applied Materials Inc. APCC said that Nancy Handel, chief financial officer and senior vice president, plans to retire, effective Jan. 5. Brooks Automation Inc. BRKS, +1.92% said it has filed an amended Form 10-Q quarterly report for its first fiscal quarter of 2006 ended Dec. 31, 2005, bringing it current on SEC filings. Cheesecake Factory Inc. CAKE, +0.46% said it had delayed the filing of its Form 10-Q due to a review of its stock-option practices. The Calabasas Hills, Calif.-based restaurant operator also said the review's preliminary results indicate potential adjustments are likely to result in a restatement of financial results for the fiscal year ended Jan. 3 and for the quarter ended April 4, among others. Chevron Corp. CVX, +1.73% said its Australian unit has successfully bid for rights to deepwater natural-gas exploration off Western Australia. China Finance Online Co. JRJC, -0.89% reported second-quarter net earnings of $442,000, or 2 cents per American Depositary Share, compared with $1.01 million, or 5 cents, in the same period last year. It also named Jun Wang as chief financial officer. F5 Networks FFIV, +1.40% said it has received a noncompliance letter from Nasdaq indicating it is subject to delisting because it did not file Form 10-Q for the quarter ended June 30 on time. GlobalSantaFe Corp. GSF, +0.28% said it has closed a 5-year, $500 million revolving credit facility. The new facility will be used for general corporate purposes, the Houston-based provider of offshore oil and gas drilling and drilling management services said. Golfsmith International Holdings Inc. GOLF, +0.09% reported a second-quarter net loss of $7.94 million, or 73 cents a share. During the same period a year ago, the Austin, Texas-based company posted net earnings of $6 million, or 60 cents a share. Inco Ltd. N (N) said its board will evaluate Teck Cominco Ltd.'s TCK (TCK.A) amended acquisition offer when it is made available, and will issue a recommendation to its shareholders. Earlier Tuesday, Teck Cominco raised its bid for fellow Canadian mining company Inco, offering to pay as much as C$89 a share in what it called its "best and final offer." Jones Apparel Group Inc. JNY said its board has decided not to pursue a sale of the company. The Bristol, Pa.-based apparel designer and marketer said that the company will continue the execution of its strategic plan instead. La-Z-Boy Inc.'s LZB, -2.76% first-quarter earnings fell, dragged down by a drop in casegoods sales, the company said Tuesday. The company said net income was $2.3 million, or 4 cents a share, on sales of $418.9 million vs. last year's profits of $3.2 million, or 6 cents a share, on sales of $428.9 million. Limited Brands Inc. LTD, +0.52% said Chief Financial Officer Ken Stevens has decided to retire. The Columbus, Ohio-based apparel retailer said Martyn Redgrave, chief administrative officer, will assume CFO responsibilities. Linn Energy LLC LINE said it swung to net earnings of $10.2 million, or 36 cents a share, in the second quarter, on the back of strong revenue growth. In the same period last year, the Pittsburgh-based oil and gas company posted a net loss of $5.28 million, or 26 cents a share. Microtune Inc. TUNE, +0.90% said it will request a hearing before Nasdaq in response to a noncompliance letter the company received from the exchange due to the delayed filing of its Form 10-Q for the quarter ended June 30. Pep Boys PBY, -2.02% reported second-quarter earnings from continuing operations of $1.47 million, or 3 cents a share, compared with $832,000, or a penny a share, during the year-ago period. Revenue at the Philadelphia-based automotive aftermarket retail and service chain rose to $578.6 million from $577.4 million a year ago. PetSmart PETM earned $34.6 million, or 25 cents a share, in its fiscal second quarter - down slightly from the $35.7 million, or 24 cents, recorded in the year-ago period. Included in the per share figure is 1 cent worth of expenses related to a potential acquisition and 1 cent for a one-time distribution expense. Pfizer Inc. PFE, +0.54% said its Chief Executive Jeffrey Kindler is establishing a new organizational structure that will include a new executive team. Vice Chairman David Shedlarz will expand his responsibilities and Vice Chairman Karen Katen will leave the company. Photronics Inc. PLAB, +1.23% reported third-quarter net earnings of $4.56 million, or 11 cents a share, compared with $14.8 million, or 35 cents a share, in the same period last year, as the company's flat panel display business slowed down. Rambus Inc. RMBS, +0.67% said that former Chief Executive Geoff Tate plans to resign from the board. Tate was CEO and the sole member of the board's stock option committee plans during a period in which the company has found flaws in how it accounts for the cost of stock options. Shanda Interactive Entertainment Ltd. SNDA reported second-quarter net earnings of 133.6 million yuan ($16.7 million), or 1.86 yuan (24 cents) per American Depositary Share, compared with 223 million yuan, or 3.06 yuan per ADS, during the year-ago period. Western Gas Resources Inc. WGR said it has received the last remaining regulatory approval required to close its merger with a subsidiary of Anadarko Petroleum Corp. Wilsons The Leather Experts Inc. WLSN reported a second-quarter net loss of $24.5 million, or 63 cents a share, compared with a net loss of $14 million, or 36 cents a share, in the same period last year. Zoran Corp. ZRAN said it has received a non-compliance letter from Nasdaq indicating that the company's stock is subject to delisting because it did not file its Form 10-Q for the quarter ended June 30 on time. More from MarketWatch How to Get a Job: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue Don’t ever do this with your credit card Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Hewlett-Packard, Applied Materials, Abercrombie & Fitch

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- ABM Industries ABM, +0.75% said late Tuesday that it settled a World Trade Center legal dispute with insurer Zurich Financial Services zfsvy for $80 million. The payment, due in September, will increase ABM's net income in the quarter ending Oct. 31 by roughly $45 million, or 90 cents a share, the company said. The settlement resolves ABM's business-interruption insurance claims for losses it incurred from the destruction of the World Trade Center in 2001, the company added. ABM provided janitorial, engineering, and lighting services in the buildings. ABM said it will have received $95.2 million from Zurich in claim payments for its commercial insurance policy covering business interruption, property damage, and other losses related to the World Trade Center attacks.
title: ABM settles World Trade Center suit vs. Zurich for $80mln

content: Robbins & Myers quarterly profit rises (7:49 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Robbins & Myers Inc. RBN, +0.00% late Wednesday reported fiscal second-quarter net earnings of $1.2 million, or 8 cents a share, vs. $51,000, or breakeven on a per-share basis, in the year-ago period. Excluding restructuring charges, the per-share profit was 21 cents compared with 11 cents. Revenue at the Dayton, Ohio-based company rose to $150 million from $145.6 million last year. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had forecast revenue of $148 million. The company expects fiscal third-quarter earnings of 22 cents to 27 cents a share, and fiscal 2006 earnings of 80 cents to 90 cents a share. Both forecasts exclude restructuring charges. ABM Industries quarterly income falls; OKs 2M share buyback (6:53 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- ABM Industries Inc. ABM, +0.75% Wednesday evening said first-quarter net income was $3.99 million, or 8 cents a share, less than $5.48 million, or 11 cents a share, during the same period in the prior year. The facility services contractor said quarterly revenue was $666.6 million, up from $638.2 million. ABM added that it has filed its 2005 10-K after a delay. For the fiscal year, sales and other income totaled $2.59 billion, compared with $2.38 billion in 2004. Net income was $57.9 million, or $1.15 a share, up from $30.5 million, or 61 cents a share, in 2004. Also on Wednesday, ABM said it has approved a buyback program of up to 2 million shares through Oct. 31, 2006. Ruby Tuesday quarterly profit up 10%; revenue rises (5:31 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Ruby Tuesday Inc. RI, +5.40% after the closing bell on Wednesday reported third-quarter net earnings of $30.2 million, or 50 cents a share, up 10% from $27.5 million, or 42 cents a share, during the year-ago period. Revenue at the Maryville, Tenn.-based restaurant chain rose to $338.6 million from $289.2 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had forecast third-quarter earnings of 46 cents a share on revenue of $334 million. During the third quarter, comparable sales at company-owned restaurants rose 4.7%, and were up 5.4% at its domestic franchise restaurants. For the fourth quarter, Ruby Tuesday said it now expects per-share earnings growth of 25% to 30%. The company had previously forecast growth of 20% to 22.5% for the period. For fiscal 2007, Ruby Tuesday said it sees per-share earnings growth within the lower end of its long-term goal of 12.5% to 15%. Resources Connection quarterly profit rises (4:40 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Resources Connection Inc. RECN, +0.62% was up 2.3% in after-hours trading Wednesday. After the closing bell, the company reported fiscal third-quarter net earnings of $13.8 million, or 27 cents a share, up from $13.2 million, or 26 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue at the Costa Mesa, Calif.-based professional services firm rose 19% to $160.3 million from $135.2 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had forecast earnings of 28 cents a share on revenue of $159 million. Arrow quarterly profit more than doubles; revenue up 7% (4:32 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Arrow International Inc. ARRO after the closing bell on Wednesday reported second-quarter net earnings of $12.6 million, or 28 cents a share, compared with $5.35 million, or 12 cents a share, during the year-ago period. Revenue at the Reading, Pa.-based medical device company rose 7% to $116.5 million from $109.2 million. Arrow said it reduced its second-quarter operating results by 3 cents a share to reflect changes in its accounting for U.S. shipping terms. For the third quarter, Arrow expects per-share earnings of 33 cents to 35 cents on targeted revenue of $122 million to $126 million. Additionally, the company sees fiscal 2006 earnings of $1.26 to $1.30 a share on targeted revenue of $476 million to $484 million. Thomas Weisel quarterly income falls (3:52 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Thomas Weisel Partners Group Inc. TWPG on Wednesday said fourth-quarter net income was $7.1 million, down from $13.5 million in the prior year. Quarterly income attributable to shareholders was $2.99 million, down from $9.47 million. The investment bank, which completed its initial public offering on Feb. 7, said quarterly revenue was $73.7 million, compared with $73.1 million in the prior year. The company did not provide per-share figures. Omni Energy Services swings to quarterly profit; rev flat (11:54 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Omni Energy Services Corp. OMNI on Wednesday reported fourth-quarter net earnings of $100,000, or a penny a share. During the same period a year ago, Omni posted a net loss of $9.99 million, or 88 cents a share. Net income from continuing operations was $800,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter. A year ago, the net loss from continuing operations was $3.6 million, or 31 cents a share. Revenue for the quarter was $11.1 million, unchanged from a year ago. IHS shares rally; co. sees FY revenue growth of 8-10% (11:44 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of IHS Inc. IHS, -1.23% gained 15% to $27.95 on Wednesday after the Englewood, Colo., technical information provider reported first-quarter earnings of $13.5 million, or 24 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $13.1 million, or 23 cents a share. Revenue rose 11% in the latest three months to $129.9 million from $117 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 24 cents a share in the February period. Looking ahead, the company lifted its outlook for the full year, forecasting organic revenue growth of 8% to 10%. CORRECT: Sempra Energy sees FY07 earns 3.50-$3.70 a share (11:26 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Sempra Energy SRE, +0.81% Wednesday forecast earnings of $3.50 to $3.70 a share for fiscal 2007. The current average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for a profit of $3.67 a share in the period. The San Diego energy services company also set a target for earnings of $4.20 to $4.75 a share in fiscal 2010. The company made the comments ahead of a conference with financial analysts. Sempra also said it expects capital spending of about $2.3 billion for 2006, and an average annual capital spending of about $2 billion for 2007 through 2010. The stock closed Tuesday at $46.77, up 10 cents. (A previous version of this incorrectly stated the company lifted its financial outlook for fiscal 2007.) Eastman Kodak to stop x-ray film coating ops at French site (10:32 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Eastman Kodak Co. EK said Wednesday it will stop x-ray film coating operations and the associated production of film base at its plant in Chalon-sur-Saone, France, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The closure will be completed in the coming months, and the operations will be transferred to other company plants with available capacity. Roughly 330 jobs will be affected, Eastman Kodak said. The company will take a related restructuring charge of $85 million, and will record an additional $1 million in operational charges. Crown Media Holdings 4Q losses $59.8M vs $129M (9:01 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Crown Media Holdings CRWN, -1.41% Wednesday posted a fourth-quarter loss of $59.8 million, or 57 cents a share, narrower than a year-ago loss of $129 million, or $1.23 a share. Revenue rose 39% in the latest three months to $60.5 million from $43.6 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of two analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a loss of 37 cents a share in the December period. Studio City, Calif.-based Crown Media, which operates the Hallmark Channel and other cable television channels, said the results for the latest quarter reflect a $2.6 million impairment of film assets. The stock closed Tuesday at $5.68, down 3.9%. Guidant to suspend stent, to take charge (8:33 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Medical device maker Guidant Corp. GDT said Wednesday it would not release its current Xience V stent inventory because a small percentage of it was not manufactured to its quality standards. As a result, Guidant said it voluntarily stopped enrolling new patients in the 4.0 mm and the Japan arms of the non-randomized portion of its Spirit III clinical trial, which is designed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the Xience V Everolimus Eluting Coronary Stent System for the treatment of coronary artery disease. Guidant said it would re-supply units to investigators as soon as new inventory is available. The company will not utilize existing inventories and will rebuild devices for SPIRIT III and the upcoming European launch. This will result in a first-quarter charge of about $15 million to write-off existing Xience V inventory and will delay the European launch of Xience V until the third quarter of 2006 CGI Group plans to cut 1,000 jobs in 2006 (8:29 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- CGI Group Inc. GIB, +1.66% said Wednesday it plans to eliminate roughly 1,000 jobs in 2006, primarily in Montreal and Toronto locations. The company attributed more than half of the layoffs to lower than expected work volumes with Bell Canada Enterprises, or BCE, and said the remainder of the cuts relate to adjustments of its cost base. It plans to make 500 of the layoffs immediately, and implement the rest by the end of the year. CGI believes acceleration and expansion of its Global Delivery Model will create about 400 jobs, partially offsetting the reductions. The Montreal-based provider of information technology and business process services expects BCE-related revenue for the second quarter will be significantly lower than previously anticipated on a sequential basis. The company noted its business with BCE is currently tracking slightly below the minimum guaranteed levels on an annualized run rate basis. CGI anticipates a pre-tax charge of C$90 million to be recorded over the next year related to severance and other initiatives. Steelcase net income rises 11x (8:05 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Steelcase Inc. SCS, +0.00% on Wednesday reported fourth-quarter net income of $11.2 million, or 8 cents a share, up sharply from $1 million, or a penny a share in the year-ago period. Revenue rose 7% to $739.3 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call forecast earnings of 11 cents a share and revenue of $735.6 million. The Grand Rapids, Mich. company said it expects first-quarter earnings of 10-to-15 cents a share, including restructuring charges of less than $5 million after-tax, compared to earnings of 5 cents a share in the year-ago period. Analysts are expecting earnings of 15 cents a share for the first quarter. Steel Tech. provides earnings, revenue outlook (7:08 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Steel Technologies STTX, +0.00% said it expects fiscal second-quarter earnings of 21 cents a share and revenue of $250 million. In the fiscal first quarter, earnings were 25 cents a share on revenue of $212.6 million. Shipments for the quarter ending March are estimated to be 320,000 tons, which is in line with prior projections. The steel producer's stock closed Tuesday down 16 cents at $24.52. Meade Instruments sees wider loss; confidentiality pact set (6:45 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Meade Instruments Corp. MEAD revised lower its loss forecast for fiscal 2006. The Irvine, Calif.-based designer and manufacturer of optical products including telescopes said it now estimates a net loss of up to $5 million, or 25 cents a share, for the year ended Feb. 28, wider than the loss of up to 5 cents a share previously projected. Meade also pegged full-year revenue at $120 million to $122 million, as opposed to about $120 million previously. The company's incurring "significant costs" related to outside management consultants as well as executive-search consultants helping Meade management seek out a new chief executive, said Harry Casari, chairman. He added that Meade's aiming to return to profitability in fiscal 2007. In addition, the company announced a confidentiality agreement with Hummingbird Management, Meade's largest shareholder. The pact grants Hummingbird certain observation rights concerning the business and operations of the company, with Hummingbird in turn agreeing not to seek a seat on the company's board of directors at the 2006 annual meeting. Shares of Meade Instruments lost 7 cents, or 2.4%, to end Tuesday's trading at $2.79. HealthSouth reports 05 loss, ends accounting reconstruction (6:39 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- HealthSouth Corp. HLSH said in a 10-K filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that its 2005 net loss was $446 million, including a previously disclosed $215 million non-cash charge relating to a preliminary litigation settlement. HealthSouth said the process of reconstructing its historical accounting records is now complete. The health-care clinic operator has been embroiled in a long-running scandal over inflated earnings figures, which saw former CEO Richard Scrushy cleared of charges including accounting fraud. Bombardier quarterly profit up 54% as revenue slides (6:20 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Canadian aerospace and transportation conglomerate Bombardier Inc.(CA:BBDMVA)said fourth-quarter net profit rose 53.6% to $86 million, or 5 cents a share, while revenue slipped 14.6% to $4.04 billion. The company said it had focused on cutting costs, resulting in a $2.5 billion reduction in net debt. Bombardier added it has seen increasing demand for business jet and turboprop aircraft, while demand for its 50-seat regional jets has fallen. The company said it will continue to focus on cost savings during 2007 and will also increase its presence in fast-growing transportation segments, including services and signalling. Spanish retailer Inditex annual profit climbs 26% (1:46 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Inditex SA(ES:014839601), the Spanish conglomerate that owns the Zara, Pull & Bear and Massimo Dutti retailers, said annual profit rose 26% to 803 million euros, with sales up 21% to 6.74 billion euros and same-store sales up 5%. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were expecting a profit of 801 million euros on revenue of 6.94 billion euros. It will pay a 0.52 euros a share dividend alongside an extraordinary payment of 0.15 euros a share, Inditex added, and it plans to pay out 50% of its earnings in dividends starting in 2006. It expects to open between 410 and 490 stores in 2006. (Updates to include future dividend payment plan.) Barratt six-month net profit nudges higher (1:39 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. homebuilder Barrat Developments Plc(UK:BDEV)said Wednesday that net profit in the second half of 2005 rose slightly to 114.8 million pounds ($200.7 million) from 114.4 million pounds. Revenue for the period rose 2% to 1.17 billion pounds and the company said it intends to increase its interim dividend by 15% to 10.34 pence a share. Barratt said its wide geographical spread, use of brownfield sites and growth of social housing all contributed to the performance. The company added it has a land bank of 63,365 plots, which equates to 4.3 years supply. Barratt said the market remains competitive, but there have been positive signs in the first weeks of 2006 that buyer confidence is improving. It added current conditions are sufficient to meet its targets. Woolworths swings to profit while sales fall (1:24 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. retailer Woolworths Group Plc(UK:WLW)said Wednesday that it swung to a 2005 net profit of 10.2 million pounds ($17.8 million), or 0.7 pence a share. The company reported a loss of 8.1 million pounds in 2004. Total sales from continuing operations fell 4.1% to 2.63 billion pounds as same-store sales fell 3.9%. The company said it had managed to significantly reduce costs, but noted that sales fell due to the closure of some out-of-town stores and reduced floor space at other stores. Woolworths said it will raise its final dividend by 6.3% to 1.34 pence a share. The company also said it will continue to focus on cost controls because it expects competition to remain fierce over the next 12 months. Ahold profit drops 86%, lowers retail targets (1:23 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Royal Ahold AHO (NL:33181), the Dutch and U.S. supermarkets operator and catering firm, said its fourth-quarter profit fell 86% to 108 million euros, or 0.07 euros a share, after a year-ago option gain and results from discontinued operations, with sales up 0.3% to 10.83 billion euros. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were looking for earnings of 0.07 euros on revenue of 10.9 billion euros. But it said the targets it set back in 2003 have become "increasingly challenging," and it now expects comparable sales in its retail arms to rise between 2.5% and 3% and that its operating margin willl be between 4% and 4.5%. More from MarketWatch How to Get a Job: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 Don’t ever do this with your credit card Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- ABM Industries Inc. ABM, +0.75% Wednesday evening said first-quarter net income was $3.99 million, or 8 cents a share, less than $5.48 million, or 11 cents a share, during the same period in the prior year. The facility services contractor said quarterly revenue was $666.6 million, up from $638.2 million. ABM added that it has filed its 2005 10-K after a delay. For the fiscal year, sales and other income totaled $2.59 billion, compared with $2.38 billion in 2004. Net income was $57.9 million, or $1.15 a share, up from $30.5 million, or 61 cents a share, in 2004. Also on Wednesday, ABM said it has approved a buyback program of up to 2 million shares through Oct. 31, 2006.
title: ABM Industries quarterly income falls; OKs 2M share buyback

content: Lone Star Steakhouse profit rises 31% as revenue dips (9:04 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Lone Star Steakhouse & Saloon Inc. STAR, +0.89% late Monday reported fourth-quarter net earnings of $13.8 million, or 60 cents a share, up 31% from $10.5 million, or 47 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue at the Wichita, Kan.-based company fell to $202.9 million from $204.8 million, while same-store sales fell 0.5%. CORRECT: Sonus Networks reports $5M fourth-quarter profit (8:15 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Sonus Networks Inc. SONS on Monday reported a fourth-quarter profit of $5 million, or 2 cents a share, on revenue of $57.2 million. During the same period a year ago, the maker of Voice Over Internet Protocol technology earned $6.3 million, or 2 cents a share, on $45.1 million in revenue. (Corrects to reflect that the company is a maker of Voice Over Internet Protocol technology.) Alpharma swings to a quarterly gain (6:45 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Alpharma Inc. ALO, -1.52% Monda evening said fourth-quarter net income was $87.1 million, or $1.62 a share. During the same period last year, the company reported a net loss of $307.5 million, or $5.89 a share. The speciality pharmaceutical company said quarterly revenue was $156.4 million, up from $132.3 million last year. For 2006, Alpharma expects per-share income from continuing operations of $1.25 to $1.35. H&R Block delays filing 3Q 10-Q; updates restatement (6:32 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- H&R Block Inc. HRB, +1.03% has delayed filing its quarterly report on form 10-Q as it continues analyzing its state income tax expense to determine the final restatement adjustment, the company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission late Monday. The provider of tax preparation services previously said that it would restate its results for the fiscal years 2004 and 2005, plus previous 2006 quarters, mainly because of errors in calculating its state effective income tax rate. The mistakes resulted in H&R Block understating its state income tax liability by about $32 million as of the end of April 2005, the company had said. In its filing, H&R Block said it has recorded a state tax return error of $4.3 million in the second quarter of 2005. As part of the restatement, the error will now be recorded in the 2004 and 2005 fiscal years. Additionally, the company said it has discovered errors resulting in an understatement of state income tax liability for calendar tax year 2004 of about $10 million. As a result of the recalculated 2004 state income tax effective rate based on actual tax year returns, H&R Block updated the estimate used to calculate the state income tax provision for January 2005 to April 2005. The change in estimate resulted in a $17.5 million increase in income tax liability for the period, the company said. SMTC swings to a profit as revenue rises 21% (5:04 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- SMTC Corp. SMTX, +1.58% after Monday's closing bell reported fourth-quarter net earnings of $1.42 million, or 10 cents a share. In the year-ago period the company reported a net loss of $3.2 million, or 22 cents a share. Revenue at the Toronto-based electronic manufacturing services provider rose 21% to $58.1 million from $48 million. Miva swings to quarterly loss; revenue falls 27% (4:55 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Miva Inc. MIVA, -2.70% were trading down 5% to $4.38 after the closing bell on Monday. Miva reported a fourth-quarter net loss of $4.66 million, or 15 cents a share. During the same period a year ago, the company posted net earnings of $4.75 million, or 15 cents a share. The adjusted net loss was 2 cents a share for the quarter. A year ago, adjusted earnings were 20 cents a share. Revenue at the marketing network company fell 27% to $43 million from $58.7 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had forecast a fourth-quarter loss of a penny a share on revenue of $43 million. Miva said it expects a first-quarter per-share loss of 7 cents to 10 cents, or a penny to 4 cents on an adjusted basis, on revenue of $43 million to $45 million. Analysts are currently looking for first-quarter earnings of 2 cents a share on revenue of $46 million. NGAS quarterly income falls (4:47 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- NGAS Resources Inc. NGAS, +1.44% after Monday's closing bell said fourth-quarter net income was $564,000, or 3 cents a share, down from $619,000, or 4 cents a share, during the same period last year. The natural gas developer said quarterly revenue was $15.7 million, down from $15.73 million last year. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected revenue of $20 million. Int'l DisplayWorks quarterly income rises; names Bedewi CFO (4:32 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- International DisplayWorks Inc. IDWK after Monday's closing bell said first-quarter net income was $1.4 million, or 4 cents a share, up from $1.02 million, or 3 cents a share, during the same period last year. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected per-share income of a penny. The manufacturer of liquid crystal displays said quarterly revenue was $23.5 million, up from $18.1 million last year. Analysts were looking for revenue of $22 million. For the second quarter, International DisplayWorks expects revenue of $24 million to $30 million, with analysts looking for $30 million. The company also named Joe Bedewi chief financial officer. Bedewi succeeds Jeff Winzeler, who became chief operating officer in December 2005. Procter & Gamble raises dividend, narrows forecast (4:31 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - Consumer products giant Procter & Gamble Co. PG, +0.56% on Monday raised its dividend to 31 cents a share from 28 cents, and confirmed previously announced target for sales growth and earnings per share for the third quarter. The company narrowed its earnings per share forecast to 59 cents to 61 cents a share, including 7 cents to 10 cents a share dilution related to the Gillette acquisition and said sales growth for the quarter is currently trending toward the mid point of its previous 20% to 23% range. Mercury Computer to cut 80 jobs in bid to pare costs (4:21 PM ET) LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) -- Mercury Computer Systems Inc. MRCY, +2.42% late Monday said it would cut 80 jobs, or about 8% of its workers globally, as it looks to cut costs on previously revised growth expectations. Mercury said the cuts would be made across its business units and are expected to save it over $7 million a year. The company, which makes real-time digital signal processing systems for the defense and medical imaging segments, expects to take a charge of around $2 million, which it will accrue in its fiscal third quarter ending March 31, related to the job cuts, it said. The company will provide further details on its latest quarterly results and financial outlook for the rest of the year on April 27. Chipmos Tech reports higher profit, sales (4:19 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Chipmos Technologies late Monday reported fourth-quarter net income of $14.5 million, or 21 cents a share, up from $3.2 million, or 5 cents a share, for the same period last year. Revenue rose 16% to $130.4 million. Chipmos IMOS, +0.00% a Taiwan-based maker of chip equipment, said first-quarter revenue will be in the range of $127 million to $130 million. Gaiam swings to a quarterly profit (4:19 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Gaiam Inc. GAIA, -1.59% after Monday's closing bell said fourth-quarter net income was $1.48 million, or 7 cents a share. During the same period last year, the company reported a net loss of $564,000, or 4 cents a share. The media company said quarterly revenue was $64.3 million, up from $34.8 million last year. Gaiam added that it expects 2006 revenue of more than $200 million, with annual gross margins of 60%. BellSouth sees after-tax job cuts charge totalling $107M (3:11 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- BellSouth Corp. BLS, +0.00% now expects the amount of charges recorded in 2005 and 2006 related to job cuts to total $107 milion after taxes, according to a filing Monday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Charges of $100 million related to the expected workforce reduction of 1,300 to be taken in connection with BellSouth's acquisition by AT&T Corp. T, +0.25% will be recorded in 2006, the telecom giant said, with $85 million of it to be taken in the second quarter. Also as a result of the AT&T deal, BellSouth has modified the terms of its previously announced job cuts plan by eliminating an involuntary component. The firm is subsequently largely reversing a $52 million related charge taken in the fourth quarter of 2005 by recording a $45 million after-tax credit to its first-quarter income. The charge for the early termination benefit will be recorded in the second quarter upon acceptance of the offer by the affected employees, BellSouth said in the filing. Aftermarket Tech revises 1Q EPS, FYO6 revenue forecasts (11:48 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Aftermarket Technology Corp. ATAC, -0.60% on Monday said it now expects to report first-quarter earnings from continuing operations of 23 cents to 25 cents a share, citing the impact of a 5-cent per-share charge related to deferred debt, the recognition of its independent aftermarket business as a discontinued operation, and soft demand for remanufactured transmissions. The Downers Grove, Ill.-based provider of outsourced engineered solutions and supply chain logistics services also increased its full-year 2006 revenue forecast, to $440 million to $465 million, on expectations of further growth in its logistics business and a return to stabilized demand patterns for its Drivetrain customers. Aftermarket Tech said it still expects to post earnings from continuing operations of $1.50 to $1.60 a share for the full-year period. Analyst: Adobe results seen slightly above average estimate (11:03 AM ET) LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) -- Adobe Systems Inc. ADBE, +1.67% is likely to report quarterly results slightly ahead of the average of analysts' estimates, Piper Jaffray analyst Gene Munster said on Monday. The average estimate calls for the company to post a profit of 29 cents a share on revenue of $650.1 million, according to a Thomson First Call survey. Adobe's fiscal first-quarter results, nevertheless, are likely to fall within the company's forecasted range that calls for a profit before items of 28 cents to 30 cents on revenue of $630 million to $660 million, according to Munster. He maintained an outperform rating on the shares with a $45 price target and said Adobe is "entering a strong product year in 2006." Adobe, which makes the nearly ubiquitous Acrobat digital-document sharing software program, is scheduled to report financial results on March 22. Pinnacle Entertainment buys Aztar for $2.1B (9:43 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Pinnacle Entertainment Inc. PNK, +0.57% said Monday it will acquire Aztar Corp. AZR, -8.33% for about $2.1 billion, or $38 a share in cash. The deal, which includes about $1.45 billion in equity and about $723 million in debt, represents a premium of 24% to Aztar's Friday closing price. The gaming companies expect the deal to close by the end of the year. Trizec sells First Citizens Plaza for $77.3M (9:30 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Real estate investment trust Trizec Properties Inc. TRZ, +0.54% said it has sold First Citizens Plaza in Charlotte, N.C. to Osprey Ltd for $77.3 million. Trizec said it expects to recognize a gain on the disposal of the 23-story office building of approximately $32 million during the first quarter of 2006. ABM Indus. updated outlook falls short of expectations (9:10 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- ABM Industries ABM, +0.75% said it now expects fiscal first-quarter earnings of 7 cents a share, and 2006 earnings of 85 cent to 95 cents a share. The updated outlook is a result of disappointing results, anticipated future losses from a previously-acquired business and professional fees associated with an ongoing independent investigation into accounting errors. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting first-quarter earnings of 15 cents a share and 2006 earnings of $1.13 a share. The facility services contractor's stock closed Friday up 3 cents at $18.74. Stewart Enterprises reverses loss with $8.4M net income (8:52 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Stewart Enterprises Inc. STEIE reported first-quarter earnings Monday of $8.4 million, or 8 cents a share, reversing a loss in the year-earlier period of $145.3 million, or $1.33 a share. The company said adjusted income for those periods in 2006 and 2005 would have been 9 cents a share and 8 cents a share, respectively. In the three months ended Jan. 31, the funeral services and cemetery operator said sales rose 3% to $126.6 million. CRA International sees earnings of 47 cents a share (8:50 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- CRA International Inc. CRAI, +2.69% said Monday it expects first-quarter profit of about $5.6 million, or 47 cents a share, on revenue of $72.5 million. Analysts' average estimate stands at 45 cents a share, according to Thomson First Call. The Boston financial and business consulting firm released preliminary results ahead of a presentation scheduled for Monday afternoon. Vail Resorts earns, revenue rise (8:46 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Vail Resorts MTN, -0.91% reported fiscal second-quarter earnings of $43 million, or $1.12 a share, up from $32.2 million, or 89 cents a share in the year-ago period. Excluding certain one-time items, earnings would rose to $1.15 a share from last year's 90 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 94 cents a share, on average. Revenue rose 8.8% to $288 million from $264.6 million, as a 15% increase in mountain revenue and 23% growth in real estate revenue helped offset a 25% decline in lodging revenue. The company said it set a stock repurchase program of up to 3 million shares of common stock. The mountain resort operator's stock closed Friday up $1.27 at $35.28. AM Castle quarterly profit more than triples (8:40 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AM Castle & Co. CAS, +1.29% said Monday that fourth-quarter profit more than tripled to $7.3 million, or 39 cents a share, from $2.1 million, or 12 cents, a year ago. Sales for the three months ended Dec. 31 rose to $227.3 million from $197.8 million in last year's fourth quarter. The company, of Franklin Park, Ill., distributes specialty metals and plastics. Alaska Airlines fleet to become all Boeing 737 by 2008 (8:23 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Alaska Airlines ALK, +0.63% said Monday it would take a charge of $130 million to $150 million in the first quarter to accelerate the retirement of its MD-80 planes in favor of an all-Boeing 737 fleet by the end of 2008. Alaska plans to spend about $750 million to take delivery of 39 737-800s over the next two years. After the transition is complete, the airline expects to save $115 million in expenses. The charge reflects a reduction in the carrying value of the MD-80 aircraft to fair market value. Dominos ups 2006 earnings by 6c a shr after stock purchase (7:38 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Domino's Pizza DPZ, -0.13% on Monday said it has repurchased 5.6 million shares of its stock held by private equity firm Bain Capital. The value of the stake is about $145 million, the company said. The transaction reduced Bain's stake in the company to 28% from 34%. The shares purchased will not decrease the company's publicly-available shares, since it was a private transaction. Domino's management estimates that the transaction will increase its 2006 earnings per share by approximately 6 cents for the remainder of the year. Computer Horizons quarterly loss widens (7:31 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Computer services company Computer Horizons Corp. CHRZ said its fourth-quarter net loss widened to $39.5 million, or $1.24 a share, from $24.3 million. Revenue for the quarter slipped 2.7% to $65.8 million. The fourth-quarter loss included special charges of $36.6 million related to restructuring and losses on the sale of investments. Computer Horizons said that it expects to report modest profitability in the first quarter of 2006 following its restructure. For the whole of 2006 it expects revenue in the range of $280 million to $290 million and earnings in the range of 20 cents to 25 cents a share. SafeNet restates 2005 second-quarter earnings (7:24 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- SafeNet Inc. SFNT restated Monday its 2005 second-quarter earnings. The security software company said it now made a loss of 20 cents a share compared with a loss of 15 cents a share reported earlier. The company already announced in a Feb. 2 press release a restatement of its 2005 fourth-quarter earnings due mainly to adjustments in the carrying value of its deferred income tax assets and liabilities and an additional adjustment to lease exit costs. In the Feb 2 press release, SafeNet cut its fourth-quarter earnings by 3 cents to 25 cents a share. On Monday, the stock rose 18 cents to $24.38. Jackson Hewitt reiterates profit targets (7:14 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Jackson Hewitt JTX on Monday said it continues to see 2006 earnings of $1.51-$1.56 a share, and revenue of $260-$265 million. Bovis Homes 2005 pretax profit slips 19.8% (2:29 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. house builder Bovis Homes Group(UK:BVS)said Monday that 2005 pretax profit fell 19.8% to 116.1 million pounds ($201.1 million) as revenue from continuing operations fell 6.8% to 521.1 million pounds. The company said in 2005 it focused on building a larger number of smaller, more affordable homes in response to the challenging market. The group said its operating margin fell to 24% from 27.1% in 2004. It added it plans to increase its total dividend by 25% to 25 pence a share. Bovis Homes also said that reservations level so far in 2006 have been "encouraging." Northern Foods warns on profit, to conduct review (2:28 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. convenience foods maker Northern Foods(UK:NFDS)said it's fiscal year profit before tax and exceptional items will fall to around 45 million pounds from 62.2 million pounds, as sales in the first two months of the fourth quarter ending April 1 have been very disappointing. Underlying sales for continuing operations have been flat, hurt by a downturn in the biscuit market and by changing pastry eating habits. It's now undertaking a strategic review to examine the business model, product portfolio and cost base, with a plan to present the review at a May 1 shareholder meeting. More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? More Coverage Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’ Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- ABM Industries ABM, +0.75% said it now expects fiscal first-quarter earnings of 7 cents a share, and 2006 earnings of 85 cent to 95 cents a share. The updated outlook is a result of disappointing results, anticipated future losses from a previously-acquired business and professional fees associated with an ongoing independent investigation into accounting errors. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting first-quarter earnings of 15 cents a share and 2006 earnings of $1.13 a share. The facility services contractor's stock closed Friday up 3 cents at $18.74.
title: ABM Indus. updated outlook falls short of expectations

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- ABM Industries Inc. ABM, +0.75% said late Thursday it expects adjustments to its preliminary fiscal 2005 financial statements to reduce net income by $4.4 million from the figures it reported on Dec. 14. The company now expects fiscal 2005 net income of $65.1 million and income from continuing operations of $50.7 million. The San Francisco-based provider of janitorial, parking, security, engineering and lighting services said it also expects to revise its fiscal year 2006 forecast.
title: ABM: Adjustments to cut FY05 net earns by $4.4M

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- ABM Industries Inc. ABM, +0.75% reported Wednesday evening fourth-quarter earnings of $15.1 million, or 30 cents a share, compared with $3.65 million, or 7 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter. The facility services contractor reported quarterly revenue of $658.7 million, compared with $619.8 million last year. The company's outlook for income from continuing operations for fiscal 2006 is a range of $1.08 to $1.14 a share, exclusive of future acquisitions, and including 6 cents of stock-based compensation expense.
title: ABM Industries quarterly earnings surge

content: LONDON (MarketWatch) -- IBM IBM, +0.60% said its part of a 1.8 billion euro, five-year IT contract that was announced earlier this morning by Dutch bank ABN Amro ABN, +8.33% nl:30110 is valued at 1.5 billion euros ($1.85 billion).
title: IBM portion of ABN Amro contract worth 1.5B euros

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- ABM Janitorial Services, a unit of ABM Industries Inc. ABM, +0.75% said on Friday that it has been awarded a multiyear, multimillion dollar contract renewal with Midwest Generation, a unit of Edison International EIX, +0.94% The contract covers comprehensive janitorial service and maintenance for three power-generating facilities located in Illinois. San Francisco-based ABM Janitorial operates in 42 states.
title: ABM Janitorial renews Midwest Generation contract

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- ABM Industries Inc.'s ABM, +0.75% janitorial services division said Friday it has renewed a multi-year, multi-million contract with Lambert-St. Louis International Airport. Terms weren't disclosed.
title: ABM Janitorial, St. Louis Int'l Airport renew contract

content: ABM Industries quarterly profit rise; ups 2005 view (7:01 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- ABM Industries Inc. ABM, +0.75% after Tuesday's closing bell reported second-quarter net earnings of $10.5 million, or 20 cents a share, compared with $7.3 million, or 15 cents a share, in the same quarter last year. Revenues rose to $628.8 million from $569.6 million. The San Francisco-based facility services contractor said it expects to realize a $21 million pre-tax gain in the third quarter from the sale of CommAir Mechanical Services and that, combined with continuing operational strength, prompted ABM to increase its full-year 2005 per-share net income forecast to a range of $1.17 to $1.23. Sierra Wireless to exit Voq Pro phone initiative (6:42 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Sierra Wireless Inc. SWIR, +1.54% after Tuesday's closing bell said that it plans to exit its Voq Professional Phone initiative and will shift some of its Voq resources over to its core PC card and embedded modules business. Although the Vancouver, Canada-based wireless company's second-quarter operating results are tracking in-line with the forecast issued in late April, Sierra Wireless expects to incur restructuring charges associated with these moves, including possible employee severance expenses, impairment of inventory and other assets and contractual liabilities. Sierra Wireless employs 319 people, of which 55 have been working directly on the Voq product. Of those 55, 15 will be transferred to programs in the core business, while others will remain working on the Voq product until its end. La-Z-Boy swings to Q4 profit on 6.3% higher revs (5:17 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- La-Z-Boy Inc., LZB, -2.76% the Monroe, Mich., furniture producer, swung to a fourth-quarter profit from a year-earlier loss as revenue rose 6.3%. For the quarter ended April 30, La-Z-Boy reported earnings of $20.8 million, or 40 cents a share, compared with a loss of $42.1 million, or 80 cents, in the year-earlier period. Earnings from continuing operations for the latest quarter were 35 cents. The consensus estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call was 31 cents. The company's revenue climbed to $565.6 million from $532.2 million. La-Z-Boy reported that its operating-profit margin widened to 5.8% from negative 6.6%. La-Z-Boy estimated that in Q1, its weakest quarter of its fiscal year, it expected to earn 10 cents to 14 cents a share, against a year-earlier loss of 7 cents after a 12-cent charge. La-Z-Boy estimated that first-quarter revenue would rise low single digits in percent from the year-earlier $455 million. The company's shares rose 4 cents to $13.85 on Tuesday. Majesco Entertainment swings to quarterly profit (4:43 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Majesco Entertainment Co. COOL, +5.47% after Tuesday's closing bell reported second-quarter net earnings attributable to common shareholders of $189,000, or 1 cent a share. Last year, its loss attributable to common shareholders was $50.1 million, or $8.35 a share. The digital entertainment products and content provider reiterated its fiscal 2005 forecast for operating income of $16 million to $18 million on revenue of $175 million to $185 million. Texas Instruments lifts profit forecast (4:39 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Texas Instruments Inc. TXN, +1.94% late Tuesday lifted its second-quarter profit forecast. In its mid-quarter update, Texas Instruments projected earnings between 27 cents a share and 30 cents a share, up from a previous range of 25 cents a share to 29 cents a share. Its revenue forecast was lifted to the high end of its previous target. Texas Instruments predicts sales in the range of $3.12 billion to $3.24 billion, up from $3 billion to $3.24 billion. Martek Biosciences quarterly profit up 1%; rev up 33% (4:21 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Martek Biosciences MATK after Tuesday's closing bell reported fiscal second-quarter net earnings of $3.43 million, or 11 cents a share, compared with earnings of $3.4 million, or 11 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue was $55.8 million, up 33% from $41.9 million last year. Fortune Brands reaffirms 2Q, 2005 earns forecasts (11:30 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Fortune Brands Inc. FO, -1.47% on Tuesday reaffirmed its earnings forecast for the second quarter and full year 2005. The Lincolnshire, Ill. consumer goods conglomerate still sees double-digit growth on a per-share basis before charges and gains. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call expect Fortune Brands to report second-quarter earnings of $1.44 a share on revenue of $2.02 billion and 2005 earnings of $5.24 a share on revenue of $7.81 billion. Bakers Footwear quarterly profit more than doubles (10:12 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Bakers Footwear Group Inc. BRKS, +1.92% on Tuesday posted first-quarter net earnings of $1.85 million, or 33 cents a share, compared with $745,000, or 15 cents a share, in the same period last year. Revenue at the St. Louis-based footwear retailer came in at $44.9 million vs. $38.7 million, while same-store sales rose 7.8%. Stewart Enterprises posts Q2 loss; adj earns 15c vs 11c (9:36 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Stewart Enterprises Inc., STEI, +0.00% the Jefferson, La., provider of funeral merchandise and services, swung to a second-quarter loss from a year-earlier profit as revenue rose 4.2%. For the quarter ended April 30, the company posted a net loss of $4 million, or 4 cents a share, compared with earnings of $14.8 million, or 14 cents, in the year-earlier period. On an adjusted basis, Stewart earned 15 cents against 11 cents. Revenue reached $136.7 million from $131.1 million. School Specialty loss widens, while revenue rises (8:49 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- School Specialty SCHS, +16.67% reported a fiscal fourth-quarter loss of $8.4 million, or 37 cents a share, wider than the $6.1 million, or 32 cents a share it lost in the year-earlier period. Revenue rose 8.5% to $175.2 million from last year's $161.4 million, topping the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of $169.8 million. For fiscal 2006, the education services provider reiterated its revenue growth target of 4 to 7% to $1.04 billion to $1.07 billion. Earnings are expected to be $2.35 to $2.60 a share, surrounding analyst projections of $2.51 a share. The stock closed Monday down 9 cents at $46.74. Carreker Corp. reverses loss (8:49 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Carreker Corp. CANI, -13.55% reported first-quarter net income of $498,000, or 2 cents a share, reversing a net loss of $1.1 million, or 4 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The provider of payments technology and consulting services reported revenue of $28.2 million, down from $28.9 million, and said second-quarter revenue and operating income would "improve" over first-quarter levels. Shares of Carreker gained a penny Monday to $5.20. ConAgra lowers quarterly earnings expectations by 10c (8:28 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - ConAgra Foods CAG, +1.54% Tuesday said its fourth-quarter earnings per share result will be 10 cents below the company's prior estimate, citing weak packaged meats profits. Previously ConAgra said its fourth-quarter earnings would modestly exceed those of the third quarter, when it earned 32 cents a share, excluding 2 cents a share of items that impact comparability. The company said it is not providing a specific fourth-quarter profit estimate because the results are not yet final. The Thomson First Call analysts' average estimate is for earnings of 36 cents a share. ConAgra also said a headcount reduction program will save it $100 million in annual costs. On Monday shares of the Omaha packaged foods seller rose 7 cents to $25.89. Monsanto ups earns outlook (8:08 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Monsanto Co. MON, -0.05% raised its forecast for third-quarter earnings from continuing operations to $1.05 a share from $1 due to strength in its seeds and traits businesses. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 94 cents a share, on average. The agricultural products company said its full-year earnings forecast remained unchanged. The stock closed Monday down 12 cents at $58.80. Analogic profit rises sharply on asset sale gain (8:05 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Analogic Corp. ALOG, +1.75% Tuesday reported third-quarter net income of $28.1 million, or $2.07 a share, including a special $2.01 a share gain from a securities sale. A year earlier the company earned $1.1 million, or 8 cents a share. The recent quarter's results also include asset writedowns of $5.6 million. Revenue rose to $94 million from $89 million. On Monday shares of the Peabody, Mass. maker of medical subsystems rose 41 cents to $42.98. Columbus McKinnon turns a profit as revenue rises (7:45 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Columbus McKinnon CMCO, +0.93% reported fiscal fourth-quarter earnings of $8.3 million, or 56 cents a share, vs. a loss of $1.5 million, or 10 cents a share in the same period a year ago. The results include several special items, including gains from the sale of assets and discontinued operations, and a charge related to increased pension reserves. Revenue rose 19% to $144.5 million from last year's $121.2 million. The two analysts submitting revenue estimates to Thomson First Call had been expecting $126.7 million to $132.9 million. The maker of material handling products said it expects steady revenue growth over the next year. The stock closed Monday up 40 cents at $10.95. Sears Holdings swings to loss on accounting charge (7:37 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Sears Holdings Corp. SHLD, -4.98% the company formed from the merger of Kmart Holding Corp. and Sears, Roebuck and Co., swung to a first-quarter ending April 30 loss of $9 million, or 7 cents a share, hurt by a $90 million or 72 cent per share impact from accounting changes. Excluding the accounting move, earnings slowed to 65 cents a share from 94 cents a share, with revenue rising to $7.63 billion from $4.63 billion, the company said in a filing to the Securities and Exchange Commission. The results for the first quarter include approximately five weeks of Sears results and 13 weeks of Kmart's results. On a proforma basis as if the companies had been merged at the beginning of 2004, it swung to a $78 million, or 48 cents a share, loss, with revenue flat at $12.76 billion. American Woodmark profit drops as costs rise (7:20 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - American Woodmark Corp. AMWD, +3.04% Tuesday reported fourth-quarter net income of $7.4 million, or 44 cents a share, down from $8.4 million, or 50 cents a share, a year before, citing higher materials and transportation costs. The Thomson First Call average analysts' estimate was for earnings of 55 cents a share. Sales increased 15% to $207.1 million. The Winchester, Va. cabinet maker forecast first-quarter earnings a share of 30 cents to 40 cents; the First Call projection was for 61 cents. The company also authorized a new $10 million stock buyback. On Monday the company's stock rose $1.16 to $35.15. Albertson's 1Q profit beats Street view, rev. higher (6:48 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Food and drug retailer Albertson's Inc. ABS, +1.81% said first-quarter net income rose to $100 million, or 27 cents a share, from $36 million, or 10 cents a share. Sales grew 16% to $10 billion from $8.6 billion, with same-store sales up 1.8%. Earnings from continuing operations were 29 cents a share, ahead of Thomson First Call estimates of 27 cents a share, with revenue seen at $10.25 billion. Looking ahead, the company reaffirmed fiscal 2005 earnings from continuing operations guidance of between $1.37 to $1.47 a share. Same-store sales are expected to be positive for the year. UPDATE: LG.Philips signs $5B deal with H-P (5:52 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- LG.Philips LCD Co. LPL, +0.67% the joint venture between Korea's LG Electronics and Philips Electronics PHG, +0.79% (NL:00953), said it has has signed an agreement with computer manufacturer Hewlett-Packard Co. HPQ, +1.06% to be the primary supplier for notebook PC and monitor LCD panels over the next three years. Wire reports put the deal at $5 billion. "This deal is a substantial increase over the existing HP supply agreement," it said. (Updates pulse to include media reports that size of the deal was $5 billion.) Severn Trent FY net pft drops to GBP138.8M; div up 3.1% (2:40 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- British water utility Severn Trent PLC(UK:SVT)said Tuesday that fiscal 2005 net profit dropped to 138.8 million pounds, from 184.1 million pounds, after incremental pension charges of 31.3 million pounds, while sales rose 3.3% to 2.1 billion pounds. The company declared a 3.1% rise in its fiscal dividend to 48.51 pence. "We intend to maintain, as a minimum, dividends in real terms at least up to 2009/10," said John Egan, chairman. Carphone Warehouse:mobile services ops 'very promising' (2:28 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- British mobile phone retailer Carphone Warehouse PLC(UK:CPW)on Tuesday said its markets remain "very attractive" and the outlook for its mobile services operations is "very promising" as it reported fiscal year pre-tax profit before exceptional items and amortization of goodwill up 33.8% to 102.1 million pounds. Sales for the period increased 27.4% to 2.355 billion pounds. The results were in-line with the average forecast of analysts polled by AFX News. Carphone Warehouse said current trading was strong across all divisions with connections in the nine weeks to June 4 up 20%. The company lifted its dividend for the year to 1.8 pence a share compared to 1.3 pence a share a year ago. More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? More Coverage 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- ABM Industries Inc. ABM, +0.75% after Tuesday's closing bell reported second-quarter net earnings of $10.5 million, or 20 cents a share, compared with $7.3 million, or 15 cents a share, in the same quarter last year. Revenues rose to $628.8 million from $569.6 million. The San Francisco-based facility services contractor said it expects to realize a $21 million pre-tax gain in the third quarter from the sale of CommAir Mechanical Services and that, combined with continuing operational strength, prompted ABM to increase its full-year 2005 per-share net income forecast to a range of $1.17 to $1.23.
title: ABM Industries quarterly profit rise; ups 2005 view

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- ABM Industries Inc. ABM, +0.75% said after Friday's closing bell that on Thursday a Washington Court of Appeals upheld a state court 2003 jury's award to a former employee. In 2003, the same jury also returned a verdict in ABM's favor in the employment case of a second former employee. ABM said it will take a charge of $6.3 million to establish a reserve in a gender discrimination case against one of its janitorial companies, American Building Maintenance Co. - West. San Francisco-based ABM said it plans to appeal to the Washington State Supreme Court.
title: ABM unit loses appeal in Washington state

content: Advancers Able Laboratories ABRX gained more than 7 percent after the company reported fourth-quarter earnings of $6.2 million, or 32 cents a share, up from $2.4 million, or 13 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue was $31.4 million, compared with $22.8 million. Analysts expected earnings of 26 cents a share on revenue of $32 million. ABM Industries ABM, +0.75% surged more than 2 percent in afternoon action. The move comes after the San Francisco-based provider of facility services posted strong first-quarter earnings of $7.9 million, or 16 cents per share, amid a 13.4 percent increase in sales to $647.4 million. The company also authorized the buyback of up to 2 million shares of its common stock, increased its quarterly dividend by 5 percent, and said it has secured a renewal of its contract with the Minneapolis-St. Paul International airport. Adesa Inc. KAR, +0.71% shares added more than 1 percent after the provider of vehicle auctions services received an upgrade to "buy" from "neutral" from UBS. Adolor Corp. ADLR rose more than 16 percent after the company and partner GlaxoSmithKline GSK, -0.79% said initial results of a phase II trial of Enterg for the treatment of opioid-induced bowel dysfunction found the drug achieved statistically significant effects on both the primary and secondary endpoints of the study. Applied Signal Technology APSG shares advanced more than 5 percent after the company received an upgrade to "outperform" from Thomas Weisel. Cadence Design Systems CDN shares rose nearly 3 percent after Morgan Stanley lifted its rating on the San Jose, Calif., maker of electronic design automation software to "overweight" citing valuation.
