Checkpoint Systems' CKP, -1.02% shares jumped more than 11 percent after the company offered a bullish outlook for 2005, forecasting earnings of $1.15 to $1.25 per share on revenue growth of 5 to 7 percent. The current First Call average estimate is for full-year earnings of $1.06 per share. Checkpoint also posted a fourth-quarter loss of $29.3 million, or 78 cents a share, down from a profit of $4.5 million, or 13 cents a share, in the same period a year earlier. Excluding charges, the maker of source tagging and hand-held labeling systems would have earned 30 cents a share. Dendreon DNDN shares increased more than 6 percent after UBS raised its rating on the stock to "neutral" citing valuation. Financial Federal Corp. FIF, +1.35% shares jumped nearly 8 percent after the New York-based financial services company posted second-quarter earnings of $9.2 million, or 53 cents per share, late Monday. This performance was an improvement over its year-ago equivalent profit of $7.8 million, or 42 cents per share. Finish Line FINL, -2.52% shares tacked on almost 2 percent on news that the company will replace Yellow Roadway YELL in the S&P SmallCap 600 index on March 11. Yellow Roadway is moving to the S&P MidCap 400, replacing Varco International, which is being acquired by National Oilwell. FuelCell Energy FCEL, +0.58% shares rose 1 percent after the company narrowed its first-quarter loss to $18 million, or 40 cents a share, from $27.9 million, or 59 cents a share, a year ago. Adjusted net loss was $15.9 million, or 34 cents a share, the Danbury, Conn.-based company said. Revenue was $7.6 million vs. $7.4 million a year earlier. Shares of GuruNet GRU, +0.55% soared more than 23 percent after the Wesley Hills, N.Y., online reference technology company inked an agreement with Google Inc. GOOG, +2.71% . The deal calls for Google's contextual AdSense advertising to be included on GuruNet's information pages and for Google's search technology to be integrated into GuruNet's Answers.com product. Financial terms weren't disclosed. Johnson Controls Inc. JCI, +2.77% gained more than 3 percent after the company said second-quarter income from continuing operations would be 85 cents per share, compared with 76 cents per share in the same period in 2004. Johnson Controls also affirmed its 2005 estimate of sales growth of 8 percent to 10 percent over the $25.4 billion it recorded in 2004. After-tax income in 2005 from continuing operations will be higher than operating income because of a lower tax rate, the company said. See full story. National Oilwell NOI rose almost 1 percent on news that the company will replace Power-One PWER in the S&P 500 index after it closes its deal to acquire Varco Energy VRC, -2.50% on March 11. Revlon Corp. REV, +0.98% rallied more than 11 percent after the company recorded it's first profitable quarter in six years on much lower costs and strong sales of new products in North America, the New York cosmetics company said Tuesday. For the fourth quarter ended Dec. 31, Revlon recorded earnings of $46.2 million, or 12 cents a share, versus a year-ago loss of $12.6 million, or 18 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were looking for earnings, on average, of 11 cents a share. Sales advanced to $378.3 million from $368.5 million a year ago. See full story. Seagate Technology STX, +2.87% tacked on almost 2 percent after the company said it expects to exceed Wall Street's third-quarter earnings and revenue forecasts because of increased demand for consumer and enterprise hard-disk products. See full story. Ventiv Health VTIV surged more than 6 percent after the company said net income for the fourth quarter rose to $14.1 million, or 52 cents a share, from $11.9 million, or 49 cents a share, including a one-time tax benefit. Revenue rose to $117.4 million from $75.3 million, on "momentum" in wins by its Sales team, and record earnings in Health Products Research. It said it is increasing its 2005 revenue expectations to between $460 million and $475 million from $430 million to $450 million, and its 2005 earnings outlook to between $1.03 and $1.09 a share from between 98 cents and $1.04. Shares of ViroPharma VPHM rallied more than 11 percent after Piper Jaffray initiated research coverage of the drugmaker with an "outperform" rating and $5 price target. Analyst Thomas Wei said the company has transformed itself into a development and commercialization company through the acquisition of Vancocin and the refocusing of its pipeline. "Even with modest conservative growth rate assumptions, we believe Vancocin will allow ViroPharma to be cash flow positive in 2006," Wei said. Wheaton River Minerals WHT (WRM) gained more than 5 percent after the company reported fourth-quarter earnings of $56 million, or 9 cents a share, up from $27.8 million, or 5 cents a share, a year ago. Goldcorp GG, +2.29% which is in the process of acquiring Wheatin River, saw its shares rise more than 5 percent in late trades. WMC Resources WMC, +1.68% tacked on more than 2 percent after BHP Billiton Ltd. BHP, +2.16% offered to acquire WMC for $7.3 billion, trumping a hostile offer from Xstrata Plc (XTA). See full story. Yahoo YHOO rose nearly 1 percent after the Internet search company was upgraded to "buy" from "neutral" by UBS, which cited the company's decision to expand its Content Match product. See full story. Decliners 99 Cents Only Stores' NDN shares dropped more than 6 percent, extending Monday's skid after the company said it's reviewing its lease accounting procedures and that it may have to restate certain financial statements. The company also its ongoing review of its results will delay the filing of its Form 10-K with the Securities and Exchange Commission. In addition, A.G. Edwards downgraded the stock to "sell." AK Steel AKS, +5.84% shares continued their slide in Tuesday's session, dropping nearly 11 percent in late trades. The move follows a drop of about 7 percent on Monday after Soleil Securities downgraded the stock to "sell" from "hold" citing concerns about valuation and the impact of higher raw material costs on the company's bottomline. AK Steel shares hit a 52-week high of $18.23 on Feb. 28. Asset Acceptance Capital Corp. AACC shares lost more than 6 percent after the company filed a shelf registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a secondary public offering of 5 million shares of its common stock. Shares of Bentley Pharmaceuticals BNT, +1.67% slid more than 6 percent after the Exeter, N.H., drug maker posted fourth-quarter earnings of $2 million, or 9 cents per share, down from its year-ago profit of $1.7 million, or 8 cents per share. Revenue increased 8 percent in the latest three months to $19.5 million. The average estimate of two analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 8 cents per share on revenue of $23 million in the December. The company noted that its expenses increased year-over-year to 12 percent of revenue from 11 percent in the year before. Butler International BUTL, -0.94% shares fell more than 4 percent in midday action. The move comes after the company reported fourth-quarter net income of $1.3 million, or 9 cents per share, up from a loss of $1.3 million, or 13 cents per share, last year. Revenue for the Montvale, N.J. outsourcing firm climbed to $65.3 million from $54 million. Thomson First Call doesn't publish a consensus estimate for the company's results. C&D Technologies' CHP, -16.67% shares sank more than 15 percent after the Blue Bell, Pa., maker of electrical power storage products forecast a surprise loss for the fourth quarter due to weak profits from its power electronics unit, the high costs of raw materials, and transition expenses related to a plant in Mexico. Circuit City Stores' CC, +5.43% shares dropped more than 2 percent after the consumer electronics retailer rejected Highfield Capital Management's offer to buy the company for $17 a share in cash. It said the bid was not in shareholders' best interest. Circuit City also increased its stock repurchase program to $800 million from $400 million. Cognizant Technology CTSH, +1.04% shares slid more than 3 percent after the company received a downgrade to "neutral" from UBS, which cited valuation concerns for the move. Jo-Ann Stores' JAS, +1.53% shares lost more than 4 percent after the company topped Wall Street's consensus estimate for the fourth quarter but forecast first-quarter earnings of 27 to 32 cents a share. The current estimate of a single analyst polled by Thomson First Call is for a profit of 46 cents per share in the April period. Korn Ferry International KFY, +0.47% shares dipped almost 2 percent after the Los Angeles executive staffing firm topped Wall Street's consensus view for the third quarter but said it expects earnings of 22 to 25 cents per share for the fourth quarter. The current average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for earnings of 25 cents per share in the April period. Shares of Kroger Co. KR, +1.35% tumbled more than 4 percent after the company reported a loss of $675.9 million, or 93 cents per share, for the fourth quarter on Tuesday, a performance that reflects a goodwill impairment charge of $884 million, or $1.21 per share, related to its Ralph's and Food 4 Less operations. In the same period a year ago, the Cincinnati-based supermarket operator lost $337.4 million, or 45 cents per share, including items that, in total, reduced earnings by $663.1 million, or 89 cents per share. Sales rose 5.1 percent in the fourth quarter ended Jan. 29 to $13.7 billion. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings before items of 35 cents per share in the January period. Looking ahead, Kroger sees earnings of more than $1.16 per share in 2005, an outlook that it says reflects improved results in Southern California, better balance in its operations and lower interest expenses. Wall Street's current consensus estimate is for a profit of $1.29 per share in fiscal 2006. Landry's Seafood Restaurants' LNY, -25.00% shares fell more than 5 percent after the Houston restaurant operator forecast first-quarter earnings of 28 to 29 cents a share, and said it would restate past earnings and review its lease accounting procedures. The restatement is expected to reduce reported 2003 earnings by 3 cents. The current average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for a profit of 39 cents per share in the March period. Las Vegas Sands Corp. LVS, +1.58% shares slid more than 4 percent after the casino operator posted in-line results for the fourth quarter in its first financial report as a publicly held company. See full story. Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia MSO, +0.00% shares slid more than 7 percent in afternoon action. The stock has lost roughly 29 percent of its value since Martha Stewart's release from a federal prison on Friday. See full story. McDonald's Corp. MCD, -1.28% slumped more than 2 percent after the Dow component said February same-store sales, or sales in restaurants open at least a year, increased 1.6 percent. The company said European results were hurt by weakness in Germany. See full story. Millennium Cell MLNM shares tumbled more than 3 percent after J.P. Morgan lowered its rating on the company to "neutral" from "overweight," citing more tepid outlook for its Velcade multiple myeloma treatment. Perficient Inc. PRFT, +1.73% shares lost more than 14 percent after the Austin, Texas-based IT consulting company filed a registration statement for a proposed public offering of 5 million common shares. Perficient is selling 4.25 million of the shares. Rite Aid Corp. RAD, +0.60% gave back more than 3 percent aftee the Camp Hill, Pa., drugstore retailer said same-store sales edged 0.6 percent higher in February. Total sales for the period fell 1.3 percent to $4.3 billion. Salem Communications Corp. SALM, -5.26% fell more than 4 percent after the company reported fourth-quarter earnings of $3.7 million, or 14 cents a share on revenue $52 million. Analysts expected earnings of 15 cents a share on revenue of $51 million in the January period. For the first quarter, it forecast earnings of 6 to 8 cents a share. See full story. Sonus Networks' SONS shares slid nearly 5 percent after Pacific Growth Equities lowered its rating on the company to "underweight" citing valuation and a belief that current Wall Street consensus estimates for the company are too high. Texas Instruments' TXN, +1.94% shares lost more than 3 percent after the semiconductor giant reduced the high end of its forecast range for first-quarter sales and earnings, citing lower than expected demand for chips used in televisions. See full story. Warren Resources WRES, -2.70% shares fell more than 6 percent after KeyBanc Capital Markets lowered its rating on the stock to "hold" from "buy" citing valuation. More from MarketWatch Samsung Galaxy S9: Putting the Camera to the Test More Coverage 2 sexy ways to get paid to save My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Highlights of rising and falling U.S. stocks

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- ABM Industries Inc. late Monday reported its first-quarter profit rose 25 percent to $7.9 million, or 16 cents a share, from $6.3 million, or 13 cents a share a year ago. Revenue for the San Francisco-based company rose to $647.4 million from $570.8 million a year earlier. ABM ABM, +0.75% said it expects second-quarter earnings in a range of 21 cents to 23 cents a share. For 2005, the company raised its forecast to 98 cents to $1.03 a share, excluding certain costs. ABM also said its board authorized the buy back of up to 2 million shares through Oct. 31, 2005. The purchases would be about 4 percent of the 49.7 million shares outstanding as of Feb. 28. The company, which provides cleaning, engineering, park and security services at commercial and public buildings, also raised its quarterly cash dividend by 5 percent to 10.5 cents a share. The dividend is payable May 2 to shareholders of record April 8. On Monday ABM shares closed up 12 cents to $18.85 ahead of the news. More from MarketWatch Samsung Galaxy S9: Putting the Camera to the Test More Coverage 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid
title: ABM Q1 profit rises 25 percent

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- ABM Industries Inc. ABM, +0.75% said late Monday that it plans to buyback 2 million shares of its common stock at any time through Oct. 31.
title: ABM Industries to buyback 2M of its shares

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- ABM Industries' ABM, +0.75% Amtech Lighting Inc. unit said Tuesday that it has been awarded a multiyear, multimillion dollar contract with Trammell Crow Co. TCC, +0.00% Under the terms of the deal, the Anaheim, Calif.-based illuminated sign maker will provide lighting and maintenance for over 5,000 Trammell Crow-managed Bank of America BAC, +2.04% buildings in the eastern United States. Specific financial terms were not disclosed.
title: ABM unit awarded multimillion deal with Trammell Crow

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- ABM Industries Inc. ABM, +0.75% said Thursday after the bell that the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit had granted summary judgment in favor of ABM for its insurance claims for business interruption losses resulting from the World Trade Center disaster. The court also ruled that ABM is entitled to recovery for the extra expenses it incurred after Sept. 11. These costs include millions of dollars related to increased unemployment claims and costs associated with the redeployment of WTC personnel at other facilities, the San Francisco-based company said.
title: ABM Indus gets favorable judgment for insurance claims

content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Among the stocks likely seeing active trading in Thursday's regular session are American Greetings and PalmSource. American Greetings Corp. AM, +1.65% which makes greeting cards, is seen posting earnings of 69 cents a share for the third quarter, according to analysts polled by Thomson First Call. PalmSource Inc. PSRC swung to a second-quarter profit late Wednesday and surpassed its outlook, but investors punished the company's shares after it predicted results for the current quarter would fall short of Wall Street expectations. See full story. Thursday's watch list ABM Industries Inc. ABM, +0.75% said it bought Colin Service Systems Inc. for about $13.6 million in cash. Aeterna Zentaris Inc. AEZS, -2.67% said it granted marketing rights for its Neovastat compound to a subsidiary, Atrium Biotechnologies Inc. As a result, Aeterna Zentaris will increase its stake in Atrium from 60.2 percent to 61.1 percent. Alcan Inc. AL, +1.43% said its shareholders approved the spin-off of its rolled products unit to a newly created company called Novelis. Novelis will be domiciled in Canada, but headquartered in Atlanta. Shares are expected to trade on both the New York and Toronto stock exchanges under the ticker symbol "NVL." Archstone-Smith ASN, +0.00% said it expects to receive about $25 million of eBay Inc. EBAY, +0.32% common stock from its investment in Rent.com. eBay announced plans to purchase Rent.com for about $415 million on Dec. 17. Bristol-Myers Squibb BMY, +1.09% said it entered into a commercialization and distribution agreement with Somerset Pharmaceuticals for Somerset's Emsam transdermal antidepressant treatment. Somerset is a joint venture between Mylan Laboratories MYL, +1.65% and Watson Pharmaceuticals WPI, +0.00% Camden Property Trust CPT, +0.14% a major investor in Rent.com, said it expects an $18 million first-quarter gain in income from its sale of eBay Inc. EBAY, +0.32% common stock. Charter Communications CHTR, +1.62% said in a U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission filing it will issue $862.5 million in 5.875 percent convertible senior notes due 2009. The notes will be convertible to about 356 million Class A shares. Cognizant Technology Solutions CTSH, +1.04% will join the Nasdaq-100 Index beginning Dec. 29. Cognizant is replacing PeopleSoft Inc. PSFT, +0.00% Conexant Systems Inc. CNXT, +2.41% said in a federal filing it will continue to pay former Chief Executive Armando Geday his base salary of $550,000 as a non-executive employee until June 30. See full story. Curtiss-Wright Corp. CW, +2.69% said it was awarded a five-year $12 million contract from VT Miltope to provide a battery-charging device for communications equipment used by the U.S. Army. Edelbrock Corp. EDEL said its shareholders approved a proposed merger to take the company private. It will merge with a subsidiary of a corporation controlled by O. Victor Edelbrock Jr., Edelbrock's chairman and chief executive. Edelbrock stockholders will be paid $16.75 for each share they own. ElkCorp ELK, -1.09% increased its second-quarter earnings forecast by 15 cents a share and now sees earnings of 60 cents a share. El Paso Corp. EP, +0.00% said it agreed to sell its interests in its Cedar Brakes I and Cedar Brakes II power-supplier subsidiaries to a unit of Arroyo Energy Investors for $106 million. It said the deal with Arroyo Energy, an affiliate of Bear Stearns Cos. BSC, +1.30% is expected to close in the first quarter of 2005. Enzon Pharmaceuticals ENZN, +0.00% said Jeffrey Buchalter is the president and chief executive in addition to his duties as chairman. Gateway Inc. GTW said it repurchased all of its Series A and Series C preferred stock and 2.7 million common shares from Time Warner Inc. TWX, +0.40% unit America Online for $315.6 million. Global Payments Inc. GPN, +1.31% said it bought a group of European electronic money transfer firms, called Europhil, from individual investors. Terms weren't disclosed. Kindred Healthcare Inc. KND, +0.00% said it bought two hospitals from Ventas Inc. VTR, -0.28% for about for $21.6 million in cash. Kindred plans to resell the facilities as soon as possible. Kmart Holding Corp. KMRT said it and Sears, Roebuck, & Co. (S: news, chart, profile), voluntarily agreed to withdraw their previously filed Hart-Scott-Rodino notification and report forms and will re-file them by Dec. 28, when the 30-day waiting period will recommence. Kmart announced plans to buy Sears for about $11 billion in mid-November. Lexicon Genetics Inc. LEXG, +12.33% said it was awarded a one-year $1.9 million grant from the U.S. Army Medical Research Institute of Infectious Diseases for the discovery of drugs that could provide resistance to ricin poisoning. Marsh & McLennan MMC, +0.85% the SEC started a formal investigation into funds run by its private-equity unit MMC Capital. See full story. Masonite International Corp. MHM, +0.00% (MHM) said it is being bought by an affiliate of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. for C$3.1 billion ($2.5 billion). See full story. Merisel Inc. MSEL said its shares were delisted from the Nasdaq market at the start of trading. The Nasdaq listing qualifications panel denied its appeal of an Oct. 1 delisting decision. Micron Technology Inc. MU, +1.26% saw first-quarter earnings surge, narrowly beating Wall Street's estimates for the period as revenue grew 14 percent. See full story. Novartis Pharmaceuticals NVS, -0.49% said its Enablex drug, which is used to treat overactive bladders, was approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration and is expected to launch in early 2005. Patina Oil and Gas Corp. POG, +0.00% said President Jay Decker retired ahead of schedule because of the company's pending merger with Noble Energy Inc. NBL, +3.20% Patina Chairman and Chief Executive Thomas Edelman replaced Decker. Pioneer Railcorp PRRR, +3.43% said it doesn't plan to renew its listing with Nasdaq or the Chicago Stock Exchange in 2005 and expects it will no longer be traded on either exchange beginning Jan. 3. Pope & Talbot Inc. POP said it will buy the Fort St. James sawmill from Canfor Corp. for about $32 million. The sale is expected to close March 1. Precision Optics Corp. POCI said it received notice from the Nasdaq that it has regained listing compliance by raising its minimum bid price to $1 a share or higher for 10 consecutive days. Raytheon Co. RTN, +2.26% was awarded a $200.5 million U.S. Air Force contract to provide 434 advanced medium range Air-to-Air Missiles. The work will be completed by September 2007 at Raytheon Missile Systems in Tucson, Ariz. Red Hat Inc. RHAT reported a 2005 third-quarter profit of $10.8 million as subscription revenue nearly doubled over the year-ago period. See full story. Resources Connection Inc. RECN, +0.62% reported second quarter earnings tripled over last year's. See full story. Tibco Software Inc. TIBX said its fourth quarter earnings rose on increased sales to new and existing customers. See full story. More from MarketWatch How to Run a Better Meeting: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Stocks to watch Thursday: AM, PSRC

content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- ABM Industries Inc. ABM, +0.75% said Wednesday after the bell that it has acquired Colin Service Systems, Inc. for about $13.6 million in cash. Additional consideration may include about $1.9 million with the collection of the acquired receivables and three annual contingent cash payments of about $1.1 million, which are based on achieving annual revenue targets.
title: ABM Industries buys Colin Service for $13.6M cash

content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) - Among the stocks likely seeing active trading in Tuesday's regular session are Bear Stearns, Paychex, and Solectron. Bear Stearns BSC, +1.30% is seen posting fourth-quarter earnings of $2.14 a share; Paychex PAYX, +1.63% a payroll processing company, is expected to report earnings of 23 cents a share for the second quarter; and Solectron SLR, +1.69% a manufacturing services provider, is seen posting earnings of 5 cents a share for the first quarter, according to analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Tuesday's watch list ABM Industries Inc. ABM, +0.75% said late Monday, after completing an insurance accounting review, that it will result 2000-2003 annual results, 2003 quarterly results and results from the first three quarters of 2004. Amdocs Ltd. DOX, +0.80% said its board authorized an additional $100 million stock buyback. American Healthways Inc. AMHC reported first-quarter earnings of $7.8 million, or 22 cents a share, vs. $4 million, or 12 cents a share, a year ago. Revenues rose to $71.2 million from $51.1 million a year ago. See After Hours column. AngioDynamics Inc. ANGO, +2.19% reported second quarter earnings of $1 million, or 9 cents a share, vs. $606,000, or 6 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue rose to $14.4 million from $11.8 million last year. Analysts estimated earnings of 5 cents a share on revenue of $14 million. Arrow International Inc. ARRO said first-quarter earnings fell to $13.6 million, or 31 cents a share, from $14.4 million, or 33 cents a share, a year ago. Excluding charges, earnings were $15.5 million, or 35 cents a share. Revenue was $113.2 million vs. $103.1 million. The company expects second-quarter earnings to be between 35 cents and 37 cents a share on sales of $116 million to $118 million. Applied Signal Technology APSG which makes reconnaissance equipment, is expected to report earnings of 29 cents a share for the fourth quarter. Belo Corp. BLC, +0.00% a media company, said its newspaper group's November revenue fell 8.9 percent while its television group's revenue rose 7.8 percent. Bestway Inc. BSTW said it has been notified it will be delisted from the Nasdaq SmallCap Market effective Dec. 21. The company is going private. Black Box Corp. BBOX, -2.44% said it will buy Norstan Inc. NRRD for $95 million in cash and assumption of $12.4 million in debt. The deal is expected to close in the fourth quarter. Capital Bank Corp. CBKN, -9.32% increased its quarterly dividend 20 percent to 6 cents a share, payable on Jan. 18 to shareholders as of Jan. 3. Charles & Colvard Ltd. CTHR, -0.73% said it expects fourth-quarter revenue of $8.1 million to $8.6 million, vs. $4.8 million last year. Cognos COGN which makes business intelligence software, is expected to report earnings of 33 cents a share for the third quarter. ConocoPhillips COP, +0.95% and Anadarko Petroleum Corp. APC, +2.56% said they have approved development of two Alpine satellite oil fields on Alaska's North Slope. They will drill about 40 wells, with the first production scheduled for late 2006. EFJ Inc. EFJI said it expects 2004 earnings to be between $5.6 million and $5.9 million and revenue in the range of $78 million to $80 million. Encysive Pharmaceuticals ENCY said a Phase III study of Thelin showed the drug in the 50-milligram dosage to be "ineffective" vs. a 100-milligram dosage. The company said its STRIDE-4 study is not necessary. General Dynamics Corp. GD, +1.67% said it was awarded a $267 million contract by the U.S. Army for an Egyptian tank co-production project. Delivery of the tank kits will begin in 2005 and continue through 2008. General Mills Inc. GIS, +1.60% is seen posting earnings of 87 cents a share for the second quarter. Illumina Inc. ILMN, +0.61% and Invitrogen Corp. IVGN said they have formed a strategic alliance for Illumina's Oligator DNA synthesis technology. Invitrogen will invest $3.4 million in Illumina's facility to aide in the research and development of the technology, and will also provide the sales, marketing and distribution outlets for the product. Intermagnetics General Corp. IMGC said second-quarter earnings fell to $4.1 million, or 15 cents a share, from $4.4 million, or 17 cents a share, a year ago. Excluding expenses, earnings were $7.9 million, or 28 cents a share. Revenue was $75.2 million vs. $39.9 million. Jabil Circuit Inc. JBL, +1.74% reported its first-quarter profit rose almost 32 percent from a year ago. It also said second-quarter results could fall below analysts' estimates due to changes in its equipment-production levels. See full story. Liberty Media Corp. L, +0.59% said it has agreed with Merrill Lynch MER, -2.35% on the early termination of its total return swap and will acquire the News Corp. NWS Class B shares the swap held. Liberty Media will give Merrill Lynch 86.9 million News Corp. Class A shares in exchange for 92 million shares of News Corp. The deal is expected to close by mid-January. Manugistics Group MANU, +2.95% which makes supply chain management software, is seen reporting a third-quarter loss of 4 cents a share. Marisa Christina Inc. MRSA, +0.00% said it will be delisted from Nasdaq on Dec. 27 and will not appeal the decision. Morgan Stanley MWD, +0.78% is seen reporting a fourth-quarter profit of $1.01. Norstan Inc. NRRD reported second-quarter earnings of $1.4 million, or 10 cents a share, vs. a loss of $3.4 million, or 26 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue rose to $47.6 million from $48.5 million last year. Perry Ellis International Inc. PERY, -1.64% said it has promoted George Pita to chief financial officer. Pita has been interim CFO since November. Progress Software PRGS, -0.08% is expected to report earnings of 29 cents a share for the fourth quarter. Remec Inc. REMC said Chelton Microwave Corp. will purchase its Remec Defense & Space subsidiary for about $260 million in cash. Chelton Microwave is a subsidiary of Chelton Ltd., a division of Cobham Plc (COB). Research In Motion RIMM which makes the BlackBerry device, is seen posting earnings of 55 cents a share for the third quarter. The company also said a judgment will be entered in its favor and against InPro on InPro's patent infringement claims. The judgment is subject to appeal by InPro, the company said. Silicon Storage Technology SSTI, -4.61% cut its fourth-quarter financial targets due to weak demand and falling prices. See full story. Skechers USA Inc. SKX, +1.38% said it has reached a preliminary agreement to settle three class action lawsuits brought by former and current store employees. The company said the settlement should lead to a fourth-quarter pre-tax charge of about $1.8 million, or 2.5 cents a share. Timken Alloy Steel Europe, a subsidiary of The Timken Co. TKR, +0.44% said it has increased the base price on carbon and alloy steel tubing by about 20 percent, effective Feb. 1. Transaction Network Services Inc. TNS said it has signed a five-year contract with PayPoint to provide dial-up connectivity between PayPoint's retail terminals and its headquarters in Hertfordshire, United Kingdom. Terms weren't disclosed. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration issued a warning about the generic drug naproxen after the National Institutes of Health halted a clinical trial involving patients at risk of developing Alzheimer's Disease. Naproxen, a non-steroidal, anti-inflammatory drug, is sold under a variety of brand names, including Aleve, from Bayer BAY, +15.56% ; and Naprosyn, from Roche RHHBY, -0.61% See full story. U.S.I. Holdings USIH, +0.24% said it will cut staff and terminate certain contracts resulting in savings of $5 million and a charge of $11 million in 2005. The company also said it plans to sell part of its insurance brokerage and specialized benefits unit, resulting in a pre-tax loss of $10 million to $13 million. U.S.I. lowered its 2004 earnings outlook to a range of 96 cents and 98 cents a share from $1.02 to $1.07 a share. For 2005, the company expects earnings of $1.10 to $1.15 a share. York International Corp. YRK, +3.45% revised its 2004 earnings outlook to between $1.90 and $2 a share. It previously expected earnings to be between $2.20 and $2.30 a share. Analysts expect earnings of $2.43 a share. Yukos YUKOY said Sunday's auction of its assets was a violation of the automatic stay that resulted from its Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing in a U.S. court. Yukos claims its assets are property of the Chapter 11 estate, and if completed, the sale would damage the company in excess of $20 billion. More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? More Coverage Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Stocks to watch Tuesday: BSC, PAYX, SLR

content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- ABM Industries Inc. ABM, +0.75% said Monday after the bell that it has completed its previously announced insurance accounting review. ABM said $22 million of the $27 million adjustment will affect numerous prior financial statements. As a result, the company will restate its financial statements for fiscal 2000, 2001, 2002, and 2003. It will also restate its quarterly financial statements for all quarters of fiscal 2003 and the first three quarters of fiscal 2004.
title: ABM Indus completes accounting review

content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) - Among the stocks likely seeing active trading in Tuesday's regular session are ABM Industries and Electronic Arts. ABM Industries Inc. ABM, +0.75% one of the United States' largest facility services contractors, is seen posting fourth-quarter earnings of 29 cents a share, according to analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Share of Electronic Arts Inc. ERTS rose 4.4 percent in after-hours trading Monday after it signed exclusive five-year licensing agreements with the National Football League and Players Inc. to use NFL stadiums, teams and players in its video games. See full story. Tuesday's watch list American Express Co. AXP, +1.16% said it has reached an agreement for Citibank, a division of Citigroup Inc. C, -1.11% to issue credit cards in the U.S. that will be accepted on American Express's network worldwide. American Express said the cards will be available in late 2005. See full story. Aspen Insurance Holdings AHL, -0.33% said Peter Coghlan, president and chief executive of subsidiary Aspen Specialty Insurance, has resigned following his admission that he misstated educational credentials in U.S. regulatory submissions. Chris Maciejewski replaces Coghlan. The U.S. Supreme Court ruled Aviall Services AVL, -3.85% can't collect $5 million from Cooper Industries CBE, +50.00% for cleaning up polluted sites in Texas it bought from Cooper. See full story. BlueLinx Holdings BXC, +4.56% priced its initial public offering of 9.5 million shares at $13.50, raising $120.3 million. The pricing came in under the expected $15 to $17 range. Goldman Sachs led the underwriting. Shares are due to start trading on the New York Stock Exchange on Tuesday. Boeing Co. BA, +2.46% raised its quarterly dividend 25 percent to 25 cents a share, payable March 4 to shareholders of record as of Feb. 11. See full story. Cablevision Systems CVC, -0.36% has named Joseph Lhota executive vice president and co-chief financial officer of its subsidiary, Rainbow Media Enterprises. Lhota had been executive vice president of corporate administration for Cablevision. ChevronTexaco Corp. CVX, +1.73% said an affiliate of its global gas group and a subsidiary of Cheniere Energy LNG, +2.20% finalized a 20-year, liquefied natural gas deal for 700 million cubic feet a day of reserved regasification capacity at Cheniere's Sabine Pass LNG terminal. CKE Restaurants CKR reported a 13-fold increase in earnings for the third-quarter earnings as same-store sales jumped. See full story. Clayton Williams Energy CWEI said it has sold two properties in Texas and Louisiana for about $30.3 million in cash proceeds. Together, these properties contributed about 725 barrels of oil a day and 840 thousand cubic feet of gas a day to the company's third quarter 2004 production. Cooper Cos. COO, +1.63% said fourth-quarter earnings rose 38 percent to $28.7 million, or 79 cents a share, from $21 million, or 61 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue jumped 16 percent to $131 million from $113 million last year. Analysts had estimated earnings of 72 cents a share. Corixa Corp. CRXA said it sold development and marketing rights for its Bexxar cancer treatment to GlaxoSmithKline GSK, -0.79% effective Dec. 31. Terms were not disclosed. Crosstex Energy LP. XTEX said it will build an $80 million, 110-mile pipeline for producers to move natural gas from the Fort Worth Basin to major pipelines serving Texas, the Midwest and East. The pipeline is expected to be completed by January 2006. Engineered Support Systems EASI which provides specialized services for the U.S. military, is expected to report fourth-quarter earnings of 71 cents a share. FuelCell Energy FCEL, +0.58% reported a fourth-quarter loss of $20.8 million, or 43 cents a share, compared with a loss of $15.4 million, or 39 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue rose to $8.9 million from $7.3 million, a year ago. Analysts expected a loss of 44 cents a share on revenue of $9 million. Global Signal GSL, +6.80% increased its quarterly dividend 6.7 percent to 40 cents a share, payable Jan. 20 to stockholders of record on Jan. 7. Goodrich Corp. GR, +5.88% said Boeing Co. BA, +2.46% will use its cargo system on the new 7E7 jet. The deal is expected to generate more than $450 million in sales for Goodrich through 2028. Knoll Inc. KNL, +0.95% priced its initial public offering of 11 million shares at $15, raising $165 million. The furniture maker's pricing came in the high end of the expected $14 to $16 range. Goldman Sachs led the underwriting. Shares will begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange on Tuesday. Kronos Worldwide KRO, +3.67% announced a price increase for all of its North American titanium dioxide grades, effective Jan. 1. In the United States, prices will increase by 6 cents a pound and in Canada, by 7 Canadian cents a pound. Mapics Inc. MAPX has named Dave Morgan interim chief financial officer. Morgan previously was vice president and controller for worldwide accounting and finance operations. He replaces Michael Casey. McDonald's Corp. MCD, -1.28% said in a U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission filing it is amending the terms of more than 1.43 million stock options held by ex-Chief Executive and President Charlie Bell, who resigned earlier this year to fight cancer. The company also said Claire Babrowski, the highest-ranking woman at McDonald's, is resigning after 31 years at the fast-food giant. See full story. Monolithic Power Systems MPWR, +2.26% has filed an antitrust suit against O2Micro International OIIM, -2.86% in U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Texas. Monolithic alleges O2Micro is attempting to enforce patents obtained by fraud. PepsiCo PEP, -0.03% and General Mills GIS, +1.60% have signed an agreement for PepsiCo to buy General Mills' 40.5 percent ownership interest in Snack Ventures Europe for $750 million. See full story. Pier 1 Imports PIR, +2.88% an imported goods retailer, is seen reporting third-quarter earnings of 22 cents a share. PPD Inc. PPDI said it sees fiscal 2005 earnings in the range of $1.85 to $1.93 a share on revenue between $885 million and $900 million. RailAmerica Inc. RRA said its November carloads increased 9.5 percent to 107,097. The company said acquisitions of the Midland Subdivision, the Chicago, Fort Wayne & Eastern Railroad and the Central Michigan Railroad in 2004 accounted for 7,815 of the additional carloads. Skyworks Solutions SWKS, +1.41% said it will take a fourth-quarter non-cash tax charge of $3.5 million, or 2 cents a share. It said the charge stems from foreign exchange translation errors of tax benefits related its equipment and machinery in Mexicali, Mexico. SR Telecom SRX, +7.69% said it has extended its key supplier relationship with Telstra Corp. TLS, +0.58% under which Montreal-based SR Telecom will provide maintenance and support services for Telstra's extensive network of swing fixed wireless access systems. The initial maintenance and support contract period extends until July 2007 and is valued at about C$10 million ($8.1 U.S.) Sykes Enterprises SYKE, +0.31% said it has reached a cash settlement of about $7 million on an insurance claim for its damaged customer contact management center in Marianna, Fla. Sykes said its total gain on the settlement, excluding expenses and other related items, is about $5.3 million, or 13 cents a share. Terra Industries TRA, +6.67% said Anglo American Plc AAUK through a wholly-owned subsidiary, agreed to sell its remaining 25.1 million shares of Terra common stock in a private placement to a group of investors at a price of $7.50 a share. The transaction is expected to close on Dec. 20. UAL Corp. UALAQ parent company of United Airlines, said it will cut pay of salaried workers and managers beginning Jan. 1 as part of its goal to emerge from bankruptcy. See full story. Unocal Corp. UCL, +0.00% said it reached a settlement in principle with parties to human-rights lawsuits, which alleged the oil and gas producer ignored the use of slave labor to build a natural-gas pipeline in the 1990s Burma. See full story. Washington Group International WGII said it has signed a contract with DTE Energy DTE, +0.38% for major environmental control system installations, capital improvement retrofits and plant maintenance projects at DTE subsidiary Detroit Edison's DTA, -3.05% fossil-fuel electricity generating stations. The potential value of the contract is up to $2 billion over eight years, Washington Group said. More from MarketWatch What Picking Up an Apple Tells You About the Future of Robotics More Coverage Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Stocks to Watch Tuesday: ABM, ERTS

content: Advancers Ableauctions.com AAC, +1.86% shares soared almost 15 percent after the company forecast earnings of more than $211,000 for the fourth quarter, a performance that would represent an improvement of more than 400 percent from its total profits for the preceding three quarters. Shares of Advancis Pharmaceuticals Inc. AVNC jumped 24 percent after the company's study of pulsatile dosing was published by the Journal of Antimicrobial Chemotherapy. Results of the published study indicated that pulsatile delivery of amoxicillin may represent a more potent strategy to kill the bacteria responsible for causing both widespread infection and the deaths that result from upper respiratory tract infections and community-acquired pneumonia. Anadys Pharmaceuticals ANDS whose shares rose almost 4 percent, and LG Life Sciences reported positive interim data from a Phase II clinical trial of ANA380, a treatment for patients infected with lamivudine-resistant hepatitis B virus. The companies said that after 12 weeks of treatment, patients receiving 30 mg and 60 mg doses of ANA380 showed an average DNA viral load reduction of 2.8 and 3.2 log10units, respectively. Shares of Brillian Corp. BRLC jumped more than 9 percent after the company agreed to sell certain assets to JDS Uniphase Corp. JDSU for $5.1 million. In addition, Brillian agreed to license technology from JDS Uniphase in order to begin pilot production of light engines at Brillian's facility in Tempe, Ariz. Shares of Central European Media Enterprises Ltd. CETV, +2.44% rose more than 18 percent after the company said it has agreed to acquire a controlling interest in TV Nova, a television network in Central and Eastern Europe, from PPF Group for roughly $642 million in cash and stock. Chalone Wine Group Ltd. CHLN, +1.27% shares jumped more than 17 percent after the company received a $13.75 per share acquisition offer from an undisclosed party, trumping its current agreement to be acquired by Domaines Barons de Rothschild for $11.75. Eye Care International Inc. EYCI shares soared almost 34 percent after the company said that it has signed a letter of intent to acquire N-Cam, an alternative medicine company. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. The combined organization will be the largest wellness company in the U.S. The deal is expected to close before the end of December Fibernet Telecom Group FTGX shares surged more than 5 percent after the company agreed to acquire Con Edison's ED, +0.49% communications unit for approximately $37 million in cash. Hirsch International Corp. HRSH shares advanced more than 14 percent after the sewing equipment maker reported a third-quarter profit of $508,000, or 6 cents a share. Last year, Hirsch reported a loss of $78,000, or a penny a share. Sales for the quarter were flat at $11.9 million. Honeywell HON, +0.87% shares gained more than 3 percent despite the company's forecast for earnings of $1.90 to $2.00 a share in 2005, an outlook that's below the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call for a profit of $2.01. The company added that its acquisition of Novar Plc, if completed, would add to 2005 earnings. For the fourth quarter of 2004, the diversified industrial company expects earnings of 49 cents a share, in line with analyst forecasts. See full story. IMAX Corp. IMAX, -1.79% shares surged more than 8 percent after the company said it expects 2004 earnings to exceed its prior forecast of 23 cents a share due to the settlement of litigation with the former owners of United Cinemas International Multiplex (UCI) and the success of the movie "The Polar Express." The large screen movie theater operator did not disclose details of the settlement with UCI, but said it would receive cash payments in the fourth quarter of 2004 and the first quarter of 2005. Ivanhoe Energy Inc. IVAN shares gained more than 11 percent after the company said that it has agreed to buy Boston-based Ensyn Group for $10 million in cash and $75 million in stock. Under the deal, Ivanhoe will acquire Ensyn's heavy-oil upgrading business, Ensyn Petroleum International Ltd., but will spin off its biomass processing business, Ensyn Renewables Inc., prior to the deal's close. The deal is expected to close in the second quarter of 2005. MediaBay MBAY, -99.00% shares jumped more than 12 percent after the Cedar Knolls, N.J.-based media marketing company said it has signed a deal with HarperCollins Publishers to offer downloadable audiobook editions of titles from the HarperAudio and Caedmon audiobook libraries. These titles will be offered beginning in early 2005 through Microsoft's MSFT, +2.10% MSN network as part of MediaBay's recently announced agreement with MSN. Financial terms were not disclosed. Motorola Inc. MSI, +1.29% shares surged more than 5 percent after the company said that it will realign into four distinct business groups effective Jan. 1. The company said the new groups -- personal devices, networks, connected home and government and enterprise -- will help improve operating efficiency. There will be no change in reporting relationships, the company said. Novel Denim Holdings Limited NVLD shares soared almost 20 percent after the company said it's agreed to a merger with a subsidiary under which all shareholders except K. C. Chao, Novel's CEO, will receive $1.20 per share in cash. Shares of NSS Group Inc. NSS, +0.12% jumped more than 25 percent in midday action, topping the percentage gainers list for the New York Stock Exchange. The move comes after Raymond James lifted its rating on the company to "strong buy" from "outperform" as part of a bullish call on oil-services providers based on the firm's belief that much of the downside risk to lower oil prices has been realized. Oracle Corp. ORCL, +1.71% whose shares surged more than 10 percent, and PeopleSoft Inc. PSFT, +0.00% whose shares advanced more than 10 percent, have reached an agreement for Oracle to buy PeopleSoft for $26.50 per share in a deal valued at $10.3 billion, ending a takeover battle that has lasted more than a year. A close is seen in early January. Separately, Oracle said second-quarter net income rose to $815 million, or 16 cents per share, from $617 million, or 12 cents per share, in the year-earlier quarter. Analysts polled by Thompson First Call had expected earnings of 14 cents per share on revenue of $2.6 billion. See full story. Overseas Shipholding Group OSG, +10.51% whose shares climbed more than 8 percent, said Monday it would acquire Stelmar Shipping Ltd. SJH for $48 per share, about $843 million, plus debt of about $457 million. Stelmar shareholders must approve the buyout, which represents an 8.3 percent premium over Stelmar's closing price Friday. The combination adds 40 crude oil and petroleum product-carrying ships to OSG's 61 vessels. Stelmar's shares rose more than 7 percent in morning trading. See full story. Tibco Software TIBX shares advanced more than 5 percent after the company was upgraded to "buy" from "hold" by Jefferies & Co. The firm cited channel checks that indicate a better-than-expected quarter ahead, an upcoming product cycle and a strong performance from its Staffware division. Jefferies also lifted its price target on the stock to $15 from $9.50. Shares of Westlake Chemical WLK, +2.91% leapt 8 percent after UBS Investment Research reiterated a "buy" rating for the maker of basic chemicals, vinyls, polymers and fabricated products and increased its price target for the stock to $38 from $35. The day's gains helped offset losses the stock endured on Friday after Banc of America Securities downgraded shares to "neutral" from "buy." World Fuel Services INT, +4.42% shares surged more than 10 percent, after the company, a distributor of fuel to airlines and ships, earned high praise from Barron's for "a solid balance sheet, shrewd management" and a profitable niche. The company effectively hedges on fuel prices by selling petroleum before shipping it. Its biggest risk is $36 per share of receivables, though Barron's says the days sales outstanding have consistently dropped, signaling improving collection. Z-Tel Technologies ZTLDC shares soared more than 64 percent after the company raised its year-end 2004 forecast for retail service lines to more than 230,000 on Monday and said it remains comfortable with a fourth-quarter forecast for earnings, before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization of $2.5 million. Tampa, Fla.-based Z-Tel said its active consumer bundled service line count now exceeds 183,000 and its active business line count is roughly 47,000, bringing its total bundled service line count to about 230,000. Decliners 3Com Corp. COMS shares slid more than 8 percent after the company agreed to buy networking and security technology company TippingPoint Technologies TPTI in a deal valued at $430 million. 3Com will pay $47 per share in cash, a 13 percent premium over TippingPoint's closing price on Friday. ABM Industries ABM, +0.75% shares skidded more than 6 percent in afternoon action. The company raised its quarterly dividend 5 percent early Monday, to 10.5 cents a share. The dividend is payable Feb. 7 to shareholders of record as of Jan. 14. Autobytel Inc. ABTLE shares plunged more than 29 percent after the company, which provides Internet automotive marketing services, said late Friday that its previous fiscal 2004 per-share forecast of 25 cents per share "should no longer be relied upon," citing higher costs. The Irvine, Calif.-based company reaffirmed its 2004 sales forecast of $120 million and $125 million. Autobytel also said it now expects fiscal 2005 earnings to be substantially lower than previously forecast, but reaffirmed its revenue outlook for the period. Ditech Communications DITC shares fell more than 8 percent after the communications equipment maker was downgraded to "neutral" from "buy" at First Albany on concerns that a potential merger between Nextel Communications NXTL which is one of Ditech's largest customers, and Sprint FON, +5.56% may cause Nextel to reduce some capital spending in the near term. Glycogenesys Inc. GLGS shares sank more than 9 percent after the company said that its board has approved a 1-for-6 reverse stock split. The split will occur after the close of trading on Dec. 20. Following the split, the company's common stock will trade under the temporary symbol GLGS.D for 20 trading days. Glowpoint Inc. GLOW, -3.28% shares tumbled more than 11 percent in afternoon action. The company said that it has named Rod Dorsey chief financial officer, effective immediately. Dorsey was last at Tatum Partners LLP, a provider of supplemental financial and information technology leadership, where he was a CFO engagement partner directly responsible for developing and growing a technology-focused practice for publicly held and emerging growth companies. Interstate Bakeries IBCIQ shares slid more than 6 percent after the company, the bankrupt maker of snack desserts such as Twinkies, said late Friday that it filed details of some preliminary fiscal 2004 details and some fiscal 2005 details. Citing auditing snags, the company said it is uncertain when it will file its 2004 10-K. See full story. II-VI Inc. IIVI, +3.54% shares lost more than 4 percent after the company said that it has bought Marlow Industries Inc. of Dallas, Texas, for $31 million in cash. The company said the acquisition will immediately add to earnings and sales. II-VI said earnings for the second quarter ended Dec. 31 will be between 38 cents and 42 cents a share, and revenues will be between $43 million and $45 million. OmniVision Technologies OVTI, +1.49% shares gave up more than 9 percent after the company said its revised financial statements issued in June had "principally corrected the timing of revenue recognition for certain sales." OmniVision made the remarks in response to queries about an informal SEC inquiry, which it mentioned in filings made Friday. Shares of Portal Software Inc. PRSF fell more than 6 percent after the company delayed the release of its third-quarter earnings report. Portal said auditors are looking at the company's application of revenue recognition principles. The release had previously been scheduled for after the bell Monday. A new date has not been set. Secure Computing Inc. SCUR shares skidded more than 6 percent after the San Jose, Calif.-based security software provider was downgraded by Janney Montgomery Scott to "hold" from "buy." The firm said that although the departure of the company's president, Timothy McGurran, may not have an impact on near-term forecasts, "we are somewhat concerned since Mr. McGurran was an integral member of Secure's sales and management team," the firm told clients. Tenet Healthcare THC, +1.76% shares sank more than 8 percent after the company said its results for the fourth quarter and fiscal 2005 remain under pressure due to reduced patient volumes, high levels of bad debt from uninsured and under-insured patients, higher costs, and a shift in its managed care business to contracts with lower reimbursement levels. Tuesday Morning Corp. TUES, +0.00% shares tumbled almost 18 percent after the company said it cut its fourth-quarter earnings-per-share outlook to 83 cents per diluted share, below the Thompson First Call forecast of $1.05 per share and flat from the year-ago period. Tuesday Morning attributed the revision to weak sales during the quarter. Ultimate Electronics ULTE plummeted more than 53 percent after the company expressed doubt about its ability to stay in business. The consumer electronics company said it would likely violate one or more of its financial covenants given the continued deterioration sales trends, and said its creditors may not grant requests for waivers. More from MarketWatch Samsung Galaxy S9: Putting the Camera to the Test More Coverage Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Highlights of rising and falling U.S. stocks

content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- ABM Industries ABM, +0.75% raised its quarterly dividend 5 percent early Monday, to 10.5 cents a share. The dividend is payable Feb. 7 to shareholders of record as of Jan. 14.
title: ABM Industries ups quarterly div 5% to 10.5c

content: LONDON (CBS.MW) -- ABM Industries ABM, +0.75% said that it will delay issuing its audited 2004 earnings while it completes an accounting treatment evaluation of a change in insurance reserves methodology. The methodology change will increase the company's self-insurance reserves at Oct. 31, 2004 by $27 million. The company will also record a $15 million increase in insurance related reserves from "adverse" developments related to workers compensation claims. Excluding any impact from reserves, ABM sees fourth-quarter continuing operations income rising 13 percent to $1.5 million, or 29 cents a share. The company expects to report 2005 income from continuing operations of between 95 cents and $1.00 a share.
title: ABM to delay 2004 earnings due to accounting evaluation

content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- ABM Janitorial Services, a unit of ABM Industries Inc. ABM, +0.75% said Friday it has signed an extended, multi-year contract with University of Buffalo State University of New York. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. The contact covers janitorial service for 16 campus facilities, the company said. ABM has been providing services at the university's other campus facilities since 2003.
title: ABM Industries unit extends contract with U of Buffalo

content: Chico's: Storms may cut same-store Sept sales 1.5%-2.5% (8:09 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Chico's FAS CHS, +0.33% said Wednesday evening that same-store sales during the first 10 days of September are down 2 percent. Chico's said it attributes the weakness to the impact of hurricanes Charley and Frances, as well as unusually low coupon-redemption rates in certain parts of the country. The clothing retailer said it estimates the direct impact of the storms are likely to reduce September sales between 1.5 percent and 2.5 percent. Seperately, Chico's said it has approved a $100 million buyback of its stock over the next 12 months. On Wednesday shares for Chico's closed down 38 cents to $36.76. Remec shares decline after-hours (7:06 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Remec Inc. REMC shares fell 65 cents, or 12.3 percent, to $4.65 in after-hours trading late Wednesday following the wireless technology provider's report of second-quarter results. Remec said it lost $76.5 million, or $1.23 a share, compared to a loss of $3.6 million, or 6 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The loss in the latest period includes a goodwill impairment charge of $62.4 million. Sales rose 36 percent to $108.8 million. Equity Residential cuts Q3 forecast due to hurricanes (6:57 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Equity Residential Properties Trust EQR, +0.11% cut its third-quarter forecast late Wednesday, citing damage at its Florida properties from Hurricanes Charley and Frances. The Chicago-based company cut its third-quarter earnings forecast to a range of 19 cents to 20 cents a share from 22 cents to 24 cents a share, and took its FFO forecast for the period to a range of 50 cents to 51 cents a share from 53 cents to 55 cents a share. Equity Residential also reiterated its expectation that its full-year earnings and FFO results will come in near the bottom of it forecast. The firm is looking for $1.21 to $1.35 a share in earnings and FFO of $2.15 to $2.29 a share for the year. Equity Residential stock ended Wednesday's session down 20 cents at $32.94 ABM Q3 net rises (6:46 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- ABM Industries Inc. ABM, +0.75% said late Wednesday that its third-quarter net income rose to $13.4 million, or 27 cents a share, from $11.7 million, or 23 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The figure in the latest period includes $1.2 million, or 2 cents a share, in after-tax income from operations that were sold to Otis Elevator. Sales rose 9.6 percent to $623.8 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were expecting a profit of 25 cents a share on revenue of $625.3 million in the latest quarter. The company also reiterated its full-year earnings forecast of 80 to 85 cents a share. Furniture Brands updates Q3 earnings outlook (5:12 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Furniture Brands International FBN late Wednesday said it expects to report third-quarter earnings of 36 cents to 38 cents per share. The forecast is on the upper-end of its earlier estimate. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call are expecting earnings of 36 cents per share. Shares of Furniture Brands closed down 87 cents at $23.52. Ulticom says Q2 sales increase 71% (5:10 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Internet and telecommunications software-maker Ulticom ULCM late Wednesday reported second-quarter income of $4 million, or 9 cents a share, compared with $1.3 million, or 3 cents a share, a year ago. Sales were $16.1 million, up from $9.4 million last year. Shares of the Mount Laurel, N.J.-based company closed down 5 cents at $10.50 ahead of the announcement. Geac Q1 sees earns rise 44.3 percent, misses on revenue (4:45 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Geac Computer GEAC said after the bell Wednesday that its first-quarter earnings rose 44.3 percent on strong software license revenue growth, but the software company missed analysts' revenue mark. Geac said earnings for the first quarter were $13.5 million, or 15 cents a share, compared with $9.4 million, or 11 cents per share. Geac said first-quarter revenue was $106.9 million versus $101.5 million a year ago. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were looking for first-quarter earnings of 14 cents a share on revenue of $111 million. On Wednesday in evening trading shares for Geac were down 35 cents, or 5.6 percent, to $5.86. Kforce ups Q3 forecast (4:45 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Staffing firm Kforce Inc. KFRC, +1.12% late Wednesday raised its third-quarter forecast due to strong demand for skilled workers. The company increased its third-quarter earnings outlook to 13 cents to 15 cents per share from its previous target of 9 cents to 15 cents. Revenue is now expected to be between $183 million and $186 million, vs. the earlier estimate of $170 million to $180 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were expecting a profit of 12 cents a share on $176.9 million in revenue. Shares fell 32 cents to $6.70 ahead of the announcement. Martek Biosciences Q3 sales rise (4:33 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Martek Biosciences MATK late Wednesday reported third-quarter earnings of $5 million, or 16 cents per share, compared to $4.6 million, or 16 cents per share, a year ago. The company had revenue of $47 million, up from $29 million in 2003. Shares of Martek Biosciences closed up $2.91 at $55.98. Corning reaffirms Q3 revenue, earnings outlook (4:15 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Corning GLW, +1.94% late Wednesday reaffirmed its third-quarter revenue forecast of $950 million to $1 billion and pro forma earnings view of 10 cents a share to 12 cents a share, before special items. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call expect the company to report third-quarter earnings of 11 cents a share on sales of $974 million. The company also said it expects the worldwide market for liquid crystal display glass to increase about 60 percent this year. Shares of Corning closed up 9 cents at $10.15 ahead of the announcement. Charles & Colvard expects slightly higher Q3 sales (4:08 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Charles & Colvard CTHR, -0.73% said late Wednesday it expects to report third-quarter sales of $3.9 million to $4.2 million. The company said the estimate is about 3 percent to 11 percent above last year's reported $3.8 million. Shares of Charles & Colvard closed down 5 cents at $7.12. Texas Instruments sees Q3 earns 27c to 29c (4:05 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Texas Instruments TXN, +1.94% said its third-quarter earnings would be between 27 and 29 cents a share on sales between $3.1 billion and $3.24 billion. At the start of the quarter the communications and analog chipmaker predicted earnings of 26 to 29 cents a share and sales of $3.2 billion to $3.4 billion. Analysts predicted earnings of 27 cents a share and sales of $3.31 billion, on average, according to Thomson First Call. KEMET lowers Q2 sales outlook (2:33 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- KEMET KEM, +3.66% lowered its sales outlook for the second quarter on Wednesday, saying it now expects that revenue will be 10 percent to 12 percent lower than in the first quarter. Jeffrey Graves, KEMET's CEO, speaking at the Smith Barney Citigroup Technology Conference, said that while sales picked up in August, the company does not believe "that the momentum in the electronics industry will pick up sufficiently in September" to achieve its previously anticipated revenue results. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call estimate second-quarter revenue of $126 million. Shares of KEMET last traded 32 cents lower to $8.28. Retail Ventures tops NYSE gainers list (2:12 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Retail Ventures RVI surged 19 percent, enough to make the discount retailer the NYSE's biggest percentage gainer, after the reported a fiscal second-quarter profit vs. expectations for a loss. The stock was last up $1.20 at $7.59 on volume of 280,000 shares, which is more than double the daily average. The company reported late Tuesday earnings of $1.2 million, or 3 cents a share, vs. a loss of 11 cents a share in the same period a year ago and the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call for a loss of a penny a share. Sales rose 4.5 percent to $631.7 million while same-store sales fell 1.7 percent. New Century reports increase in production volume (11:14 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Shares of New Century Financial NCEN, -40.00% slipped 1 percent to $55.63 in morning trading Wednesday after it reported loan production volume for August 2004 of $3.2 billion, an increase of seven percent from the same period a year earlier. On a year-to-date basis, production is up 75 percent over last year's production of the same period. The Irvine, Calif.-based non-prime mortgage finance company also reaffirmed its production volume of $10 billion to $12 billion for both the third and fourth quarters and earnings per share outlook of $8.25 to $8.75 for the year. One broker reporting to Thomson First Call expects a profit of $8.75 per share for the year. American Land Lease revises outlook, citing Frances (11:12 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- American Land Lease ANL, -5.69% revised its outlook for the remainder of 2004, citing the impact of Hurricanes Charley and Frances. The housing developer said it expects capital replacement costs from Hurricane Frances to be in a range of $175,000 to $275,000, or an additional 2 cents to 3 cents a share, which will be spread out between the third and fourth quarters for a cumulative charge from both hurricanes, of 4 cents to 6 cents a share. It also expects a loss of 20 percent to 25 percent in new home sales for the remainder of 2004 because of the storms. The company said it now expects funds from operation in a range of $1.45 to $1.55 a share, down from its previous forecast of $1.40 to $1.60 a share. Additionally, the company reported that 11 of its 29 housing communities sustained "limited damage" in Hurricane Frances, but that no homes were lost. Shares of American Land Lease last traded 3 cents higher to $19.10. Station Casinos lifts Q3 earns, rev. forecast (9:08 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Station Casinos STN, +1.65% raised its third-quarter earnings and revenue citing strong same-store revenue and strength in the Las Vegas local economy. The casino operator now expects earnings of 42 to 46 cents a share and revenue of $86 million to $90 million, vs. prior forecasts for earnings of 37 to 42 cents a share and revenue of $81 million to $86 million. The company also raised its 2004 earnings projection to $1.87 to $1.97 a share from $1.84 to $1.93, and its 2005 forecast to $2.13 to $2.26 a share from $2.04 to $2.18 a share. Same-store revenue for the two months ending Aug. 31 at its major Las Vegas operations and at Green Valley Ranch increased more than the previously projected growth of 8 to 10 percent. The stock closed Tuesday down 7 cents at $46.60. Commerce Bancorp to meet/exceed Wall St. Q3 view (9:05 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Commerce Bancorp CBH, +0.00% said it expects to meet or exceed the Wall Street's profit views for both the third quarter and full year. The current average estimates of analysts polled by Thomson First Call are for earnings of 83 cents per share and $3.23 per share for the respective periods. The company added that total deposits increased roughly $1.66 billion in the third quarter, and loan growth is up 31 percent on a year-over-year basis as of August 31. The stock closed Tuesday at $54.28, up 2.2 percent. Carmax Q2 same-store sales down 7% (8:58 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW)--Carmax KMX, +2.14% Wednesday said its same-store sales for its fiscal second quarter fell 7 percent and that it expects to report quarterly earnings per share of 27 cents. The Thomson First Call consensus estimate is for second-quarter earnings per share of 29 cents. The Richmond, Va.-based used car seller said its total second-quarter sales increased 7 percent to $1.32 billion from $1.24 billion. The company's full second-quarter report will be released Sept. 20 and will include third-quarter guidance. On Tuesday the stock rose 82 cents to $21.32. Hayes Lemmerz Q2 sales rise 4 percent (8:52 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Hayes Lemmerz International HAYZ reported a second-quarter loss of $10 million, or 26 cents a share. For the year ago, the company reported a loss of $9.2 million, or 31 cents per share for the two months ended July 31, 2003, and in May of last year, the company reported net income of $1.06 billion, mostly on an extraordinary gain on debt discharge from its predecessor company. Second-quarter sales at the Northville, Mich. maker of highway wheels, brakes, powertrain and suspension components rose 4 percent to $523.7 million, compared with $502.8 million a year earlier. Shares rose 9 cents to $13.02 on Tuesday. Stewart Enterprises Q3 earns exceed expectations (8:52 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Stewart Enterprises STEI, +0.00% reported fiscal third-quarter earnings of $10.8 million, or 10 cents a share, vs. a loss of 2 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 8 cents a share, on average. Revenue rose 3.1 percent to $127.6 million, as a 9.8 percent rise in cemetery revenue offset a 2.2 percent decline in funeral sales. The company said it was "on track" to reach its target of 2 to 3 percent growth in average revenue per funeral service. The funeral services company's stock closed Tuesday down 7 cents at $6.90. Cole National posts Q2 profit of $1M (8:27 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Cole National CNJ, -7.74% reported second-quarter earnings of $1 million, or 5 cents per share, up from its year-ago loss of $5.5 million, or 34 cents per share. Revenue rose 1.7 percent in the latest three months to $312.8 million from $307.7 million in the same period a year earlier. The Cleveland-based optical services and gift retailer attributed the improved results to better operating income in both its businesses and a lower level of unusual expenses. A single analyst polled by Thomson First Call was looking for a profit of 25 cents per share in the July period. Cole National added that same-store sales for its optical services business rose in the low double-digits in August due to a successful promotion at Sears Optical. At its Things Remembered stores, same-store sales slipped less than 1 percent in the quarter. The company also said it believes its profit performance will improve in fiscal 2004 before unusual items. The stock closed Tuesday at $27.30, up 4 cents. JetBlue sees lower-than-expected Q3 profit (8:22 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- JetBlue Airways JBLU, +0.74% on Wednesday said that third-quarter earnings will be lower than expected because of high jet fuel costs and two hurricanes in its key Florida market. Analysts expect a profit of 19 cents a share, according to Thomson First Call. Dow Jones sees Q3 earnings in line w/ year-ago (8:17 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Dow Jones & Co. DJ said it expects third-quarter earnings before items to be in line with its year-ago profit of 14 cents per share. The current average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for earnings of 22 cents per share in the September period. The New York media company said advertising reservations at its flagship publication The Wall Street Journal are below expectations for September, offsetting favorable trends in the first two months of the quarter. Dow Jones cited weak bookings in the technology, travel and general business-to-business categories for the September shortfall. For August, advertising linage for U.S. editions of The Wall Street Journal rose 4.7 percent. The stock closed Tuesday at $41.80, up 32 cents. Movado Q2 earnings rise , sees 2005 earnings up 20% (7:58 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW)--Movado Group MOV, +15.66% Wednesday reported fiscal second-quarter net income of $7.1 million, or 28 cents per share, up from $5.8 million, or 23 cents per share a year earlier. The Thomson First Call consensus estimate was for earnings per share of 20 cents. Operating profit fell to $8.7 million from $8.8 million a year earlier, due largely to the costs of acquiring the company's Ebel business. Second-quarter net sales rose 27.8 percent to $97.8 million from $76.5 million. The designer and seller of wrist watches expects fiscal 2005 earnings to rise 20 percent from fiscal 2004 levels to about $410 million, including sales of the Ebel unit. The company anticipates 2005 earnings per share after special items in the 95 cents to $1 range. The stock Tuesday closed up 28 cents to $14.99. Korn/Ferry tops Q1 earns, rev. expectations (7:58 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Korn/Ferry International KFY, +0.47% reported fiscal first quarter earnings of $8.4 million, or 20 cents a share, vs. a loss of 25 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 15 cents a share. Revenue rose 38 percent to $108.2 million, exceeding analyst forecasts of $98.1 million, as an increase in the number of new engagements led to a 42 percent rise in fee revenue. The executive search services provider expects fiscal second-quarter earnings of 14 to 20 cents a share, surrounding analyst forecasts of 16 cents a share, and revenue of $96 million to $103 million, vs. analyst projections of $99.8 million. The stock closed Tuesday up 84 cents at $19.99. Avon reiterates Q3 and 2004 earnings view (7:50 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Avon Products AVP, -1.05% on Wednesday reaffirmed its third-quarter and 2004 earnings forecasts. The New York-based cosmetics seller said it expects third-quarter earnings of 34 cents per share, in line with the forecast in a survey of analysts by Thomson First Call. Avon sees 2004 earnings of $1.72 per share, consistent with its July 28 forecast, but below the figure of $1.75 per share in a First Call survey. Avon said "robust strength" in its international business "is fully offsetting softness in the U.S., where lower-than-expected consumer response to recent brochure offers is impacting results." Shares of Avon rose 24 cents to $45.66 on Tuesday. LeCroy backs prior Q1 earnings view (7:44 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- LeCroy LCRY said it expects results for the first quarter to in line with its prior projections for an increase of 35 to 50 percent in operating income to between $2.7 million and $3 million with revenue rising 15 percent on a year-over-year basis to between $31 million and $32 million. Shares of the Chestnut Ridge, N.Y., maker electronic signal analysis technology closed Tuesday at $13.99, down 2.1 percent. RadioShack sees EPS growth of 19-21% in 2005 (7:38 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- RadioShack RSH, -0.07% said it expects earnings per share growth of 19 to 21 percent and sales growth of 4 to 6 percent in fiscal 2005. The Fort Worth, Texas-based electronics retailer also unveiled its growth plan for the next three years. The plan includes an accelerated rollout of its latest store format, international geographic expansion in North America, and a retailing services business. The company also said it plans to buy back between $200 million and $250 million worth of stock in 2005. The shares closed Tuesday at $29.15, up 1.2 percent. Dave & Busters Q2 16 cents per share, affirms 2004 EPS (7:37 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Dave & Buster's Inc. DAB, +0.23% reported Wednesday second quarter net income of $2.2 million, or 16 cents per share, compared to $1.5 million, or 11 cents per share in the same period a year earlier. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call projected a consensus estimate of 14 cents per share. Same store revenue at the restaurant and entertainment center operator rose 0.5 percent in the quarter and total revenues increased 1.7 percent to $89.8 million. The Dallas company reiterated its fiscal year estimate for earnings of 89 cents to 92 cents per share on revenue of $379 million to $382 million. Shares closed up Tuesday 44 cents to $16. Salton reports Q4 loss despite increased sales (7:28 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Salton SFP, +0.88% reported a fourth-quarter loss of $50.2 million, or $4.42 per share, compared with a loss of $8.8 million, or 79 cents per share in the year-ago period. Sales grew to $249.7 million from $189.2 million as the Lake Forest, Ill. maker of the George Forman Grill and other appliances reported an additional $42.5 million in sales from Amalgamated Appliances Holdings Ltd. Excluding restructuring charges and other items, the company would have reported a fourth quarter net loss of $19.2 million, versus a net loss of $8.8 million in the year-ago period. The company is not tracked by analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Shares of Salton rose 8 cents to $4.70 on Tuesday. Priority Healthcare cuts Q3 outlook (7:19 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW} - Priority Healthcare PHCC Wednesday reduced its fiscal third-quarter outlook, citing shipment delays of its flu vaccines. The company cut its quarterly earnings per share guidance by 1 cent to 2 cents, projecting earnings of 29 cents per share to 30 cents per share. The prior Thomson First Call estimate was for earnings per share of 31 cents. Priority Healthcare now anticipates third-quarter sales of $436 million to $446 million. The inventory in question is presold and should shift entirely to the fourth quarter. Priority Health now expects fourth-quarter, 2004 revenue to increase by 20 percent to 23 percent over third-quarter, 2003 levels. On Tuesday the stock closed up 27 cents to $22.25. ValueClick sees FY05 revs above Wall St. view (7:16 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- ValueClick VCLK said it expects revenue of roughly $210 million for fiscal 2005, above the current average estimate of eight analysts polled by Thomson First Call for revenue of $195.1 million in the period. The Westlake Village, Calif., marketing technology company also forecast an EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) margin of about 25 percent for the year.
