"In 2005, we expect to produce significant growth and a healthy EBITDA margin, while investing to expand further into Europe and establish the presence of our comparison-shopping business in the U.S.," said James Zarley, chairman and CEO of ValueClick, in a statement. "We look forward to delivering the growth and profitability in 2005 that our investors have come to expect from us." The stock closed Tuesday at $7.34, up 11 cents. Guitar Center reiterates Q3 earns, sales forecasts (7:04 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Guitar Center GTRC reiterated its third-quarter earnings forecast of 39 to 42 cents a share, and said it continues to expect revenue of $342 million to $352 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call are expecting earnings of 42 cents a share and revenue of $349.1 million, on average. Same-store sales are still projected to rise 6 to 8 percent from year-earlier levels. The guitar retailer's stock closed Tuesday up 50 cents at $43.25. Correct: Carrier Access warns of 15-20% Q3 rev. decline (6:59 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Carrier Access CACS, -0.15% warned that third-quarter revenue would fall 15 to 20 percent from the sequential second-quarter's $30.8 million, as consolidation among wireless service providers has resulted in a short-term spending decline. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting revenue of $30.4 million, a decline of just 0.3 percent. The company sees fourth-quarter revenue increasing "slightly" above third-quarter results. The telecommunications network operator's stock closed Tuesday up 39 cents at $7.40. (This replaces an earlier item to reflect revised data from the company.) R.R. Donnelley sees Q3 earns in line with expectations (6:51 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- R.R. Donnelley RRD, +1.39% said it expects third-quarter earnings, excluding non-recurring items, of 48 cents a share, which is in line with the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call. The printing company also reiterated its 2004 earnings estimate of $1.55 a share, vs. current analyst projections of $1.54. The stock closed Tuesday up 13 cents at $31.95. Atos Origin sees 'modest recovery' in IT market in 2005 (3:53 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Atos Origin(FR:005173), the French IT services group, said operating profit rose 29.1 percent to 158.3 million euros for the first half, in line with forecasts by analysts polled by AFX News. Sales increased 72 percent to 2.65 billion euros. Net income before non-recurring items rose 43 percent to 112.2 million euros. It said it much of its performance in the second quarter came from organic growth in France, the U.K. and the Netherlands, despite declining revenues from two major clients, Philips(NL:00953)and Euronext(FR:005777). Atos Origin said: "We remain optimistic that a modest but sustainable recovery in the market will occur next year." The group also reconfirmed its target of achieving an operating profit margin in excess of 7 percent for the full year. Umbro H1 profits rise 47% in first results since IPO (3:13 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Umbro(UK:UMB), the soccer sportswear company, said pre-tax profits before exceptionals rose 47.1 percent to 16.5 million pounds for half-year ending July 4. Revenue increased 36.4 percent to 94.1 million pounds. In its first set of results since the company floated in June, Umbro said it was boosted by record sales of Umbro-sponsored team uniforms in advance of the recent European soccer tournament, as well as an agreement with sportswear chain Foot Locker FL, +1.70% to put Umbro products in over 1,000 stores in the U.S. by the end of the fourth quarter. The company said: "As expected, performance in the first half of 2004 in sales and profits has been exceptionally strong. Against this background the board is confident of the outcome for the full year to December 2004 and of delivering increased shareholder value." Umbro shares rose 0.97 percent in early morning trading. French hotels Accor sees upscale hotels recovery (2:48 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- French hotels and services group Accor(FR:012040)Wednesday said it expects to report full-year pretax profit in the range 570 million to 590 million euro, up from 523 million euro a year ago. The consensus estimate for the full-year pretax profit is aroud 600 million euro, according to AFX News. Accor posted a rise in pre-tax profit in the half year to 225 million euro, up from 180 million euro a year ago and in line with the analyst estimates. Operating results in its upscale segment in the U.S., the U.K., Asia-Pacific, South America and certain countries in Continental Europe rose sharply on a like-for-like basis," it said. The economy segment in the U.S. and the hotels business in France saw only modest like-for-like growth in the period, Accor said, AFX News reported. Gallaher H1 pre-tax profits in line with expectations (2:47 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Gallaher(UK:GLH), the U.K. tobacco company, said profits before tax, amortization and exceptionals for the first half rose 4.4 percent to 250 million pounds, slightly higher than analyst predictions of 248 million pounds, according to an AFX News poll. Net sales increased 10.7 percent to 1.94 billion pounds. The company, which produces Benson and Hedges cigarettes, warned in a trading update in June that the ban on smoking in the workplace in Ireland had cut five-month volumes in that country by over 9 percent. Gallaher said: "We continue to grow our volumes and profits year-on-year in the face of difficult trading conditions in (France, Germany and Austria), coupled with the negative effect of foreign exchange." The company said it said its overall trading remains in line with expectations and benefits from its restructuring programme in the U.K. "should broadly offset worsening conditions" in continental Europe, most notably the impact of the "continued deterioration" of the cigarette market in Germany. UK home builder McCarthy sees prices stabilizing (2:29 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- U.K. home builder McCarthy & Stone(UK:MCTY), echoing an outlook from its peers, Wednesday said it expects the rate of housing price rises in Britian to stabilize following the recent interest rate hikes at the Bank of England. "We now anticipate lower levels of price rises. Demographic factors and the needs of our target market should continue to support strong demand for our form of housing," it said in a sales update ahead of the Aug 31 final results for the year. On Aug. 31, it was carrying forward levels of reservations "comfortably ahead of last year and finished stock and work in progress are approximately 10 percent higher" U.K. retailer Woolworths 1H loss narrows (2:24 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- U.K. retailer Woolworths Group(UK:WLW)said its pre-tax loss in the first half of the year narrowed to 34.4 million pounds from 36.4 million in the year ago period as sales rose 5.9 percent to 1.1 billion pounds. Same-store sales rose 0.3 percent. Looking ahead, it said sales "in the first five weeks of the second half has been mixed although the underlying retail gross margin has continued to improve compared to last year... We move into Christmas with confidence." More from MarketWatch How to Get a Job: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Don’t ever do this with your credit card Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Among the companies whose shares are likely to see active trading in Thursday's session are chipmakers National Semiconductor NSM, -0.28% and Texas Instruments TXN, +1.94% National Semiconductor is expected to report earnings of 26 cents a share for its fiscal first quarter, according to analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Shares of Texas Instruments rose 1.5 percent in late trading Wednesday after it said it expects third-quarter earnings above the midpoint of its current target range, but warned that sales could fall below its original forecast due to inventory reductions among its semiconductor customers. See full story. Also in late trading Wednesday, Cosine Communications COSN fell 13 percent after it said it would lay off most of its workers this month after evaluating strategic alternatives. It said it would keep a few employees to supply customer support. Thursday's watch list ABM Industries ABM, +0.75% said that its third-quarter net income rose to $13.4 million, or 27 cents per share, from $11.7 million or 23 cents a share in the year-ago period. The figure includes $1.2 million, or 2 cents a share, in after-tax income from operations that were sold to Otis Elevator. Sales rose 9.6 percent to $623.8 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were expecting a profit of 25 cents a share on revenue of $625.3 million in the latest quarter. The company also reiterated its 2004 earnings forecast of 80 cents to 85 cents a share. AFC Enterprises AFCE said it is selling Cinnabon to privately held Focus Brands for $30.3 million in cash. The deal includes franchise rights for Seattle's Best Coffee in Hawaii, U.S. military bases and 11 countries. The transaction is expected to close in the fourth quarter. America's Car-Mart CRMT, +0.00% is expected to report earnings of 59 cents a share for its fiscal first quarter. Boeing BA, +2.46% said it has received a contract to build three satellites for DirecTV DTV, +0.36% Boeing said these spacecrafts will provide DirecTV with national and local broadcast coverage in high-definition television. Shares of Comverse Technology CMVT which makes systems and software for multimedia communications, rose 4.9 percent after it reported second-quarter earnings of 6 cents a share on sales of $233.4 million, ahead of expectations for a profit of 5 cents a share on sales of $228 million. See full story. Corning GLW, +1.94% reaffirmed its third-quarter revenue forecast of $950 million to $1 billion and its pro-forma earnings view of 10 cents a share to 12 cents a share, before special items. Analysts expect the company to report third-quarter earnings of 11 cents a share on sales of $974 million Dun & Bradstreet DNB, -0.71% said it is increasing its 2004 earnings forecast because it has agreed to sell its France-based business for about $32 million. See full story. Equity Residential Properties Trust EQR, +0.11% cut its third-quarter forecast, citing damage at its Florida properties from Hurricanes Charley and Frances. The Chicago-based company cut its third-quarter earnings forecast to a range of 19 cents to 20 cents a share. Its funds from operations forecast for the period is now 50 cents a share to 51 cents a share. Equity Residential also reiterated its expectation that 2004 results will be near the bottom of its forecast. The firm is looking for $1.21 a share to $1.35 a share in earnings and funds from operations of $2.15 to $2.29 a share for the year. FNB FNB, +0.98% said Litz Van Dyke, its chief operating officer, has resigned. Van Dyke also resigned as president and chief executive of FNB unit First National Bank. R. Bruce Munro was named First National Bank's interim president and chief executive. Furniture Brands International FBN said it expects to report third-quarter earnings of 36 cents to 38 cents a share. The forecast is on the upper end of its earlier estimate. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call are expecting earnings of 36 cents a share. Geac Computer GEAC said its first-quarter earnings rose 44.3 percent on strong software license revenue growth, but the software firm missed analysts' revenue mark. Geac said earnings for the first quarter were $13.5 million, or 15 cents per share, compared with $9.4 million or 11 cents per share. The company added that first-quarter revenue was $106.9 million versus $101.5 million a year ago. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were looking for first-quarter earnings of 14 cents a share on revenue of $111 million. Grey Global Group GREY has a new bidder in French advertising conglomerate Havas. See full story. Jos. A. Bank Clothiers JOSB is seen reporting a profit of 24 cents a share for its second quarter. Staffing firm Kforce KFRC, +1.12% raised its third-quarter forecast due to strong demand for skilled workers. The company increased its third-quarter earnings outlook to 13 cents to 15 cents a share. It sees revenue of $183 million and $186 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were expecting a profit of 12 cents a share on $176.9 million in revenue. Main Street Banks MSBK named Samuel Hay its chief executive officer, effective January 1, 2005. Hay is currently the company's chief operating officer and president. He is replacing the outgoing chief executive, Edward Milligan, who will continue to serve as chairman of the board. Shares of Martek Bioscience MATK which makes products derived from microalgae, fell 4.8 percent after it reported fiscal third-quarter profit of 16 a per share on sales of $47.3 million. Analysts were expecting a profit of 14 cents per share on sales of $46 million for its fiscal third quarter. But the company said demand for its product significantly exceeded its production capacity. Massey Energy MEE, +1.42% said third-quarter earnings could fall at, or slightly below, the low end of its previous expectation of earnings in the range of 10 cents to 30 cents a share. The outlook excludes a noncash, pretax charge of about $3.5 million, or 3 cents per share. The coal company blamed productivity issues and shipping shortfalls for the revised outlook. Monarch Community Bancorp MCBF said it named Don Denney as president and chief executive. Monarch said Bill Kurtz, who was Monarch's acting chief executive, would remain as chief financial officer. Outback Steakhouse OSI, -2.84% said it estimates its Hurricane Frances losses of about 250 operating days and between $2.8 million to $3 million in revenue. Separately, the restaurant operator said it bought an additional 39 percent interest in the joint venture that runs Fleming's Prime Steakhouse and Wine Bar for about $39 million. It expects the acquisition to add $2 million to $2.2 million to its net income over the next 12 months. Quiksilver ZQK is expected to report a fiscal third-quarter profit of 29 cents a share. Communication products company Remec REMC fell 12 percent after reporting a loss of $1.23 per share, including a goodwill impairment charge of $62.4 million. It said sales rose 35.6 percent to $108.8 million. Rent-A-Center RCII, -0.80% warned investors that third-quarter earnings will come in below analysts' forecasts because of the impact from higher fuel prices. See full story. Shoe Carnival SCVL, -1.65% said W. Kerry Jackson has been promoted to chief financial officer. Shoe Carnival said Jackson has held various accounting positions with the company. Shuffle Master SHFL said it has named Richard Baldwin as chief financial officer. Take-Two Interactive Software TTWO, +0.33% is seen posting a loss of 30 cents a share for its fiscal third quarter. TCF Financial TCB, +0.00% said it plans merge its TCF Mortgage unit into TCF National Bank as of Dec. 1. TCF Financial expects expenses related to the reorganization to total $2.5 million, with $1.2 million in the third quarter. Troy Group TROY which makes of electronic payment and check printing systems, said it has filed a lawsuit against investment firm Westar Capital for allegedly making bids to buy Troy, with the sole intent of "disrupting the market" for Troy stock and foiling the proposed acquisition of the company by its founder, Patrick Dirk. Ulticom ULCM which makes human resources and payroll management software, rose 6.9 percent after it reported a second-quarter profit of 9 cents per share on sales of $16.1 million. Analysts had been expecting a profit of 5 cents per share on sales of $13 million. United Airlines UALAQ said it will begin charging passengers $5 for tickets that they buy at airport counters and $10 for tickets they purchase over the phone through their reservation offices. United said the move is meant to help lower its distribution costs. URS URS, +1.00% said it has received a contract extension worth about $14 million from the Los Angeles Unified School District to provide services to the schools' repair and construction bond program. The total maximum value of the contract to URS is now more than $80 million. Verizon Communications VZ, -0.37% said it has agreed to sell its Canadian directory business, SuperPages Canada, to investment firm Bain Capital for $1.54 billion. The deal is expected to close by the end of 2004. More from MarketWatch Uber for Bikes Could Save Your Commute More Coverage 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Geac, Jos. A. Bank, Nat Semi, Remec

content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- ABM Industries Inc. ABM, +0.75% said late Wednesday that its third-quarter net income rose to $13.4 million, or 27 cents a share, from $11.7 million, or 23 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The figure in the latest period includes $1.2 million, or 2 cents a share, in after-tax income from operations that were sold to Otis Elevator. Sales rose 9.6 percent to $623.8 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were expecting a profit of 25 cents a share on revenue of $625.3 million in the latest quarter. The company also reiterated its full-year earnings forecast of 80 to 85 cents a share.
title: ABM Q3 net rises

content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Among the companies whose shares are likely to see active trading in Wednesday's session are Texas Instruments and Amvescamp. Texas Instruments will issue a midquarter update shortly after the markets close. Amvescamp's Invesco Funds Group and AIM Advisors late Tuesday agreed to pay $450 million in penalties and reduced fees to settle allegations that they allowed fraudulent trades in their funds. In one of the harshest punishments against mutual fund companies implicated in the industry trading scandal, British financial services giant Amvescap's AVZ, +8.51% Invesco and AIM units agreed to pay $140 million in civil penalties and $235 million in restitution in a preliminary settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission and the states of New York, Colorado and Georgia. They will also lower management fees by $75 million, Amvescap said. See full story. Texas Instruments, the world's fourth largest chipmaker in 2993 according to iSuppli, will issue a third quarter midquarter update after the close of market Wednesday. Previously, TI had predicted earnings of 26 to 29 cents a share and sales of $3.2 billion to $3.4 billion. Analysts on Wall Street expect earnings of 27 cents and sales of $3.31 billion, on average, according to Thomson First Call. See full story. Wednesday's Watch List ABM Industries ABM, +0.75% is expected to report earnings of 25 cents a share Wednesday for its fiscal third quarter, according to analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. AirTran Holdings AAI, +0.00% parent of AirTran Airways, said late Tuesday that it will report a third-quarter loss. The Orlando, Fla.-based low-cost carrier blamed the two recent hurricanes in Florida, record high fuel prices, and a weak revenue environment for airlines. AirTran did not estimate how much it expects to lose. "Both our Orlando headquarters and aircraft hangar in Orlando suffered damage and further harmed operations," the airline added in a statement. Bob Evans Farms BOBE said same-store sales in its core Bob Evans Restaurants (those open for the full 12 months in both fiscal 2003 and 2004) fell 4.6 percent in August. Same-store sales at core Mimi's Café restaurants, meanwhile, were up 2.9 percent for the month. Bob Evans maintained its previously announced second-quarter earnings forecast of 40 cents a share. Coach COH, +6.26% said it expects to report first-quarter results above analysts' estimates. The company forecast first-quarter sales of $335 million, with an earnings outlook of 32 cents a share, up from last year's reported $258 million in sales, with earnings of 22 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call are expecting first-quarter earnings of 31 cents a share, on sales of $333 million. Coach said it expects to report sales of $1.6 billion for the fiscal year 2005, with earnings of $1.71 a share. The leather-goods maker also announced that it completed its repurchase and retirement of 2.4 million common shares at a cost of $39.06 a share. Comverse Technology CMVT is expected to report second-quarter earnings of 5 cents a share according to analysts. Dave & Busters DAB, +0.23% is expected to report second-quarter earnings of 14 cents a share. Dean Foods DF, -0.12% lowered its third-quarter financial outlook, citing high costs, rising raw milk prices and a highly competitive grocery environment. The company said it now expects to report third-quarter earnings of 44 cents to 46 cents a share; fourth-quarter earnings of 63 cents to 66 cents a share; and full-year earnings of $2 to $2.05 a share. Separately, Dean Foods announced that it has increased it share buyback authorization to $200 million. In the third quarter, the company repurchased $78.6 million in stock. Dominion Resources D, -0.53% said that it has agreed to buy three electric power plants from USGen New England for $656 million. The purchase price includes $536 million in cash and an inventory adjustment and reimbursement of capital expenditures, estimated at an additional $120 million. See full story. E-Trade Financial ET, +2.49% said that it has cut fees on its index funds again to lure assets away from rivals such as Fidelity, Vanguard and Charles Schwab. E-Trade said dropped the expense ratio on its S&P 500 index funds to nine basis points from 10. The expense ratio on its international index funds was also lowered to nine basis points from 33. E-Trade began lowering fees on its index funds in April. See full story. Korn Ferry International KFY, +0.47% is expected to report first-quarter earnings of 14 cents a share. Martek Boscience MATK is expected to report third-quarter earnings 14 cents a share when it reports Wednesday. NCI Building NCS, +1.72% said it has filed suit against its founder and former chief executive officer, Johnie Schulte, over claims of breach of contract. The company alleges that Schulte has violated terms of an agreement he made with the company in exchange for an accelerated option vesting schedule and payments totaling more than $3.6 million. Under the agreement, made upon his retirement, Schulte agreed not to compete with NCI Building, solicit its employees or divulge its confidential information. The company claims Schulte is in violation of those terms and is asking the court to terminate its $3.6 million worth of payments to him and to enjoin him from further violations. Neiman Marcus NMG said that strong sales at full prices helped the luxury retailer post a fourth-quarter profit that zipped 187 percent higher than year earlier earnings and easily sailed past Wall Street's expectations. The parent of the namesake chain as well as Bergdorf Goodman stores earned $20.5 million, or 42 cents a share, compared with $7.1 million, or 15 cents a share, a year ago. At Thomson First Call, analysts had reached a consensus earnings estimate of 36 cents a share. See full story. Radiation Therapy Services RTSX said it has agreed to buy three radiation centers in New Jersey for an undisclosed sum. The purchase, which the company will finance, using its existing credit line, is expected to add to Radiation Therapy's earnings. Remec REMC is expected to report second-quarter earnings of 7 cents a share. Stewart Enterprises STEI is expected to report third-quarter earnings of 8 cents a share. TriQuint Semiconductor TQNT fell 3.8 percent in Tuesday evening trading after it cut its financial outlook for the current quarter due to a few wireless phone customers working off excess inventory. The communications chipmaker now expects a third-quarter loss of 3 or 4 cents a share and sales between $88 million and $90 million. TriQuint had predicted breakeven earnings or a loss of 1 cent a share and sales between $92 million and $94 million. See full story. Tyco International TYC, +74.50% in a bid to strengthen its balance sheet, said it repurchased $350 million of its 2.75 percent convertible bonds, due in 2018, with $511 million in cash. The move will result in a $167 million charge to the company's fourth-quarter earnings, it said. "As a result of this action ... Tyco's underlying common shares will be reduced by 15 million," the Bermuda-based company said. Tyco, a diversified equipment manufacturer, also reaffirmed its previous earnings forecast of 41-43 cents a share for the fourth quarter of 2004, excluding restructuring and early debt retirement. Ultimate Software ULTI, +2.55% is expected to report a third-quarter loss of 6 cents a share. More from MarketWatch How to Get a Job: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’ S&P 500 logs longest losing streak of the year as trade-war jitters weigh Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Texas Instruments, TriQuint Semi, Neiman Marcus, ABM

content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) - Among the companies whose shares are expected to see active trading is H&R Block HRB, +1.03% The tax preparation firm is expected to report fourth-quarter earnings of $3.16 a share on sales of $2.14 billion, according to analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Martek Biosciences MATK is seen reporting a per-share profit of 14 cents on sales of $39 million for its second quarter. Martek makes products derived from microalgae. Analysts expect Net2Phone NTOP to post a third-quarter loss of 12 cents a share and revenue of $20 million. Omnivision Technologies OVTI, +1.49% is scheduled to report results for fourth-quarter. The company, which produces semiconductor image sensor devices, is seen earning 31 cents a share on sales of $101 million. Smithfield Foods SFD, +2.50% is expected to post a fourth-quarter EPS of 51 cents with sales of $2.51 billion. Liberty Media L, +0.59% is holding its annual shareholder meeting while Brocade Communications BRCD is hosting an analyst meeting in San Francisco. MGM Mirage MGG, +3.51% has extended to Friday night a deadline for Mandalay Resort Group's MBG, +0.43% response to a $7.6 billion buyout offer. See full story. ABM Industries ABM, +0.75% reported a narrower profit in its second quarter. ABM posted a second-quarter profit of $6.8 million, or 14 cents a share, vs. $9.9 million, or 20 cents a share, last year. It also said it sees 2004 per-share earnings of 80 cents to 85 cents. Separately, the facilities services firm upped its dividend 5.3 percent to 10 cents a share. More from MarketWatch Uber for Bikes Could Save Your Commute More Coverage Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau Don’t ever do this with your credit card Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: H&R Block, Market, MGM Mirage, ABM, Smithfield Foods

content: Editor's note: Corrects to reflect the company reported a profit. SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- ABM Industries reported a lower second-quarter profit late Tuesday. ABM ABM, +0.75% posted a second-quarter profit of $6.8 million, or 14 cents a share, vs. $9.9 million, or 20 cents a share, last year. Shares closed up 23 cents to $19.55 ahead of the announcement. The facilities services provider reported sales of $590.3 million, up from $562.5 million last year. ABM said its second-quarter results included after-tax income of 2 cents a share from the sale of its elevation operations to Otis Elevator during the fourth quarter of 2003. The company reported a 33.6 percent jump in sales for its security unit and an 11 percent rise in engineering sales. ABM said it was disappointed in its lighting unit, sales for which fell almost 14 percent from last year due to a slowdown in retrofit projects. It also said it sees 2004 per-share earnings of 80 cents to 85 cents. Separately, ABM said it upped its dividend 5.3 percent to 10 cents a share, payable to shareholders of record as of July 12. title: ABM Industries posts Q2 profit

content: On June 8, CBS MarketWatch incorrectly reported quarterly earnings for ABM Industries ABM, +0.75% The company posted a profit of $6.8 million. See full story. More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? More Coverage Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date S&P 500 logs longest losing streak of the year as trade-war jitters weigh
title: ABM Industries earnings

content: Among the companies whose shares are expected to see active trading in Tuesday's session is ABM Industries ABM, +0.75% The a provider of janitorial, parking and security services for commercial facilities is seen reporting earnings of 25 cents a share for the fourth quarter, according to analysts polled by Thomson First Call. AutoZone AZO, +1.80% the largest U.S. auto parts retailer, is expected to post a fiscal first-quarter profit of $1.28 a share. Fiscal first-quarter numbers are due for release from Costco Wholesale COST, +2.63% for which the largest U.S. warehouse club operator is seen posting a 31-cent per-share profit. Grocer Kroger Co. is expected to report earnings of 29 cents a share for the third quarter. Hewlett-Packard HPQ, +1.06% will host an analyst meeting Tuesday morning in New York. Analysts will likely get an update on organizational changes at H-P, which include Friday's appointment of long-time executive Gilles Bouchard to head up the company's information technology and global operations. On Monday, Sanford Bernstein analyst Toni Sacconaghi issued a research note that said H-P would have been more profitable this year had it not merged with Compaq in 2002. The meeting is scheduled to begin at 8 am EST. Pharma giant and Dow component Merck & Co. MRK, -1.13% will hold an annual business update starting at 9 am EST. Texas Instruments TXN, +1.94% said late Monday that fourth-quarter earnings, including an expected 7 cents a share from the sale of Micron Technologies MU, +1.26% stock, should be 25 to 27 cents, while revenue should be between $2.64 billion and $2.77 billion. The gain of 7 cents a share stems from TI's previously announced sale of shares in Micron Technology. During the previous quarter, TI also sold some Micron stock, which it had acquired as compensation from its 1999 sale of its memory unit to Micron. See full story Internet access provider EarthLink ELNK said late Monday it expects a net addition of 225,000 subscribers in the fourth quarter, up from a previous estimate of 100,000 to 175,000. Fifty thousand of the subscribers come from the company's acquisition of Stargate.net. EarthLink did not change its outlook for earnings or revenue in the fourth quarter. Shares of EarthLink added 1.6 percent to trade at $9.54 after the bell. Drugmaker Sepracor SEPR said it planned to raise $600 million through a debt offering that's convertible into company stock. Sepracor said it would use the money to redeem an earlier convertible debt offering. Sepracor shares fell $1.22, or 4.7 percent, to $24.50 after-hours. Akamai Technologies AKAM, +1.33% raised its fourth-quarter and full-year sales forecasts, citing strong demand, including an increase in holiday season e-commerce-related traffic. Akamai said it expects fourth-quarter revenue of $43 million to $45 million and full-year sales of $159 million to $161 million. In October, the company said it expected sales in the quarter of $42 million to $44 million, and full-year sales of $158 million to $160 million. One analyst polled by Thomson First Call expects sales of $43 million the fourth quarter, while two analysts are forecasting sales of $159.5 million for the year. Shares of Akamai fell 65 cents, or 5.9 percent, in late dealings to $10.33. Luxury home builder Hovnanian Enterprises HOV, +0.55% reported a fourth-quarter profit of $91.2 million, or $2.79 a share, compared with earnings of $54.4 million, or $1.66 a share, the year before. Revenue rose to $1.05 billion from $831.4 million. Analysts had expected the company to post a profit of $2.68 a share, according to Thomson First Call, on sales of $955.1 million. Hovnanian also upped its forecast for fiscal 2004, saying it now expects earnings of $9 a share on sales of $3.9 billion. Analysts are currently looking for earnings of $9 a share for the year and revenue of $3.85 billion, according to Thomson First Call. At last check, shares of Hovnanian fell 19 cents to $96.42 Remec REMC which makes voice and data transmission equipment, said it lost $4.08 million, or 7 cents a share, in the third quarter, narrowing from a loss of $12 million, or 26 cents a share, the year before. Sales in the period rose to $104.1 million from $59.4 million. The results missed the forecast of analysts, who had been looking for a loss of a penny a share, according to Thomson First Call. Shares of Remec lost 71 cents, or 6.4 percent, in late dealings to $10.35. Stanley Works SWK, +1.56% said late Monday that it was upping its fourth-quarter revenue forecast after sales growth for the first two months of the quarter exceeded expectations. Year-over-year sales at the tool maker rose 19 percent in October and November and as a result, the company expects fourth-quarter revenue to increase by a percentage in the midteens. Stanley Works also said it had accelerated work on its Operation 15 project and now sees a corresponding fourth-quarter charge of 18-22 cents a share. Overall, the company now expects GAAP earnings of 45-53 cents a share for the fourth quarter, and earnings excluding charges of 68-71 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call are currently looking for a fourth-quarter profit of 64 cents a share. Stanley Works stock closed up 84 cents at $34.26 on Monday. US Airways UAIR said late Monday that due to higher booking fees, its ticket and reservations will no longer be available through Expedia.com, effective immediately. US Airways said that Expedia raised the booking fee that it charges customers to purchase US Airways tickets from $5 to $8.99 while the booking fee for other airlines remains at $5, according to a company press release. US Airways also said that Expedia's booking fees have gone up about 80 percent. Shares of US Airways ended Monday's session down 62 cents at $6.13, while share of Interactive Corp. IACI, +0.00% Expedia's parent company, rose 6 cents to close at $30.29 Brown Shoe Co. BWS said late Monday that it will close its Perth, Ontario manufacturing plant and taking a corresponding fourth-quarter charge. The maker of Naturalizer shoes said the move is an effort to reduce costs and focus its Canadian operation on building market share. Brown said it will take an after-tax charge of $3.8 million to $4.2 million, or 20-22 cents a share, in the fourth quarter. The plant employs 304 people. In an unrelated development Monday, the company said a Colorado state jury found a Brown subsidiary partially responsible for environmental damage to a neighborhood near a former Brown plant and ordered it to pay residents $1 million in damages. Shares of Brown ended Monday's session up 76 cents at $33.26 Monday's advancers Shares of Cardiac Science DFIB, +0.00% shot up more than 15 percent after the company announced overnight that it was granted a patent covering portable defibrillators. The company plans to launch its fully-automatic version of its Powerheart AED G3 - which can be used on a heart attack victim by a bystander - in the first quarter of 2004. The bystander only needs to properly attach the AED to the victim, the AED G3 does the rest. Shares of Petroleum Development Corp. PETD gained more than 11 percent after the natural gas company announced late Friday that its fourth 2003 drilling partnership, with $35 million in subscriptions, closed earlier than anticipated with maximum subscriptions allowable. In 2002, subscriptions in the fourth partnership were $29.1 million. For the year, total partnerships total $78.3 million, up 38 percent from 2002's $56.9 million. Shares of Sorrento Networks FIBR, -0.08% rallied more than 16 percent after the optical network equipment maker said fiscal third-quarter revenue rose 22 percent over year-earlier levels to $6.7 million, due to new orders for its LuxN products. In addition, the company noted that it shipped its first Internet backbone system to a Web access provider in Japan. The company expects to reveal full quarterly results on Dec. 17 Shares of Valley Commerce Bank VLYB soared almost 46 percent after it said late Friday that it would pay a special cash dividend of $2.25 a share on Jan. 5, 2004, to shareholders of record as of Dec. 15. "This $3 million extraordinary dividend is a reward to shareholders for their support over the years which was accomplished with the commitment and loyalty of the bank's clients and employees," said chief executive Robert Homco. Monday's decliners Avon Products AVP, -1.05% gave up almost 8 percent after it raised its fourth-quarter earnings forecast to $1.03 to $1.04 a share to reflect the gain of approximately 5 cents a share from the settlement of tax issues. Analysts surveyed by Reuters Research had previously been expecting earnings of $1 a share, on average. Sales for the quarter should grow 13 percent, or in the "high-single-digits" when excluding the impact of currency translation, due to 16 percent growth in the sale of beauty products and 9 percent growth in the number of active representatives. Shares of BioCryst Pharmaceuticals BCRX, -0.21% dropped more than 10 percent after the company presented results of the first of four ongoing Phase I studies for intravenous BCX-1777 in aggressive T-Cell malignancies. Volume is 1.4 million shares, which is already about 10-times the full-day average. The company said a clinical effect was seen in 4 of the patients, and that it was well-tolerated, with few drug-related adverse events. Shares of biotechnology firm CV Therapeutics CVTX slid more than 27 percent after First Albany downgraded the stock citing negative Food and Drug Administration briefing documents that suggest that its angina treatment Ranexa is unlikely to be approved without a substantial new clinical trial. An FDA advisory panel is expected to make a recommendation on whether should be approved on Tuesday. The FDA typically follows the recommendations of its advisory panels. Health Management Associates HMA took a more than 11-percent dive after UBS downgraded hospital operator's shares to "reduce" from "neutral," given that the gross charges have come under increased scrutiny from policy makers, as well as from attorney generals and the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The firm also cut its price target on the stock to $18 from $25. Investment Technology Group ITG, +0.77% slumped more than 5 percent after saying U.S. trading volume for the month of November was 1.4 billion shares, or an average of 73 million shares a day, down 26 percent from 1.9 billion shares, or an average of 80 million shares a day, in the year-earlier period. In October 2003, 1.8 million shares, or 73 million shares day, changed hands. Shares of the equity trading services provider closed Friday down 44 cents at $16.62. SCO Group shares SCOX slumped 8 percent after IBM IBM, +0.60% won a legal point Friday in the Linux patent infringement suit filed against it by SCO, according to CNet. At a Salt Lake City hearing, Judge Dale Kimball ordered SCO to produce evidence within 30 days of the specific infringement by IBM. Big Blue had sought the computer code specifics in a motion to the court. Smith & Wesson Holding Corp. SWB the parent company of the handgun manufacturer, dropped almost 6 percent after saying late Friday that its chairman, president and secretary have resigned as part of a corporate governance move. Mitchell Saltz stepped down as chairman and chief executive officer of the holding company; Colt Melby resigned as president; Sherry Noreen resigned as secretary. Saltz and Melby will remain on the company's board. Roy Cuny, the CEO of the company's Smith & Wesson Corp., was named as chairman, chief executive officer and president of the holding company and will continue in his other roles, as well. More from MarketWatch What Picking Up an Apple Tells You About the Future of Robotics More Coverage 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Stocks to watch Tuesday: TI, HPQ, AMB, REMC, SEPR

content: Among the companies whose shares are anticipated to be active in Tuesday's trading session is ABM Industries ABM, +0.75% The cleaning and parking services company is seen posting earnings of 24 cents a share for the third quarter of 2003, according to Thomson First Call, a penny below the comparable quarter last year. Neiman-Marcus NMG is scheduled to report fourth-quarter results, with expectations of a 12 cent per-share profit. And Texas Instruments TXN, +1.94% will hold a conference call to discuss its progress thus far in the third quarter. RIM RIMM maker of the BlackBerry e-mail device, said that it expects to earn 2 cents to 5 cents per share in the second quarter, topping its previous forecast. The Waterloo, Ont.-based company also said that, due to global demand for the BlackBerry, sales could be as high as $123 million to $126 million, well above its previous range of $105 million to $115 million. See full story. Shares of RIM added $6.82 to change hands for $35.06. Shares of McDonald's MCD, -1.28% jumped 8 percent, to $25.22, after the fast-food giant said same-store sales in August climbed 3.8 percent system-wide and 8.8 percent in the U.S. Total sales jumped 10 percent to $4.19 billion. In Europe, promotions and menu changes helped increase same-store sales 1 percent and contributed to "positive performance" in several markets, including France and Germany. Cymer CYMI, +0.00% which makes eximer lasers used to manufacture semiconductors, said third-quarter revenue will be about $64 million, at the high end of its targets, while other operating results will be in line with expectations. The outlook sent Cymer stock up 1.6 percent, to $48.99. Comverse Technology CMVT a supplier of telecom software, said it swung to a loss in the second quarter. Comverse lost $1.1 million, or a penny per share, versus earnings of $3.9 million, or 2 cents a share, last year. Excluding items, the company said it lost 3 cents a share, beating the consensus forecast of analysts surveyed by Thomson First call that had been expecting a 4-cent per-share loss. Sales in the period rose to $188.5 million from $181.2 million. At last check, Comverse shares had shed 9 cents, to $17.70. Voice and data transmission equipment maker Remec REMC beat analysts expectations by a penny. The company reported a second-quarter loss for fiscal 2004 of $3.6 million, or 6 cents a share, versus a loss of $10.9 million, or 24 cents a share in the same period last year. Revenue rose to $86.2 million from $53.5 million. The results sent shares of Remec up 14 percent in recent dealings, to change hands for $12.19. FirstEnergy Corp. FE, -1.10% which issued stock Monday, said the public offering would reduce the company's 2003 earnings by 2.5 percent. FirstEnergy now expects to earn $2.61 to $2.81 a share, down from $2.68 to $2.88 a share. Including special items, FirstEnergy expects to earn $1.91 to $2.11 a share. Shares closed at $30.60, up 35 cents, ahead of the announcement. Lucent Technologies LU will make changes to its management retiree healthcare subsidies that will yield the telecom equipment company about $75 million in annual savings, according to a document filed Monday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Lucent said that as of 2004, it will no longer pay for dental coverage for its management retirees and their dependents and will not reimburse them for the cost of Medicare Part B premiums. The firm will no longer provide subsidies for dependents of management retirees who retired on or after March 1, 1990, and whose base salary at retirement was $87,000 or more. Lucent shares ended Monday up 15 cents at $2.37. The Federal Trade Commission has asked ArvinMeritor ARM, +3.57% for more information related to its $2.2 billion hostile bid for Dana Corp. DCN, -3.61% The requests extends the regulatory waiting period, during which the FTC can review the proposed acquisition, ArvinMeritor said in a statement. ArvinMeritor said the FTC's request was not unusual and it will work with the regulator. Standard Microsystems SMSC said it will collaborate with Intel INTC, +5.00% on input/output parts and sensors on future Pentium 4 platforms and motherboards. Monday's advancers Abgenix ABGX shares rose 16 percent after Merrill Lynch said the valuation gap between the biotech company and partner Imclone is not justified. In a note to clients, analyst Eric Ende said positive news on Imclone's Erbitux cancer drug should benefit Abgenix, which is developing another cancer treatment called ABX-EGF in collaboration with Imclone. ABX-EGF works using a similar mechanism to Erbitux but may have a better safety profile and more flexible dosing schedule because it is a fully human antibody, said Ende. "We do not believe the valuation gap deserves to be quite as large as this," said the analyst. Imclone currently has a market cap of $3 billion, against Abgenix' $1 billion. Shares ended up 16 percent at $15.67. IBM IBM, +0.60% shares rose more than 2 percent after Credit Suisse First Boston upgraded its rating on the company to 'outperform' from neutral overnight. Shares in euro trading in Frankfurt rose 93 cents to $87.88, dealers said. CSFB raised its 2004 earnings estimate to $5.10 from $4.80 a share, and put a $102 price target on the stock, representing 20-times its 2004 earnings estimate. "Due to the complexion of its installed base - mainly large, slower moving IT commercial customers, IBM is the ideal late cycle tech spending recovery play," the broker said. "Tech spending has recovered in consumer and SMB markets but has yet to experience meaningful recovery in large commercial accounts. We believe this is about to change." Shares rose 2.5 percent to close at $89.10. Nabi Biopharmaceuticals' NABI shares rose more than 14 percent after the Rockville, Md., firm said it has successfully completed an immunogenicity trial using material from the lot of StaphVAX that it plans to use in a phase III trial later this year. The company said the results demonstrate an excellent safety and tolerability profile for StaphVAX and that Nabi can transfer production of StaphVAX to a contract manufacturing facility. StaphVAX is being developed to treat renal disease. Shares added 14.2 percent to end at $7.40. Proxim PROX, +0.00% jumped 17 percent after the wireless networking equipment maker said Swedish wireless infrastructure giant Ericsson ERICY said it would incorporate Proxim wireless products into the wireless local area networking (WLAN) products Ericsson is delivering to China Mobile. Ericsson's WLAN product will be deployed by China Mobile in 10 cities and provinces, including Beijing and Shandong. Shares added 17 percent to close at $2.34. Redback Networks' RBAK gained more than 77 percent after the company unveiled its SMS 1800 SL system, and the XFE Forwarding Engine module. The company said these products are able to boost the performance of a broadband network by two to three times over its existing platform. Shares finished at 78 cents, up 77.3 percent. RF Micro Devices RFMD rallied more than 16 percent after the communications chipmaker upped its fiscal second-quarter outlook in a phone interview with Reuters, citing and improved product mix and rising customer demand. The company now expects to post a slight net profit for the quarter ending September, or breakeven on a per-share basis, versus an average analyst loss forecast compiled by Thomson First Call of a loss of 3 cents a share, Reuters reported. Revenue is expected to grow at least 10 percent to the middle $140 million range, the report said, versus analyst projections of $135.8 million. Shares rose 16.1 percent to $10.46. Monday's decliners LCC International LCCI shares fell more than 8 percent after the company filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of 2 million shares to be issued by the company, and 5 million shares held by certain shareholders. The deal includes an over-allotment option for the sale of an additional 1.05 million shares owned by LCC. Shares ended at $4.92, down 8 percent. Shares of Peet's Coffee & Tea PEET lost more than 7 percent after WR Hambrecht cut the stock to "hold" from "buy" and said its current valuation amply reflects its growth outlook and financial performance. "We see little if any upside to our estimates to justify a higher valuation at this time," analyst Kristine Koerber told clients in a note. Koerber applauded the marketer of fresh whole bean coffee's efforts to improve unit growth, revamp store menus, increase office distribution and expand grocery store distribution but cautioned that the management team has a lot on its plate. Hambrecht is sticking with a $20 price target on the stock. Shares fell 7.1 percent to close at $21.49. Selectica SLTC tumbled more than 8 percent on news that CEO Sanjay Mittal is quitting. The provider of interactive selling systems for e-business also warned that second quarter revenues could miss targets by 10 percent if a health insurance transaction does not go through. Selectica shares were down 40 cents, or 9.5 percent, at $3.79. The company said the CEO is stepping down for personal reasons and confirmed that a search for a replacement is underway. "The quarter is currently tracking according to our expectations," said CFO Stephen Bennion. "However, if we fail to close one specific transaction related to our health insurance vertical by the end of the quarter as planned, our revenue would fall approximately 10 percent below our guidance." Shares shed 8.3 percent to end at $3.85. More from MarketWatch Samsung Galaxy S9: Putting the Camera to the Test More Coverage Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid 2 sexy ways to get paid to save S&P 500 logs longest losing streak of the year as trade-war jitters weigh Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Stocks to watch Tuesday: RIMM, ABM, MCD, NMG.A, TXN

content: With President Bush set to ask for billions in new aid to reconstruct Iraq, firms such as the oil and gas expert Halliburton HAL, +1.93% could be the beneficiaries. Administration officials say the war-ravaged country's water, gas, phone and other networks need to be quickly rebuilt to speed up the reconstruction process. On Tuesday, Neiman-Marcus NMG is scheduled to report fourth-quarter results, with expectations of 12 cents a share, a penny below the year-ago number. ABM Industries ABM, +0.75% is seen posting 24 cents a share, also a penny below results the cleaning services company reported in the comparable 2002 quarter. Alfacell ACEL said late Friday that it completed a private placement of $1.5 million in stock and warrants to an institutional investor. The cancer research company said it sold about 1.7 million shares and about 852,000 warrants that carry an exercise price of $1.50 a share. If shareholders approve a plan at their next meeting to increase the number of shares, the latest buyer will gain a warrant to purchase an additional $1.5 million worth of shares. American Bio Medica ABMC, +0.00% which makes diagnostic kits for biotechnology, said late Friday that Gerald Moore is leaving as board chairman and chief executive officer. Donal Carroll will be the interim CEO. Board member Gerald Lynch will fill in as chairman. American Pharmaceutical Partners APPX said late Friday that it filed to sell $150 million of stock or debt securities but that nothing will be offered until it unblinds and analyzes results later this month of a Phase 3 clinical trial for its breast cancer medication. Boston Scientific BSX, +2.40% could face surprising setbacks in its drive to license a drug-coated stent, Barron's says. The company's product, already approved in Europe, faces a key Food and Drug Administration hearing Sept. 15 in a bid for U.S. approval. With the U.S. market for the artery devices estimated at $4 billion a year, Johnson & Johnson's stent has already been approved by the FDA. Barron's notes J&J attempts to block Boston Scientific with patent claims and says its examination of court transcripts suggest the maneuver might work. Such a setback would alter the pricing assumptions on Boston Scientific, as Barron's notes Wall Street is assuming a product approval. Casella Waste Systems CWST, -0.04% said late Friday that a committee of county officials in Ontario County in New York had approved the company for a 25-year contract to develop and manage a solid-waste landfill. A final vote is required by the county council. Chico's FAS CHS, +0.33% an apparel retailer, said late Friday that it completed the purchase of The White House, a women's clothing label, for $85.7 million in cash and 150,622 shares of Chico's common stock. Ciber CBR, +5.48% provided a quarter outlook late Friday of $175 million to $177 million in revenue and earnings per share of 7 to 9 cents. Thomson First Call's consensus of analyst estimates had been for 10 cents per share earnings on about $179 million in revenue. Ciber also said that it cut about 140 jobs in its software consulting operations as a telecommunications company trimmed its services. Cincinnati Bell CBB, +1.47% said late Friday that regulators had approved its sale of a broadband division to privately held C III Communications and will receive $10.2 million released from escrow. Cypress Semiconductor CY, +2.05% said late Friday that it sold about 687,000 shares of NVE NVEC, +6.83% which makes semiconductor chip equipment and has partnered with Cypress on chip technology. Cypress said it netted $23.4 million from the stock sale. Cypress CEO T.J. Rodgers said the companies' project is taking longer than expected and that the stock-sale revenue will help finance the continuing research. Dillard's Department Stores DDS, +0.96% had it's debt securities rating placed on review for a possible downgrade late Friday by Moody's. Analysts cited the retail chain's failure to meet its results from the previous year and said inventory was at "undesirable levels through the end of the second quarter." Comparable-store sales weakness was also cited. Disney DIS, +1.93% shares fell 2.1 percent in Friday after hours trading after a roller-coaster accident at Disneyland killed one person and injured 10. A locomotive broke loose on the computer-operated Big Thunder Mountain Railroad. Energy West EWST, +0.00% which sells natural gas and propane in Rocky Mountain states, said late Friday that it refinanced its credit facility from Wells Fargo WFC, +1.81% A new $10.4 million loan includes $2.6 million in reserve for letters of credit; a $3 million credit revolver for working expenses. Gen-Probe GPRO, -1.03% which makes medical lab testing equipment, said late Friday that it will split its 24 million shares 2-for-1 to holders as of Sept. 16. Distribution in the form of a dividend is expected on Sept. 30. Impath IMPH which provides medical advice on cancer treatments based on its database of cases, said late Friday that the Securities and Exchange Commission has opened a formal investigation of its compliance with financial laws. Impath said that it previously had disclosed cooperation with an informal SEC probe of its accounts receivable and how it capitalized its database assets. The company said it will cooperate with the stepped-up investigation. Insituform Technologies INSU said late Friday that it completed the purchase of the final company that held licenses of its process for upgrading sewer lines. Insituform said it paid about $5.5 million for Insituform East. The company installs liners in old sewer lines to prevent leakage, a procedure that also eliminates trench digging. Janus Capital Group JNS conceded late Friday that it allowed market timing by hedge funds, a trading practice that was supposedly banned by its customers. Janus said it will reimburse any losses its fund shareholders suffered. See full story. KB Home KBH, +2.60% said late Friday that it paid about $33 million to acquire assets and assume debt of privately held homebuilder Zale Homes. Kramont Realty Trust KRT, +96.35% said late Friday that it sold a building in Florida and a shopping mall in New Jersey, bringing in net proceeds from the deals of about $8.2 million. A third-quarter gain of $2 million will be booked, Kramont said. Lufthansa (823212) plans to make a formal bid for long-struggling Swiss International Air Lines (001326969), Reuters reported, citing a Swiss newspaper. The German carrier's bid would be contingent on Swiss International securing a 500 million Swiss franc ($352 million) infusion of capital from shareholders. Lufthansa would return 300 million francs to shareholders through profit-sharing or dividends, and provide Lufthansa stock options valued at 200 million Swiss francs. The options, exercisable in 2010, would give the Swiss airline's shareholders a 7 percent stake in Lufthansa, making them the largest minority investors. Manchester Technologies MANC, -2.08% which provides computer systems, said late Friday that it will take a noncash charge in its fiscal fourth quarter, ended July 31, of between $2.3 million and $2.6 million, or 29 cents to 33 cents a share. The charge will write down assets of Donovan Consulting Group, which closed. Martek Biosciences MATK said late Friday that it paid about $10 million in a combination of cash and stock to buy the assets of FermPro Manufacturing and also assumed liability on a $10 million note secured by FermPro assets. Martek makes medical and food products derived from algae. Microsoft MSFT, +2.10% said late Friday that it settled an antitrust suit by software company Be Inc., which will receive $23.25 million. Be is dissolving and will pay out cash to shareholders of record as of March 15, 2002. The National Rural Utilities Cooperative Finance Corp. NRX, +0.00% which finances electric system co-ops, said late Friday it will redeem the entire $200 million of a financial offering for $25 per share plus accrued interest of about 15 cents a share. Omega Protein OME a processor of fish oil, said late Friday that it determined a purchase offer from an Argentina company was not credible. Omega said it broke a policy of not commenting on speculation because the $9.50 a share offer was posted on the Internet. Pacific Sunwear PSUN a retailer of casual clothing, said late Friday that its split shares will trade beginning Monday. The 3-for-2 split was distributed to shareholders Friday. Piezo Instruments PEZO said late Friday that it completed the purchase of a majority of outstanding shares in Omni Medical Holdings, which provides services for medical records and billing. Piezo completed a reverse stock split and will issue 16 million of the new shares to Omni owners. The company will change its name to Omni Medical Holdings, with Arthur Lyons named as president and CEO. Barron's looks at the pharmaceutical sector and notes that Pfizer PFE, +0.54% and Merck MRK, -1.13% carry lower price-to-earnings ratios than the S&P 500. Considering dividends, Pfizer and Johnson & Johnson JNJ, +0.55% have 2 percent yields and Merck delivers 3 percent. Suggesting the entire sector appears to be a value, Barron's says it traditionally has similar P/E ratios as the technology sector, yet now is priced at about 62 percent of the technology multiple. St. Paul Cos. SPC, -2.57% saddled with major claim liabilities, could be a good value in the insurance sector, according to Barron's. As CEO since late in 2001, Jay Fishman has been pulling the company out of troubled coverage areas and has taken its annual loss down from $900 million in 2002 to an estimated $200 million in 2003. An 80 percent stake in Nuveen Investments, with $88 billion under management, is a potential source of ready cash if St. Paul's sells part of its stake, Barron's says. A continuing question mark, says Barron's, is the insurer's exposure to the energy industry, especially surety bonds tied to Aquila, which is facing federal regulatory scrutiny. Stifel Financial SF, +2.47% a financial holding company, said its board approved a stock buyback of up to 850,000 shares, about 12 percent of shares outstanding, for $13.25 a share. Stifel shares closed Friday at $12.57. Vianetworks VNWI said late Friday that Fraser Park is leaving as chief financial officer at the end of September and will be replaced by Controller Matt Gough on an interim basis for the Internet business connection provider. More from MarketWatch Uber for Bikes Could Save Your Commute More Coverage Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Ciber, Cypress Semiconductor, Impath
