title: Stocks to watch Monday

content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Intel took top billing in late trading Friday, heading up the most-actives' list on Island ECN for the second day running. Intel, a Dow component, said late Thursday it now expects sales in the current quarter of $7.6 billion to $7.8 billion, versus the $7.3 billion to $7.8 billion target range announced two weeks ago. See the story. Intel INTC, +5.00% shares were down 3 cents in recent dealings at $28.68. The stock failed to buoy either the Dow Jones Industrial Average or the Nasdaq Composite during the regular session. The Dow DJIA, +1.07% ended down 84.56 points, or 0.9 percent, at 9,503.34, while the Nasdaq $COMPQ shed 10.73 points, or 0.6 percent, to 1,858.24. But both indexes came out on top for the week. See Market Snapshot. After the closing bell, the Nasdaq-100 After Hours indicator, which tracks late trading in technology stocks, edged up 0.49 points. The bell brought a smattering of news before investors headed home for the weekend. One person was confirmed dead and 10 other injured when a locomotive broke loose on Disneyland's DIS, +1.93% Big Thunder Mountain Railroad roller coaster Friday, officials said late Friday, according to the Associated Press. The roller coaster takes amusement park visitors on a twisting, turning ride aboard what is supposed to be a runaway train in the Old West. Riders zoom through mineshafts and caverns, past falling rocks and tumbling waterfalls. The ride is one of Disney's newer roller coasters, having opened in 1979, and is computer-operated, said Joe Aguirre, a park spokesman. Shares of Disneyland fell 2.1 percent in late trade action, to $20.75. Gen-Probe GPRO, -1.03% which makes diagnostic tests, said its board had approved a 2-for-1 stock split in the form of a 100 percent stock dividend. At last check, shares of Gen-Probe were unchanged from their 4 p.m. closing piece of $59.51. Shares of business communications company Via Net.Works VNWI fell 3 cents to $1.34 after announcing that CFO Fraser Park had resigned for personal reasons. Park will leave the firm at the end of September and corporate controller Matt Gough, will become interim CFO. Cancer diagnostic company Impath IMPH said that the Securities and Exchange Commission has opened a formal investigation of possible accounting irregularities. Impath said it would continue to cooperate with the SEC. The company also said it didn't appeal the Nasdaq's decision to delist Impath shares, which are now listed on the OTC Pink Sheets. Shares of Impath closed at $4.05 on the over-the-counter market. They fell 5 cents in late trading but volume was extremely thin. And finally, new financial goals, staff cuts and a stock buyback plan announced late Thursday sent shares of PeopleSoft PSFT, +0.00% above Oracle's bid price of $19.50 for the first time Friday morning. See full story. Shares of both companies stayed active after the closing bell. PeopleSoft added 3 cents in recent dealings, to change hands for $19.33, while shares of Oracle, which extended its tender offer for PeopleSoft shares yet again late Thursday, fell 4 cents to change hands for $13.04. The moves come ahead of Oracle's latest quarterly results, due out next Friday. The company's first-quarter fiscal 2004 profit is expected to rise a penny from last year, according to the average consensus of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Oracle is seen posting a profit of 8 cents a share, up from 7 cents a share in the same period a year earlier. A number of other companies are also due out with their latest numbers next week. On Tuesday, Neiman-Marcus NMG is scheduled to report fourth-quarter results. Analysts expect the company to report a profit of 12 cents a share, a penny less than the same quarter last year. On Aug. 7, the retailer posted a 10.2 percent gain in same-store sales versus analysts' expectations of a 4.8 percent increase. Total sales rose 13.3 percent, to $188 million. Neiman-Marcus shares lost 2.1 percent to end at $40.65. Similar results are expected from ABM Industries ABM, +0.75% which is due to report numbers from the third quarter on Tuesday. Analysts polled by Thomson expect the firm to post a profit of 24 cents per share compared with 25 cents a year earlier. Shares of ABM closed off 0.7 percent, at $15.89. On Wednesday, Adobe Systems ADBE, +1.67% is seen reporting earnings of 25 cents a share, according to Thomson First Call. That compares with 22 cents in the same period last year. On July 31, Adobe backed its fiscal third-quarter revenue and earnings-per-share targets, noting that all its major geographic markets are on track. Adobe's third-quarter range for revenue is $300 million to $315 million and earnings per share are expected to fall within the range of 22 cents to 25 cents a share. Adobe stock shed 2.2 percent to finish at $37.91. Also Wednesday, analysts expect Korn/Ferry International's KFY, +0.47% loss to widen for the first quarter of fiscal 2004, to 5 cents a share from 2 cents a share last year. The company's own forecast calls for first-quarter results to run between breakeven and a loss of 10 cents per share, excluding items. Shares of the recruitment services company closed up 3.1 percent at $10.69. More from MarketWatch Samsung Galaxy S9: Putting the Camera to the Test More Coverage Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets NY Stock Exchange NASDAQ
title: Intel bustling after the bell

content: Industry leaders crunch their numbers early next week. The world's biggest retailer, Wal-Mart WMT, +1.37% is expected to report earnings of 42 cents per share on Tuesday. Top chip-equipment maker Applied Materials AMAT, +2.87% is forecast by analysts to post 2 cents a share vs. 3 cents a year earlier. Regulators are expected to begin considering the spinoff of Airborne's air operations this month. ABX Air, the air operations of Airborne ABF, -0.44% plans to notify the Department of Transportation in May of its plan to separate from Airborne. See full story. Shares of Altria Group MO, -0.21% parent of Philip Morris, may be too cheap to ignore, according to Barron's. The price-to-earnings multiple on 2003 results is under 7 and the company pays an 8 percent dividend, Barron's notes. Investors are clearly worried by legal fights, but Barron's quotes Morgan Stanley analyst David Adelman as expecting the tobacco king to prevail in such cases as the Illinois suit over "light" cigarettes, a $74 billion verdict in Florida and the Justice Department's racketeering suit. Ampco System Parking, a subsidiary of ABM Industries ABM, +0.75% said late Friday that it bought parking property with $23 million in annual revenue from Valet Parking Service. Ninety-three parking contracts in the transaction cover sites around Los Angeles and Las Vegas. The price was not disclosed. AOL Time Warner AOL and Bertelsmann are in talks to merge their music divisions into an entity that would rival industry leader Vivendi Universal's V, +2.25% Universal Music Group, according to a published report. Read full report. Barron's cover story reviews the travails of Bank One ONE, -0.46% since Jamie Dimon took over in 2000 and sliced costs and jobs. Dimon, a lieutenant of Sanford Weill during Travelers Group's buildup and merger with Citigroup, is credited with whipping Bank One into shape, though his cuts ruffled the feathers of 12 top executives who were cut loose, Barron's says. Shares dropped recently as Bank One fell short of analysts' earnings consensus by a penny, yet Barron's mocks critics of that miss. Bank One has enough cash that Dimon could have bought back some shares to artificially hit the target, Barron's says, adding that there's enough money in the bank to puff up earnings by 30 cents a share via buybacks. A Bear Stearns BSC, +1.30% analyst appeared in a video promoting the initial public offering of IPayment just days after a $1.4 billion settlement was reached between brokerage houses and securities regulators prohibiting such activity, according to a published report Monday. Read full story. Cedara Software CDSW said late Friday that Nasdaq determined that its shares met minimum price requirements. Also, Cedara, which makes medical imaging software, said it received an exception through June 30 on shareholder equity rules so that shares can stay listed on the Nasdaq SmallCap Market under the ticker symbol "CDSWC" CDSWC Central Pacific Financial CPF, -0.39% said late Friday that it revised its offer for CB Bancshares CBBI, +0.00% though the $70.10 per share total remains the same. The cash component rises to $24.50 per share, up from $21, while a stock portion of the purchase changes to 1.7606 of a Central Pacific share for each CB share, down from 1.8956. Payment of CB's 10 percent stock dividend would change the offer to $22.27 in cash and a 1.6005 share exchange ratio. A new CB shareholder meeting in late June is expected to consider the offer revision. China's dominant oil and gas producer CNOOC CEO, +0.49% has been stymied in its bid to acquire a significant stake in the North Caspian Sea Project in Kazakhstan because other owners of the project have chosen to exercise their right to buy the stake. Read fulll report. Consolidated Mercantile CSLMF late Friday said its subsidiary Polyair Inter Pack finished the purchase of Jacuzzi and related units, which the financial holding company said generate about $55 million annually in sales. The purchase price was not disclosed. Warehouse club Costco COST, +2.63% looks poised to prosper, says Barron's. The large-lot retailer has gotten a handle on rising costs and should reap revenue from new ventures in Atlanta, Chicago, Texas and Minneapolis-St. Paul, says Barron's. Daisytek International DZTK late Friday named Eric. T. Logan as interim CFO. Ralph Mitchell had resigned the post Monday in an executive purge as CEO James Powell also stepped down. The distributor of computer and office supplies had said it would post a large fourth-quarter loss and make a large number of job cuts. Descartes Systems Group DSGX, +2.70% said late Friday it had hired financial advisers to improve performance and enhance shareholder value. That could mean a potential sale of assets or search for partners for the maker of business inventory software. In a potential blow to Disney's DIS, +1.93% Winnie the Pooh products, the Slesinger family said a federal judge's ruling rejected the Magic Kingdom's attempt to crush its copyright. Disney said in November that a granddaughter of Pooh author A.A. Milne had decided to cut off the Slesinger copyright, which was granted in the 1930s. With a judge rejecting that move, said a Slesinger statement, the path is clear for a federal trial in September. The Slesingers seek hundreds of millions of dollars from Disney. In what it called a procedural step, electronic commerce company First Data FDC, +1.07% said it will refile its merger notification on Concord EFS CE, +0.47% with the Justice Department, which will reset its antitrust review under the Hart-Scott-Rodino law. First Data said the move allows it to continue to directly address questions from regulators and that it expects to complete the $7 billion stock-swap transaction in the second half of 2003. The deal was first announced in early April. Footstar FTS, +0.27% said late Friday that it will not file its 10-Q report due Tuesday, based on an external audit by KPMG. Footstar, which operates discount shoe stores under such names as Thom McAn and Footaction, said discrepancies found in November are hanging up the quarterly report. Lenders led by Fleet National Bank waived requirements for financial statements at this time, Footstar said. Goodyear Tire's GT, +0.83% unions said late Friday that they rejected a three-year contract offer that would have cut jobs and wages, according to Reuters. The United Steelworkers of America represents about 19,000 workers at Goodyear factories. Goody's Family Clothing GDYS said late Friday that it had lost a court decision over the sale of counterfeit Tommy Hilfiger T-shirts and labeling on lines of jeans formerly sold by the apparel chain. Goody's said a federal court award totaled $11 million plus attorney's fees and costs, adding that its insurance coverage exceeds that amount. Mexican cell-phone operator Grupo Iusacell CEL, -1.25% said late Friday that starting Monday its ratio of ADS shares to ordinary shares will be 1-to-100 instead of 1-to-10, raising the price tenfold so that they will comply with NYSE minimum share-price rules. Hecla Mining's HL, +1.94% Arthur Brown retired late Friday as CEO, and will remain chairman. Phillips Baker Jr. was named CEO of the gold and silver mining company. Newspaper publisher Journal Register JRC said late Friday that it had been told that Warburg Pincus Investors was distributing its 2.8 million shares of Journal Register to partners. Heavy-equipment manufacturer Manitowoc MTW, +3.87% said late Friday that it will close its National Crane division's boom-truck plant in Waverly, Neb., and shift the operations to Shady Grove, Pa., where it has operations from Grove Worldwide, purchased last year. Manitowoc said the sale of assets at the closed plant will likely exceed shutdown costs and will be accounted for as an adjustment in its Grove Worldwide deal. Navistar NAV, +7.43% said Saturday that it reached a tentative accord with the Canadian Auto Workers union that could keep a Canadian factory open. The heavy-truck plant in Chatham, Ontario, is due to close July 18. Terms of the union pact will not be released while it is reviewed by management and union members, Navistar said. Realty developer Rouse RSE, -0.67% said late Friday its board approved redemption of about $142 million in 9.25 percent subordinated debentures. Rouse said $9 million of the debentures will be redeemed on June 16. Baby Bell SBC SBC, -0.65% will be allowed to nearly double the access fee it charges long-distance carriers AT&T T, +0.25% and MCI WCOEQ in Illinois. A state law passed Friday was quickly signed by the governor, a move the Chicago Tribune labeled unusually fast since most bills are signed weeks or months after passage. The local phone company and its unions had lobbied heavily for the bill. Siebel Systems SEBL said Friday that a CBS.MarketWatch.com report on May 1 has prompted the Securities and Exchange Commission to inquire about the company's compliance with Regulation FD. The story said the business software maker's stock rose about 8 percent after a dinner attended by certain financial analysts, investors and company executives. Siebel said that it has launched an internal review of the circumstances involving the statements made to CBS.MarketWatch.com. Siebel shares rose 5 cents on Friday to close at $9.53. See full story. Synavant SNVT said late Friday that its board approved accepting a takeover offer from Dendrite International DRTE for $2.83 per share in cash, a deal that would unite two service providers for pharmaceutical distribution. The acceptance overrides a previous $2.30 per share offer by France-based marketer Cegedim. Dendrite has paid Cegedim a $1.01 million breakup fee. Canadian power generator TransAlta TAC, +1.87% said late Friday that it completed its $66 million sale of Calgary, Alberta, headquarters to Forum Leasehold Partners. TransAlta said it will lease back the property for a 20-year term and reinvest the sale proceeds into its operations. Via Net Works VNWI which operates Internet service providers around the world, set an automated trading plan as part of its stock repurchases. Under SEC rules, the plan establishes limits on price and other factors that allow purchases even when a company's "trading window" is closed. Wegener WGNR, -0.62% late Friday lashed at the hostile offer by Radyne ComStream RADN a day after Wegener's board rejected a $1.55 cash offer. Radyne was trying to "steal" profit potential, Wegener said, hours after Radyne accused management of its target with enriching themselves via severance agreements. Wegener makes communications equipment and Radyne makes satellite equipment. West Corp. WSTC which provides video and audio conference services, said late Friday that it completed a $399.6 million purchase of InterCall. West said Intercall's 2002 revenue totaled $196 million, with $30.1 million in earnings. WorldCom WCOEQ has a $65 million deal to sell wireless assets to BellSouth BLS, +0.00% according to Reuters, which said the bankrupt telecom company paid about $1 billion for the assets in several acquisitions. The pact requires approval from a New York bankruptcy court. More from MarketWatch What Picking Up an Apple Tells You About the Future of Robotics More Coverage S&P 500 logs longest losing streak of the year as trade-war jitters weigh 2 sexy ways to get paid to save My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Stocks to watch Monday: AOL, CNOOC, Siebel, more

content: Tuesday stocks to watch Fairchild Semiconductor FCS, +1.96% raised the low end of its revenue target but said gross margins will contract more than expected due to pricing pressure. Pacific Sunwear said late Monday that earnings in its fourth fiscal quarter surged more than 63 percent to $23.2 million, or 46 cents a share, against last year's $14.2 million, or 28 cents a share. The results were 2 cents ahead of the average estimate at Thomson First Call. Same-store sales jumped 15.6 percent, thanks to strong holiday sales and a growing girls business at the casual-wear retailer for teens. Total sales climbed 27.9 percent to $265.6 million from $207.6 million last year. Pacific Sunwear's PSUN shares closed at $17.77, up 6 cents. Monday advancers American Superconductor AMSC, +7.98% charged up more than 19 percent after it said it won a $70 million, 37 month contract from the U.S. Navy to design and build a high temperature superconductor propulsion motor for electric warships. The company has teamed with Northrop Grumman NOC, +1.28% to optimize the design and test the motor. The company, which recorded revenue of $2.75 million during the quarter ending December, said that it expects revenue for the first 12 months of the contract is expected to be approximately $24 million. Unionized pilots at AMR's AMR, -4.53% American Airlines agreed late Friday to negotiate wages, work rules and other job issues amid a call from the troubled carrier for $1.8 billion more in cost cuts. Pilots said their goals are to protect pensions and minimize layoffs. The stock ascended more than 12 percent. CenterPoint Energy CNP, +1.67% zoomed almost 25 percent higher after the energy delivery company said late Friday that it successfully negotiated an amendment to its existing $3.85 billion credit facility. The term of the facility has been extended to June 2005, and the company is no longer required to make $1.2 billion in mandatory payments this year. The company said that as part of the amendment to the facility, it would cut its quarterly dividend to 10 cents a share from 16 cents a share. Firstwave Technologies FSTW charged up more than 23 percent after the provider of customer relationship management services announced the receipt of a $1.2 million purchase order for licenses, the largest in its history. The company added that professional services revenue should grow in response to increasing license revenue. Priority Healthcare PHCC hiked more than 5 percent higher after the company announced the signing of a long-term license agreement with Wal-Mart WMT, +1.37% to be the exclusive provider of specialty pharmacy services. The company said its services would be phased in over the next two years. Shares of Zemex ZMX, +12.50% soared more than 42 percent after the minerals producer announced an agreement to be acquired by Peru's Cementos Pacasmaya for $8.80 a share, or $100 million in cash and assumed debt. The price represents a 46 percent premium to Friday's closing price and a 21 percent premium to its 52-week high. Monday decliners ABM Industries ABM, +0.75% slumped nearly 18 percent after it lowered late Friday its first-quarter outlook to 8 to 9 cents earnings per share, compared to the year-earlier 16 cents. Full-year earnings were lowered to 85 to 95 cents a share, down from a previous range of $1 to $1.10. Thomson First Call's consensus had been expecting 16 cents for the quarter and 97 cents for the year. ABM cited contract problems in janitorial operations, primarily in New York, and higher labor costs in its Northeast lighting operations. Capital One Financial COF, +1.64% slid nearly 9 percent after saying its chief financial officer, David Willey, has resigned effective immediately after receiving a notice from the staff of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission indicating that it would recommend the SEC bring a civil action against Willey. The action, which follows a formal order of investigation issued in July 2002, would allege that Willey traded in Capital One's stock while in possession of non-public information. Palm PALM, -2.60% fell 11 percent after it warned that fiscal third-quarter sales would miss forecasts due primarily to weaker than anticipated demand for its high-end products in the U.S. The company said it intends to take restructuring charges of $40 million to $45 million during the quarter related to previously-announced restructuring actions, including a workforce reduction of approximately 19 percent, and added that it would take a $100 million charge to reduce the carrying value of land it owns in San Jose, Calif. The handheld products maker said sales for the quarter ending February are now expected to be $205 million to $210 million, versus previous forecasts of $230 million to $250 million. Barron's Sizing Up Small Caps doesn't dig Royal Gold RGLD, +3.18% a Denver-based handler of gold royalties that has just eight employees. With the run-up in precious metals, the company jumped from $2 to $28, and rested Friday at $19.45. That values Royal Gold at 5.6 times its book value and 65 times its earnings. Calculating the future revenue from Royal Gold's best asset -- data that Barron's says is from a trader who has shorted the stock -- a best-case scenario on gold provides a $9 share price, according to the column. The stock was knocked almost 33 percent lower. The American Depositary Receipts of Turkish telecommunications firm Turkcell Iletisim TKC, +4.48% slumped more than 12 percent Monday. Turkey's stock market plunged 11 percent overnight after the country's parliament voted to not allow the deployment of U.S. troops in Turkey, which borders Iraq. The decision raised fears that the promised $15 billion aid package to the country would be not be delivered. A federal loan board rejected a $250 million guarantee late Friday for Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel, a unit of WHX Corp. WHX, -1.51% The No. 8 U.S. steel producer sought the backup as part of its plan to emerge from bankruptcy, with financing from Royal Bank of Canada. The stock was pummeled for a 29 percent loss. More from MarketWatch Uber for Bikes Could Save Your Commute More Coverage Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Stocks to watch: Fairchild Semi, more

content: Lost your shirt in the market? Pacific Sunwear PSUN and Philips-Van Heusen PVH, +5.15% will show what's up their sleeves and report financials Monday. ABM Industries ABM, +0.75% late Friday lowered its first-quarter outlook to 8 to 9 cents earnings per share, compared to the year-earlier 16 cents. Full-year earnings were lowered to 85 to 95 cents a share, down from a previous range of $1 to $1.10. Thomson First Call's consensus had been expecting 16 cents for the quarter and 97 cents for the year. ABM cited contract problems in janitorial operations, primarily in New York, and higher labor costs in its Northeast lighting operations. Federal regulators and medical experts are expected Tuesday to examine a potential link between cancer and a new generation of blockbuster rheumatoid arthritis drugs from Abbott Labs ABT, +1.16% Amgen AMGN, +0.01% and Johnson & Johnson JNJ, +0.55% See full story. Advanced Healthcare Technologies AVHC said late Friday that the OTC bulletin board had, in error, placed an "E" at the end of its ticker symbol, a mistake that will be corrected Monday. Advanced Healthcare said it filed its 10Q form to the SEC in a timely manner Feb. 14. Altria Group's MO, -0.21% Philip Morris said late Friday that it and co-defendant RJR Reynolds RJR, +0.00% won a jury verdict in a Florida lawsuit brought by the family of a smoker. The case involving deceased James Allen is unrelated to a class-action suit in Florida, which is on appeal after a jury awarded about $145 billion in punitive damages. Unionized pilots at AMR's AMR, -4.53% American Airlines agreed late Friday to negotiate wages, work rules and other job issues amid a call from the troubled carrier for $1.8 billion more in cost cuts. Pilots said their goals are to protect pensions and minimize layoffs. Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway BRK.A, +1.04% dropped its $579 million cash bid for Burlington Industries BRLG Friday after a bankruptcy court balked at a breakup fee. See full story. Boeing BA, +2.46% said late Friday it is consolidating its manufacturing of Delta space rockets. An assembly plant in Pueblo, Colo., will close, eliminating about 90 jobs as the work and about 160 workers shift to a Decatur, Ala., factory. Boeing said the switch should be complete by mid-2004. Bristol-Myers Squibb BMY, +1.09% shares look like a bargain, says Barron's. A promising schizophrenia drug in the pipeline, plus the possibility of becoming a takeover target were cited as reasons the troubled drugmaker's stock could perk up. See full story. Chinese airline Cathay Pacific CPCAY, +1.17% attracts attention as the subject of Barron's cover story. The Hong Kong airline's profits are expected to soar as it reports 2002 results in the next week. Barron's sees promise in a route-sharing pact with American Airlines and a cooperative accord with freight-hauler DHL. A dividend boost is also foreseen by ING analysts Philip Wickham and Belinda Chan. A crucial event for Cathay will be decisions on whether it can fly into mainland China, shedding its restriction to Hong Kong. Analysts tell Barron's that such a move could add 5 percent to Cathay revenue. Excalibur Industries EXCB late Friday said it is pulling out of a deal to buy Tecon Services, which provides fire-proofing services. Excalibur, a design and manufacturing company, had said when the deal was announced that Tecon was profitable and had $17 million in annual revenue. General Motors GM, +2.45% said late Friday that it will contribute about 150 million shares -- about 15 percent of shares outstanding -- of its GM Hughes Electronics GMH division to its retirement plans. With the GM Hughes division's DirecTV unit figuring in sale plans, the move could lower the price needed by any acquirers. The Wall Street Journal recently reported that Liberty Media L, +0.59% might split with Rupert Murdoch's News Corp. NWS, +1.90% in the media baron's plan to buy DirecTV. One factor cited was a lower price as a result of the GM shift of GMH shares. In a related move, GM amended a shelf registration in an SEC filing to increase the amount of securities offered to $10 billion, from a previous filing on $5 billion in securities. Knight Trading Group NITE, +2.00% disclosed after Friday's bell that it had bought back $69 million of its authorized $70 million in share repurchases. Knight said it now has about 112 million shares outstanding. Life Sciences Research LSRI said late Friday that Deloitte & Touche will step down as its auditor as a result of pressure from animal rights groups. Telecom network manufacturer Lightpath Technologies LPTH, +2.33% said late Friday that shareholders approved a reverse stock split and that directors set a 1-for-8 ratio, effective at the open of trading Tuesday. Mantech International MANT, +2.44% said late Friday that it agreed to buy computer service provider Integrated Data Systems for $57.7 million in cash, but possible adjustments of about $5 million. Mantech, which provides computer and communications services to the federal government, said the purchase price of defense contractor IDS is about 12.2 times its EBITDA, or earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization. Mantech said a goodwill deduction will make the purchase price roughly 10 times EBITDA. Canada-based Manulife Financial MFC, +1.47% said late Friday that it will not compete with Great-West Lifeco GWL in the bidding for Canada Life. Manulife had offered $6.3 billion in December, which was topped by Great-West's $7.3 billion offer on Feb. 17. Papermaking giant MeadWestvaco MWV said late Friday that it acquired privately held Amcal, which makes calendars, stationery and gifts. Terms were not disclosed. Peoples Financial PFBX, +0.00% which operates 15 banks in Mississippi, said late Friday it is adding $1.5 million to loan-loss reserves related to a loan problem that did not surface until after it filed 2002 earnings. Net income for the year was revised to $3.19 million, or 57 cents a share, after the loss provision was charged to fourth-quarter results. Those numbers are down from the $4.2 million and 75 cents per share reported on Jan. 10. In a move that satisfied requirements of a bankruptcy creditors committee, Peregrine Systems PRGNQ said late Friday that it had filed amended financial statements for the past three years. The software maker said about $509 million had been dropped from a previously reported $1.34 billion in revenue. The revisions related, among other things, to unsubstantiated sales, irregular booking of installment-contract revenue and erroneous calculations. Barron's Sizing Up Small Caps doesn't dig Royal Gold RGLD, +3.18% a Denver-based handler of gold royalties that has just eight employees. With the run-up in precious metals, the company jumped from $2 to $28, and rested Friday at $19.45. That values Royal Gold at 5.6 times its book value and 65 times its earnings. Calculating the future revenue from Royal Gold's best asset -- data that Barron's says is from a trader who has shorted the stock -- a best-case scenario on gold provides a $9 share price, according to the column. Shenandoah Telecommunications SHEN, +0.42% said late Friday that it completed the sale of a wireless system in Virginia to Verizon VZ, -0.37% for $37 million in cash. The Justice Department filed suit Friday against Virginia-based Smithfield Foods SFD, +2.50% accusing the nation's largest hog producer and pork packer of twice failing to notify antitrust regulators before making acquisitions of stock in IBP Inc. between 1998 and 2001. IBP was later purchased by Tyson's Foods. See full story. Starbucks SBUX, -0.02% said Saturday that it agreed to buy out its corporate partner's interest in its Switzerland and Austria operations. Without disclosing terms of the cash deal, the coffee-store chain said the pact with Bon Appetit Group would not affect its fiscal 2003 earnings target of 67 to 68 cents a share. Steel Technologies STTX, +0.00% said late Friday that it acquired a cold-rolled strip steel factory in Ottawa, Ohio, and other assets for $10 million in cash. A bankruptcy court overseeing the seller, Cold Metal Products, has approved the deal, which will close next Friday. Technical Olympic TOUS said late Friday that it improved its homebuilding prospects in the Denver area as it bought the assets and land of the James Company for $30 million in cash. Technical Olympic said James had sold 310 homes in the past year at an average price of $198,000. Bermuda-based insurer Trenwick Group TWK said it is negotiating with its debtholders, specifically regarding $75 million in notes due April 1. Also, a December letter of credit that set a March 1 deadline for refinancing has had the deadline extended, Trenwick said. Universal Ice Blast UIBI sake late Friday it received an order from Ford F, +2.03% for its anti-rust spraying machinery and that orders for its auto products could total $1.4 billion over the next seven to 10 years. Wabash National WNC, +2.97% said late Friday that its lenders waived noncompliance with financial covenants through April 15. The maker of truck trailers said that without the forebearance, about $347 million would convert to a current liability on its balance sheet and likely cut off its credit, as well as affect customers and suppliers. A federal loan board rejected a $250 million guarantee late Friday for Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel, a unit of WHX Corp. WHX, -1.51% The No. 8 U.S. steel producer sought the backup as part of its plan to emerge from bankruptcy, with financing from Royal Bank of Canada. Worldport Communications WRDP said late Friday that Heico Companies LLC, which owns nearly all its preferred stock, accepted an offer from the company to repurchase that stake. That deal satisfies a key term of the preferred shares that would have blocked common-share repurchases by Worldport. Consequently, Worldport said it is offering 50 cents a share to buy all its common stock. Shares closed Friday at 41 cents. Worldport said a recent tender at 50 cents a share by WCI Acquisition Corp. did not receive satisfactory response and expired. More from MarketWatch How to Get a Job: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Stocks to watch Monday

content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- ABM Industries shares fell 2.2 percent Tuesday after the company said it lost nearly $1 million in its fourth quarter because of an extraordinary charge. ABM ABM, +0.75% which before Sept. 11 counted the World Trade Center as its biggest client, said Monday night that it lost $865,000, or 4 cents a share, in the quarter ended Oct. 31. A year earlier, the provider of services such as parking and building maintenance had posted a profit of $14.5 million, or 60 cents a share. Without the charge, which was a set-aside of $20 million to cover future self-insured losses, income would have come in at 46 cents per share, in line with the consensus estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call. Revenue for the period increased to $496.7 million, compared to revenue of $477.1 million in the same period the year before. Shares of ABM fell 69 cents, or 2.2 percent, to close at $31.31 Tuesday after being down as much as twice that earlier in the day. The company began as a one-man window-washing business in San Francisco in 1909. By 2001, it had a staff of more than 60,000, customers across North America and revenue for 2000 exceeding $1.8 billion. Its nine divisions include Ampco System Parking, ABM Janitorial and American Commercial Security. ABM's largest aggregate contract was the World Trade Center, with more than 800 staff from three divisions working there over a typical 24-hour period. The company lost 17 of those employees on Sept. 11. Annualized revenue from the combined permanent contracts at the World Trade Center totaled about $65 million, or 3 percent of total revenue, with gross profits of $10 million. ABM has filed a claim for more than $14.8 million in earnings losses and property damage with Zurich Financial Services. The company confirmed reports in its conference call Tuesday morning that Zurich had filed a lawsuit against ABM disputing claims made over the $10-million mark. Chief Financial Officer George Sundby said ABM was "continuing to work with Zurich." ABM said it expects full-year earnings for 2002 to come in between $2.10 and $2.20 per share before the recovery of any WTC-related insurance claims, largely due to a change in accounting rules for goodwill amortization. The firm also expects to continue with acquisitions, primarily in its janitorial and security divisions. "I believe the number of companies available [for acquisitions] for multiples that will make economic sense for us are greater than they've ever been before," said President and CEO Henrik C. Slipsager. In light of its 50-cent-per-share charge in fiscal year 2001, ABM is taking a dose of preventive medicine and increasing its self-insurance rates by 21 percent for 2002, a charge that the company said it will pass on to clients. "The big question is whether they can pass it all along to clients," said analyst David Gold of Sidoti Co., "It will be hard to pass [the whole charge] on to clients in this economic environment." Following the earnings release, Gold is maintaining his "neutral" rating on the stock. He doesn't recommend buying shares at this juncture. "Going forward, things are too murky," he said. "Next year is going to be tough for these guys." title: ABM reports Q4 loss

content: WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) -- Dozens of U.S. companies reaffirmed their commitment to buy back their stock or accelerate stock-repurchase programs on Monday under eased government rules in the wake of the terrorist attacks that destroyed the World Trade Center and part of the Pentagon. See full story. The Securities and Exchange Commission late Friday waived certain corporate stock-repurchase restrictions to lend stability to the U.S. markets. The rules will be eased for at least the next five days. Below is a list of some of the companies that have made announcements since Sept. 14: (Note: Some companies listed the total number of shares they may purchase from time to time. Others gave a maximum dollar amount they are authorized to use. In addition, these figures do not represent a figure a company is committed to buying during the five-day period under the SEC's relaxed buyback rules.) Allstate ALL, +0.20% : $500 million ABM Industries ABM, +0.75% : 1 million shares Applied Micro Circuits AMCC : $200 million Bank One ONE, -0.46% : $500 million BEA Systems BEAS : $100 million Camtek CAMT, +1.50% : $3 million Cima Labs CIMA : $20 million Cisco Systems CSCO, +2.95% : $3 billion Coach COH, +6.26% : $80 million Compaq CPQ : $550 million First Data FDC, +1.07% : $700 million FleetBoston Financial FBF, -11.49% : $4 billion Gabelli Asset Management GBL, +0.77% : $10 million General Electric GE, -1.46% : $2.8 billion HCC Insurance HCC, +1.38% : 3 million shares H&R Block HRB, +1.03% : 15 million shares Hewlett-Packard HWP : $1.8 billion K-Swiss KSWS : $25 million Intel INTC, +5.00% : 300 million shares Interneuron Pharmaceuticals IPIC, -1.67% : 1 million shares Landstar System LSTR, +2.29% : 500,000 shares Morgan Stanley MWD, +0.78% : $1 billion Pfizer PFE, +0.54% : $4 billion PepsiCo PEP, -0.03% : $2 billion PetroCorp PEX, +0.76% : 1 million shares Rare Hospitality RARE, +1.21% : $15 million Siebel Systems SEBL : $500 million Solectron SLR, +1.69% : $200 million Starbucks SBUX, -0.02% : $60 million More from MarketWatch What Picking Up an Apple Tells You About the Future of Robotics More Coverage This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date
title: U.S. corporations gear up buybacks

content: Positive surprises Due to better-than-expected sales and continued effective cost control measures, Papa John's International PZZA, -0.68% believes its third-quarter earnings will be in the middle to upper middle range of its previous estimate. Previously the company anticipated earnings falling at the low end of its estimate of 42 cents to 49 cents. The company continues to believe fourth-quarter earnings will be in the range of 51 cents and 58 cents a share. Analysts polled by First Call currently expect third-quarter earnings of 42 cents a share, and fourth-quarter earnings of 51 cents a share. Shares closed down $1.19 to $23.81 ahead of the news. After the market closed, Copart CPRT, +2.21% reported fourth-quarter earnings of $12.9 million, or 23 cents a share, on sales of $68.6 million, compared with the year-ago total of $8.16 million, or 15 cents a share, on sales of $51.3 million. Analysts polled by First Call anticipated a profit of 21 cents a share. Shares closed down $1.10 to $22.90. After delaying its financial report due to the attacks in New York and Washington and the closure of the U.S. equity markets, General Mills GIS, +1.60% reported better-than-expected first-quarter earnings Monday morning. The cereal manufacturer posted first-quarter earnings of $181.8 million, or 62 cents a share, excluding one-time item, while analysts expected a profit of 59 cents a share. Excluding extraordinary items, the year-ago total was $164.8 million, or 57 cents a share. Sales totaled $1.77 billion, up 5 percent compared with the year-ago period. "This performance met our expectations and puts our current businesses on track to deliver another year of double-digit earnings per share growth in 2002," said Steve Sanger, chairman and chief executive officer. Including items, the latest quarter showed a profit of 64 cents a share, compared with the year-ago total of 55 cents a share. Shares traded 69 cents to $45.04. Oracle ORCL, +1.71% posted first-quarter earnings without comment last week due to the company having seven people missing from the World Trade Center and one person lost on United Flight 93. The company posted first-quarter net income of $511 million, or 9 cents a hare, on revenue of $2.24 billion. Last year, the company earned $500 million, or 8 cents a share, on revenue of $2.26 billion. Analysts polled by First Call had been expecting a profit of 8 cents a share. Shares closed down 45 cents to $11.01. Excluding one-time items, Tektronix TEK, -16.67% posted first-quarter earnings of $12.5 million, or 13 cents a share, compared with the year-ago total of $27.6 million, or 28 cents a share. Analysts expected the latest quarter to show a profit of 11 cents a share. Sales totaled $216.6 million for the latest quarter, down compared with the year-ago total of $278.2 million. Including one-time items, net income totaled $8.3 million, or 9 cents a share, for the latest quarter. The company noted that it expects second-quarter sales to drop about 35 percent compared with the year-ago total of $325 million. Analysts polled by First Call currently expect sales of about $229 million for the second quarter. The stock closed down $1.02 to $17.33. Negative surprises After the market closed, Electro Scientific Industries ESIO, +3.42% posted first-quarter losses of $2.8 million, or 10 cents a share, excluding one-time items, missing the consensus estimate by a penny. Including one-time items, the company lost $8 million, or 30 cents a share, in the latest quarter. In the prior quarter, the company earned $12 million, or 43 cents a share. Sales totaled $50 million for the first quarter, down 45 percent compared with the fourth quarter of 2001. The company noted that although its near-term outlook remains uncertain, the company believes it is well positioned for future growth and profitability. Shares closed down $1.40 to $24. ABM Industries, which confirmed that the World Trade Center is its largest single job site, reported third-quarter results late Wednesday. The company ABM, +0.75% said that in deference to its employees and customers who are among those missing, it was releasing results without further comment. ABM reported third-quarter net income of $13.2 million, or 52 cents per share, compared with net income of $12.4 million, or 52 cents per share, in the same period a year before. Analysts, on average, were expecting earnings of 55 cents per share, according to Thomson Financial/First Call. Revenue rose to $492.4 million from $461.9 million a year before. Shares lost $2.43 to close at $29.56. Virco Manufacturing Corp. VIR, +0.00% reported Wednesday that its second-quarter net income totaled $4.5 million, or 36 cents a share, compared with a year-ago profit of $4.3 million, or 34 cents a share. One analyst polled by Thomson Financial/First Call had anticipated that the furniture manufacturer would turn a profit of 45 cents a share. Sales totaled $89.2 million, down 7.6 percent compared with $96.6 million in the year-ago period. Shares closed flat at $9.70. Earnings advisories After the market closed, VISX Inc. EYE, -0.28% said that due to the severity of the continued economic downturn, licensing revenue dropped 25 to 30 percent, along with a drop in international and domestic equipment sales. As a result the laser vision correction company expects earnings to be in the range of 6 cents to 8 cents a share. Analysts polled by First Call expected a profit of 18 cents a share. Shares closed down $1.85 to $14.20. Mirant MIR, -20.00% said it expects third-quarter earnings to be at least 65 cents a share, up from a previous estimate of 60 cents. In addition, it projects full-year 2001 earnings of at least $1.95 a share, up from $1.90. Fiscal 2002 earnings continue to be targeted at $2.55 to $2.65, after adding about 20 cents for new accounting rules pertaining to goodwill and intangibles. Analysts polled by First Call currently expect a third-quarter profit of 61 cents a share, 2001 earnings of $1.94 and fiscal 2002 earnings of $2.55 a share. Shares closed down 65 cents to $24.60. Kinder Morgan KMI, +1.69% said it expects third-quarter earnings to meet or beat analysts' current average estimate of 45 cents per unit. Full-year earnings are also expected to meet or beat the consensus estimate of $1.88 per unit. The energy company also predicts earnings growth of 30 to 35 percent in 2002. Shares closed up 30 cents to $56.16. Kinder Morgan Energy Partners KMP, +0.63% also said it expects to meet or beat Wall Street's third-quarter earnings estimate of 36 cents per unit. Full-year earnings also will meet or beat the estimate of $1.56 per unit, the company said, on the strength of internal growth and strong performance by pipeline and terminal assets. Shares closed up 32 cents to $36. . BancFirst Corp. BANF, -0.28% said it expects third-quarter earnings to be below the consensus estimate of 86 cents a share. The company noted the recent interest rate cuts. Shares closed down $1.85 to $37.35. Instituform Technologies INSUA said it expects third-quarter earnings, excluding one-time items, to be about 15 cents a share. Analysts polled by First Call currently expect a profit of 48 cents a share. The proprietary technologies and services company now projects revenue for its North American rehabilitation operation for the third quarter to be about $12 million less than previously estimated. Shares plunged 39 percent to close at $16. See full story. Vitesse Semiconductor VTSS lowered its fourth-quarter revenue and earnings targets, citing continued order delays. Vitesse now sees fourth-quarter revenue in the range of $37 million to $40 million, down from earlier expectations of roughly $50 million, as well as a loss in the range of 12 cents to 15 cents per share. Analysts have been expecting a fourth-quarter loss of 9 cents per share on revenue of $49.6 million, according to First Call. " Shares plunged 18 percent to $10.37. See full story. Dow Jones & Co. DJ said it remains hopeful of meeting the bottom end of its outlook for third-quarter earnings of 20 cents to 30 cents per share. The New York financial news firm said that total advertising linage for its flagship product, The Wall Street Journal, fell 40.7 percent in August. The company had been projecting a decline of 25 to 30 percent. General ad lineage dropped 45.8 percent in August, and its down 38.7 percent year-to-date. Dow Jones also noted that its corporate offices have been re-located to South Brunswick, N.J., in the wake of Tuesday's terrorist attacks. The stock closed down $3.75 to $49. Rowan RDC, +4.43% warned that it expects earnings of 20 cents to 25 cents a share in the third quarter, below the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call for a profit of 29 cents a share. The company noted that its offshore rig utilization for the quarter is estimated at 70 percent, down from 90 percent in the second quarter. Rowan's average offshore day rate for the period is expected to be around $57,000, down from $61,000 in the second quarter. "We believe the worst soon will be behind us and, during the fourth quarter, our utilization and average day rates should begin to improve," said Bob Palmer, the company's chairman and CEO, in a press release. "But, obviously, the light in our crystal ball is powered by natural gas." The shares closed down $1.12 to $14.80. Citigroup C, -1.11% said after-tax losses in its insurance business related to last Tuesday's tragedies could negatively impact third quarter earnings by $500 million, or about 10 cents a share. Losses related to the closing of stock exchanges, as well as a number of branches, are anticipated to be $100 million to $200 million, or 2 cents to 4 cents a share. Excluding the impact of the tragedies, the financial services giant expects to report earnings of 77 cents a share, topping the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson Financial/First Call of 75 cents. The stock is a component of the Dow Industrials DJIA, +1.07% Shares closed down $2.85 to $39.60. Universal American Financial UHCO said that "to the best of its knowledge, it will occur no material losses" from last week's terrorist attacks. Universal American provides supplemental life and health insurance products primarily to the senior market and third-party administration services for insurance and non-insurance programs in the senior market. Shares closed down 68 cents to $5.05. Addressing investors' concerns, John Hancock Financial Services JHF "reluctantly given the circumstances" said that it believes that there is no reason to conclude that the tragedy will have a material impact on the company's financial strength. "We lost one of our own employees as well as many friends, and empathize with the pain people are feeling," noted the David F. D'Alessandro, chairman and chief executive officer. The stock closed down $1.82 to $36.68. Insurance company Cincinnati Financial Corp. CINF, +0.54% said there was no "known" direct property loss to policyholders of its property casualty insurance group. Although the company did say it participates in reinsurance pools that spread large losses, such as aviation losses, among many insurers and that it is too early to determine what the total loss will be. However, the company doesn't expect any losses that would materially affect the company. The stock closed down 76 cents to $39.14. Zenith National Insurance ZNT, -1.46% said there is considerable uncertainty as to the nature and amount of monetary losses associated with the events of Sept. 11. The company said it is exposed to a potential loss in the range of about $7 million to $15 million, or 26 cents to 56 cents a share, related to its reinsurance operations. However, the company's primary property and casualty operation is not expected to sustain any losses in connection to the events. Shares slipped $1.29 to $27.80. Citing parts shortages stemming from freight transportation issues, particularly in airfreight transport and movement of freight through border crossings, Ford F, +2.03% said it would reduce its North American production plans. In addition, the company said current production plan for the third quarter calls for 810,000 to 820,000 vehicles, down 110,000 to 120,000 vehicles from the prior forecast. As a result, third quarter results will fall short of its previous estimate for earnings of 10 cents a share. Currently, analysts polled by First Call expect a profit of 10 cents a share. The stock closed down $2.85 to $16.55. General Electric GE, -1.46% said that it expects to incur an after-tax loss of about $400 million in claims due to the attacks. That will cut third-quarter earnings by 4 cents a share. Analysts polled by First Call currently expect a profit of 37 cents a share. Shares closed down $4.20 to $35.15.
