title: General Mills Q1, Citigroup advises

content: Quarterly report delays Several companies delayed earnings reports, or conference calls due to Tuesday's terrorist attacks and the closure of the equity markets. National Beverage FIZ said it was prepared to release earnings Tuesday but that in light of the national tragedy the release seemed "so unimportant and pale in the face of the act of madness on our America." The company plans to release its first-quarter report "sometime next week." Harvey Electronics HRVE said it will delay its third-quarter financial conference call, scheduled for Sept. 17, as a result of Tuesday's attacks. The company was will release its financial results for the quarter on Sept. 17. The electronics company said the move was made out of respect and concern for those individuals and firms impacted by the attacks. Landec Corp. LNDC, -1.51% is the latest to delay its third-quarter financial conference call as a result of Tuesday's attacks. The company is now set to have the call on Sept. 18. The company did release its results Tuesday, Sept. 11. The company posted a loss of $1.3 million, or 8 cents a share, compared with the year-ago loss of $568,000, or 4 cents a share. The one analyst polled by First Call had expected a loss of 10 cents a share. Sales totaled $50.2 million for the latest quarter compared with the $61.5 million recorded in the year-ago period. Carreker CANI, -13.55% delayed its second-quarter earnings release and conference till Thursday, Sept. 20. The company added that on behalf of its employees around the world, would like to extend its heartfelt condolences to the victims and their families of Tuesday's attacks. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call expect the company to breakeven for the second quarter. Adobe Systems ADBE, +1.67% said Wednesday that it's postponing the release of its third-quarter results. Adobe was expected to report third-quarter results Sept. 13. It will now report results Sept. 19. Eighteen analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call currently expect a third-quarter profit of 28 cents a share, on average. Meridian Medical Technologies, Inc. MTEC, -0.21% said it will postpone the release of its fourth-quarter and full year financial reports until after the market closes on Sept. 19. The medical products and pharmaceutical systems company will host a conference call to discuss the results at 4:30 p.m. EST the following day. The one analyst polled by First Call currently expects a fourth-quarter profit of 33 cents and full-year profit of 81 cents a share. General Mills GIS, +1.60% also delayed its first-quarter financial results, set for Wednesday. The company didn't provide a new date for the release. "For many of our shareholders and friends in the investment community, business as usual is far from top of mind right now," said Steve Sanger, chairman and chief executive. The Penn Traffic Company PNFT announced that it will also postpone its second-quarter conference call, originally scheduled for Thursday, but is releasing its financial results. "While it is a national tragedy for all Americans, the terrible events that occurred yesterday have dramatically disrupted the lives of virtually everyone in the financial community, including many of our shareholders and others interested in Penn Traffic," said Joseph V. Fisher, Penn Traffic's president and chief executive officer. "Our hearts reach out to the families and friends of the many victims of these senseless acts." The supermarket operator will announce a new date for the conference call next week. Earnings advisories Addressing investors concerns, John Hancock Financial Services JHF "reluctantly given the circumstances" said that it believes that there is no reason to conclude that the tragedy will have a material impact on the company's financial strength. "We lost one of our own employees as well as many friends, and empathize with the pain people are feeling," noted the David F. D'Alessandro, chairman and chief executive officer. Insurance company Cincinnati Financial Corp. CINF, +0.54% said there was no "known" direct property loss to policyholders of its property casualty insurance group. Although, the company did say it participates in reinsurance pools that spread large losses, such as aviation losses, among many insurers and that it is too early to determine what the total loss will be. However, the company doesn't expect any losses that would materially affect the company. Zenith National Insurance ZNT, -1.46% said there is considerable uncertainty as to the nature and amount of monetary losses associated with the events of Sept. 11. The company said it is exposed to a potential loss in the range of about $7 million to $15 million, or 26 cents to 56 cents a share, related to its reinsurance operations. However, the company's primary property and casualty operation is not expected to sustain any losses in connection to the events. Citing parts shortages stemming from freight transportation issues, particularly in airfreight transport and movement of freight through border crossings, Ford F, +2.03% said it would reduce its North American production plans. In addition, the company said current production plan for the third quarter calls for 810,000 to 820,000 vehicles, down 110,000 to 120,000 vehicles from the prior forecast. As a result, third quarter results will fall short of its previous estimate for earnings of 10 cents a share. Currently, analysts polled by First Call expect a profit of 10 cents a share. General Electric GE, -1.46% added Friday that it expects to incur an after-tax loss of about $400 million in claims due to the attacks. That will cut third-quarter earnings by 4 cents a share. Analysts polled by First Call currently expect a profit of 37 cents a share. Huffy HUF, +0.00% said it expects a third-quarter loss of between 26 cents and 30 cents a share. Last year, third-quarter earnings totaled 48 cents a share. Full-year results for 2001 will be between breakeven and a profit of 12 cents a share, compared with the company's previous estimate of 50 cents to 70 cents a share. The two analysts polled by First Call expected a full-year profit of 59 cents a share. The company noted the continued overall weakness in the retail environment and in the economy. Instituform Technologies INSUA said it expects third-quarter earnings, excluding one-time items, to be about 15 cents a share. Analysts polled by First Call currently expect a profit of 48 cents a share. The proprietary technologies and services company now projects revenue for its North American rehabilitation operation for the third quarter to be about $12 million less than previously estimated. Although its internal forecasts still call for the fourth quarter to be stronger than the third, the company said it doesn't plan any forecasts for the time being. Gehl GEHL lowered expectations for full-year 2001 earnings to $1.13 to $1.18 per share, excluding expenses incurred from its strategic review, down from its previous estimate of $1.52. Analysts polled by First Call had also been expecting a profit of about $1.52 a share. Sales for the period are anticipated to be $256 million to $261 million. The maker of construction equipment attributed the expected shortfall to the deteriorating global economy, slow inventory turnover among dealers, the weak euro currency, excessive used equipment levels and lowered rental rates. The company said it was taking action to reduce costs and adjust production to reflect market conditions. Gehl said its review of strategic alternatives will be completed "shortly," and the findings would be shared with shareholders once it has been completed. Alliance Semiconductor ALSC lowered its revenue target for the second quarter Wednesday, saying it continues to see weak demand for its products and hasn't seen significant upturn in the industry. The Santa Clara, Calif.-based company said it now sees second-quarter revenue 50 to 60 percent below the $12 million it reported in the first quarter. "Our first two quarters of this fiscal year we have experienced weak demand both [for] DRAM and SRAM products as customers are dipping into existing inventories," said N.D. Reddy, chairman, in a company statement. Alliance will release final second-quarter results Oct. 18 after the market closes Actuant ATU, +1.97% announced its adoption of the new accounting standard No. 124, noting that the move would increase its fiscal 2002 net income. The motion control systems manufacturer said net income for fiscal 2002 would increase by about $3.2 million, or 38 cents a share. The company added that it's comfortable with its previous fourth-quarter sales target of between $116 million and $121 million and earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization of between $20 million and $23 million. Shares of Actuant closed down 13 cents to $21.37 Monday. Mobile equipment maker Nokia NOK, +0.74% warned that it expects third-quarter revenue to fall 5 percent on a year-over-year basis, compared with earlier expectations of zero to 5 percent growth. But the company said it still expects to reach its third-quarter profit estimate made on July 19. Analysts polled by First Call currently expect a profit of 13 cents a share. Nokia said that, with operators reassessing the timing of their GSM network investments, there would likely be lower year-over-year sales and profitability for its networks division in the third quarter. But it said revenue derived from its mobile phone sales should be at about the same level, with demand showing signs of picking up in the U.S. market. Third-quarter earnings will be reported on October 19. Nokia's U.S.-traded shares closed flat in Monday's action at $13.75. UnitedHealth Group UNH, -2.06% said Tuesday it's comfortable with the current consensus of analysts earnings expectations for 2001, while slightly increasing financial expectations for 2002. Analysts surveyed by Multex have been expecting the health-care services provider to earn $2.74 per share for the current year, on average. The company, which canceled plans for Wednesday presentations to analysts and investors, also disclosed that it expects growth in earnings per share of 16 to 18 percent in 2002 on revenue of approximately $26 billion. Analysts are currently anticipating earnings growth of 15 percent -- to $3.16 a share -- on revenue of $25.4 billion. The stock closed Monday up $1.10 at $66.40. Vitesse Semiconductor VTSS lowered its fourth-quarter revenue and earnings targets, citing continued order delays. Vitesse now sees fourth-quarter revenue in the range of $37 million to $40 million, down from earlier expectations of roughly $50 million, as well as a loss in the range of 12 cents to 15 cents per share. Analysts have been expecting a fourth-quarter loss of 9 cents per share on revenue of $49.6 million, according to First Call. "Order pushouts have continued and the anticipated turns business in storage has failed to materialize," said Lou Tomasetta, president and CEO, in a statement. "Based on current backlog and demand for new products, we expect revenues and pro forma losses in the December 2001 quarter to be flat to slightly up from these numbers." Shares closed down 35 cents in Monday's action to $12.71. Northrop Grumman NOC, +1.28% reiterated financial targets that it outlined in July when it reported second-quarter results. The defense and aerospace contractor said it still sees 2001 sales exceeding $13 billion, with 2002 sales of roughly $16 billion and 2003 sales of roughly $18 billion. Northrop Grumman also reiterated its expectation of 2001 earnings per share of $6.20 to $6.50, with the expectation of double-digit earnings per share growth in 2002 and in 2003. Four analysts polled by First Call currently expect 2001 earnings of about $5.84. Shares closed up 34 cents at $81.94 Monday. PNC Financial Services Group PNC, +1.20% said third-quarter earnings will come in within Wall Street's earnings expectations of $1.05 to $1.10 per share, although venture capital is expected to have a "modest adverse impact" on the quarter's results. In addition, PNC currently expects its level of non-performing assets to remain "relatively stable" but that net charge-offs compared to the second quarter will see some increase due to the slower economy and to actions taken to downsize institutional lending. The stock closed Monday at $59.95, down 0.3 percent. Quintiles Transnational QTRN raised earnings expectations for 2002 amid a new operational plan, a restructuring that will result in a work-force reduction of nearly 6 percent. The provider of technology services for the health-care industry said it now expects to report per-share earnings of 64 to 72 cents next year, while analysts surveyed by First Call had been expecting a profit of 63 cents, on average. The restructuring, which Quintiles anticipates will save it $50 million to $55 million annually beginning in 2002, calls for reorganizing its informatics unit as well as a "rationalization" of internal services. Quintiles says its work force of approximately 18,000 employees will be reduced by about 1,000 globally. The company expects to record a charge of approximately $50 million in the third quarter, primarily related to severance and lease termination costs. "I believe these steps will help us grow our business, improve margins, streamline our operations and create stronger customer relationships based on our contributions to their success," said Pam Kirby, Quintiles's chief executive. The stock closed Monday down 44 cents at $15.70. Allied Waste Industries AW said it expects third-quarter earnings and revenue will be "essentially flat" compared with the second quarter, reflecting the state of the economy. Specifically, the company now doesn't anticipate an increase in disposal volumes in the third quarter. In the second quarter, earnings totaled 22 cents a share, with revenue of $1.41 billion. Analysts polled by First Call had been expecting a third-quarter profit of 27 cents a share. As a result of the weak conditions, the company lowered its operating cash flow outlook for 2001 by 3 to 4 percent. Shares slipped 54 cents to $17.21 ahead of the news Monday. Technology company Xilinx XLNX, +1.25% reiterated that it expects second-quarter revenue to be down 20 to 25 percent compared with the first quarter's $289.3 million, implying a top line of $217 million to $231.7 million. Analysts polled by First Call had been expecting revenue of about $224 million. Excluding an inventory write-down in the range of $65 million and $85 million, the company expects gross margin to come in slightly ahead of 50 to 52 percent. Shares closed down 29 cents to $36.96 ahead of the news Monday. After the market closed Monday, Valspar Corp. VAL, +0.00% said it will take a restructuring charge of $39 million on a pre-tax basis for the fourth quarter. The restructuring, along with other initiatives, will eliminate redundant facilities resulting from the Lilly acquisition, the company said. On a per-share basis, the after-tax charges to the fourth quarter will be about 44 cents a share. The restructuring plan includes closing another seven more plants, a partial closing of four additional plants and a reduction of about 350 jobs, or 5 percent, of its total work force. Shares closed up 18 cents to $37.13 ahead of the news Monday. Newport Corp. NEWP said it's going to take a charge of $38.5 million during the third quarter, more than the $6 million to $10 million charge it had previously announced, because of inventory issues. Of the revised charge, $32.5 million will be in non-cash form. The company also will cut more jobs and said it sees weak demand continuing through the first half of 2002. Newport's total layoffs will thus reach 350 to 375 employees. As well, it's going to consolidate some facilities in California, Colorado and Sweden. Shares closed down $1.11 to $14.79 Monday. Pharmaceutical giant Pfizer PFE, +0.54% said Monday it's reaffirming earlier earnings targets for 2001 and 2002. The New York-based drug maker said it expects earnings from continuing operations of $1.27 to $1.30 per share for 2001 and earnings from continuing operations in 2002 of $1.56 per share "or better." The maker of anti-impotence treatment Viagra, among other drugs, was expected to earn $1.30 per share in 2001 and $1.59 per share in 2002, according to average estimates of analysts polled by First Call. Shares of Pfizer gained $1.17 to close at $38.17 Monday. Positive surprises Oracle ORCL, +1.71% posted first-quarter earnings without comment due to the company having seven people missing from the World Trade Center and one person lost on United Flight 93. The company posted first-quarter net income of $511 million, or 9 cents a hare, on revenue of $2.24 billion. Last year, the company earned $500 million, or 8 cents a share, on revenue of $2.26 billion. Analysts polled by First Call had been expecting a profit of 8 cents a share. Excluding one-time items, Tektronix TEK, -16.67% posted first-quarter earnings of $12.5 million, or 13 cents a share, compared with the year-ago total of $27.6 million, or 28 cents a share. Analysts expected the latest quarter to show a profit of 11 cents a share. Sales totaled $216.6 million for the latest quarter, down compared with the year-ago total of $278.2 million. Including one-time items, net income totaled $8.3 million, or 9 cents a share, for the latest quarter. The company noted that it expects second-quarter sales to drop about 35 percent compared with the year-ago total of $325 million. Analysts polled by First Call currently expect sales of about $229 million for the second quarter. Cutter & Buck CBUK reported a first-quarter loss of $1.4 million, or 13 cents a share, 2 cents better than the two analysts polled by First Call expected. Sales totaled $37.7 million, down compared with the year-ago total of $39 million. In the year-ago period, the company earned $1.3 million, or 13 cents a share. The company designs and markets upscale sportswear and outerwear. Verity VRTY, +64.50% reported a first-quarter loss Wednesday as customers continued to cancel, delay and downsize their capital spending on infrastructure software. Santa Clara, Calif.-based Verity, which had warned of the loss last month, posted a profit in the same quarter a year ago. The provider of reported a net loss of $2.5 million, or 7 cents per share. In same quarter a year ago, Verity reported net income of $7.2 million, or 20 cents per share. Analysts were expecting a loss of 11 cents per share, according to the consensus estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call. Negative surprises ABM Industries, which confirmed Wednesday that the World Trade Center is its largest single job site, reported third-quarter results late Wednesday. The company ABM, +0.75% said that in deference to its employees and customers who are among those missing, it was releasing results without further comment. ABM reported third-quarter net income of $13.2 million, or 52 cents per share, compared with net income of $12.4 million, or 52 cents per share, in the same period a year before. Analysts, on average, were expecting earnings of 55 cents per share, according to Thomson Financial/First Call. Revenue rose to $492.4 million from $461.9 million a year before. Virco Manufacturing Corp. VIR, +0.00% reported Wednesday that its second-quarter net income totaled $4.5 million, or 36 cents a share, compared with a year-ago profit of $4.3 million, or 34 cents a share. One analyst polled by Thomson Financial/First Call had anticipated that the furniture manufacturer would turn a profit of 45 cents a share. Sales totaled $89.2 million, down 7.6 percent compared with $96.6 million in the year-ago period. Shares closed up 26 cents to $9.70 in Monday's action. More from MarketWatch Uber for Bikes Could Save Your Commute More Coverage Don’t ever do this with your credit card Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage
title: Terrorist attacks prompt reshuffled report dates

content: Oracle ORCL, +1.71% posted first-quarter earnings without comment due to the company having seven people missing from the World Trade Center and one person lost on United Flight 93. The company posted first-quarter net income of $511 million, or 9 cents a hare, on revenue of $2.24 billion. Last year, the company earned $500 million, or 8 cents a share, on revenue of $2.26 billion. Analysts polled by First Call had been expecting a profit of 8 cents a share. Excluding one-time items, Tektronix TEK, -16.67% posted first-quarter earnings of $12.5 million, or 13 cents a share, compared with the year-ago total of $27.6 million, or 28 cents a share. Analysts expected the latest quarter to show a profit of 11 cents a share. Sales totaled $216.6 million for the latest quarter, down compared with the year-ago total of $278.2 million. Including one-time items, net income totaled $8.3 million, or 9 cents a share, for the latest quarter. The company noted that it expects second-quarter sales to drop about 35 percent compared with the year-ago total of $325 million. Analysts polled by First Call currently expect sales of about $229 million for the second quarter. Cutter & Buck CBUK reported a first-quarter loss of $1.4 million, or 13 cents a share, 2 cents better than the two analysts polled by First Call expected. Sales totaled $37.7 million, down compared with the year-ago total of $39 million. In the year-ago period, the company earned $1.3 million, or 13 cents a share. The company designs and markets upscale sportswear and outerwear. Verity VRTY, +64.50% reported a first-quarter loss Wednesday as customers continued to cancel, delay and downsize their capital spending on infrastructure software. Santa Clara, Calif.-based Verity, which had warned of the loss last month, posted a profit in the same quarter a year ago. The provider of reported a net loss of $2.5 million, or 7 cents per share. In same quarter a year ago, Verity reported net income of $7.2 million, or 20 cents per share. Analysts were expecting a loss of 11 cents per share, according to the consensus estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call. Quarterly report delays Several companies delayed earnings reports and/or conference calls due to Tuesday's terrorist attacks and the closure of the equity markets. Adobe Systems ADBE, +1.67% said Wednesday that it's postponing the release of its third-quarter results. Adobe was expected to report third-quarter results Sept. 13. It will now report results Sept. 19. Eighteen analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call currently expect a third-quarter profit of 28 cents a share, on average. Meridian Medical Technologies, Inc. MTEC, -0.21% said it will postpone the release of its fourth-quarter and full year financial reports until after the market closes on Sept. 19. The medical products and pharmaceutical systems company will host a conference call to discuss the results at 4:30 p.m. EST the following day. The one analyst polled by First Call currently expects a fourth-quarter profit of 33 cents and full-year profit of 81 cents a share. General Mills GIS, +1.60% also delayed its first-quarter financial results, set for Wednesday. The company didn't provide a new date for the release. "For many of our shareholders and friends in the investment community, business as usual is far from top of mind right now," said Steve Sanger, chairman and chief executive. The Penn Traffic Company PNFT announced that it will also postpone its second-quarter conference call, originally scheduled for Thursday, but is releasing its financial results. "While it is a national tragedy for all Americans, the terrible events that occurred yesterday have dramatically disrupted the lives of virtually everyone in the financial community, including many of our shareholders and others interested in Penn Traffic," said Joseph V. Fisher, Penn Traffic's president and chief executive officer. "Our hearts reach out to the families and friends of the many victims of these senseless acts." The supermarket operator will announce a new date for the conference call next week. Negative surprises ABM Industries, which confirmed Wednesday that the World Trade Center is its largest single job site, reported third-quarter results late Wednesday. The company ABM, +0.75% said that in deference to its employees and customers who are among those missing, it was releasing results without further comment. ABM reported third-quarter net income of $13.2 million, or 52 cents per share, compared with net income of $12.4 million, or 52 cents per share, in the same period a year before. Analysts, on average, were expecting earnings of 55 cents per share, according to Thomson Financial/First Call. Revenue rose to $492.4 million from $461.9 million a year before. Virco Manufacturing Corp. VIR, +0.00% reported Wednesday that its second-quarter net income totaled $4.5 million, or 36 cents a share, compared with a year-ago profit of $4.3 million, or 34 cents a share. One analyst polled by Thomson Financial/First Call had anticipated that the furniture manufacturer would turn a profit of 45 cents a share. Sales totaled $89.2 million, down 7.6 percent compared with $96.6 million in the year-ago period. Shares closed up 26 cents to $9.70 in Monday's action. Earnings advisories Gehl GEHL lowered expectations for full-year 2001 earnings to $1.13 to $1.18 per share, excluding expenses incurred from its strategic review, down from its previous estimate of $1.52. Analysts polled by First Call had also been expecting a profit of about $1.52 a share. Sales for the period are anticipated to be $256 million to $261 million. The maker of construction equipment attributed the expected shortfall to the deteriorating global economy, slow inventory turnover among dealers, the weak euro currency, excessive used equipment levels and lowered rental rates. The company said it was taking action to reduce costs and adjust production to reflect market conditions. Gehl said its review of strategic alternatives will be completed "shortly," and the findings would be shared with shareholders once it has been completed Alliance Semiconductor ALSC lowered its revenue target for the second quarter Wednesday, saying it continues to see weak demand for its products and hasn't seen significant upturn in the industry. The Santa Clara, Calif.-based company said it now sees second-quarter revenue 50 to 60 percent below the $12 million it reported in the first quarter. "Our first two quarters of this fiscal year we have experienced weak demand both [for] DRAM and SRAM products as customers are dipping into existing inventories," said N.D. Reddy, chairman, in a company statement. Alliance will release final second-quarter results Oct. 18 after the market closes Actuant ATU, +1.97% announced its adoption of the new accounting standard No. 124, noting that the move would increase its fiscal 2002 net income. The motion control systems manufacturer said net income for fiscal 2002 would increase by about $3.2 million, or 38 cents a share. The company added that it's comfortable with its previous fourth-quarter sales target of between $116 million and $121 million and earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization of between $20 million and $23 million. Shares of Actuant closed down 13 cents to $21.37 Monday. Mobile equipment maker Nokia NOK, +0.74% warned that it expects third-quarter revenue to fall 5 percent on a year-over-year basis, compared with earlier expectations of zero to 5 percent growth. But the company said it still expects to reach its third-quarter profit estimate made on July 19. Analysts polled by First Call currently expect a profit of 13 cents a share. Nokia said that, with operators reassessing the timing of their GSM network investments, there would likely be lower year-over-year sales and profitability for its networks division in the third quarter. But it said revenue derived from its mobile phone sales should be at about the same level, with demand showing signs of picking up in the U.S. market. Third-quarter earnings will be reported on October 19. Nokia's U.S.-traded shares closed flat in Monday's action at $13.75. UnitedHealth Group UNH, -2.06% said Tuesday it's comfortable with the current consensus of analysts earnings expectations for 2001, while slightly increasing financial expectations for 2002. Analysts surveyed by Multex have been expecting the health-care services provider to earn $2.74 per share for the current year, on average. The company, which canceled plans for Wednesday presentations to analysts and investors, also disclosed that it expects growth in earnings per share of 16 to 18 percent in 2002 on revenue of approximately $26 billion. Analysts are currently anticipating earnings growth of 15 percent -- to $3.16 a share -- on revenue of $25.4 billion. The stock closed Monday up $1.10 at $66.40. Vitesse Semiconductor VTSS lowered its fourth-quarter revenue and earnings targets, citing continued order delays. Vitesse now sees fourth-quarter revenue in the range of $37 million to $40 million, down from earlier expectations of roughly $50 million, as well as a loss in the range of 12 cents to 15 cents per share. Analysts have been expecting a fourth-quarter loss of 9 cents per share on revenue of $49.6 million, according to First Call. "Order pushouts have continued and the anticipated turns business in storage has failed to materialize," said Lou Tomasetta, president and CEO, in a statement. "Based on current backlog and demand for new products, we expect revenues and pro forma losses in the December 2001 quarter to be flat to slightly up from these numbers." Shares closed down 35 cents in Monday's action to $12.71. Northrop Grumman NOC, +1.28% reiterated financial targets that it outlined in July when it reported second-quarter results. The defense and aerospace contractor said it still sees 2001 sales exceeding $13 billion, with 2002 sales of roughly $16 billion and 2003 sales of roughly $18 billion. Northrop Grumman also reiterated its expectation of 2001 earnings per share of $6.20 to $6.50, with the expectation of double-digit earnings per share growth in 2002 and in 2003. Four analysts polled by First Call currently expect 2001 earnings of about $5.84. Shares closed up 34 cents at $81.94 Monday. PNC Financial Services Group PNC, +1.20% said third-quarter earnings will come in within Wall Street's earnings expectations of $1.05 to $1.10 per share, although venture capital is expected to have a "modest adverse impact" on the quarter's results. In addition, PNC currently expects its level of non-performing assets to remain "relatively stable" but that net charge-offs compared to the second quarter will see some increase due to the slower economy and to actions taken to downsize institutional lending. The stock closed Monday at $59.95, down 0.3 percent. Quintiles Transnational QTRN raised earnings expectations for 2002 amid a new operational plan, a restructuring that will result in a work-force reduction of nearly 6 percent. The provider of technology services for the health-care industry said it now expects to report per-share earnings of 64 to 72 cents next year, while analysts surveyed by First Call had been expecting a profit of 63 cents, on average. The restructuring, which Quintiles anticipates will save it $50 million to $55 million annually beginning in 2002, calls for reorganizing its informatics unit as well as a "rationalization" of internal services. Quintiles says its work force of approximately 18,000 employees will be reduced by about 1,000 globally. The company expects to record a charge of approximately $50 million in the third quarter, primarily related to severance and lease termination costs. "I believe these steps will help us grow our business, improve margins, streamline our operations and create stronger customer relationships based on our contributions to their success," said Pam Kirby, Quintiles's chief executive. The stock closed Monday down 44 cents at $15.70. Allied Waste Industries AW said it expects third-quarter earnings and revenue will be "essentially flat" compared with the second quarter, reflecting the state of the economy. Specifically, the company now doesn't anticipate an increase in disposal volumes in the third quarter. In the second quarter, earnings totaled 22 cents a share, with revenue of $1.41 billion. Analysts polled by First Call had been expecting a third-quarter profit of 27 cents a share. As a result of the weak conditions, the company lowered its operating cash flow outlook for 2001 by 3 to 4 percent. Shares slipped 54 cents to $17.21 ahead of the news Monday. Technology company Xilinx XLNX, +1.25% reiterated that it expects second-quarter revenue to be down 20 to 25 percent compared with the first quarter's $289.3 million, implying a top line of $217 million to $231.7 million. Analysts polled by First Call had been expecting revenue of about $224 million. Excluding an inventory write-down in the range of $65 million and $85 million, the company expects gross margin to come in slightly ahead of 50 to 52 percent. Shares closed down 29 cents to $36.96 ahead of the news Monday. After the market closed Monday, Valspar Corp. VAL, +0.00% said it will take a restructuring charge of $39 million on a pre-tax basis for the fourth quarter. The restructuring, along with other initiatives, will eliminate redundant facilities resulting from the Lilly acquisition, the company said. On a per-share basis, the after-tax charges to the fourth quarter will be about 44 cents a share. The restructuring plan includes closing another seven more plants, a partial closing of four additional plants and a reduction of about 350 jobs, or 5 percent, of its total work force. Shares closed up 18 cents to $37.13 ahead of the news Monday. Newport Corp. NEWP said it's going to take a charge of $38.5 million during the third quarter, more than the $6 million to $10 million charge it had previously announced, because of inventory issues. Of the revised charge, $32.5 million will be in non-cash form. The company also will cut more jobs and said it sees weak demand continuing through the first half of 2002. Newport's total layoffs will thus reach 350 to 375 employees. As well, it's going to consolidate some facilities in California, Colorado and Sweden. Shares closed down $1.11 to $14.79 Monday. Pharmaceutical giant Pfizer PFE, +0.54% said Monday it's reaffirming earlier earnings targets for 2001 and 2002. The New York-based drug maker said it expects earnings from continuing operations of $1.27 to $1.30 per share for 2001 and earnings from continuing operations in 2002 of $1.56 per share "or better." The maker of anti-impotence treatment Viagra, among other drugs, was expected to earn $1.30 per share in 2001 and $1.59 per share in 2002, according to average estimates of analysts polled by First Call. Shares of Pfizer gained $1.17 to close at $38.17 Monday. More from MarketWatch Uber for Bikes Could Save Your Commute More Coverage Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle
title: Tragedy prompts quarterly delays

content: U.S. stocks to watch ABM Industries ABM, +0.75% reported first-quarter earnings in line with analysts' expectations, as polled by First Call/Thomson Financial. The San Francisco-based company reported earnings of $8.4 million, or 34 cents a share, vs. $7.5 million, or 32 cents a share, during the same quarter last year. Quarterly revenue jumped 10 percent to $470 million. ABM provides facility services ranging from air conditioners to janitorial to security. Shares closed up 12 cents at $31.12 ahead of the news. Adobe ADBE, +1.67% reported first-quarter results and lowered its second-quarter outlook due to the "challenging and uncertain economic environment." The maker of Photoshop and Acrobat software reported first-quarter pro forma net income, excluding non-operating items, of 33 cents a share. Analysts were expecting earnings of 28 cents a share on revenue of $343.1 million. Actual revenue was $329 million compared with $282.2 million during the same quarter last year. Net income, including one-time items, was $69.8 million, or 28 cents a share, compared with $64.6 million, or 26 cents a share, during the same quarter last year. Looking ahead to the second quarter, Adobe set a target of 15 percent revenue growth compared with the same period last year. Also, co-founder John Warnock, 60, is retiring from the company, but will remain as co-chairman, alongside co-founder Charles Geschke, who retired last year. Shares closed down $1.13 at $25. See full story. Artesyn Technologies ATSN lowered expectations for its first quarter and the full-year 2001. The company said that quarterly revenue may decline by 10 percent from last year, and it will lose between 5 and 10 cents a share. Analysts were expecting a gain of a quarter. The company expects full-year earnings between 60 and 70 cents, on revenue between $700 million and $725 million. Analysts were expecting a gain of $1.33 a share. The equipment maker for communications products blamed the weakening economy and inventory costs for the shortfalls. Shares closed up 44 cents at $15.19. Borders Group BGP, -4.96% beat the Wall Street fourth-quarter estimate by a penny a share. The bookstore chain reported net earnings, excluding one-time charges, of $98.7 million, or $1.23 a share. This compares with $98.9 million, or $1.23 a share, during the same quarter last year. Total quarterly sales rose to $1.2 billion, up from $1.1 billion last year. The Ann Arbor, Mich.-based company also said it expects to earn between $1.38 and $1.40 a share for 2001. Shares closed up 9 cents at $15.29. Compaq Computer CPQ said it will name a new CFO and will undertake a drastic restructuring that will streamline the company's PC operations and cut 7 percent of its global work force, or 5,000 workers. Such action is expected, Compaq said, to result in annual savings of $500 million to $600 million. The Houston-based PC company said it also forecasts a first-quarter profit in a range of 12 to 14 cents and revenue of $9 billion to $9.2 billion. Compaq was expected to earn 18 cents a share and notch sales of $9.6 billion. For the PC unit, the company will integrate operations between consumer and business products. Jeff Clarke was also named CFO. Shares of Compaq ended the day up 15 cents to $18.50. See full story. High-speed wireless company Metricom MCOM said it is laying off 179 employees, out of a work force of 800. The move is an attempt to match operating expenses in line with revenue growth. The company also announced the resignation of CFO James Wall. Shares were halted in after-hours trading after closing flat at $3.69. Oracle Corp., ORCL, +1.71% Nasdaq's fourth-largest company, reported fiscal third-quarter earnings of $583 million, or 10 cents a share, up 16 percent from $503 million, or 9 cents in the year-ago period. The number met Wall Street analysts' adjusted expectations, following a warning issued two weeks earlier. Revenue came in at $2.7 billion, up from $2.4 billion in the company's fiscal 2000 fourth quarter. Oracle shares fell $1.38, or 8 percent, to close at $14.69. See full story. Tektronix TEK, -16.67% beat third-quarter earnings expectations by a nickel a share. The company reported a gain of $35.2 million, or 37 cents, vs. $20.2 million, or 21 cents a share, during the same quarter last year. Sales jumped to $327 million, up from $271 million last year. The company, which tests computer and wireless equipment, said it expects fourth-quarter revenue growth of 10 to 12 percent. Shares closed down 34 cents at $24.66 ahead of the news. Temple-Inland TIN, +0.00% lowered its first-quarter expectations to roughly 20 cents a share. Analysts were expecting the packaging company to earn 55 cents a share. The Austin, Texas-based company blamed the shortfall on waning demand and a softening economy. Shares closed down 47 cents at $44.70. Advancers for Thursday American Eagle Outfitters AEOS gained 9.4 percent after the Warrendale, Pa., casual apparel retailer reported fourth-quarter earnings of $49.1 million, or 68 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $37.1 million, or 51 cents a share, and 3 cents ahead of Wall Street expectations. Sales jumped 48.5 percent in the latest three months to $423.7 million. Same-store sale rose 11.3 percent in the period. Shares closed up $2.44 at $28.50. Bally Total Fitness BFT, -0.54% rose 8.3 percent after the Chicago fitness club firm sold roughly 8 percent of its membership receivables portfolio to Household International at net book value. Bally said the sale generated initial cash proceeds of $45 million and that the deal provides for future profit participation. The company plans to use the proceeds for debt reduction and general capital needs. Shares closed up $2.15 at $27.90. Eclipsys ECLP surged 16 percent after Dain Rauscher Wessels lifted its rating on shares of the Delray Beach, Fla., provider of health-care information products to "strong buy-aggressive" from "buy-aggressive" due to the firm's "high degree of confidence in the company's ability to hit our first-quarter estimates." Dain Rauscher said its channel checks have indicated the company's business is solid. The firm is looking for earnings of 5 cents a share on revenue of $56 million in the first quarter. Analysts polled by First Call/Thomson Financial are also forecasting a profit of a nickel a share, on average. Shares closed up $2.50 at $18.13. EDS EDS advanced 3.1 percent after the company received a 10-year, $2.2 billion service contract to manage the information technology systems of Sabre TSG, +4.75% a provider of technology and marketing services for the travel industry. In addition, EDS will purchase Sabre's airline infrastructure outsourcing and internal IT infrastructure assets for $670 million. Sabre will retain $108 million in working capital. Sabre expects the deal to be "slightly" accretive to earnings in 2001, and accretive in 2002 and 2003, while EDS expects it to be neutral in 2001 and accretive thereafter. As part of the agreements, approximately 4,200 Sabre employees will transition to EDS. Sabre shares jumped 16 percent. EDS shares closed up $1.75 at $58.50. See full story. Mirant MIR, -20.00% leapt 19 percent after the company raised its first-quarter earnings projections to 46 to 48 cents a share from 16 to 18 cents a share. The company also boosted its full-year estimate to $1.55 to $1.60 per share from $1.15 to $1.20 per share. The company attributed the expected growth to a strong performance in North America. Shares closed up $4.78 at $29.84. Nextel Partners NXTP climbed 13 percent after the company backed previously disclosed 2001 financial targets late Wednesday. Chairman John Chapple said the company is on track to meet first-quarter expectations of 60,000 subscriber additions, $70 average revenue per user and customer turnover of less than 2 percent. Currently, the company is expected to post a loss of 30 cents per share for the first quarter, on revenue $65.7 million, according to the consensus estimate of analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial. Shares closed up $1.69 at $14.75. Nokia NOK, +0.74% added more than 14 percent after the company lowered its sales forecast Thursday, saying it expects growth of roughly 20 percent, below previous projections of an increase of 25 to 30 percent. Citing slower growth and difficult market conditions, the company estimated the size of the full-year 2001 mobile phone market at 450 million to 500 million units. For the first quarter, the Finnish mobile phone giant forecast earnings of 0.19 EUR per share, in line with its earlier statements. Shares closed up $3.15 at $24.95. RehabCare RHB, -0.62% leapt 5.3 percent after Merrill Lynch initiated coverage of the St. Louis provider of health-care staffing and program management services with a "long-term buy" rating and a 12-month price target of $50. "With 60 percent of its projected $551 million 2001 revenue base coming from health-care staffing, we believe RehabCare offers investors a secular growth opportunity that addresses the chronic shortage of health-care professionals, particularly nurses," the firm said in a research note to clients. "RehabCare also offers a sound track record and very high returns on invested capital." Shares closed up $1.95 at $38.40. Sprint PCS PCS a tracking stock for Sprint's FON, +5.56% wireless services unit, rose more than 3.2 percent after the Washington Post reported in its online edition that BellSouth BLS, +0.00% is pursuing the purchase of Sprint as well its wireless business Also, the paper reported that SBC Communications SBC, -0.65% has held conversations with WorldCom WCOM about acquiring the long-distance company, though no talks have been held in recent weeks. Worldcom rose 6.8 percent. Sprint PCS shares closed up 61 cents at $19.51. Universal Access UAXS leapt 3.7 percent after the Chicago provider of network infrastructure services secured a contract to supply off-net connectivity services for Aleron, a McLean, Va., Internet access services firm. Financial terms of the deal weren't disclosed. Shares closed up 17 cents at $4.78. US Unwired UNWR soared more than 28 percent in afternoon action. The stock is recovering from a plus-15 percent drop Wednesday following news that the Lake Charles, La., telecommunications carrier has deployed wireless data access technology from 3Com COMS to deliver Sprint PCS' PCS Wireless Web services to its customers. Shares closed up $1.63 at $7.38. Verity VRTY, +64.50% edged 7.6 percent higher after the company reported third-quarter net income of $9.2 million, or 25 cents a share, compared with $7.8 million, or 22 cents a share, during the same quarter last year. Analysts expected earnings of 23 cents a share. Revenue was $28.7 million compared with $22.5 million during the same quarter last year. Also, Verity extended its contract with Regent Pacific Management through August 2002, which allows for Verity CEO and Chairman Gary J. Sbona to remain in office. For the fourth quarter, Verity expects to achieve its targets with per-share net income of 24 cents to 27 cents a share on revenue of $41 million to $42.5 million. Analysts currently expect earnings of 25 cents a share. The stock closed up $1.75 at $24.69. Decliners for Thursday Bombay Co. BBA, +0.56% fell 4.8 percent after the Fort Worth, Texas, specialty furniture retailer reported fourth-quarter earnings of $13 million, or 40 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $11.7 million, or 32 cents a share, and 2 cents ahead of the average estimate of analysts polled by First Call/Thomson Financial. Sales rose 12 percent in the latest three months to $156.6 million. But the company also said it expects losses in the first and second quarters of fiscal 2001 to exceed losses in the same periods a year earlier, respectively. Specifically, Bombay said higher selling, general and administrative expenses would lower earnings by 2 to 3 cents a share in the periods. The company is forecasting earnings growth of 10 to 15 percent in fiscal 2001. Shares closed down 14 cents at $2.75. Breezecom BRZE dipped 18 percent after the company revised its financial estimates for the first quarter due to the current economic slowdown in the U.S. The maker of wireless access products said it now expects to breakeven on a per-share basis, and estimates revenue to be $23 million to $26 million, compared with the average analyst estimate compiled by Multex for a profit of 10 cents a share on revenue of $32 million. For all of 2001, the company expects EPS of 15 to 20 cents on sales of $120 million, while analysts had forecast 45 cents and $145.7 million, respectively. Shares closed off $1.22 at $5.69. CoSine Communications COSN plunged 23 percent after the company lowered pro forma revenue expectations for the current quarter. The company said it's now looking for first-quarter revenue to come in between $6 million and $8 million. CoSine, which makes switches and software used by network service providers, blamed the lowered expectations on delayed acceptances of networks currently in trial and a general industry wide slowdown. Shares closed off $1.25 at $4.25. Dollar Tree Stores DLTR, +1.05% fell 25 percent after the discount retailer warned that earnings would fall well below expectations due to inclement weather and downturn in the U.S. economy. The chain of $1 variety stores expects first-quarter profits to come in at 9 cents a share, 5 cents below the consensus of analysts' estimates reported to First Call/Thomson Financial. CEO Macon Brock also said he expects the second quarter's same-store sales to be down, as well, thanks partly to tough comparisons a year ago when sales jumped 14.3 percent. Shares closed off $6 at $18.19. See full story. ECollege ECLG sank 17 percent after the Denver provider of e-learning software and services forecast a loss of $5.2 million to $5.5 million, or 32 to 34 cents a share, for the first quarter. This view is wider than its previous outlook for a loss to $4 million to $5 million, or 26 to 31 cents a share. Revenue is projected at $4 million to $4.2 million. eCollege attributed the shortfall to longer sales cycles as institutions slow capital spending and weak course development revenue due to faculty opting to author courses themselves using the company's Techning Solutions 4.2 platform. Shares closed off 69 cents at $3.44. Globespan GS.PN, +0.48% dropped 17 percent after the company said it is lowering its first- and second-quarter expectations due to the slowing economy and inventory issues. The Red Bank, N.J.-based firm now expects to earn between 10 and 13 cents a share for its first quarter and between 8 and 10 seconds for its second quarter. Analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial were expecting first-quarter earnings of 18 cents a share and 17 cents for the second quarter. The provider of integrated circuits and software for DSL lines also said it expects to report revenue between $105 million and $115 million, 12 to 20 percent lower than the fourth quarter. Shares closed up 75 cents at $24.63 ahead of the news. Shares closed off $4.25 at $20.38. Intuit INTU, +1.42% plummeted 30 percent after the company said revenue growth will be slower than expected during the third-quarter and full year, but that it "remains committed" to 32 percent pro forma operating income growth. Specifically, Intuit said it expects third-quarter revenue of $425 million to $450 million and $1.26 billion to $1.3 billion during the full year. Analysts currently expect revenue of $467 million for the third quarter and $1.31 billion for 2001. Intuit reiterated targets for 2001 operating income of $205 million to $213 million and that it will deliver a minimum of 20 percent pro forma operating income growth during the next three fiscal years. For 2002, the firm expects minimum pro forma operating income growth of 25 percent to 30 percent. Intuit shares closed off $12.63 at $29.63. See full story. Mesaba Holdings MAIR lost 5.4 percent after the Minneapolis airline said that fourth-quarter earnings would not exceed 10 cents a share. Analysts polled by First Call/Thomson Financial were looking for a profit of 33 cents a share, on average. Shares closed off 63 cents at $11.25. META Group METG slumped 27 percent after Stamford, Conn., provider of research and consulting services reported a fourth-quarter loss of $10 million, or 91 cents a share, down from a year-ago pro forma earnings of $2.5 million, or 23 cents a share. Revenue rose 9 percent in the period to $30.9 million. "We were disappointed with our ability to control expenses during 2000. We anticipated much higher top line growth and had budgeted accordingly," said Dale Kutnick, the company's chairman and CEO, in a press release. Shares closed off $1.31 at $3.63. MIND CTI Ltd. MNDO, -3.91% dived 55 percent after the Israeli provider of billing and customer management services warned that first-quarter results would miss its previous expectations. The company forecast a loss of 5 cents a share on revenue of $2.5 million. Sales could fluctuate as much as 10 percent above or below this estimate. MIND CTI attributed the weak performance to the rapid deterioration of the global economy and current uncertainty in the telecommunications, information technology and Internet markets. Shares closed of $2.41 at $1.97. Outback Steakhouse OSI, -2.84% slid 6.2 percent in afternoon action. Merrill Lynch has issued a midday research note on the company, saying it knows of no fundamental reason for the sell-off. In addition, the firm went on to say that concerns that Outback is vulnerable to beef supply/safety problems related to the proliferation of hoof and mouth disease among cattle in Europe are unjustified. "According to management, FY01 beef supply is already locked up," Merrill told clients. "As a reminder, beef represents less than 50 percent of the core OSI format's sales." The firm left its "buy" rating on the stock intact. Shares closed off $1.59 at $24. Rambus RMBS, +0.67% tumbled 32 percent on heavy afternoon volume. SG Cowen said in a research note to clients that Judge Robert Payne had made a pre-trial ruling, siding with an expert witness from Infineon Technologies IFX, -8.16% which in effect limits the scope of Rambus's patents on SDRAM and DDR memory. Infineon's stock is up 93 cents at $36.48. In September 2000, Rambus filed suit against Infineon in a German district court, alleging infringements of intellectual property protected by a European patent. Previously, Rambus had filed suit against Infineon in Virginia for willful patent infringement. Shares closed off $11.26 at $24.09. See full story. Roadway Express ROAD, +0.00% dipped 2.9 percent after the company said it would not meet first-quarter expectations. Analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial had been expecting the motor carrier to earn 56 cents a share. The Akron, Ohio-based firm blamed the slowing economy and said that tonnage levels are currently 10 to 11 percent below last year's levels. Shares closed off 63 cents at $20.94. SanDisk SNDK fell 4.8 percent after the company said it expects to report first-quarter sales and earnings that are "significantly lower" than previously expected as a result of the continued economic weakness and customer inventory corrections. The flash memory maker said it now sees sales falling 45 percent from the sequential fourth quarter, compared with previous estimates of a 15 to 20 percent decline. SanDisk also anticipates breaking even on a per-share basis, while analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial had forecast earnings of 20 cents per share. In response, Dr. Eli Harari, SanDisk's chief executive, said the company would cut its regular and contract employee work force and reduce discretionary spending. Shares closed off $1 at $19.88. Service Corp. International SRV, +0.58% lost 6.8 percent after the Houston funeral and cemetery firm reported a fourth-quarter loss of $3.2 million, or 1 cent a share. These results, which reflect continuing and discontinued operations prior to unusual items and the implementation of SAB-101 accounting standards, missed Wall Street expectations for a profit of 4 cents a share. The company plans to continue to sell certain funeral and cemetery assets that it deems aren't well aligned with its long-term strategy. Service plans to use the proceeds of these sales to reduce debt, which it has cut to $3.29 billion as of Dec. 31 from $4.06 billion at the same time a year earlier. Shares closed off 27 cents at $3.72. See full story. Steris STE, +2.37% dropped 19 percent after the company said it expects fourth-quarter earnings, excluding items, to meet Wall Street expectations of 16 cents a share. However, including a restructuring charge of roughly $40 million, the Mentor, Ohio, firm said it would record a loss for the period. The company plans to consolidate certain manufacturing operations and reduce staff by 300 to 350 employees. For fiscal 2002, the company expects earnings growth of 35 to 40 percent and revenue growth in the mid-single digits. Shares closed off $3.37 at $14.15. TeleTech TTEC, -0.16% plunged 36 percent after the company lowered its first-quarter earnings outlook and named founder Ronald Tuchman as interim chief executive officer, succeeding Scott Thomas, who resigned as CEO and as a board member. The company said it now expects first-quarter earnings either 11 or 12 cents a share on revenue between $230 million and $235 million. Analysts were expecting earnings of 17 cents a share. The integrated customer care company also said Larry Kessler has resigned from his recently assigned post as chief operating officer. Tuchman, who served as CEO from the company's inception in 1982 to 1999, will continue as chairman. TeleTech has started an executive search for a new chief executive. Shares closed off $5.06 at $9.06. Virata VRTA, +2.44% dropped 15 percent after the company lowered fourth-quarter revenue targets amid a slowdown in the U.S. economy, inventory overhang, shipment cancellations and delays in expected DSL roll-outs. Virata now expects fourth-quarter revenue of $19 million, with a GAAP loss between 5 cents and 7 cents per share. Analysts currently expect the chip company to earn 3 cents per share on revenue of $45.9 million, according to First Call. Due to the slowdown, Virata expects to take a charge of $9.5 million to $10.5 million to cover headcount reduction, inventory changes and facility consolidation. CEO Charles Cotton said the company's short-term outlook on revenue and earnings remain poor, but demand for DSL remains strong globally. Shares closed off $1.75 at $10. Vitech America VTCH sank 66 percent following news that the Miami provider of PC-based information technology services has filed suit against Gateway GTW alleging fraud, misrepresentation and breach of contract. Vitech said the suit is related to an agreement between the two companies that called for Gateway to provide funding and operational support for Vitech's efforts in Brazil. Gateway has filed a separate lawsuit in New York, which Vitech said it believes has no merit. Shares closed off $2.06 at $1.06. title: Stocks to watch: Adobe, Borders, Compaq and more

content: (EDGAR Online via COMTEX) -- ITEM 2. MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS. The following Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations ("MD&A") is intended to facilitate an understanding of the results of operations and financial condition of ABM Industries Incorporated and its subsidiaries (collectively referred to as "ABM," "we," "us," "our," or the "Company"). This MD&A is provided as a supplement to, and should be read in conjunction with, our unaudited consolidated financial statements and the accompanying notes ("Financial Statements") and our Annual Report on Form 10-K for the year ended October 31, 2017 ("Annual Report"), which has been filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission ("SEC"). This MD&A contains forward-looking statements about our business, operations, and industry that involve risks and uncertainties, such as statements regarding our plans, objectives, expectations, and intentions. Our future results and financial condition may be materially different from those we currently anticipate. See "Forward-Looking Statements" for more information. Throughout the MD&A, amounts and percentages may not recalculate due to rounding. Unless otherwise indicated, all information in the MD&A and references to years are based on our fiscal year, which ends on October 31. Business Overview ABM is a leading provider of integrated facility services, customized by industry, with a mission to make a difference, every person, every day. 2020 Vision In September 2015, we announced a comprehensive transformation initiative ("2020 Vision") intended to drive long-term profitable growth through an industry-based go-to-market approach. Our 2020 Vision involves three phases: During Phase 1, completed on November 1, 2016, we realigned our organization; in Phase 2, which is continuing today, we are focused on improvements to our operational framework to promote efficiencies and process enhancements; and in Phase 3, on the foundation of benefits realized from Phases 1 and 2, we anticipate accelerating growth with our industry-based, go-to-market service model. 2020 Vision Developments in 2018 During 2018, we expect to continue focusing on certain aspects of our business practices to further build the foundation upon which we deliver leading industry-based facility services. We anticipate that we will continue to roll out enterprise-wide standard operating procedures (the "ABM Way") and improve our account planning, labor management, manager development, and safety initiatives. To achieve this, we are focusing on long term, profitable growth relating to both existing clients and targeted opportunities, and we have launched a "Tag Pricer" tool that will help us capture work orders more efficiently. In addition, we continue consolidating our procurement activities and investing in technology platforms to help drive and sustain 2020 Vision performance. Developments and Trends United States Tax Reform The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (the "Tax Act"), which was enacted on December 22, 2017, represents the most significant overhaul of the U.S. tax code in more than 30 years. Among other provisions, the Tax Act provides for a reduction of the federal corporate income tax rate from 35% to 21% and a "transition tax" to be levied on the deemed repatriation of indefinitely reinvested earnings of international subsidiaries. Since we have an October 31 fiscal year-end, the lower corporate income tax rate will be phased in, resulting in a U.S. statutory federal rate of 23.3% for fiscal 2018 and 21% for subsequent fiscal years. Other provisions under the Tax Act will not be effective for us until fiscal 2019, including limitations on deductibility of interest and executive compensation as well as anti-deferral provisions on Global Intangible Low-Taxed Income ("GILTI"). As a result, in 2019 we expect our effective tax rate to increase from the 2018 rate. The estimated impact of the Tax Act, as summarized below for the three months ended January 31, 2018, is further described in Note 11, "Income Taxes," in the Financial Statements. Three Months Ended (in millions) January 31, 2018 Remeasurement of U.S. deferred tax assets and liabilities $ 28.7 Transition tax on non-U.S. subsidiaries' earnings (7.0) Total impact of the Tax Act on the benefit for income taxes $ 21.7 Due to the complexities of implementing the provisions of the Tax Act, the staff of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission issued Staff Accounting Bulletin  Three Months Ended (in millions) January 31, 2018 Education $ 140.5 Technology & Manufacturing 58.6 Business & Industry 40.7 Healthcare 7.5 Aviation 4.3 Total $ 251.6  Following this acquisition, during 2018 we initiated a restructuring program to achieve cost synergies from our combined operations. We include these costs within corporate expenses. We do not expect to incur significant severance expenses related to GCA restructuring in the future.  Three Months Ended (in millions) January 31, 2018 Employee Severance $ 8.8 External Support Fees 2.0 Other Project Fees 0.8 Total $ 11.7  Segment Reporting Effective November 1, 2017, we reorganized our reportable segments to reflect the integration of GCA into our industry group model. Our reportable segments consist of Business & Industry ("B&I"), Aviation, Technology & Manufacturing ("T&M"), Education, Technical Solutions, and Healthcare, as further described below.  REPORTABLE SEGMENTS AND DESCRIPTIONS B&I, our largest reportable segment, encompasses janitorial, facilities engineering, and parking services [[Image Removed: fy18bni.jpg]] for commercial real estate properties and sports and entertainment venues. B&I also provides vehicle maintenance and other services to rental car providers ("Vehicle Services Contracts"). Aviation supports airlines and airports with services [[Image Removed: fy18aviationa01.jpg]] ranging from parking and janitorial to passenger assistance, catering logistics, air cabin maintenance, and transportation. T&M combines our legacy Industrial & Manufacturing business, which was previously included in our B&I [[Image Removed: fy18tnm.jpg]] segment, with our legacy High Tech industry group, which was previously reported as part of our Emerging Industries Group. T&M provides janitorial, facilities engineering, and parking services. Education delivers janitorial, custodial, landscaping and grounds, facilities engineering, and parking services for [[Image Removed: fy18educationa01.jpg]] public school districts, private schools, colleges, and universities. This business was previously reported as part of our Emerging Industries Group. Technical Solutions specializes in mechanical and [[Image Removed: fy18technicalsolutions.jpg]] electrical services. These services can also be leveraged for cross-selling across all of our industry groups, both domestically and internationally. Healthcare offers janitorial, facilities management, clinical engineering, food and nutrition, laundry and [[Image Removed: fy18healthcare.jpg]] linen, parking and guest services, and patient transportation services at traditional hospitals and non-acute facilities. This business was previously reported as part of our Emerging Industries Group.  Prior Year Reclassifications Effective with the reorganization of our reportable segments, we have revised our prior period segment information to conform with our fiscal 2018 presentation. These changes had no impact on our previously reported consolidated balance sheets, statements of comprehensive income (loss), or statements of cash flows. Government Services Business We sold our Government Services business on May 31, 2017. The reported results for this business are through the date of sale and future results could include run-off costs. As this business has been sold and is no longer part of our ongoing operations, we have excluded a discussion of its results for the periods in this report. Operating profit decreased by $4.3 million, or 18.2%, during the three months ended January 31, 2018, as compared to the three months ended January 31, 2017. The decrease in operating profit is primarily attributable to higher amortization expense, incremental selling, general and administrative expenses, and restructuring and related costs associated with the GCA acquisition. This decrease was partially offset by higher operating profit in our Education and T&M segments associated with the GCA acquisition. Interest expense increased by $11.1 million during the three months ended January 31, 2018, as compared to the three months ended January 31, 2017, primarily related to increased indebtedness incurred to fund the GCA acquisition and higher relative interest rates under our credit facility. Our income taxes from continuing operations for the three months ended January 31, 2018 were favorably impacted by a net discrete tax benefit of $21.7 million related to the Tax Act. Net cash provided by operating activities was $33.7 million during the three months ended January 31, 2018. Dividends of $11.5 million were paid to shareholders, and dividends totaling $0.175 per common share were declared during the three months ended January 31, 2018. At January 31, 2018, total outstanding borrowings under our credit facility were $1.2 billion, and we had up to $330.5 million of borrowing capacity under our credit facility; however, covenant restrictions limited our actual borrowing capacity to $245.5 million. Mar 07, 2018 (c) 1995-2018 Cybernet Data Systems, Inc. title: 10-Q: ABM INDUSTRIES INC /DE/

content: NEW YORK, Mar 29, 2018 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE via COMTEX) -- ABM ABM, +0.75% a leading provider of facility solutions, has been named a preferred partner and awarded a five-year janitorial services contract at LaGuardia Airport's Terminal B by LaGuardia Gateway Partners, the private operator and developer of Terminal B. This includes servicing the existing Terminal B, as well as the new state-of-the-art terminal that will open in phases through 2022. The redevelopment of Terminal B is one of the most complex airport construction projects in the world and when complete, the new Terminal B will be a 1.3 million square foot facility with 35 gates and dual pedestrian bridges that span active aircraft taxi lanes. "We are excited to partner with LaGuardia Gateway Partners on this amazing project," says Don Stephens, President of Aviation, ABM. "As an industry leader in facility services and solutions with one of the industry's largest aviation service portfolios, we are uniquely positioned to provide best-in-class cleaning for the flying public with our outstanding people, innovative standards and materials, and an environmental focus." "LaGuardia Gateway Partners is pleased to welcome ABM as our custodial partner," says Marisa Von Wieding, Director of Operations, LaGuardia Gateway Partners. "Improving the experience for all of our 15 million annual guests is at the core of our mission at LaGuardia Gateway Partners, both in the current Terminal B and in the new Terminal that we are building. ABM shares our focus on guest experience and innovation and will meet our high standards in delivering a clean facility for travelers and employees each and every day." ABM's Aviation team provides service excellence in passenger and facility maintenance services, including aircraft and airport cleaning, wheelchair services, catering, parking and transportation, to airports and airlines globally, including LaGuardia, John F. Kennedy International Airport and Newark Liberty International Airport. For more information about our end-to-end Aviation services and solutions, visit www.abm.com/aviation/. CONNECT WITH ABM LinkedIn Twitter Facebook Google+ YouTube ABOUT ABM ABM ABM, +0.75% is a leading provider of facility solutions with revenues of approximately $5.5 billion and more than 130,000 employees in 350+ offices throughout the United States and various international locations. ABM's comprehensive capabilities include janitorial, electrical & lighting, energy solutions, facilities engineering, HVAC & mechanical, landscape & turf, mission critical solutions and parking, provided through stand-alone or integrated solutions. ABM provides custom facility solutions in urban, suburban and rural areas to properties of all sizes - from schools and commercial buildings to hospitals, data centers, manufacturing plants and airports. ABM Industries Incorporated, which operates through its subsidiaries, was founded in 1909. For more information, visit www.abm.com. CONTACT Media: Jennifer Miller (404) 926-4212 jennifer.miller@abm.com Investor & Media Relations: Susie Choi (212) 297-9721 susie.choi@abm.com Copyright (C) 2018 GlobeNewswire, Inc. All rights reserved. title: ABM Selected as Preferred Partner and Awarded Janitorial Services Contract at LaGuardia Airport's Terminal B

content: NEW YORK, Mar 22, 2018 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE via COMTEX) -- ABM ABM, +0.75% a leading provider of facility solutions, announced that Brooks County Schools, headquartered in Quitman, Georgia will implement comprehensive infrastructure improvements through ABM's Energy Performance Contracting Program, with additional operational improvements provided by ABM's custodial services. ABM's customized solution is projected to save Brooks County Schools more than $10.5 million in energy and operating costs over a 15-year period by providing energy-efficiency enhancements within the schools' facilities, while also providing custodial services. ABM began making energy-efficiency improvements within the schools in February 2018, and are expected to complete them in January 2019. "ABM is very excited to help Brooks County Schools implement an energy performance solution that helps improve the students' learning environment without cutting into their capital budget," said Mark Newsome, President of Technical Solutions at ABM. "We are also able to provide Brooks County Schools a way to outsource custodial services with ABM by incorporating the cost of janitorial equipment into the energy performance contracting program, allowing them to fit the school system's custodial program within their existing budget." "At ABM, we're dedicated to keeping schools and universities clean, so staff can focus on doing what they do best -- educating young minds," said Mike Morris, President of ABM Education. "We look forward to providing custodial service excellence throughout the school district." Brooks County Schools' six school buildings were challenged by an aging infrastructure and reduced funding. With the majority of the school system's capital funds dedicated to paying an existing bond, administrators needed to address issues affecting the learning environment across the school system. In three of the school system's buildings - Brooks County Board of Education J.H. Wells Education Center, Quitman Elementary School and Brooks County Middle School - the HVAC units have outlived their useful life. Brooks County Board of Education J.H. Wells Education Center needs a new roof and throughout the school system, security cameras and a VOIP system are needed. "ABM is delivering a customized solution to Brooks County Schools to remedy our infrastructure challenges," said Vickie Reed, Superintendent of Brooks County School System. "ABM is providing facility, personnel and financial solutions that no other company has the processes or expertise to achieve." ABM's Energy Performance Contracting Program will enable the school system to finance the replacement of its aging infrastructure. The program is designed as a financial solution to meet clients' technical facility needs and sustainability goals. The goal is to drive costs out of a client's operating budget, allowing savings to be reallocated to fund mission critical facility needs. Click here for a video on how ABM is providing facility and financial solutions to school districts without upfront costs or tax increases. While working in another school system, Reed worked with ABM to implement two Energy Performance Contracting Programs and to provide custodial services. "The fact that the superintendent, who has been a client for years, brought ABM into Brooks County Schools to help with facility and financial solutions is a testament to the quality of service we provide," Newsome said. "ABM is able to take a holistic look at Brooks County Schools' needs and provide efficiencies they may not be able to achieve otherwise." Energy-efficiency enhancements include: Installing 15 new rooftop units at the Brooks County Board of Education J.H. Wells Education Center, and upgrading a number of units at other facilities to high-efficiency HVAC units All school system HVAC units will be controlled by state-of-the-art HVAC control systems to maximize energy and operational efficiency Ventilation systems at each of the school system's buildings will be upgraded, and each building will be sealed The Brooks County Board of Education J.H. Wells Education Center's roof will be replaced and coated, and a sprinkler system will be installed in the building's Pre-Kindergarten and Kindergarten wing Three of the school's cafeterias will undergo freezer monitoring and optimization, or refrigeration management programs to ensure systems are operating efficiently Security cameras, VOIP systems, and new water fountains and hand dryers will be installed across the entire school system For more information on ABM's Energy Performance Contracting Program and other offerings, visit www.abm.com. Connect with ABM LinkedIn Twitter Facebook Google+ YouTube ABOUT ABM ABM (NYSE: ABM) is a leading provider of facility solutions with revenues of approximately $5.5 billion and more than 130,000 employees in 350+ offices throughout the United States and various international locations. ABM's comprehensive capabilities include janitorial, electrical & lighting, energy solutions, facilities engineering, HVAC & mechanical, landscape & turf, mission critical solutions and parking, provided through stand-alone or integrated solutions. ABM provides custom facility solutions in urban, suburban and rural areas to properties of all sizes - from schools and commercial buildings to hospitals, data centers, manufacturing plants and airports. ABM Industries Incorporated, which operates through its subsidiaries, was founded in 1909. For more information, visit www.abm.com. CONTACT Media: Alex Varjan (212) 297-9737 alex.varjan@abm.com Investor & Media Relations: Susie Choi (212) 297-9721 susie.choi@abm.com  Copyright (C) 2018 GlobeNewswire, Inc. All rights reserved.
